HEADLINE: He Found $50 Billion in a Five-and-Ten-Cent Store

BYLINE: By Richard Lingeman; Richard Lingeman, the executive editor of The Nation, is the author of "Small Town America" and a two-volume biography of Theodore Dreiser.

 BODY:

SAM WALTON
Made in America: My Story.
By Sam Walton with John Huey.
Illustrated. 269 pp. New York:
Doubleday. $22.50. 
 IN 1945, Sam Walton opened a dime store on the courthouse square in Newport, Ark., a small town like those in which he was raised. By 1951 he had launched his third store, Walton's Five and Dime, in Bentonville, Ark., where he made his permanent home and where Wal-Mart, the company he founded a decade later, would establish its corporate headquarters. By 1990, Wal-Mart had become the largest retail chain in the world, with 1,748 stores. In 1992, its sales are expected to total $53 billion.
Walton's autobiography, which he worked on with John Huey, a senior editor at Fortune magazine, until Walton's death in April at the age of 74, seems a sure-fire all-American success story: the Horatio Alger tale of an ordinary guy who made it big by remaining true to his small-town roots. As Walton writes, Wal-Mart's basic strategy was "simply to put good-sized discount stores into little one-horse towns which everybody else was ignoring."
Walton had seen firsthand the demise of the retailing era he knew as a boy, when farmers drove to country towns on Saturday to do their trading. After World War II, the number of farmers dwindled; their sons and daughters moved to urban -- or rather suburban -- areas. Housing developments spread over rural land like kudzu; an expanding grid of interstate highways and trunk roads accelerated urban sprawl; shopping malls sprouted in former cornfields to lure a new breed of mobile shoppers, who were willing to drive 50 miles for a bargain. Mass marketing, television and personal mobility forged cultural links between rural and urban consumers.
By the early 1960's, Walton had realized that discounting was the wave of the future and began opening the first Wal-Marts, which featured high volume and low, low prices. He planted his stores, standardized modules that came in five different sizes, in rural locations bypassed by his largest competitors -- Target, Kmart and Woolco. He would often pick new sites by aerial survey: an obsessive, hands-on manager, he had learned to fly in order to keep a close check on his scattered stores. As he buzzed the countryside, he could see the pattern of rural traffic or urban sprawl. He would pick a site outside town boundaries, where the land was cheaper and taxes lower, and then add other stores in nearby towns, until he had saturated a marketing area.
His only competition was the town merchants, who could not offer the low prices, the parking space or the consumerist cornucopia of a Wal-Mart store. The company built a sophisticated high-tech distribution operation -- 20 warehouses around the country (whose combined size would equal that of 23 football fields) that stock 85 percent of the 80,000 items Wal-Mart sells, where orders are fed to waiting delivery trucks on laser-guided conveyor belts. Mammoth mainframe computers in Bentonville voraciously crunch the daily sales numbers relayed by satellite from every cash-register scanner in every store.
No question that Sam Walton was a Napoleon of merchandising, keeping his troops lean and competitive, demanding 16-hour days of his managers, giving his "associates" pep talks, exhorting them to look customers in the eye, personally leading them in the company cheer ("Give me a W! . . .") and installing "people greeters" at the door, whose job is both to exude friendliness and to warn shoplifters that We're Watching You. Wal-Mart is stubbornly anti-union, and Walton confesses that in the early days he underpaid his employees. He has since instituted incentive bonuses, discount stock purchases and a profit-sharing plan, on which an employee collects when he or she leaves the company.
"Sam Walton: Made in America" is a very readable, down-to-earth story of Walton's life, a life so completely immersed in Wal-Mart that it serves as a history of the company. It is also informative about Walton's business methods, and his colleagues add testimonials and anecdotes. The lay reader learns some nuts-and-bolts details about retailing, all about fast-selling items that "blow out the door," "action alley" (the big aisle behind the checkout counter) and "shrinkage" (loss from theft).
But a full assessment of the economic and social impact of Wal-Mart needs a more objective narrator. The company has, willy-nilly, been a powerful agent for socioeconomic change, and sociologists study "the Wal-Marting of rural America." In some towns the news that the Wal-Martians were coming caused local businesses to shut their doors; many of those that held on went under, leaving gaping storefronts along Main Street.
Walton counters that the downtown merchants who flopped deserved to. "The small stores were just destined to disappear," he writes, "because the whole thing is driven by the customers, who are free to choose where to shop." What's more, for every town that opposes Wal-Mart, "I'd say we have another 200 begging us to come."
There's some truth there, and studies in Kansas and Iowa have shown that many Wal-Marts strengthen local economies and create new jobs (albeit low-wage, nonunion ones) to replace the ones that have been lost. But Wal-Marts have a particularly deleterious impact on the smaller, more vulnerable towns in a store's 20-mile trading radius, vacuuming dollars from their businesses and leaving them to survive -- if they do -- as bedroom communities.
Some towns that want to preserve the central business district as the beating economic and social heart of the community have resisted Wal-Mart's incursions, denying zoning permits or persuading the company to situate within the municipal limits, so the store will pull business to Main Street rather than away from it. For its part, Wal-Mart seems to have become more sensitive to demands that it involve itself in community activities.
Sam Walton preaches "think small" and writes, "Above all, we are small-town merchants." That's a good management philosophy for a $50 billion corporation, but it has little to do with small-town values or valuing small towns -- that is, in ways that cannot be quantified on a spreadsheet.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 21; Column 2; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 1306 words

HEADLINE: Survival of the Loudest

BYLINE: By Nicholas Lemann; Nicholas Lemann, author of "The Promised Land: The Great Black Migration and How It Changed America," is a national correspondent for The Atlantic.

 BODY:
Politically, the lesson of the Presidential campaign so far is that anger trumps.
The candidates who have done better than expected have been best at striking an indignant-outsider pose: Pat Buchanan, Paul Tsongas, Jerry Brown and, finally and most dramatically, Ross Perot. Even the Bush-Quayle ticket is trying to appear as fed up with Washington as it plausibly can. 
 It's possible to tease out of these campaigns a political story line that can be used (with variations) all the way across the ideological spectrum. It goes like this:
1. The country is in crisis. Never mind the political science bromides that during peacetime and rocky-but-not-disastrous economic conditions people want continuity rather than change. So far, voters are responding to a picture of the nation as perched on the brink of real disaster.
2. The crisis is the fault of a small, cosseted, evil group. The group might be Congress or welfare mothers or lobbyists for Japanese companies or cultural liberals or political-action committees. Any news story that seems to confirm this suspicion (like the House bank scandal) engenders a tremendous public response and sends politicians and the media scurrying to demonstrate that they, too, are reacting with fascination and horror.
3. The people hurt worst are members of the great middle class -- "the forgotten middle class," as Bill Clinton calls it.
4. The way to resolve the crisis is through a dramatic change in leadership (in the Bush campaign's version, a change in Congressional leadership). New, good leaders will send the evil group packing and bring back good times for the middle class.
The story line owes a lot to our populist tradition, but there are differences. Classic populism flourishes during depressions, not recessions, and its constituency is people in desperate economic trouble and cut off from the mainstream of national life.
Traditional populist rhetoric appeals to "the little people" and "poor folks." But contemporary Presidential candidates who are true populists, like Tom Harkin and Jesse Jackson, haven't done well. What we have now is the triumph of middle class populism -- a creed that appeals to voters who would be offended if a politician told them they were the little people.
Middle class populism has been a wonderful strategy for winning elections. It brought the Republicans out of the ashes after 1964, it could revive the Democrats this year and it lies at the heart of the Perot campaign. But its apotheosis will almost surely not be the prelude to a golden age of governance. Middle class populism fosters a fantasy of oppression that has little to do with the state of the country.
The U.S. isn't really in a wholesale crisis. There isn't really an evil group responsible for our problems. The people who are hurting worst and who need the most help are the poor and the working class, not the middle class. And a change in leadership won't make much difference because our leaders are already following the will of the people (especially the middle class) with fantastic devotion. You'd never know from the campaign that only two months ago the worst domestic disturbance in a generation, and the most obvious sign of trouble in the U.S. in 1992, took place in Los Angeles. As far as national politics is concerned, if it didn't involve the middle class, it didn't happen.
The natural impulse is to attribute 1992's populism to current conditions -- mainly the recession. But this explanation is too narrow. Anger has been at or near the center of Presidential politics for almost a quarter century. In large part it is the result of longer-term issues than the current state of the economy.
In 1968, Kevin Phillips, a young Nixon aide and author of "The Emerging Republican Majority," correctly predicted that playing on middle class voters' resentment of the cultural elite could help win a Presidential election. Vice President Dan Quayle's recent maneuverings have been right out of the Phillips playbook. Meanwhile, Mr. Phillips has been saying that the way to run for President now is to play on middle class voters' resentment of the economic elite. This year, several Democratic campaigns have taken this advice.
In 1972, Pat Caddell helped construct an outsider campaign for George McGovern, whose themes were similar to the outsider campaigns he later created for Gary Hart and Jerry Brown. Hamilton Jordan, architect of Jimmy Carter's run against the Washington establishment in 1976, is now one of Ross Perot's campaign managers. And Ronald Reagan, the dominant American politician of the last 25 years, was the most adept outsider candidate of all.
Why are people so upset? Part of it is that the social order established at the end of World War II has, during one of the more stable periods in American history, become creaky and arteriosclerotic. The political and economic system is less flexible, less able to respond to changing conditions than it was a generation ago.
An even more important source of anger is the great shift in the postwar economy. In the 1950's and 1960's, indices like median family income, productivity and average weekly wages grew rapidly. In the early 1970's, however, with the OPEC oil embargo, growth leveled off abruptly.
Because of the time lag between economic conditions and people's expectations, it was late in the postwar boom before a prosperity mentality set in -- look at almost any house built in the 1950's and 1960's and you'll see how un-plush those prosperous decades really were.
Expectations still haven't adjusted to the virtual nongrowth of the last 20 years. At the same time, the range and number of citizens demanding a share of the American dream has increased since the boom days, when women and members of racial and ethnic minorities were second-class citizens economically, and quiescent. The result is a sour and fragmented country, whose public discourse is dominated by a cacophony of complaints.
In his interviews with the journalist William Greider a decade ago, David Stockman, Ronald Reagan's first budget director, complained that the Government is beholden to "powerful clients with weak claims." Exactly the same point can be made about political rhetoric in our media culture.
Unlike the political machines it replaced, the press-polling-advertising nexus that dominates politics is very good at letting a multiplicity of voices be heard, but it is bad at adjudicating among them. Inevitably, the complaints of the middle class -- the largest, most powerful group in the society -- dominate.
The politician most responsible for figuring out how to appeal to the frustrations of the middle class was Howard Jarvis, father of Proposition 13 in California. Mr. Jarvis's inspiration was to move political debate from the spending side of government, where it had been for years, to the revenue side. Ronald Reagan quickly picked up on Mr. Jarvis's idea of putting tax cuts at the center of a political agenda.
But when he became President, Mr. Reagan found that the middle class, which wanted its taxes cut, was also passionate about protecting Government programs that benefited its own members. The interlocking political taboos against tax increases and cuts in entitlements helped create an enormous deficit -- and then, irony of ironies, the deficit became the emblem of a crisis produced by bad leaders who didn't listen to the middle class.
The truth is that the deficit was produced by leaders who listened to the middle class only too well. While they were attending to its wants and feeding its sense of grievance, society's worst problems -- the suffering and social chaos in the ghettos, deindustrialization -- went unattended, and they have gotten more and more severe. Villains aren't causing these problems. We are.

HEADLINE: Anyone Who Knows Schools Could See Falling Scores Coming

 BODY:
To the Editor:
For most parents and teachers, there's no debate about the cause of the drop in achievement scores in New York City public schools (news report June 26). We recognize the pattern because we've seen it before.
When school budgets were devastated in the city's last fiscal crisis in the mid-1970's, we lost a generation of kids. Crammed into dilapidated classrooms, without adequate books and supplies, they dropped out in record numbers and became the unemployed and unemployable adolescents and young adults of today. 
 By the late 80's, the system began to rebuild: class sizes were reduced; new educational standards and programs came in; entry-level salaries were raised to attract qualified teachers, and teachers received valuable support and training. Higher reading and math scores, increased attendance and fewer dropouts resulted.
In the last two years, schoolchildren have had the rug pulled out from under them again. Three-quarters of a billion dollars was cut from the school budget. Huge classes, outdated and insufficient textbooks, and rotting buildings have taken their toll. Experienced teachers have fled to better-paying suburbs.
For city officials to say better management would have solved these problems is a denial of their obligation to our children. Unless this cynical attitude changes, the next generation of young adults -- and the next city administration -- will reap the whirlwind of their irresponsible leadership.
 
SANDRA FELDMAN
President
United Federation of Teachers
New York, June 26, 1992

PUB-DATE: July 13, 1992

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; National Desk; The Convention

LENGTH: 2613 words

HEADLINE: THE CAMPAIGN;
Democrats Display a New Optimism, Reflected in Poll

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER

 BODY:
Fired by new optimism about Gov. Bill Clinton's appeal, Democrats will open a national convention in New York today that their leaders describe as a carefully scripted kickoff for a party more eager to win this fall than to argue this week.
The Democrats' new sense of possibilities was underscored by the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll, which shows Mr. Clinton gaining ground in a tight three-way race. Mr. Clinton now essentially ties President Bush when voters are asked how they would vote if the election were held today: Mr. Bush is at 33 percent, Mr. Clinton at 30 percent, and Ross Perot, the all-but-declared independent candidate, is at 25 percent.
 
Improving Popularity
 Even more important to the Arkansas Governor is the improvement in voters' views of him personally over the last month, after a primary campaign that left his image in tatters. During the same period, Mr. Perot's image continued to decline, while Mr. Bush's ratings on job performance, economic stewardship and personal image remained remarkably weak for an incumbent President. 
 As a result, Mr. Clinton has enjoyed some pre-convention momentum and will avoid the nightmare that seemed possible just weeks ago, when many Democrats feared he would come limping into New York a stalled and distant third, turning the convention into a grim parody.
Democratic leaders spent the day trumpeting their unity, but there were still a few rough spots. Former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. kept Democrats guessing much of the day, despite pressure from party leaders and his own politically venerable family to join the unity tableau. And the Rev. Jesse Jackson continued to snipe at the Arkansas Governor, even though he had grudgingly endorsed him the day before.
 
A Glut of Fetes
 Nonetheless, the Democratic delegates who are to nominate Mr. Clinton on Wednesday night were far more engaged yesterday in parties than in feuds. The muggy midsummer heat did little to dampen the innumerable brunches, cocktail parties, lunches, dinners, river cruises and fund-raising events that sent nearly 5,000 delegates and alternates into the streets of New York. There were parties at Gracie Mansion, Carnegie Hall, Lincoln Center and Central Park, to name a few; New Yorkers hustled to disprove the negative stereotypes and present themselves as happy and amiable hosts.
The quadrennial exercise of Democrats' trying to recapture the grandeur of their past was crystallized in one poignant fact: The most sought-after pass was for the party held at Gracie Mansion to honor Robert F. Kennedy.
 
Gore's Contribution
 The new nationwide telephone poll of 1,032 registered voters suggests that Mr. Clinton has profited from his selection of Senator Al Gore of Tennessee as his running mate, as well as the pre-convention hoopla: his standing in the three-way trial heat improved over the course of the poll, which was conducted Wednesday through Saturday and has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus 3 percentage points.
The poll also showed that Mr. Gore was beginning this campaign with a far more positive image than Vice President Quayle, although he is obviously much less known.
The Clinton forces say they hope to use the next four days to build on these gains and "re-introduce" the Governor to the American people.The theme of the convention is "Putting People First," an effort to find a fresh way to capitalize on a traditional Democratic advantage during an economic downturn. The most important story line, however, will be the profile of Bill Clinton that emerges by week's end.
If the Clinton strategists have their way, it will be an all-American tale of a poor but smart boy who rose from humble origins to a life in government aimed at "putting people first."
The counter-image is already coming from the Republican National Committee, which has set up shop in New York. The Republican chairman, Rich Bond, held a news conference yesterday in which one phrase was repeated over and over: "The failed Governor of a small state."
 
Quiet Day for Clinton
 The Governor from Arkansas spent a quiet day, continuing to work on his acceptance speech for Thursday night. With his wife, Hillary, and his daughter, Chelsea, he attended services at Calvary Baptist Church on West 57th Street, but left much of the public politics of the day to Mr. Gore.
He did talk by phone with Mr. Brown, an aide said. And party leaders said they remained hopeful that the former California Governor, who has seemed unwilling to wind down his anti-politics crusade, will return to the fold this week.
Mr. Gore, speaking to reporters at Nashville's airport before his flight to New York, asserted that the Republicans clearly intended to wage a negative campaign -- and tried to present the Democrats as above all that, more concerned with policy than politics as usual. "We want to do what is in the best interests of the country," he said.
But Gov. Ann W. Richards of Texas suggested on the CBS News program "Face the Nation" that the Democrats were not becoming pacifists in the political battle. "Al Gore may not be the one that does it," she said, "but I don't think that the Democrats are going to make the mistake that they made in the Dukakis-Bush race."
 
'A Lot More Scripting'
 The convention will be called to order in Madison Square Garden at 5 P.M. today. Ronald H. Brown, the Democratic Party chairman, said proudly that his party was attempting "a lot more scripting than we've done in the past." While the Republicans have excelled in recent years in turning their convention into a strictly controlled political commercial, Democratic conventions sometimes have the air of a family therapy session. This time, however, the Democrats resolved many of their conflicts in advance.
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York, who will nominate Mr. Clinton on Wednesday night, devoted his day to an earnest defense of a man he has often clashed with in the past. "I think probably he will make the best candidate since Kennedy," Mr. Cuomo said on the Channel 2 program "Sunday Edition." He did, however, offer some advice on the NBC News program "Meet the Press" that might seem counter-intuitive, suggesting that Mr. Clinton present himself as someone willing to raise taxes.
Mr. Jackson, meanwhile, indicated on "Meet the Press" that he would not be a quiet foot soldier for Mr. Clinton. He complained that the Clinton campaign had sought to distance itself from core Democratic constituencies like organized labor, urban voters and his own political group, the Rainbow Coalition. "That push-off has insulted and infuriated a lot of people," Mr. Jackson said.
Mr. Jackson also took pains to defend Ross Perot, who sparked considerable outrage at Saturday's meeting of the N.A.A.C.P. when he twice used the phrase "your people" in singling out the problems of blacks. "That gaffe was not intentional or a politically motivated or racially calculated statement," said Mr. Jackson. "I have seen race-baiting, and that was not that."
Mr. Clinton, meanwhile, issued a statement hailing Mr. Jackson's endorsement and taking a slap at the Republicans: "The Reagan-Bush-Quayle Administration has deprived this country of any real investment in our people. The lack of leadership is appalling and the American people deserve better."
His statement, however, was silent on Ross Perot, and silence is expected to be the trend here. Many Democrats argue that their candidate has so far prospered by staying out of the Bush-Perot battle.
 
Strongly Competitive
 Poll ratings at this stage of the campaign can be ephemeral. Michael S. Dukakis left his convention in Atlanta with a 17-point lead, but it melted to 7 percentage points in two weeks, and then disappeared.
Still, the latest Times/CBS poll showed an extremely competitive race. Mr. Perot had slipped, and the remarkably positive image he had last spring is largely gone. He shares the situation of Mr. Bush and Mr. Clinton in having more people view him negatively than positively.
The Dallas billionaire, who has come off a month of Republican attacks and intense press scrutiny, is now viewed favorably by 19 percent, and unfavorably by 27 percent. And many Democrats here predicted that Mr. Perot would suffer further damage in the aftermath of his speech at the N.A.A.C.P. convention this weekend.
Mr. Clinton, meanwhile, gained ground in his personal popularity during the same period. Those who viewed him positively rose to 20 percent, up from 16 percent in June. And those who viewed him negatively dropped to 31 percent, down from 40 percent in June. Mr. Bush's ratings were essentially unchanged since June, standing at 30 percent favorable, 43 percent unfavorable.
Still, Mr. Clinton has continuing weaknesses. Only 40 percent said he had strong qualities of leadership; 60 percent said that about Mr. Bush, and 45 percent about Mr. Perot. Only 32 percent said Mr. Clinton had good judgment under pressure, while 62 percent said that of Mr. Bush and 40 percent about Mr. Perot.
And the Democrat still has a problem with the "character issue," after a primary season in which he was repeatedly forced to deny accusations of avoiding the draft and infidelity. While only 11 percent of the voters say that assertions about Mr. Clinton's character will cause them to choose someone else, 41 percent said they thought it would bother other voters enough to make him lose the election.
Among his strengths were specificity: 49 percent said he had offered specific ideas to solve the problems facing the country, as against 34 percent for Mr. Bush and 30 percent for Mr. Perot.
And nearly three-fourths said Mr. Clinton cared about the "needs and problems" of people like themselves; 57 percent said that of Mr. Bush, and 59 percent of Mr. Perot.
The Democratic Party, in fact, was gaining ground on this front: 32 percent said the party favored the middle class, up from 22 percent who said that a year ago. In contrast, just 8 percent said the Republican Party favors the middle class, while 68 percent said it favored the rich.
The poll also showed that the Republicans, in the person of Mr. Bush, had lost their traditional advantage as the party more willing to hold the line on taxes. Seventy-seven percent said they thought Mr. Bush was likely to raise their taxes if he was re-elected, about the same as the 75 percent who predicted that of Mr. Clinton. Sixty-four percent said they thought Mr. Perot would do so.

HEADLINE: Michigan's Singular Tax Is Studied as U.S. Model

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LANSING, Mich., July 8

 BODY:
A form of taxation in Michigan that is the only one of its type in America is the wave of the future, some politicians and economists say. Others, particularly thousands of small businesses, would like to wave it goodbye.
For the last 16 years, Michigan has departed from all its sister states by taxing businesses according to the volume of their business activity rather than their profits, meaning that businesses owe taxes even when they lose money. Michigan calls it the single business tax. 
 The Michigan tax embodies the principle of taxing consumption -- all the factors of production except for capital investment -- rather than incomes. For opponents, the taxing of money-losing businesses is only the most common complaint against Michigan's single business tax, the only value-added tax in the United States.
But the idea of taxing consumption, either through a valued-added tax or national sales tax, is emerging as an increasingly inviting model for other states and even for the Federal Government. A growing band of national politicians of both major parties see such a tax as one answer to the nation's low savings rate and lack of investment.
In essence, a value-added tax is a sales tax imposed on the difference between what a company pays for goods that go into a product and the value of the finished product when it is sold. If a company buys $600 worth of raw materials from other companies and produces something that sells for $1,000, for example, the added value is $400. If the value-added tax is 10 percent, the liability will be $40. Presumably, the tax will be passed along to consumers in the form of higher prices.
 
Questions of Fairness
 "Equity is in the eyes of the beholder," insists Douglas B. Roberts, Michigan's state treasurer and a staunch defender of the single business tax, which has been in place for a decade and a half. He wonders why it seems so unfair to tax a multibillion-dollar auto company that uses vast amounts of state services just because it happens to have a bad year for profits.
In Congress, there is now considerable ferment in favor of a value-added tax or some other sort of national sales tax. The notion has long been resisted by liberals as "regressive," because it would put a proportionately larger tax burden on poorer consumers who must spend much of their income and have little left over for saving or investing. And consumption taxes have been scorned by conservatives, who see them as a "money machine" for Big Government.
Such criticisms notwithstanding, Senate Finance Committee members John C. Danforth, a Missouri Republican, and David Boren, an Oklahoma Democrat, have formed an advisory group whose work is aimed at shifting policy toward taxing consumption. The second meeting is July 20.
Members of the group include officials from the Treasury, which did some perfunctory analysis of value-added taxes in 1984 and would be obliged to do more work on the idea under a bill pressed by Representative Robert E. Wise Jr., Democrat of West Virginia. In addition, Sam Gibbons, Democrat of Florida, a trade-oriented member of the House Ways and Means Committee, contends that for competitive reasons the United States must adopt a value-added tax.
 
U.S. Has Resisted the Trend
 A value-added tax can be regarded as the revolution in tax policy that has entirely bypassed the United States, with the exception of Michigan. All but five of the 25 industrialized countries belonging to the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development now have such a tax, with Japan adopting it in 1988 and Canada in 1990. Of the five holdouts, four have a national sales tax, making the United States the only O.E.C.D. nation with neither a value-added tax nor a national sales tax.
It was in 1976, after years of revenue gyrations and in the aftermath of an income-shrinking recession, that Michigan began its version of the value-added tax, one limited to business but given a broad base that included such traditionally small and unincorporated enterprises as law firms and accounting firms.
At a conference in Chicago sponsored by the National Tax Association, "I got to thinking this might be a good idea for a state," Robert J. Kleine, then director of the Michigan's Office of Revenue and Tax Analysis and now a private consultant, recalled the other day. Because the new levy was designed to supplant numerous others -- and because the term "value-added tax" had unfavorable connotations -- the name chosen for it was the single business tax.
 
Concessions and Revisions
 From the outset, the tax was a political lightning rod, supported initially by the 6,000-member Michigan Chamber of Commerce only after heated internal debate and sustained over the years by repeated modifications.
One largely successful effort was obtaining concessions for small business, many of which end up not even owing money but nevertheless find the paperwork onerous. They are now offered a choice between the single business tax and a 3 percent tax on profits. Another change was to limit the severity of the tax on labor-intensive businesses.
Value-added taxes take two basic forms. The most common is the transactional, or credit, value-added tax that is widely used in Europe. Each company in the production chain gets to apply a credit for the tax it pays on purchases against the tax it owes on sales.
The other form is the so-called operational valued-added tax, a one-shot calculation under which companies calculate their tax liability by subtracting outside purchases from sales. Or, as in Michigan, they may add the components of "value" -- wages, rent, interest and depreciation -- to Federal taxable income, the profit-based starting point for the calculation.
 
Noises From Detroit
 By treating capital investment favorably, Michigan's value-added tax is a levy on consumption as opposed to one on output or income.
While officials here express disappointment in how the "purity" of the single business tax has been eroded, most believe it will survive. This is despite noises from Detroit, currently awash in red ink, and elsewhere that the single business tax should be reviewed -- a not surprising attitude in hard times.
"We just thank our lucky stars we don't have a corporate income tax any more," Mr. Kleine said, "because we'd be refunding money to the Big Three for the next 10 years."
For one thing, contrary to one common fear, the original 2.35 percent statutory rate has never been raised, though Richard K. Studley the vice president for government relations of the Michigan Chamber of Commerce, frets about a constantly expanding base that rises automatically with pay increases, a major component. Mr. Kleine observes that the single business tax's inclusiveness, even with exemptions for groups like agriculture, means unified opposition to any rate-raising proposal.
This means that the single business tax has to some extent broken the traditional ratcheting-up of the size of government as the public sector expanded in good times and then relied on tax increases to sustain itself when hard times arrived.
 
Other States Study Michigan
 There is also the practical problem of a lack of suitable alternatives, with estimates ranging from 15 to 20 percent as the tax rate that might be necessary to raise the same amount of money through a traditional corporate income tax.
"Maybe this mongrel that we've developed is exactly what we ought to have," suggested H. Lynn Jondahl. A Democrat who heads the Taxation Committee of the Michigan House of Representatives, Mr. Jondahl says he initially had more reservations than enthusiasm for the single business tax.
Other states, including Texas and Florida, have sought advice from Michigan officials about adopting single business taxes of their own and are generally given an upbeat appraisal.
Some specialists also think the Michigan levy, compromised and complicated though it has become, might provide some kind of model for concerted action by cash-starved states. One is Alice Rivlin, a former director of the Congressional Budget Office who, citing Michigan specifically, proposes a commonly collected and shared corporate income tax.

HEADLINE: Ruling Party Challenged in 2 Mexican States

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN

DATELINE: CHIHUAHUA, Mexico, July 12

 BODY:
Mexicans in two politically crucial states chose their Governors today in voting that the opposition has called a test of President Carlos Salinas de Gortari's commitment to fair elections.
In Michoacan, where tensions were running high and the leftist Democratic Revolutionary Party faced the possibility of a devastating loss, its officials said the vote had been badly tainted. 
 "There have been a whole load of irregularities," the party's candidate, Cristobal Arias, said by telephone after the polls closed tonight. "All of the reports I have indicate that there were many incidents of provocation, many acts committed by people of the official side."
In contrast, Government and opposition officials in Chihuahua, a border state that is a stronghold of the conservative National Action Party, said the voting there had proceeded fairly smoothly. Reporting only minor incidents at the polls, National Action officials were predicting victory for their candidate, Francisco Barrio Terraza, as they announced early returns.
An outright opposition victory in either contest would be only the second since the Government founded its political party, now called the Insitutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI, 63 years ago. While opposition complaints of fraud are the norm in Mexican elections, they could embarrass Mr. Salinas, who is to meet with President Bush in San Diego on Tuesday to discuss their final negotiations with Canada on a free trade agreement.
Chihuahua and Michoacan, while both unusually important for the strength of their political opposition, represent almost opposite poles of Mexican reality.
Chihuahua prides itself on both economic vigor and political independence, and it chose primarily between two former mayors of Ciudad Juarez -- Mr. Barrio and the PRI candidate, Jesus Macias -- whose policy views are not radically different.
Michoacan, one of the poorest of Mexico's 31 states, weighed Mr. Arias, a leftist firebrand who promises to help small farmers and the poor, against a wealthy PRI businessman, Eduardo Villasenor, who says he will help the state by stimulating investment. Opinion polls before the vote showed Mr. Arias trailing Mr.Villasenor by ratios of more than 2 to 1.
In their elections, however, the two states have shared some problems. In both, debates over policy and ideology have been overwhelmed by controversy over the vastly greater campaign resources of the governing party. And today, opposition officials in both states complained of systematic Government pressure on the voters.
Mr. Arias and other Democratic Revolutionary Party officials said the problems in Michoacan included last-minute changes to the voter rolls, the switching of locations for polling places in areas of opposition support, the expulsion of opposition poll watchers, the theft of several ballot boxes, and intimidation of voters by Government and PRI officials. The state police announced tonight that five members of the Democratic Revolutionary Party had been arrested for trying to destroy election materials in the town of Nueva Italia. The party said its people were arrested after they tried to stop members of the governing party from stealing ballot boxes.
Officials of the State Electoral Commission in Michoacan declined to comment on the accusations.

HEADLINE: Cuomo Calls Back Legislative Leaders On Unsettled Issues

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET

 BODY:
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has summoned state legislative leaders back to Albany on Thursday in hopes of reaching agreement on several measures left unresolved when the Legislature's session ended on July 3, a spokeswoman for the Governor said last night.
Governor Cuomo decided to call the meeting after talks between members of his staff and members of legislative staffs showed "significant progress" late last week, said the spokeswoman, Anne W. Crowley. 
 She said the Assembly Speaker, Saul Weprin, agreed to attend the meeting when Governor Cuomo invited him while they were at a party for the New York delegation to the Democratic National Convention last night. The Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, had not yet responded to an invitation to the meeting that Governor Cuomo left on his answering machine at home, she said.
 Because legislators settled on a budget on April 2, virtually on time for the first time in eight years, there had been hope that they would be free to address other issues.
But lawmakers ended the session still battling over two major pieces of legislation: an $800 million bond act, which Governor Cuomo had vigorously sought to create jobs as the showpiece of his plan to pull New York State out of recession, and a fiscal bailout for Nassau and Suffolk counties on Long Island, which the Republican-led state Senate wanted.
The Governor had strongly hinted that he would veto the bailout because he thought it was irresponsible, and in the end, amid much partisan bickering, neither measure passed.
 
Items Under Consideration
 Both measures would be dealt with on Thursday, along with a bill to give the Thruway Authority new power to oversee construction projects, and other legislation, Ms. Crowley said.
But she said that Governor Cuomo was awaiting a recommendation from his budget advisers as to whether the bailout plans were sound, and that he might not receive that recommendation by Thursday.
Ms. Crowley said that because the meeting would be held early on Thursday, Governor Cuomo would have time to fly to New York City to attend the closing of the Democratic convention, when Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas is scheduled to receive the nomination. But he might miss a reception or two, she said.
"The opportunity to get some good legislation like this passed would probably override that," she said.

HEADLINE: Ruble Support May Be Delayed to '93

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 12

 BODY:
A $6 billion fund to help stabilize the ruble will probably not be set up until early next year, several months later than originally planned, a senior official of the International Monetary Fund says.
Russian officials had hoped that the fund would be established this summer, saying that a stable ruble is needed as soon as possible to create an anchor for the Russian economy. 
 In what seems like a chicken-or-the-egg riddle, Russian officials are eager to have a ruble fund sooner rather than later to help attract foreign investment and restore badly needed confidence and order in their economy.
But I.M.F. officials say that before such a fund is set up, the Russians must re-establish faith and order in their economy so that people will have enough confidence in the ruble that it might have a chance of being sought after and becoming stable.
 
Budgets and Inflation
 The I.M.F. official said Russia still faced several stiff challenges before the $6 billion fund could be established: bringing its budget deficit and inflation rate down sharply, and sorting out which of the former Soviet republics plan to continue using the ruble. If these conditions are not met by early next year, the official indicated, the stabilization fund might be further delayed.
Disclosing details of Russia's new agreement with the monetary fund, the official said Moscow had agreed to reduce its inflation rate to less than 10 percent a month from about 15 percent and to reduce its deficit to 5 percent of the gross domestic product from about 17 percent by the end of the year.
That would be smaller, in relative terms, than the United States deficit, which is expected to be 6.3 percent of the gross domestic product this fiscal year.
Russian officials, facing domestic pressure against tough economic decisions, say they will not be able to cut their deficit by the promised amount unless creditors allow Russia to defer interest payments on its more than $70 billion in foreign debt.
The I.M.F.'s managing director, Michel Camdessus, flew to Moscow last weekend to help hammer out an agreement in time for the economic summit meeting in Munich. Under that accord, Moscow will receive a $1 billion loan from the fund in exchange for agreeing to undertake reforms.
 
Rebuilding Currency Stocks
 Russia is expected to receive that $1 billion after the I.M.F.'s executive board votes early next month. Fund officials said Russia would probably use the money to build up its depleted hard-currency reserves.
A stabilization fund would, in effect, back the ruble with foreign money. Russia could use the $6 billion to buy rubles in order to prop up the nation's currency if it suffered a crisis of confidence and people rushed to sell their rubles in favor of foreign currencies. In theory, if people know that there is a fund to defend the ruble's value, they will be in less of a rush to sell out of fear that their rubles are going to plunge in value.
Mr. Camdessus and other fund officials have talked about a three-phase approach for Russian aid. In the next phase, Russia would sign another accord, in which it would qualify for $3 billion more in I.M.F. loans over the next year for agreeing to more comprehensive and stricter reforms, like setting a low ceiling on money-supply growth.
The monetary fund official said he hoped to complete that agreement in October.
The third phase would involve starting the $6 billion ruble fund, which would be administered by the I.M.F. and financed by the United States and 10 other major industrial nations. The ruble fund and the I.M.F. loans are all part of a $24 billion aid package to Russia that the Group of Seven, an alignment of leading industrial nations, unveiled in April.
 
Neighbors Keep Printing Money
 The I.M.F. official, who spoke Friday on the condition that his remarks not be released until Monday, said the greater-than-expected complications in defining a ruble zone -- all the former Soviet republics that will use the ruble -- and making it work smoothly were the main reasons for the projected delay in establishing the fund. Russian officials complain that other republics' continuing to print rubles is making it harder for them to reduce inflation.
The official, who insisted on anonymity, said another reason for the delay was that Russia let its budget deficit and inflation rate soar in the second quarter after having slashed them in the first quarter.
"When the macro-economic programs are really strong," he said, "and the hand of management does not tremble, then a stabilization fund can be put into place."
Jeffrey Sachs, a Harvard economics professor who has advised Russia on its reforms, said the I.M.F. was partly to blame for the delay in setting up the ruble-stabilization fund. He asserted that the I.M.F. staff had dragged out negotiations for an agreement by pressing Russia to take overly severe measures. He also said that the monetary fund had not done enough to help those republics so inclined to set up their own currencies and thus speed their exit from the ruble zone.
I.M.F. officials say it would be foolish to establish a fund to stabilize -- and defend -- the ruble before Moscow cuts inflation and restores confidence in the currency so that its exchange rate is no longer volatile. On July 1, the Russian Government consolidated the several different ruble exchange rates into one, and then let the ruble float against other currencies.
The Russian currency is trading at about 130 rubles to the dollar, far weaker than the Government's goal of 80 to the dollar.
"A stabilization fund that doesn't have an object to be stabilized isn't really going to help," said Richard Ericson, an economist at the Harriman Institute of Columbia University. "There would be an immediate $6 billion transfer to Russia if you don't have the ruble functioning as a real money."
Professor Sachs said he feared that the I.M.F., reluctant to see the ruble fund tapped, was asking Moscow to do so much to steady its currency that by that time, a stabilization fund would be unnecessary.
I.M.F. officials say they will work hard this summer to establish rules for republics staying in the ruble zone and to help republics so inclined to set up their own currencies. Estonia has already created its own money, and I.M.F. officials say Latvia, Lithuania and Ukraine plan to do so in the near future. Belarus, Kazakhstan and Uzbekistan plan to continue using the ruble, at least for the short term, and I.M.F. officials say most of the other republics will probably do likewise.
"It's still a little bit of a fluid situation," said the monetary fund official, who added that setting up one's own currency was a "very hard job."
Fund officials said it remained unclear how monetary policy would be determined in the new ruble zone: whether Russia, the predominant economic power among the republics, would call all the shots, or whether the others would have a vote on monetary policy.
Mr. Sachs said the main thing was that the republics embrace a single monetary policy.
Recognizing that Russia will be the dominant voice in monetary policy, the I.M.F. official said, "the center has to be in a position to hear well and take on board the specific problems of each of the other countries."

HEADLINE: Police Pact For Nassau Is Criticized

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MINEOLA, L.I., July 12

 BODY:
A proposed police union contract has touched off a debate between political and business leaders over whether Nassau County, broke and in the midst of a financial crisis, can afford it. The contract is expected to set a standard for other municipal employee unions in the New York metropolitan area.
In New York City, the police have for decades sought parity with their colleagues on Long Island and the contract could be used as a guide for negotiations between the Dinkins administration and the city's police union. The police unions on Long Island have traditionally been powerful political forces in Nassau and Suffolk Counties, and have effectively raised their salaries to among the highest in the country. 
 The proposed four-year contract in Nassau would increase the average police officer's salary by 15 percent, to more than $59,000. It also includes several concessions by the police union, which Nassau and Suffolk may seek from their other unions. Among the concessions are a freeze on base wages in the first year, the deferral of some overtime and regular pay, and lower wages and more workdays for recruits.
 
Vote on July 20
 After months of delay and political posturing, the pact was quietly placed on the Nassau County Board of Supervisors' agenda late last week for a final vote on July 20.
The Nassau County Executive, Thomas S. Gulotta, who negotiated the contract with Gary DelaRaba, president of the Nassau Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, has praised the pact as a way to ease Nassau's budget problem. He says it would cost the county little during the first two years. Mr. DelaRaba calls it "a fair deal."
However, the Long Island Association, the Island's largest business organization, says the pact is too rich in the midst of a recession. It contends that the contract would increase the average salary of Nassau's 1,800 police officers by about 21 percent during the four years.
"Our approach is not to begrudge public safety officers fair compensation," said James L. Larocca, president of the association. "Our direction really comes from a concern about what we can afford."
 
Seeking State Approval
 Nassau's $1.8 billion budget is currently running a $153 million deficit. To fill the gap, Mr. Gulotta, a Republican who is expected to seek re-election next year, is seeking state approval to borrow $70 million and increase the county's mortgage recording tax by 1 percent. But the Democratic leadership in Albany has refused to go along unless Nassau agrees to a financial oversight board.
Critics of the proposed police pact argue that it is the type of deal an oversight board might easily reject because Nassau's financial crisis has forced the county to lay off 2,300 workers, none of them police officers, and sharply cut back services in all departments, including health care at the Nassau County Medical Center.
"We recognize the county is in a financial bind, and we're giving up a lot in the first two years to help out," Mr. DelaRaba said. He estimated that the four-year contact would cost the county $2 million.
Bruce Nyman, a Democrat and Supervisor of the City of Long Beach, said he had decided to vote against the contract when it came up for a final debate and vote.
"No public employee, whether a politician, policeman or parks department worker, should get a raise until the county's fiscal crisis is resolved," he said.
Another Democrat, Benjamin Zwirn, Supervisor of the Town of North Hempstead, said he planned to support the contract, "despite some reservations."
"My determination is that it's worth it to the taxpayers in the long run," Mr. Zwirn said. "The P.B.A. is entitled to a vote on the pact and there is no reason to delay it." The motion to put the issue on next Monday's agenda was made by Mr. Zwirn and seconded by Mr. Nyman.
The outcome will be closely watched by the Nassau Civil Service Employees Association, the largest union in the county, whose contract expires on Dec. 31. In Suffolk County, which is also dealing with a record budget deficit, nine union contracts expired last year, including that of the Suffolk P.B.A. All are in the midst of negotiations.
 
Suffolk Proposes 10% Cut
 In Suffolk, county officials have proposed a 10 percent across-the board pay cut for employees, including police officers, to help close its nearly $50 million budget gap. As a result, several hundred Suffolk police officers with 20 or more years of service, several times the usual number, have filed for retirement, concerned that shrinking wages and benefits may affect their pension income. Their pension is based on one-half of their salary during their final year on the job or one half their average income in the final three years, whichever is higher.
A Nassau police officer now earns $49,124 after six years on the job. He would earn $59,522 at the end of the proposed contract. That is significantly higher than the $50,014 earned by his counterpart in Suffolk and $41,000 in New York City, where the police contract expired Dec. 30, 1991. The city is currently negotiating with most of its major unions, which are working without contracts and have not had raises in more than a year.
The Nassau police have been working without a contract since Dec. 31. Under the new pact, salaries would increase by 4.75 percent in 1993 and 1994 and by 5.5 percent in 1995. The contract would also increase the number of years needed to reach top salary from six to eight.

HEADLINE: Spirited Farewell: Benjamin Hooks Chides Bush and Defends N.A.A.C.P.

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NASHVILLE, July 12

 BODY:
Closing out 15 years as head of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, Benjamin L. Hooks called on President Bush today to form a new national commission like the Kerner Commission to address the needs of the nation's cities, called for more black self-help programs and offered an enthusiastic argument in favor of N.A.A.C.P.'s continued relevance and its accomplishments.
Presiding for the last time over the annual convention of the nation's largest civil rights organization, Mr. Hooks, at a news conference this morning and in remarks delivered tonight, offered a spirited response to questions about the effectiveness and relevance of the organization. 
 The 67-year-old director also offered an enthusiastic appraisal of the Democratic Presidential ticket and, in blunt criticism of the Republican Party, said his pride in his term in office was tempered by frustration over the environment in which he served.
"I've had the misfortune of serving eight years under Reagan and three under Bush," said Mr. Hooks, who succeeded Roy Wilkins as N.A.A.C.P. director and who announced in February that he would retire next year. "It makes a great deal of difference about your expectations. We've had to get rid of a lot of programs we had hoped for, so we could fight to save what we already had."
 
Defending Record
 Mr. Hooks, an ordained minister who combines an oratorical style that comes out of the black church with a background in law and business, returned to his home state for his final N.A.A.C.P. national convention. At turns fiesty and philosophical today, Mr. Hooks said his main goal at the official opening of the annual convention was to defend the association against accusations that it had slipped from the forefront of the drive for black equality.
In a 41-page report entitled "Let The Record Show," the organization listed a long string of achievements over the last 15 years in areas, including legislation, legal challenges, direct action like demonstrations, cultural and educational programs and economic programs. In his remarks, Mr. Hooks, who remains extremely popular with most of the association's membership, dismissed criticisms that the organization had somehow lost its edge.
"Despite what is said about the 'old fogeyism' of the association, or about its irrelevance, the N.A.A.C.P. remains the undisputed leader and major force in the civil rights arena," he said. "Even our critics acknowledge that. I'm proud of what we have managed to achieve over 15 years. These have not been the years the locusts have eaten."
In the last year, the association's board has been plagued by a leadership dispute between supporters of Mr. Hooks and of Dr. William F. Gibson, the organization's chairman. In February, the fighting boiled over when several board members, who were in Mr. Hook's camp, left the board after a dispute about limiting the terms of board members and officers.
At his news conference this morning, Mr. Hooks declined to single out specific achievements, saying instead that in areas across the political spectrum the N.A.A.C.P.'s achievements cut to the heart of the issues facing American blacks.
But in his remarks and in the report, achievements cited include civil rights legislation like the 1982 Voting Rights Act Extension and the 1991 Civil Rights Act and numerous legal challenges in areas like hiring and discrimination in housing.
 
Range of Activities
 Mr. Hooks said educational programs for black youths, conferences on issues like the black family and social services, and "fair share" programs to increase minority hiring at corporations reflected the broad range of the association's activities.
He blamed critics and overly hostile news media, and a naivete about the pace of progress for the issues raised about the organization.
Pointing to civil and ethnic strife around the world, particularly in what used to be the Soviet Union, he said Americans may be unduly optimistic how quickly the ills built up over three centuries can be cured.
"I'm not quite sure why we've got this dream and concept that in 10 years all our problems can be solved." He said.
In fact, he said Americans tended to overlook how much progress blacks have made since the beginning of the civil rights movement. He said 70 percent of blacks lived above the poverty level and 30 percent lived below it, the opposite for the figures 30 years ago.
 
Cities 'Down the Drain'
 On the other hand, looking at the problems of the nation's cities and its poor, he acknowledged a crisis the N.A.A.C.P. has been unable to ward off.
"Our cities are going down the drain," he said.
He continued: "I wish I'd been able to work at a different time with a different set of expectations. That's my greatest disappointment.
Mr. Hooks said reports of negative reactions Saturday to Ross Perot's appearance at the conference were "blown out of proportion." He said that Mr. Perot's wording was unfortunate when he referred to blacks as "you people" but that Mr. Perot clearly meant no offense.
But he also said Mr. Perot was "very long on the definition of the problems and very short on the solutions."
 
Praise for Democrats
 He offered warm praise for the Democratic ticket and predicted it would achieve the historic level of acceptance blacks have given Democratic Presidential tickets in the past.
He said having two Southerners sensitive to civil rights issues and familiar with black concerns would prove extremely attractive to black voters. He described Gov. Bill Clinton and Senator Al Gore as typical of Southerners changed by the civil rights era "who've hunted and fished with black people, who've lived with them, been in their country stores, who understand, who eat the same corn bread."
"Clinton and Gore make a very attractive ticket," he said.
Mr. Hooks, who does not yet have a successor, continues in his job until his retirement next year and is likely to have other valedictory moments. He said he had received numerous job inquiries but had no firm plans other than to stay active in civil rights and religious activities.
And, in a joking reference to what he feels is an inability to get the N.A.A.C.P. message across, he said he might move into the media.
"I'm thinking of buying a newspaper," he said. "If I could just for one year say what I wanted to say."

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

NEW YORK CITY
 
SUSPECT ARRESTED IN ROBBERY OF PRIESTS 
A New York man considered a suspect in more than 50 armed robberies in Queens and Nassau County, including the robbery of four priests Friday night, was arrested while walking through an apartment complex in Texas, the police said. Nicknamed the driveway bandit, the suspect usually approached his victims in their driveways and stole their valuables, even their cars, at gunpoint. But the suspect's lawyer said yesterday that he had talked with him by phone from Texas on Friday, hours before the priests were robbed near St. John's University. B9.
 
GAY POLICE STRUGGLE IN TWO WORLDS
In New York City, to be gay and to be a police officer is to struggle as an outsider against myths and misconceptions not only in the Police Department, one of New York's most macho enclaves, but also in gay organizations. Gay officers have been ridiculed and ostracized by their colleagues, barraged by hostility and at times have even had their cars and personal lockers vandalized. And they have also been regarded with suspicion by gays who are not officers. Faced with such hurdles, many men and women have never complained about harassment and few are open about being gay. B9.

A CLINTON-CUOMO TICKET: WHAT IF?
Would Mr. Clinton have been well-served with Mario Cuomo as his running mate? While Mr. Cuomo would have infused the ticket with electricity, it might have short-circuited at times, if his experience as lieutenant governor is any guide. And a Clinton-Cuomo ticket might have been encumbered by New York political baggage, and by the two governors' shortage of Washington and foreign expertise. Metro Matters, B9.
 
Convention coverage, B1-B6.

REGION
 
WORST STILL TO COME FOR NEW YORK ECONOMY
While the latest job figures are raising the prospect of a "triple dip" recession for the rest of the nation, economists say that the New York region has yet to emerge from the first phase of the downturn, and that the continuing loss of service jobs makes prospects for recovery here even bleaker. Across New York, Connecticut and New Jersey, the businesses that fueled the region's growth do not appear to have hit bottom. Advertising agencies, management consulting concerns and public relations companies are carving deeply into their employment, and architecture firms and real-estate brokerage houses are reeling under their worst financial losses in decades. B13.
 
AGAINST ODDS, LITTLE MUSEUM MAKES GOOD
Small art museums in small cities have always had to struggle against obscurity, and recent cuts in both public and private grants have hit them particularly hard. But the New Britain Museum of American Art is quietly thriving, and its low-key success is illustrated by a bequest it received last month of 26 works by Edward Hopper, George Tooker and 10 other early-20th-century Realist artists. The bequest, estimated to be worth several million dollars, highlights the museum's dual identity as an institution with little visibility that operates on a shoestring, but is also regarded as having one of the country's finest collections of American art. New Britain Journal, B13.

POLICE PRESENCE FOR BLACKS AT BEACH
Four weeks after a weekend beach party in Belmar, N.J., ended in a disturbance that left about 30 people injured, a large contingent of police officers turned out today to monitor a picnic here organized by black fraternities and sororities, prompting resentment and complaints from many of the youths. About 70 police officers from several surrounding towns arrived in Belmar in midmorning and most spent the afternoon, nightsticks at their sides, patrolling the ocean front boardwalk in groups of four. The afternoon passed without incident, but Belmar residents remained jittery over the street disorders that erupted after a music concert on the beach here on June 14. While the crowd on that day was racially mixed, many white residents and black visitors said the fighting quickly became roving racial battles. B13.
Governor Cuomo has summoned legislative leaders back to Albany. B11.

HEADLINE: Is Conagra Overdoing Its Healthy Choices?

BYLINE: By EBEN SHAPIRO

 BODY:
Just three years after introducing its first Healthy Choice product -- with reduced levels of fat and salt -- Conagra Inc. expects sales to reach $1 billion for its current fiscal year, which ends next May.
But some food industry experts believe Conagra is jeopardizing the success of Healthy Choice by trying to do too much too quickly -- blanketing supermarkets with a sweeping line of soups, desserts, pizza and more. 
 For one thing, these experts say, Healthy Choice's main frozen dinner business has stumbled. And that makes it even more difficult to expand a single brand name throughout the entire supermarket. When sales of Weight Watchers dinners fell in the 1980's, for example, Weight Watchers desserts and other products also fared poorly.
 
100 New Products in a Year
 "The crack in the foundation is already apparent," said Gary Stibel, president of the New England Consulting Group in Westport, Conn. "They are in danger. One must question whether they are trying to do too much."
In the last year, Conagra has introduced 100 Healthy Choice products, bringing the total to 188. Because of heavy spending on product development and advertising, most of the products are not profitable.
Now, sales of Conagra's frozen dinners are declining, victims of a bruising price war. For the 13 weeks ended in June 1992, Healthy Choice frozen dinner and entrees sales dropped by more than 12 percent, according to Nielsen Marketing Research. Sales at Stouffer, which aggressively cut prices, increased 16 percent in the same period.
Last week, Conagra, based in Omaha, began telling grocers to clear space on their shelves for its push into the cheese business -- a $5 billion-a-year market. By the fall, Conagra plans to have 30 varieties of fat-free Healthy Choice cheeses, going to head to head with Kraft General Foods and Borden Inc.
This is just the latest round of direct competition with other huge food companies. Earlier this year, Healthy Choice aimed a line of low-fat deli meats at Oscar Mayer, a Kraft subsidiary. And last fall, Conagra introduced a line of ready-to-serve soups that competed with the Campbell Soup Company.
 
'A Loser's Game'
 "To take on Oscar Mayer in meats, Kraft in cheeses and Campbell's in soup -- to me, it's a loser's game," said John M. McMillin, a food analyst with Prudential Securities. "You have to ask yourself, Is there an economic benefit to this? Are they left with 8 percent shares of seven different categories?"
Conagra executives say each product adds strength to the Healthy Choice juggernaut. "There is safety in numbers," said Steve Hughes, executive vice president of Healthy Choice. And by moving fast, he said, Conagra could be the first big company with a line of healthy products in different categories. But competitors have the same idea in mind. In fact, last fall Campbell's new healthy soups and the Healthy Choice soups hit supermarkets on virtually the same day in September.
While Healthy Choice is a relatively small part of Conagra, the parent company is indeed a juggernaut, with annual revenues of $19.5 billion and operations "across the food chain," with huge meat, poultry and grain and flour operations.
For the year ended May 26, 1991, Conagra earned $311 million, or $2.13 a share, on sales of $19.5 billion. Final results for the most recent fiscal year have not been released, but nine-month sales were up 3 percent and profits 16 percent.
 
Need to Move Quickly
 Conagra also feels that it must move quickly because each niche has "a fairly narrow window," Mr. Hughes said.
Competitors, however, contend that the window has already been slammed shut.
"In the cheese business, Conagra does not bring anything new," said Mitch Weinick, a senior group vice president for Borden.
Borden, based in New York, recently introduced a line of fat-free single-slice cheeses.
And Kraft is planning one of its biggest product introductions in years, a 22-item line of low-fat cheeses called Healthy Favorites. Kraft's Oscar Mayer division also has a line of Healthy Favorites low-fat lunch meats.
"Conagra is really going to get its nose clipped here," said Max Busetti, editor of The Food Industry Newsletter in Alexandria, Va. "Kraft has let it be known that it will not lose any more market share."
And Healthy Choice has not been successful in each aisle it has tried. A low-fat ground beef and an ice-cream-like frozen dairy dessert have not done well.
Mr. Hughes said that Conagra had never had an ice-cream-type product before and that there had been some problems figuring out how to keep grocers' freezers stocked with the best-selling flavors.
And the low-fat ground beef had distribution problems, he said.
Yet some new lines have done well. Healthy Choice soups have been successful, as have the meats and the spaghetti sauce, which competes with Ragu and other brands.
At Stouffer, which battles Conagra in the mainstream dinner category, the feeling is that Healthy Choice has become a less-focused competitor.
 
A Warning About Focus
 "It's either lack of focus or neglect," said Edward A. Marra, senior vice president of marketing for the Stouffer Foods Corporation, a Nestle subsidiary based in Solon, Ohio. "When you are trying to build a skyscraper, you have to have a solid foundation," he said.
And Jack Trout, of Trout & Reis, a marketing consulting firm in Greenwich, Conn., said: "The winner in marketing these days is the specialist. You become everything for everybody, and that is the kiss of death."
Mr. Hughes of Conagra said that because of the company's huge size, the different Healthy Choice businesses were being run by separate Conagra divisions. Armour Swift-Eckrich, for instance, is running the Healthy Choice meat business, while the Beatrice Cheese Company is handling the cheese.
"We can move fast and move focused and not overtax the resources of any one group," he said.
In fact, Mr. Hughes, said, there are are many more Healthy Choice products to come. In addition to cheese, the company is broadening its line of ready-to-serve soups and there are rumors that Conagra plans to take on Campbell's in the larger condensed-soup business.
Some food analysts also believe that Healthy Choice may introduce a line of salad dressings.t
But Mr. Trout is not convinced.
"Somebody should say 'Let's back off here,' " he said.

HEADLINE: Service Industry Founders In Unrelenting Recession

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
While the latest job figures are raising the prospect of a "triple dip" recession for the rest of the nation, economists say that the New York region has yet to emerge from the first phase of the downturn, and that the continuing loss of service jobs makes prospects for recovery here even bleaker.
Across New York, Connecticut and New Jersey, the businesses that fueled the region's growth do not appear to have hit bottom. Law and accounting firms are laying off junior and senior executives alike. Advertising agencies, management consulting concerns and public relations companies are carving deeply into their employment, and architecture firms and real-estate brokerage houses are reeling under their worst financial losses in decades. 
 "New York is at the center of the storm," said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, New York Regional Commissioner of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics, which reported that national unemployment jumped three-tenths of a percentage point in June, to 7.8 percent, and that joblessness was far more acute in the New York region.
"This is not just another dip," he added. "It's a story of ongoing decline."
 
'Unprecedented Change'
 Economists and business executives say the region's recession is being prolonged by the very same industries that have proved resilient to previous downturns, and made New York and its suburbs a showplace in the 1980's when business and professional services were thought to be replacing manufacturing as the key to the nation's economic growth.
"Service companies have awakened to an unprecedented period of structural change and competitive forces," said Stephen S. Roach, senior economist for Morgan Stanley.
To be sure, experts have long described the nation's current recession as one affecting service industries more than previous downturns. But the extent of the damage, a growing consensus that it will be prolonged or permanent, and its brutal impact on those highly paid service professionals in the New York region are proving worse than anticipated.
The New York region has always been a center of law, financial consulting and other service professions. But in the robust 1980's, the region's manufacturing base declined and its core of corporate headquarters and other centers of international business decision-making attained a more dominant place in its economy.
"Regions that depend on services are going to have to find alternatives," Mr. Roach said, "and none is more dependent than New York."
Nationally, the jump was attributed to a host of problems, including a downturn in consumer spending and home building, and economists have engaged in a fervent debate -- made no less urgent by election-year politics -- that the nation, which began a slow economic recovery late last year, may now be dipping back into recession.
 
Unemployment Jumps
 But for New York City and its suburbs, any hopes that a belated recovery was at hand were dashed by the same Federal report on June employment. It said the New York City unemployment rate jumped a full percentage point to 11.5 percent; the rate in New York State leaped to 9.2 percent from 7.9 percent; and the rate in New Jersey increased to 9.2 percent from 9 percent. June figures are not yet available for Connecticut.
Employment cuts in the service industries "have thrown a very painful wrench" into the region's prospects for a recovery soon, Mr. Ehrenhalt said.
The fallout is palpable among many of the region's professionals.
At the New York City Bar Association, monthly "emotional support" meetings, offering guidance from a psychologist, have been attracting 60 to 100 lawyers, most of whom have lost their jobs. Other support groups have been organized to counsel Bar Association members on resume writing and other job-hunting skills.
Lawyers who have attended say that, for the first time in any of their memories, partners at New York area firms are being forced out, even if that means that the ownership interests that they have acquired have to be purchased from them. Layoffs among associates are far more commonplace, they said, and a new term in the legal profession -- "portable business" -- is being invoked frequently by major firms to make clear that they expect job candidates to bring in bill-paying clients, as well as their legal skills.
 
Public Relations Firms Hit
 "We are dealing with lawyers who worked in banking, real estate, mergers and acquisitions, across the board," said Madeline Stoller, chairman of the Bar Association committee that is conducting the support groups.
Also hit hard by the recession is public relations, which grew rapidly during the free-spending, image-conscious 1980's. Over the last two years, the number of employees of New York-area public relations companies has been cut by at least 10 percent, said Howard J. Rubenstein, owner of Howard J. Rubenstein Associates, one of the largest, with 128 employees.
The problem, he said, is that most of the clients of public relations firms are the same professional service executives that are themselves struggling with layoffs and shrinking profits, adding that the only area of growth for public relations practitioners now is in "crisis management."
"We are handling a lot of economic collapse," Mr. Rubenstein said.
To be sure, business and professional service companies are not the only only ones that continue to feel the bite of the region's long recession. One industry decimated by the slump has been retail sales, in which a string of department-store closings in New York City and the suburbs have prompted huge employment cuts.
 
Manufacturing Shrinks
 Manufacturing, a weak link in the regional economy for decades, has continued to shrink. The fallout was illustrated Friday when Stroehmann Bakeries closed its Taystee Bakery plant in Flushing, Queens.
Government studies show that manufacturing employment in New York City declined to slightly below 300,000 jobs in 1991 for the first time since World War II, with unremitting losses that totaled over 200,000 jobs since 1979.
Amid the bleak government data, the region shows some glimmers of economic hope. Wall Street, after 18 months of surging profits and stock trading volume, appears to have ended a deep wave of job cuts, although new hiring is slow and anemic.
With the Democratic National Convention convening in Manhattan this week, and with the city still basking in the success of its Op Sail extravaganza, hotels, restaurants and other businesses that depend on tourism promise improved earnings, at least for the summer.
