HEADLINE: NEW BRITAIN JOURNAL;
A Museum of American Art That Quietly Thrives

BYLINE: By ANDREW L. YARROW

DATELINE: NEW BRITAIN, Conn.

 BODY:
Small American art museums in small American cities have always had to struggle against obscurity, and recent cuts in both public and private grants have hit them particularly hard.
Against this backdrop, it might seem surprising that such a museum could quietly thrive and grow, particularly in a New England industrial town whose glory days are decades past. But that is what is happening at the New Britain Museum of American Art, and its low-key success is illustrated by a bequest it received last month of 26 works by Edward Hopper, George Tooker and 10 other early-20th-century Realist artists. 
 The bequest -- by Olga Knoepke, a collector in Newtown, Conn. -- bolsters the 89-year-old museum's already strong collection of more than 6,000 works and is a testament to its director, Daniel C. DuBois, whose casual conversations about art with Ms. Knoepke in the years before her death led to the gift.
The significance of Ms. Knoepke's bequest, estimated to be worth several million dollars, highlights the museum's dual identity as an institution with little visibility that operates on a shoestring, but is also regarded as having one of the country's finest collections of American art.
"It is a wonderful little museum," said James Reinish, a senior vice president at Hirschl & Adler, a New York gallery specializing in American painting.
"Olga Knoepke's collecting was mixed, but she had a feeling about art, and 'The Bird Watchers' is a fabulous painting," he added, referring to an eerily surreal work by George Tooker in the bequest that he said was worth $300,000.
The museum, occupying a genteel, tree-shaded stone house that has had galleries added over the years, has only five full-time staff members. It has an annual budget of $400,000 and attracts barely 30,000 visitors a year. Yet its esthetic terrain ranges from sober Gilbert Stuart portraits and grand Albert Bierstadt landscapes to the bold, muscular figures of Thomas Hart Benton's murals and haunting canvases by Jacob Lawrence.
"What we try to do is relate content over time, and look at the universal concerns of American art over 250 years," said Mr. DuBois, a 42-year-old painter and sculptor.
The New Britain Museum moved in 1937 into its current quarters overlooking Walnut Hill Park, designed by the 19th-century landscape architect Frederick Law Olmsted. A major portion of the museum's holdings came from a donation in the 1940's by Harriett and Alex Russell Stanley, whose family business, the Stanley Works hardware plants, has anchored New Britain economically for a century and a half.
Although it says it is the oldest museum devoted exclusively to American painting and sculpture, its low profile and meager finances have meant that it has grown principally through the generosity of artists and benefactors like Mrs. Knoepke or Charles and Elizabeth Buchanan, who bequeathed 34 American Impressionist paintings in 1989.
"Smaller gifts make a tremendous difference for us," Mr. DuBois said. "What we can do with relatively small amounts of money, to utilize our resources, would be impossible for a large museum."
Much of the museum's appeal derives from its intimacy, in the form of touches like a Stanley Works grandfather clock that chimes each quarter-hour at the entrance and the twice-weekly jazz and chamber-music programs for 100 concertgoers.
The museum's 18 gallery rooms proceed chronologically, beginning with a sedate library and dining room replete with fireplaces and divans to complement Colonial and Federal portraits, and 19th-century Realist and Impressionist paintings by Frederic Edwin Church, Thomas Cole, George Inness, Childe Hassam and others. Newer galleries are hung with 20th-century works by Georgia O'Keeffe, Marsden Hartley and John Sloan, as well as changing exhibitions like a current show by Connecticut women artists.
The most dramatic first-floor gallery is devoted to Benton's series of five oversized murals, "The Arts of Life in America," while the second floor is largely used to display the prized collection of 1,400 American illustrations, given by a group of artists since 1964, after the death of the museum's longtime first director, Sanford Low.
Today, as Mr. DuBois talks about expanding educational programs and perhaps adding new galleries and a sculpture garden, the museum may be at a turning point. Although it has never charged admission and had never even solicited donations until the 1980's, this year it embarked on its first capital drive.
But even this concession to modern realities is tempered by a desire to maintain its sense of scale.
"We have conversations about further physical expansion," Mr. DuBois said. "But we don't want to cut down the trees."

HEADLINE: CITY IN THE SPOTLIGHT;
Mayor Dinkins Spins at the Center of a Weeklong Whirl

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
Mayor David N. Dinkins, who fought hard to bring the Democratic National Convention to New York City, has begun the exhausting week of politics, boosterism and partying required of him as the host of the 4,700 delegates and 15,000 journalists who have descended on Manhattan.
On Saturday, he greeted Gov. Bill Clinton at the airport and attended a welcoming party in Bryant Park for reporters. In the evening, he was host at a lawn party at Gracie Mansion honoring Hispanic delegates. 
 The Mayor spent yesterday in a whirlwind of appearances, rehearsing his welcoming speech at Madison Square Garden, racing up to the Apollo Theater in Harlem to pay tribute to the Rev. Jesse Jackson and then rushing back downtown to speak briefly at a reception for gay and lesbian delegates at B. Smith's Restaurant in midtown. Mr. Dinkins was clearly pleased at the attention he got at the Apollo. "I often say that Gracie Mansion may be my house -- but Harlem is my home."
The Mayor also attended a party for the Arkansas and Pennsylvania delegations at the Brooklyn Museum.
 
Civic Spin
 The busy week is a challenge he sought. He says he relishes the chance to burnish the city's image, which has been tarnished in recent years by the recession, crime, racial tensions and violent disturbances like those in Crown Heights last summer and in Washington Heights last week.
If the week goes well, it will no doubt prove useful both to the city and to the Mayor's political fortunes. After suffering through an extremely difficult first two years in office -- when the recession forced the city to make repeated and painful reductions in its budget -- Mr. Dinkins has received praise on his improved management of the city on everything from fiscal affairs to limiting violence in Washington Heights; an upbeat week as host to the Democrats could only benefit the Mayor who brought them here.
The Mayor will have ample opportunity to show off the city's brighter side. His schedule for the week includes at least a dozen radio and television interviews, many of them on national television networks.
He will also attend more than a dozen breakfasts, lunches and receptions, celebrating everything from the city's upscale restaurants and fashion and design industry to its museums. On Wednesday, for example, he will attend a breakfast at the Museum of Modern Art called "Muffins and Masterpieces at MOMA."
But Mr. Dinkins's whirlwind week will include more than civic boosterism. Tonight, he is to greet the convention delegates with a seven-minute welcoming address at the Garden. Immediately afterward, he is tentatively scheduled to be interviewed on the podium by Maria Shriver of NBC.
Mr. Dinkins will preside over a luncheon in the garden of Gracie Mansion tomorrow morning for the United States Conference of Mayors.
The Mayor is also a member of the Democrats' platform committee and is a vice chairman of the New York State delegation. And he has one other matter to consider during the four-day convention: running the city.
His aides have set aside a few hours each day for Mr. Dinkins to meet with his senior advisers, either at Gracie Mansion or at City Hall, and to attend to municipal business.
His schedule runs from 6:30 A.M. until midnight most days this week and includes time on the convention floor as well as appearances at events ranging from the delegate's three-mile run in Central Park tomorrow morning to a breakfast Thursday morning of the National Jewish Democratic Council.
The Mayor summed up his duties in an interview last week. "The idea," he said, "is for me to be as many places as I can, to be hospitable."

HEADLINE: CITY IN THE SPOTLIGHT;
Coveted Cameo Roles in a Drama With a Forgone Conclusion

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
Mario M. Cuomo, Bill Bradley and Joseph I. Lieberman -- three elected officials from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut whom Gov. Bill Clinton considered as running mates -- have been given speaking parts in this week's Democratic national convention, lending the national event a distinct regional flair.
Since the conclusion is forgone -- Bill Clinton is king, Al Gore his chancellor -- all that is left to watch is how well the others play the game at Madison Square Garden. 
 A turn at the podium is a showcase for the speaker and a bouquet proffered by the party or by Mr. Clinton for favors past or a future freighted with promise. Thus some of the players who will strut and fret their hour upon the stage spent yesterday in a kind of dress rehearsal.
 
Watching Moss Grow
 Senator Bradley, whose star quality remains undiminished despite a speaking style that he admits has in the past been akin to watching moss grow on a flat rock, has emerged as something of an orator since two years ago when he almost lost an election by refusing to talk about anything anybody wanted to hear about.
Now, Mr. Bradley has centered on themes he really does seem to care about, racial division, the pathology of urban America and the dispossessed children that are the offspring of both. And he has managed to find a style that marries the aw-shucks modesty that befits an N.B.A. superstar with a new-found sense of passionate urgency.
He spoke yesterday at Riverside Church in upper Manhattan, which is as close to a Mecca for racial equality as exists in America, and later at Covenant House, at a convention to form an agenda to reclaim the estimated 100,000 children, some barely in their teens, who have left home to wander the nation's increasingly mean and dangerous streets. He gave the same speech and got an ovation both places.
He evoked the theme of racial alienation he has sounded before, first on the floor of the Senate almost exactly a year ago in a speech excoriating President Bush both for ignoring racial problems and intensifying them by "playing the race card" with the 1990 Willie Horton television commercials, and later in a speech before the National Press Club in which he asked "when was the last time you had a conversation about race with someone of a different race?"
While Mr. Bradley was largely taking the offensive, outlining new urban programs and talking of "an economy that takes everybody to a higher ground," Governor Cuomo was defending Mr. Clinton and for the first time took out after the insurgent Texas billionaire Ross Perot.
Acknowledging the tactic has been fatal to Democrats in the past, Gov. Cuomo praised his Arkansas colleague for telling voters "the bad news" about the need to raise taxes and cut entitlements. In a round of television interviews to promote the Democratic ticket, Mr. Cuomo also made his first disparaging remarks about Mr. Perot.
 
Doesn't Understand the Rules'
 He said that Mr. Perot, in remarks to the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People on Saturday had shown that "he is not political in the best sense" and in that he "doesn't understand the rules and he doesn't understand the people."
Mr. Perot referred to blacks before his black audience on Saturday as "your people," which seemed to offend many in the crowd.
Mr. Cuomo said on Channel 2's "Sunday Edition Live" that Mr. Perot "doesn't know the groups, he doesn't know how to communicate with them." "He can't talk to the people in the inner cities the way Bill Clinton can," Mr. Cuomo said.
He also said Mr. Clinton could make "the best candidate since Kennedy."
Governor Cuomo's regional accent, as well as those of others at the convention, could be critical.
Democrats lost the state in 1984 and barely carried it four years later, and it is considered vital to a victory by Mr. Clinton in November. In 1988, President Bush carried New Jersey and Connecticut. By enlisting the leading Democrats in each state -- plus the region's only Hispanic Congressman, Jose E. Serrano of the Bronx -- as convention speakers this week, the Democratic National Committee and Mr. Clinton are playing to their party's strength and to a pivotal constituency.
 
Nominating Speech
 Governor Cuomo -- who decided only last December against running himself -- will nominate Mr. Clinton for President on Wednesday night.
Senator Bradley of New Jersey will deliver one of three speeches tonight that collectively constitute this year's keynote. Gov. Jim Florio of New Jersey is scheduled to address the convention on Wednesday before the nominating speeches.
Connecticut's lone scheduled speaker is Senator Lieberman, who represented Mr. Clinton on the platform drafting committee. He is to speak tomorrow night after the party's platform is presented.
Mr. Bradley was courted assiduously as a running mate by Mr. Clinton. Mr. Cuomo was urged by some party leaders to consider an invitation to be the candidate for Vice President. Mr. Lieberman was among the other prospects mentioned, which might have made him the nation's first Jewish Vice President.
New Yorkers may be asked to nominate other candidates or second their nominations. Besides Mr. Cuomo and David N. Dinkins, the host city's mayor, other speakers invited by the Democratic National Committee or the Clinton camp are Representative Serrano -- a bow to the city's Puerto Rican population -- and Manhattan Borough President Ruth W. Messinger, an early Clinton supporter who scored a coup in being invited to the podium.
New Yorkers, including Mayor Abraham D. Beame, were instrumental in luring the 1976 and 1980 Democratic conventions, which nominated and re-nominated Jimmy Carter, to New York. The 1976 convention was the first for New York since 1924. But New Yorkers played only cameo roles at the conventions themselves.
In 1984, the convention chose Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro of Queens as its candidate for Vice President. Mr. Cuomo delivered a stirring keynote address that immediately made him the party's most sought-after public speaker. Mayor Edward I. Koch of New York was received more cooly when he appealed for military intervention to stem the flow of illegal drugs.
In 1988, New Yorkers were again largely relegated to bit parts at best.

HEADLINE: I.B.M. in Chip Deal With Toshiba and Siemens

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF

 BODY:
In a historic shift in what has been a bitter rivalry to dominate the world's semiconductor industry, I.B.M. will announce today that it is joining with two electronics giants, Toshiba of Japan and Siemens of Germany, to develop memory chips that are likely to be a mainstay of computers used in the next century.
The joint effort will take place at an I.B.M. semiconductor factory in East Fishkill, N.Y., which industry executives regard as a victory for both the International Business Machines Corporation and the United States, with scientists and engineers from the three computer companies working together. 
 No joint manufacturing is currently planned.
"This is an unprecedented shift," said Robert Reich, a Harvard economist and expert on international trade and competitiveness. "The global economy respects no borders and these companies are all becoming extensions of one another. It's truly the arrival of the global economic web."
In the 1980's, the belief that America was in danger of losing its independent ability to manufacture the most modern computer chips raised great alarm and was the driving force behind the creation of Sematech, a United States Government and industry consortium to develop basic chip-making technology.
I.B.M. was a leading backer of the effort to create Sematech and also helped support U.S. Memories Inc., a private joint venture of American companies to make memory chips. The company failed in 1990.
It was also in the 1980's that I.B.M. -- fearful of the growing power of the Japanese -- sought a link with Siemens. The two companies currently manufacture small memory chips at a factory in France and develop larger chips.
More recently, several changes in the international climate have altered American and European executives' perceptions of the Japanese.
First, the collapse of the Japanese stock market has limited Japan's access to the huge amounts of capital necessary to build advanced semiconductors. Moreover, several other nations in Asia have entered the semiconductor market, putting added pressure on the Japanese.
"The costs and risks of developing these chips have become enormous," said Clyde V. Prestowitz Jr., president of the Economic Strategy Institute. "Toshiba has just lost too much money in the memory market. Even the Japanese are feeling the heat."
Starting in 1986, I.B.M. had agreed to make display screens for portable and other types of computers for Toshiba. But the agreement to be announced this morning goes much further, representing a commitment to a technology that is likely to be dominant when it becomes available in six to eight years.
The new chips that will be developed will be able to store 256 million bits of data each, roughly equivalent to 10,000 pages of typed text. That huge capacity is expected to let computer scientists achieve breakthroughs in areas including computer speech recognition, machine vision and computer reasoning.
The new partnership reflects, in part, the huge cost of developing each generation of memory chips, which are the backbone not only of the computer industry, but also of an increasingly wide variety of consumer products, including televisions, telephones, microwave ovens and video cameras.
I.B.M. officials say that because of the sophisticated technology needed to make chips, it costs $500 million to build a manufacturing plant capable of making today's most advanced kinds, which can store 16 million bits of information. By the end of the decade, the cost is expected to rise to $1 billion.
The alliance of I.B.M., Toshiba and Siemens also suggests a fundamental shift in the battle to control the global computer industry, a struggle that has pitted the world's most powerful companies and governments in the last decade.
"I think that in the past a number of us exaggerated the rate at which the Japanese would continue to progress in controlling semiconductor equipment and process technology and exaggerated the consequences of controlling the semiconductor market," said Charles H. Ferguson, an industry consultant and an Massachusetts Institute of Technology researcher.
I.B.M. suffered its worst financial year ever last year and in December embarked on a radical companywide decentralization, freeing its independent businesses to compete more aggressively and to strike deals with other companies.
In the past, I.B.M. used its semiconductor design and manufacturing ability largely to supply its own needs, but I.B.M. executives have said recently that the computer maker is eager to expand the role of its semiconductor business and to compete with companies that sell their chips on the open market.
Professor Reich said that as recently as two years ago, he had conversations with European manufacturers, including Siemens, in which executives of those companies talked about joining with United States manufacturers because they feared the Japanese.
Significantly, the joint development agreement will not involve X-ray lithography, a chipmaking technology in which I.B.M. has a huge investment.
Until recently, most semiconductor designers believed that it would be necessary to shift from visible light to X-rays to etch the incredibly fine circuit lines of the most advanced memory chips beyond 16 million bits. In the last two years technology advances in the use of ultraviolet light and related techniques have extended the limits of optical lithography.
Now many semiconductor engineers believe that it will be possible to use ultraviolet light to etch circuits as fine as 25-hundredths of a micron (a human hair is about 75 microns wide), the width necessary to build 256-million-bit chips.
Several industry executives and policy analysts said that the decision to carry out the research project at an I.B.M. development plant was a victory both for the computer maker and for the United States. In the past, other key development projects between the companies have been carried out in Japan and France.
Indeed, the most important point, Professor Reich said, is that the development effort will take place in East Fishkill.
"That has enormous significance for Americans," he said.

HEADLINE: Washington at Work;
Iraq Loans Put What's-His-Name in a Public Role

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 12

 BODY:
In his 12 years in government, Frank M. Lemay has always strived to fit the profile of the ideal bureaucrat, working overtime to make his superiors look smart on such specialties as Colombian coffee quotas and reducing greenhouse gases, and above all never getting his name in print.
Even his self-portrait is self-effacing. 
 "I'm not a pushover, and if I want something done a certain way I'll make my views known," the slightly built Foreign Service officer said in an interview in his remarkably neat postage-stamp-sized office in the Bureau of Legislative Affairs. "But I've always been a behind-the-scenes, pretty standard bureaucrat who doesn't seek out the limelight."
But the limelight is exactly where Mr. Lemay finds himself, hauled before Congress to be hailed by Democrats as a fearless Cassandra, frozen out by his State Department superiors as a whistleblower, and worse -- pooh-poohed by the President himself on national television.
The 35-year-old economist's cocoon of anonymity disappeared on March 30 when Representative Henry B. Gonzalez, the Texas Democrat, disclosed in a speech on the House floor the contents of a classified memo -- one of many he had requested from the State Department -- that Mr. Lemay wrote in October 1989.
 
The Famous Memo
 With a bluntness rare in diplomatese, the memo warned of evidence that President Saddam Hussein of Iraq had misused a United States farm-loan program to buy nuclear-related equipment, adding that a Federal investigation into the Atlanta bank that had been the primary lender could "blow the roof off."
"If smoke indicates fire, we may be facing a four-alarm blaze in the near future," Mr. Lemay wrote to his superiors in the office of the Under Secretary for Economic Affairs, urging caution in approving new credit guarantees.
It was a caution not taken, as $500 million in new credits of a possible $1 billion were extended a few weeks later. The disclosure has thrust Mr. Lemay into a maelstrom about the Bush Administration's policy toward Iraq before the invasion of Kuwait. And under assault, the mild-mannered Mr. Lemay, who once won a State Department award for macro-economic memo-writing under extraordinary pressure, is toughening up.
 
A Tough Response
 After two of the four senior Agriculture Department officials whose briefing was the subject of his memo told Congress that he had been writing fiction, he replied, in sworn testimony, "I was quite taken aback."
In uncharacteristically strong language, he added: "I had no motivation to make anything up," saying, "I completely stand behind the memo that I wrote. I will take full responsibility for what is said in there."
On the surface Mr. Lemay, who sometimes omits please-and-thank-you politesse in conversations with subordinates, remains dispassionate.
"I saw this attack as very personal," he said in the clipped, understated tone he used before the committee. "It impugned my professional reputation, and it was very important to me to put things straight. I wasn't a firebrand screaming, 'Kill the program!' I was simply concerned that people review the allegations."
But colleagues say that the experience has turned his life upside down. A bachelor who spends much of his spare time laboriously renovating an old row house in the ethnically mixed Mount Pleasant section of Washington, he suddenly found himself spending most of his waking hours trying to reconstruct the events of three years ago, a task made more difficult because the State Department has been unable to locate his files.
Mr. Lemay has been shunned by his superiors, these colleagues say, a result of the chilling effect of charges by some Congressional Democrats of Administration criminality.
Even some senior officials sympathetic to Mr. Lemay's plight defend their reluctance to talk to him, saying they do not want to be accused of advising him in ways that Congressional Democrats would construe as a cover-up.
None of his superiors offered to review his testimony or wished him luck before his committee appearance, or called him afterward to congratulate him on a job well done, his colleagues say, a point Mr. Lemay is unwilling to talk about. The State Department legal adviser, Edwin D. Williamson, met with him briefly before his testimony but offered no legal assistance; Mr. Lemay has paid a personal lawyer to represent him.
 
The Few Who Back Him
 "It was important in the Lemay case that it not appear that he was being coached or primed or coerced in whatever testimony he gave," says Mr. Williamson, explaining State Department tiptoeing. "Our advice to him was to tell the truth, to stick to what he knew personally and to avoid speculation. It was my impression that he was not hung out to dry and that he had access to the documents that he needed to the extent that they were available."
When asked whether Mr. Lemay might get the impression he was being ostracized by the Department, Mr. Williamson replied, "You probably can't have it both ways."
Only Mr. Lemay's former superiors have come to his defense publicly.
"He is a person of the highest integrity who did an excellent job in the time he served in my office," said Richard T. McCormack, the former Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs who assigned his young assistant to look into the farm-credit program. Sam Hoskinson, Mr. Lemay's immediate superior, who has since returned to the Central Intelligence Agency, said, "I have not seen any better than Lemay."
 
What Bush Didn't Know
 Much to Mr. Lemay's dismay, his testimony even caught the attention of President Bush, who has become progressively more flustered in explaining his pre-war Iraq policy.
When asked about the memo, he sputtered, denying that the State Department ever knew about the diversion, which in fact remains unproven. "You can talk about what one State Department employee -- and if we had known it, it wouldn't have happened," he said on a network news program on July 1.
The stakes are high. Democrats are determined to make the matter an election issue, while Republicans are worried that what was once regarded as Mr. Bush's greatest triumph as President, the Persian Gulf war, has been transformed unfairly into one of his most significant political liabilities.
State Department officials close to Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d play down the significance of Mr. Lemay's memo. They point out that the allegations he highlighted -- that a United States loan program may have paid for Iraqi arms -- are still only allegations.
And although they acknowledge that Mr. Baker was fully aware of them from memos and briefings, they say that the policy of providing Iraq with incentives, ordered by Mr. Bush less than two weeks before Mr. Lemay wrote his memo, was too important to be slowed down by unsubstantiated reports.
"The issue was brought to the attention of all the big boys and Baker was aware of all the assertions through the huge paper trail," said one official. "We knew Saddam Hussein wasn't a saint and there was this bank thing in Atlanta, but we couldn't cut off a policy based on hunches and assertions. Frank Lemay didn't report anything differently from other people. His problem was that he put it in more bombastic language."
Still, the memo was deemed so sensitive that when it reached Mr. Baker's outer office, it was stamped with a highly unusual designation: "Not For the System." The designation, which prevents distribution throughout the bureaucracy, is used only for highly secret or highly embarrassing information. No one seems to know, or wants to say, which this memo was.
 
The Loan Deal Goes Through
 On Oct. 6, well before what has come to be called the "bells and whistles memo" arrived in his office, Mr. Baker told Iraq's Foreign Minister, Tariq Aziz, that "he would immediately look into what could be done" to resolve the matter and that he was eager for the loan to proceed, according to a summary of the meeting.
Because Mr. McCormack and Mr. Hoskinson were still wary, Mr. Lemay was sent to the Agriculture Department for a briefing on the credit program and the continuing Federal investigation of the bank.
Indeed, it was only after the State Department's legal adviser concluded that there was no overwhelming reason not to go forward with the full $1 billion program that Mr. McCormack "saw the writing on the wall," as one confidant put it. He approved the program.
Mr. Lemay, who is to become staff economist for the State Department's policy planning staff, has a poster in his office that says "Wanted -- by the U.S. Congress," with his photo in the center.
Department officials point to his assignment to a key policy-making office as proof that he is not being punished for his words.
"I'm a soft-spoken economist, hero-pariah," he said of his current status, laughing. "No, just kidding."

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, a Washington at Work article on Monday about Frank M. Lemay, a Foreign Service officer, misstated the position of Richard T. Mr. McCormack approved the program on the condition that the guarantees be provided in stages and that the program include safeguards.

Companies
I.B.M. is joining with Toshiba and Siemens to develop memory chips that are likely to be a mainstay of the computers used in the next century. The venture marks a historic shift in the bitter rivalry for domination in the world semiconductor industry. [Page D1.]

LENGTH: 1434 words

HEADLINE: UNDER THE BIG TOP -- THE CONVENTION;
DEMOCRATS PLEDGE CHANGE, FOR BOTH PARTY AND NATION, AS THEIR CONVENTION BEGINS

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER

 BODY:
Democrats opened their convention last night with the traditional brass bands, balloons and hoopla, while a parade of leaders tried to assure the television audience that the party had moderated its policies and could be trusted to govern again.
The Democrats repeatedly denounced President Bush as a failed President who had let the country drift into recession and division and was utterly unequipped to steady its course. 
 Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey, one of three keynote speakers, said Mr. Bush had "waffled and wiggled and wavered" in the face of great challenges at home and abroad.
 
'We Will Not Die'
 But Democratic leaders also took pains to present Gov. Bill Clinton, who will accept the Democratic nomination on Thursday night, as the leader of a party that was tougher and smarter after its years in the wilderness.
"The Democratic Party is alive and well," said former Representative Barbara Jordan of Texas, another keynote speaker. "We will change in order to satisfy the present, in order to satisfy the future, but we will not die."[Excerpts from speeches, page A12.]
The convention was punctuated by rowdy demonstrations on the floor from supporters of former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California, who continued to withhold an endorsement of the party's presumed nominee and was thus denied a speaking role in the program. But Mr. Clinton had a firm grip on this gathering, and his forces used it to try to project the centrist image they hope will carry him to the White House.
 
'Feel the Pain'
 Mayor David N. Dinkins welcomed the Democrats to New York, and used his time to outline an urban agenda. "Walk the streets of this city and feel the pain of an entire nation," he said. "Feel the pain of families ravaged by AIDS, of tiny babies who crave deadly crack cocaine the way that other babies crave their mother's breast."
The party also used the evening to showcase its female candidates for the Senate, who have prompted new hopes of a breakthrough year for women in politics, and who were greeted with proud and emotional applause.
The 41st national convention opened with much of the pageantry expected of a political party that just celebrated its 200th birthday, but also with the edge of self-criticism expected of a party that has lost five out of the last six Presidential elections.
Ms. Jordan, with the haunting cadence that made her speech at the 1976 Democratic convention so memorable, declared, "Why not change from a party with a reputation of 'tax and spend' to one of investment and growth?" Echoing a theme often sounded by Mr. Clinton when he moved toward a Presidential campaign a year ago, she said, "We must leave this convention with a determination to convince the American people to trust us. The American electorate must be persuaded to trust us, the Democrats, to govern again."
 
Opprobrium for Bush
 Even given the norms of party conventions, the contempt heaped on Mr. Bush was striking. Ronald H. Brown, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee, led the delegates in a chant: "Read our lips: No second term!"
Numerous other speakers took the stand to paint a grim picture of what they asserted was 12 years of Republican inaction on domestic policy. Gov. Ann W. Richards of Texas, who stole the show at the Democratic convention in Atlanta with her lacerating portrait of Mr. Bush as a man "born with a silver foot in his mouth," told the group last night: "I hate to say it. But I told you so."
But Ross Perot, the undeclared independent candidate who some Democrats believe will ultimately hurt President Bush the most, was not spared, even though Mr. Clinton himself has avoided criticizing him. Gov. Zell Miller, who helped save Mr. Clinton's candidacy in the primary season by delivering Georgia, and fiercely attacking former Senator Paul E. Tsongas, took on Mr. Perot.
"Ross says he'll clean out the barn, but he's been knee deep in it for years," Mr. Miller said, in a rollicking populist counterattack that set the delegates roaring. "If he's an outsider, folks, I'm from Brooklyn." He added, "The choice in this election is clear: We've got us a race between an aristocrat, an autocrat and a Democrat."
One of the principal themes of the night was the "year of the woman," and one of the surest applause lines was voicing support for Anita F. Hill. Senator Barbara A. Mikulski of Maryland, introducing the Democratic women running for Senate this year, declared, "Never again will a woman come forward to tell her story to a committee of the United States Senate -- and then be assaulted for telling the truth."
 
Setting the Tone
 The first night of the convention had the kind of thematic consistency expected from Republicans, but unusual for Democrats, who more often use their conventions to heal lingering wounds from the primaries.
Again and again, speakers pointed to their party as one that "looks like America." As House Speaker Thomas S. Foley put it, "We can be proud that this convention looks like our country, not like a country club."
Mr. Clinton set the tone on CNN last night by describing himself and Senator Al Gore, his running mate, as "two people who have tried to immerse themselves in the kind of changes we have to make" to restore the nation's economic edge.
Still, underscoring the voter-friendly, Middle American image they seek, he added, "There is a little bit of Bubba in both of us, and I don't think that's all bad."
The Brown forces, however, refused to be scripted. When the convention rules were adopted by a voice vote, overriding the Brown delegates' attempts to debate reforms for the Democratic Party, the Brown camp erupted with shouts of "No, no, no, no." They waved banners that said, "Unity not uniformity" and "Let Jerry Speak."
 
Few Worries for Clinton
 Still, Mr. Clinton had the equanimity of a man backed by more than 2,700 of the 4,288 voting delegates, and who by the fall of the gavel yesterday had won the endorsement of all his rivals except former Governor Brown. Moreover, unlike Michael S. Dukakis in 1988, Mr. Clinton was not confronted with a dedicated contingent of more than 1,000 Jesse Jackson delegates.
Mr. Jackson remained aggrieved, but without the power inside the con vention hall he had in 1984 and 1988.
Jerry Brown, his suit wrinkled from a night spent in a homeless shelter, remained a holdout in all the determined harmony yesterday and seemed to revel in the role. "The only story is, 'Can we make some real change out there at the convention?' " he said.
Conversations continued between Mr. Brown and top party leaders, although the latter seemed increasingly exasperated. "You'll have to get the status of Jerry Brown from Jerry Brown," said Ronald Brown at one point yesterday.
Party leaders have held that Mr. Brown will not be given a speaking slot until he endorses Mr. Clinton; Mr. Brown could still address the convention, however, by giving his own nominating speech.
 
Middle Ground in Platform
 There were other tensions amid the hoopla. Gov. Robert P. Casey of Pennsylvania held a news conference to say he wanted a chance to speak against the party's strong platform plank on abortion rights. Kate Michelman, head of the National Abortion Rights Action League, countered, "Governor Casey is out of touch with the views of his delegation, Pennsylvania and America."
Still, by normal Democratic standards, this was a fairly peaceable crew.
Nowhere was Mr. Clinton's control more apparent than in the platform the delegates will consider Tuesday night, which represents the presumed nominee's careful search for a politically appealing middle ground.
It calls for more education, training and child care for those on welfare, for example, but then asserts that all the able-bodied must go to work. It declares that the party rejects "both the do-nothing government of the last 12 years and the big government theory that says we can hamstring business and tax and spend our way to prosperity." It calls for a "third way."
Mr. Clinton was keeping a limited public schedule, although he did go to a community meeting at the Henry Street Settlement on the Lower East Side, speaking against a backdrop of black teenagers, Hasidic rabbis, Asian women and Hispanic social workers. If the message of Democratic inclusive ness wasn't obvious, Mr. Clinton made it so. He promised to "give you anadministration that looks like America," adding, "I mean, look at this crowd today: This is America."

HEADLINE: E.P.A. Is Planning Strict New Testing Of Auto Emissions

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 13

 BODY:
Responding to a court order, the Bush Administration today issued a rule that will require about one-third of the nation's 180 million cars and light trucks to undergo tougher and more expensive emissions tests.
The rule, required under the 1990 Clean Air Act, is intended to clear urban skies of smog and other pollutants. Under the Environmental Protection Agency's proposal, approved by the White House, 55 urban areas nationwide that now have no auto emissions tests will be required to start them by next July. The rule is not expected to be significantly changed when it becomes final after a 90-day comment period expires in November.
 
Smog Reduction Expected
 
 The rule also calls for much more rigorous testing than now exists in cities with the most serious air pollution. Under that requirement, 84 metropolitan regions, including the New York metropolitan area, much of New England, the Middle Atlantic States and California, will be required to install $150,000 treadmills with computer-aided diagnostic equipment so sensitive that millions of poorly maintained cars that now pass inspection are likely to fail and require repairs.
Once the new program is in operation, the Government says it will reduce smog by 30 percent in many cities and carbon monoxide pollution by more than half. Smog irritates the lungs, and carbon monoxide can interfere with blood circulation, particularly among children, the elderly and people with heart disease.
The new rule is the broadest and most stringent of any issued under the Clean Air Act of 1990. Many more rules are still to be written, including most of those that are expected to place burdens on industry. Most of those future regulations, including one to reduce toxic chemical emissions and other pollutants, are a year or more overdue. For now, because of the proposed rule issued today, the greatest burden for cleaning smog in the cities will fall on individual owners of cars and trucks.
On July 1, a Federal district judge in Brooklyn, acting in a case brought by New York State, ordered the Administration to issue the testing rule by today rather than next January, as the agency had planned.
William K. Reilly, the head of the environmental agency, explained today that the Clean Air Act directed the Government to insure that the entire nation, including citizens and industry, share the burden of cleaning the nation's skies.
But while environmentalists praised the Administration's new testing requirements today, they also noted that the rules issued so far followed what they called an Administration pattern of bowing to big business.
The agency said today that 15 percent of the nation's cars produce 75 percent of auto emission problems. Many of those cars are likely to fail the new tests.
In the 80 or so metropolitan regions with the dirtiest air, the new rule would require testing cars and trucks with systems that have been tested by the E.P.A. in Baltimore, Hammond, Ind., and Phoenix, agency officials said. In those tests cars will be put on treadmills, called dynamometers, and their exhaust and fuel systems checked for excess pollutants while they are accelerating, running at speed and slowing down. Such testing systems can cost $150,000 or more, and agency officials said they did not know how many machines would be needed to service the more than 60 million cars in the 80 dirtiest regions.
When a vehicle fails the test, its owner will be required to pay for repairs that the E.P.A. estimated could cost $25 to $450. If a driver shows proof that he paid at least $450 for repairs after failing the test, the requirements will automatically be waived even if the car still does not pass. But the car would be expected to meet the standards in its next required test, unless the owner again spends at least $450.
The new requirements imposed on car owners come just two weeks after the Administration relaxed standards for 34,000 manufacturing, refining and chemical plants that emit the same pollutants as automobiles and trucks. Under that rule, issued June 25, manufacturers will be able to pour tens of millions of additional pounds of carbon monoxide, nitrogen oxide and volatile organic compounds into the atmosphere just by asking states for permission to do so. The public will not be given a chance to comment on that rule.
Both rules were approved by the President's Council on Competitiveness, a Cabinet group headed by Vice President Dan Quayle. When asked today whether the two rules were contradictory, William G. Rosenberg, the agency's Assistant Administrator for Air and Radiation, said, "I don't see a contradiction."
Of the rule for manufacturers, he said, "There was an effort to balance economic concerns and the environmental progress." He added, "In that case the White House made a decision that the procedures to require a public hearing would be too burdensome."
Mr. Rosenberg said the Administration saw today's rule as a way for the nation to see pollution reduced "at low cost and have the most stringent rules available."
The E.P.A. plan does not stipulate who will pay for the new testing equipment; the agency said it was giving states the authority to decide how to operate the program. The Department of Transporation said it would make grants available to help put the program into effect.
The E.P.A. also said it would encourage states to build centralized testing stations to prevent the sort of fraud that has plagued some testing programs now being run in private service stations. With few exceptions, the agency rule will require that testing stations or private companies conducting the tests not be allowed to make the repairs.
Automobile and oil industry officials not surprisingly expressed support for the new rule today. Reducing emissions of toxic chemicals from automobiles is likely ease the pressure on the manufacturers for additional reductions.
But the Natural Resources Defense Council, a national environmental group based in New York, was critical of the Administration's action. So wasRepresentative Henry A. Waxman, a California Democrat who was a principal author of the Clean Air Act.
Deborah A. Sheiman, a resource specialist for the environmental group, pointed out that the Clean Air Act directed that advanced diagnostic systems be installed in the most polluted cities by Nov. 15, 1992. The Administration's program will not begin operation until July 1, 1994, and will not be fully effective until 1998, the environmental agency has said.
Mr. Waxman said: "E.P.A.'s new rule to assure that autos are correctly inspected is a step forward. Unfortunately, when it comes to vitally important rules that apply not to consumers, but to big polluters like auto makers and oil companies, the Administration has consistently failed to follow the new clean-air law."
The testing rule is one of three provisions designed to reduce urban smog, half of which is caused by emissions from cars and trucks. The first provision, written into the law by Congress, directed auto makers to begin building cleaner vehicles by 1994.
The second provision, announced last year by the Administration, was a proposal for refiners to produce new gasolines with higher concentrations of oxygen that would evaporate much less easily and burn more cleanly. The Administration has not yet issued the rule on reformulated gasoline as a final measure.
Today, the environmental agency said that reducing emissions of nitrogen oxide, carbon monoxide and volatile organic compounds in cars was much cheaper than gaining the same reductions from factory smokestacks.

PUB-DATE: July 14, 1992

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 4; National Desk; The Convention

LENGTH: 1193 words

HEADLINE: UNDER THE BIG TOP -- NEWS ANALYSIS;
Savoring July's Euphoria

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr.

 BODY:
Sometime in the last three or four weeks, a lot of Democrats changed their minds. They stopped going through the motions, stopped thinking about defeat while they talked about victory, and allowed themselves to believe that they actually had a chance to win the Presidency with Bill Clinton.
"The planets are coming into alignment," said Vernon Jordan, a big-time Washington lawyer. 
 "Al Gore will wear very well," said Peter Hart, a Democratic poll taker. "He's a candidate for October as well as July."
"The Reagan Democrats in my district have started to come around," reported Representative John D. Dingell of Michigan.
"Am I wrong, or is there a new jolt of energy around here?" asked Richard Holbrooke, a State Department official in the Carter Administration, now on Wall Street.
Robert A. Farmer, a prodigious fund-raiser, added, "I'm finding it easier to persuade people to open their books and write big checks."
And so it went, from brunch on Sunday to nightcap yesterday, as the Democrats, giddy as a clutch of debutantes, revved themselves up for their quadrennial convention. They liked what they saw on television of their man speaking in Tennessee, and they liked what little they saw of him in person in New York. "More relaxed," they concluded. "Not so defensive. Upbeat."
 
Euphoria, for Now
 But the sense of euphoria was more than a little fragile, especially among those who have been to these shindigs before. The sharp sting of 1988 is still there. The statistic on everyone's mind is Michael S. Dukakis's 17-point lead in July that turned into an 8-point deficit in November.
More than anything, the Democrats worry about the Republicans reviving the charges about his private life that plagued Mr. Clinton in New Hampshire and across the country, pushing his six-point plans and four-point programs into the background.
For the moment, the White House and the Republican National Committee are concentrating on attacking Ross Perot, apparently in the belief that cutting him down to size will help President Bush. The Democrats think so, too, so they would rather keep him healthy for awhile. A top Clinton strategist predicted, "You'll barely hear Perot's name this week."
James Squires, Mr. Perot's communications director, said succinctly: "The Democrats benefited when Bush beat up Perot. Bush would benefit if they beat up Perot.'
Ronald H. Brown, the Democratic chairman, was equally blunt: "The way this campaign is shaping up, we like. We've got George Bush and Ross Perot decapitating each other." In particular, Mr. Brown and his aides think Mr. Perot helps to put some Southern states within Mr. Clinton's reach by cutting deeply into what would otherwise be support for the President.
But many of the delegates and kibitzers here feel that the Republicans will eventually go after Mr. Clinton and probably his running mate, too.
"I wonder whether Clinton is ready for them," said Tony Coelho, the former majority whip in the House of Representatives. "He needs to be telling people, 'This is what the Republicans are going to do, this is what they're going to say.' Then when they open up on him, he can go the country and say, 'You see, I told you they'd do that to me, and it's all lies.'
"It's just basic politics. You have to inoculate yourself."
 
Controlling the Tempo
 Paul Kirk, a former Democratic chairman from Massachusetts who is closely identified with the Kennedy family, offered a similar thought.
"If Bush has nothing to say about the future, they'll go negative," he said. It may be that the electorate is so upset that it does not pay any attention, he went on, "but he needs to be ready to respond anyway, or he'll lose control of the rhythm and the direction of the campaign. He'll be talking about their attacks and their issues on their schedule. That's fatal."
On the other hand, a number of Democrats are daring to cast Mr. Clinton in the Woodrow Wilson role in what they see as a rerun of the 1912 campaign. That year, an incumbent Republican President, William Howard Taft, fought a grudge match with a third-party candidate, Theodore Roosevelt, allowing Wilson, the Democrat, to sneak into office with 42 percent.
 
No Lack of Stamina
 During the primary campaign, Mr. Clinton was rocked back on his heels by a series of charges that lasted for weeks. Many gave him up for dead, but he survived, and he eventually prospered. If the presumptive nominee showed anything this year, he showed a rare sort of political stamina.
Now, to hear people chattering in the salons and the corridors, what's needed is something more than that. They want a little inspiration.
Tapes of past conventions were shown on the C-Span cable network over the weekend, reminding a lot of Democrats at this convention of the oratorical splendors of their party's past, like Robert F. Kennedy's speech about his slain brother in Atlantic City in 1964 and Hubert H. Humphrey's call to arms in Chicago four years later.
Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey, one of last night's keynote speakers, reached all the way back to the 1930's. He sounded like Franklin D. Roosevelt attacking Herbert Hoover as he scornfully opened with an assault on the Republicans' record since 1980:
"For 12 years, I've heard our leaders say, 'Nothing can be done.' People are angry, and so am I."
Gov. Zell Miller of Georgia was the night's main exception to the "hands off Perot" rule. After savaging Mr. Bush at length in his keynote speech, Mr. Miller said, "So much for the millionaire, now on to the billionaire," and delivered a shorter indictment of Mr. Perot.
Senator Paul Simon of Illinois saw his party's challenge this way: "Bush lacks force and conviction, and the country senses it, but that's not enough. The big question is, can Clinton show, day after day, that he has what Bush lacks? Can he make himself credible in this role? It's not easy. Dukakis never managed it."
A number of party leaders hope that Mr. Clinton will emphasize his economic plan, which is considerably more detailed than anything Mr. Bush or Mr. Perot has put forward. The details are not so important, one state chairman said, "as the idea that he has a plan, and it has details."
From former Vice President Walter F. Mondale, who knows a little about convention bounces himself, there was not even a hint of over-optimism.
"I don't think we're there yet," he said. "Clinton has had a spectacular month -- good economic package, terrific Vice-Presidential selection and every sign that we're heading for an excellent convention.
"But we have a lot of work to do in the suburbs. They've turned us off for the better part of 30 years, they've gone to Nixon, they've gone to Reagan, they've gone to Bush. That's got to change if we're going to win, and the only way it'll change is if we can convince people that we're a Presidential party with a ticket of Presidential caliber they can trust."
In other words, Mr. Mondale seemed to be saying, the Democrats have to trump what Mr. Bush himself has been describing as his principal electoral assets: his and his party's experience in the Oval Office.

PUB-DATE: July 14, 1992

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1224 words

HEADLINE: U.S. Says Mexico Will Allow New Foreign Role in Finance

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 13

 BODY:
As part of a push to complete a free trade agreement with Mexico and Canada within several weeks, the Bush Administration has struck a deal with Mexico to open up the banking, insurance and securities industries there to American and Canadian companies, Administration and industry officials said today.
President Bush and President Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico are scheduled to discuss the overall trade agreement during an hourlong meeting on Tuesday in San Diego before the All-Star baseball game, Administration officials said. 
 The two leaders are expected to reiterate their political commitment to signing a pact as soon as possible, but they are not expected to settle specific differences on trade in energy, government procurement, agriculture, automobiles and tariff reductions, the officials said.
Except for Citibank, which got a toehold in Mexico in 1929, foreign banks are now almost entirely barred from doing business in Mexico. Insurance companies and securities firms are limited to minority stakes in joint ventures with Mexican businesses. The deal would gradually eliminate these restrictions by Jan. 1, 2000, and would allow United States banks to own insurance and securities firms in Mexico. The banks are mostly banned from these industries at home.
 
Sides Were Far Apart
 Mexico had initially wanted to phase out only some of the restrictions, and over 20 or 30 years; American financial services companies had wanted all limits removed in one year.
The compromise represents a decision by the Mexican Government that the country needs a modern financial system for its industry to be competitive in world markets, a Mexican official said. But it also makes a nod to the concerns of Mexican leftists suspicious of United States influence on their economy, because the Mexican Government would be able to impose a three-year moratorium on foreign investment if American and Canadian businesses acquire large market shares between the years 2000 and 2004.
Resolution of the financial services issue is a big step forward for the talks, which had stagnated after heavy activity last winter and spring, when differences were settled on issues like environmental protections and cross-border legal disputes. Four days of secret talks in Washington that ended on Saturday produced little headway on the remaining issues.
Of the 22 issue groups created to negotiate the free trade agreement, a dozen, including the one for financial services, have not yet produced their final legal texts.
The timetable for the deal assumes that a free-trade agreement is signed and approved by early next year, and would be postponed slightly if that schedule is missed. The deal has won quiet approval from Wall Street and commercial banks, and their lobbying could help in winning assent in Congress.
The remaining issues are among the most politically sensitive, and could prove time-consuming to resolve. For example, negotiators are arguing this summer over how fast Mexican state-owned companies will move to buy steel beams and industrial boilers from foreign capital goods companies and hire foreign construction and oil drilling companies.
 
Strength Underestimated
 The state-owned companies have traditionally reserved these contracts for politically powerful industries at home, and have been reluctant to issue them to foreigners. American and Mexican negotiators had underestimated the strength of their opposition and both sides have dug in their heels.
The White House is also still trying to figure out the politics of reaching a free trade agreement in an election year. Some Administration and campaign officials are promoting the deal on the ground that it would help the President in border states and with Hispanic voters nationwide, particularly when both the Democratic party and Ross Perot are pursuing Southern voters.
These officials want a deal before the Republican National Convention in mid-August, campaign officials say. But other influential Republicans contend that a free trade deal could cost the President vital support in Rust Belt states where workers fear the loss of factories and jobs to low-wage competition from Mexico.
"It is the blue-collar swing votes that are a big target for the Republicans this year, and we are not doing well with them this year," a Republican strategist said.
No consensus exists on the issue, and Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative, has said repeatedly that she will not hurry an agreement or set deadlines for negotiators.
 
Reports Being Prepared
 Yet in recent weeks her office has quietly asked several of its private-sector advisory groups to begin preparing formal written reports on the draft texts of the agreement. Under section 135 of the 1974 Trade Act, these reports must be prepared before a trade agreement is signed.
The Administration has reached an early deal on one critical Rust Belt issue, the assembly of cars in Mexico by Japanese and European companies so as to avoid United States tariffs and possible future import restrictions. Negotiators have tentatively agreed that to qualify for duty-free treatment under the free trade agreement, cars will have to include a higher percentage of North American-made parts than under the 1988 free trade agreement between the United States and Canada.
But the United States and Mexico are still negotiating how to phase out Mexico's byzantine system of requiring a rough balance in imports and exports of cars and car parts. The current Mexican system uses a complex scoring that penalizes the import of fully assembled cars, and trade negotiators have been unable to figure out how to change this system gradually.
The broad outlines of the deal on financial services were actually struck at the end of June, but were not publicly disclosed and all of the documents were classified. Negotiators have been writing the legal text of the deal since then, and are still doing so.
Kathleen A. Lydon, a spokeswoman for Mrs. Hills, declined to comment on the deal. "Nothing's agreed until everything's agreed," she said, repeating the Administration's standard position on the negotiations.
 
Benefits Not Known
 The financial benefit to American financial services companies on the deal is hard to predict. "You have no way of knowing -- you have another stream of revenue," an industry official said.
While Canada and Mexico have reached a similar arrangement on financial services, negotiations continue over Canadian requests for partial exemptions from the United States laws that limit interstate banking and the sale of insurance and shares by banks.
The deal between the United States and Mexico on financial services would, soon after Congressional approval, allow American banks to own up to 8 percent of the capital in the Mexican banking system. American securities companies would be authorized to own 10 percent of the capital of the Mexican brokerage and investment banking industry.
The agreement would also impose initial capital limits on the subsidiaries of American investment banks that would prevent them at first from handling very large deals by themselves. These company limits would slowly rise through the rest of the century and be eliminated on Jan. 1, 2000, a financial services industry official said.

PUB-DATE: July 14, 1992

SECTION: Section A; Page 12; Column 1; National Desk; The Convention

LENGTH: 1895 words

HEADLINE: IN THEIR OWN WORDS;
Excerpts From Addresses by Keynote Speakers at Democratic Convention

 BODY:

Bill Bradley
Senator From New Jersey
People are angry, and so am I.
For 12 years, I've seen kids kill kids in our cities and people sleep in the streets. 
 For 12 years, I've watched workers lose their jobs and government yield again and again to the special interests.
For 12 years, I've heard our leaders say, "Everything's just fine."
For too long, American leadership has waffled and wiggled and wavered.

 	 	 		. . .	 	When we look back at the last 12 years, one pattern becomes very clear: the collapse of standards. Another bank that fails; another deficit ignored; another high school graduate who can't read; another executive who bails out of a failing company with a golden parachute; another politician who lies; another politician who lies a little better; another Supreme Court Justice who's not the best we could have; another male office holder who just doesn't get it.
The evidence of this Administration's willingness to inflame the wounds that it should heal is everywhere. And the spectacle of social crises that can be seen right through the windows of the White House does not seem to trouble our leaders' sleep. They lead the most idealistic nation in history, but they are themselves without idealism. Fear, division, and the death of hope: these are the fruits of Republican rule.
Yes, our Democratic Party comes to New York with a purpose, but it's not just to win. It's to win for a reason. We come to New York to give American men and women control over their lives again. We come to New York, in the words of the great poet Langston Hughes, to "let America be America again. Let it be the dream it used to be."
There have always been two Americas, the flawed one we live in day by day and the better one we dream of when our spirits soar. For the slave who was someone out there's great great-grandparent, the dream was the promise of freedom of the North Star's beacon. For the computer operator in Trenton, N.J., or the meat packer in Omaha, Neb., listening right now warily to what we Democrats are saying this evening, the dream is his vote, the faith her vote counts, the hope her vote, well cast, can help make a better America.
For 10 years, I played basketball for the New York Knicks in this building.
The guys on the team came from a variety of places, a variety of backgrounds. We respected each other, and we were winners. We gave up our own personal agendas so the team could succeed and win. The idea of giving up something small for yourself to gain something big for all of us is not new, but putting that ancient idea into practice is the central necessity of our new age. Giving up the desire for more of everything now is the key to having more of something better in our future.

 	 	 		. . .	 	All of us can determine what America will become. Diversity is our strength, not our weakness. It offers opportunity for world leadership that is deeper than the swagger of military might or the pride of material wealth. It implies something unique and untapped. If a new woman or a new man can be formed out of the ashes of the 20th century, with all its wars and hatreds, it will be done here in America.
At another time in our history, Martin Luther King Jr. wrote from his jail cell in Birmingham, "We will have to repent in this generation not merely for the vitriolic words and actions of bad people, but for the silence of good people."
The silence of good people. Isn't that our challenge as a party and a nation -- to reach out to our fellow Americans and mobilize the good people of all races for action, action that will stop the random violence in our cities, rebuild economic opportunity and jobs for all, and provide the moral leadership worthy of our ideals? "Let America be America again. Let it be the dream it used to be."
 
Zell Miller
Governor of Georgia
I know what Dan Quayle means when he says it's best for children to have two parents.
You bet it is!
And it would be nice for them to have trust funds, too.
We can't all be born rich and handsome and lucky . . . and that's why we have a Democratic Party.
My family would still be isolated and destitute if we had not had F.D.R.'s Democratic brand of government.
I made it because Franklin Delano Roosevelt energized this nation.
I made it because Harry Truman fought for working families like mine.
I made it because John Kennedy's rising tide lifted even our tiny boat.
I made it because Lyndon Johnson showed America that people who were born poor didn't have to die poor.
And I made it because a man with whom I served in the Georgia Senate -- a man named Jimmy Carter -- brought honesty and decency and integrity to public service.
But what of the kids of today?
Who fights for the child of a single mother today? Because without a government that is on their side, those children have no hope. And when a child has no hope, a nation has no future.
I am a Democrat because we are the party of hope.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Robbed of hope, robbed of hope, the voices of anger rise up from working Americans, who are tired of paying more in taxes, getting less in services.
And George Bush doesn't get it?
Americans cannot understand why the rich can buy the best health care in the world, but all the rest of us get is rising costs and cuts in health coverage, or no health insurance at all.
And George Bush doesn't get it?
Americans cannot walk our streets in safety, because our "tough-on-crime" President has waged a phony war on drugs, posing for pictures while cutting police, prosecutors and prisons.
And George Bush doesn't get it?
Americans have seen plants closed down, jobs shipped overseas and our hopes fade away as our economic position collapses right before our very eyes.
And George Bush does not get it!
Four years ago, Mr. Bush told us he was a quiet man, who hears the voices of quiet people.
Today, we know the truth: George Bush is a timid man who hears only the voices of caution and the status quo.
Let's face facts: George Bush just doesn't get it.
He doesn't see it; he doesn't feel it, and he's done nothing about it.
That's why we cannot afford four more years.
If the "education President" gets another term, even our kids won't be able to spell potato.
If the "law and order President" gets another term the criminals will run wild, because our commander-in-chief talks like Dirty Harry, but acts like Barney Fife.
If the "environmental President" gets another term, the fish he catches off Kennebunkport will have three eyes.
And folks, after January, George Bush is going to have plenty of time to go fishing.
So much for the millionaire.
But we've still got ourselves a billionaire -- a billionaire!
He says, he says he's an outsider who will shake up the system in Washington.
But as far back as 1974 he was lobbying Congress for tax breaks. He tried to turn $55,000 in contributions into a special $15 million tax loophole that was tailor-made for him.
Sounds to me like instead of shaking the system up, Mr. Perot's been shaking it down.
Ross, Ross says he'll clean out the barn, but he's been knee deep in it for years.
If Ross Perot is an outsider, if he is an outsider, folks, I'm from Brooklyn.
Mr. Perot's giving us salesmanship, not leadership. And we're not buying it.
 
Barbara Jordan
Former Representative From Texas
Change: from what to what?
Why not change from a party with a reputation of tax and spend to one with a reputation of investment and growth. A growth economy is a must.
We can grow the economy and sustain and improve environment at the same time. When the economy is growing and we are taking care of our air and soil and water , we all prosper. And we can do all of that.
When I say something like that, I certainly do not mean the thinly disguised racism and elitism which is some kind of trickle-down economics. I'm taking about an economy where a young black woman or a young black man born in the Fifth Ward in Houston -- my town -- or South Central Los Angeles, or a young person in the colonias of the lower Rio Grande Valley, I'm talking about an economy where those persons can go to a public school, learn the skills that will enable her or him to prosper. We must have an economy that does not force that migrant worker's child to miss school for a full day so that she can work at less, at less than the minimum wage and, doing that, the family can still only afford one meal a day. That is the moral bankruptcy of trickle-down economics. Change, change, change. We can change the direction of America's economic engine and become competitive again. The American dream is not dead.
It is not dead. It is gasping for breath but it is not dead.
We can applaud that statement and know that there is no time to waste because the American dream is slipping away from too many people. It is slipping away from too many black and brown mothers and their children; the American dream is slipping away from the homeless of every color, of every sex; it's slipping away from those immigrants living in communities without water and sewage systems. The American dream is slipping away from those persons who have jobs, jobs which no longer will pay the benefits which will enable them to live and thrive because American seems to be better at building war equipment to sit in warehouses and rot than in building decent housing. It's slipping away, it's slipping away from those workers who are on indefinite layoffs while their chief executive officers are taking home bonuses which equal than the worker will ever make in 10 or 20 or 30 years.

 	 	 		. . .	 	We must frankly acknowledge our complicity in the creation of the unconscionable budget deficits, acknowledge our complicity and recognize, painful though it may be, that in order to seriously address the budget deficits, we must address the question of entitlements, also. That's not easy, but we have to do it. We have to do it, because the idea of justice between generations, that idea mandates that the baby boomers -- that's our ticket -- the baby boomers and their progeny are entitled to to a secure future. They are. However, however, if we are going to ask those who receive benefits to sacrifice, there must be equity in sacrifice. Equity in sacrifice. That idea says that we will sacrifice for growth, but that everybody must join in the sacrifice, not just a few. Equity in sacrifice means that all will sacrifice equally, equally, equally. That is, that is the person who is retired on a fixed income, the day laborer, the corporate executive, the college professor, the Member of Congress -- all must sacrifice for equity.

 	 	 		. . .	 	I close my remarks by quoting from Franklin Roosevelt's inaugural address, which he made in 1933. Franklin Roosevelt made that address to a people longing for change from the darkness and despair of the Great Depression. And this is what Roosevelt said: "In every dark hour of our national life a leadership of frankness and vigor has met with that understanding and support of the people themselves which is essential to victory." Given, given the ingredients of today's national environment, maybe, maybe -- just maybe, we Americans are poised for a second "Rendezvous with Destiny."

GRAPHIC: Photos of Bill Bradley, Zell Miller, Barbara Jordan. (Don Hogan Charles/The New York Times)
