SECTION: Section A; Page 4; Column 3; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1097 words

HEADLINE: Tokyo Journal;
Shoguns' Foe Takes a Page From Past (and Perot)

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, July 13

 BODY:
If Japanese history had taken a different turn more than a century ago, Morihiro Hosokawa, the scion of a family of feudal warlords who were always staving off more powerful shoguns in the capital, would probably be ruling over a good part of the country today.
Instead, Mr. Hosokawa is the newest and most visible political challenger in Japan in years, reveling in his role as an outspoken defector from the governing Liberal Democratic Party. 
 In the campaign that officially began on Wednesday for control of the upper house of Parliament, he has emerged as the leader of a new party with a popular theme: Tokyo wields far too much power over the rest of the country, and the time has come once again to diminish the influence of modern-day shoguns in the capital.
"Everyone knows that we have a structural conspiracy in this country among politicians, bureaucrats and businessmen," Mr. Hosokawa said the other day. "Americans know it. Japanese know it." And, he argues in the platform of the Japan New Party, that conspiracy has created a political system that has "grown moribund and out of touch with the realities of the world."
 
Many Voters Are Dissatisfied
 Such critiques of Japan's highly centralized, crony-ridden system are hardly uncommon, but until now they have come chiefly from foreigners, including many Americans. Mr. Hosokawa is an insider's insider, not only a descendant of one of the families that ruled Japan's fiefs before the restoration of the Emperor in 1868, but a former Governor of Kumamoto, the area where his family once ruled. He is also a close friend of Noboru Takeshita, the former Prime Minister who leads the governing party's largest and most powerful faction.
As a result, his attacks on Japan's entrenched bureaucracy and the country's political machine have become the most notable feature of an election campaign that, like most here, is devoid of many big issues. But whether Mr. Hosokawa will successfully tap what polls show is an enormous reservoir of discontent with the governing party is unclear.
Though 30 to 40 percent of voters often say they are dissatisfied with the political scene in Japan, most are enormously wary of displacing the leaders who for nearly four decades presided over one of the world's most remarkable economic expansions.
By all accounts, the 54-year-old Mr. Hosokawa will not make much of a dent in the Liberal Democrats' lead on July 26. But even a modestly successful showing -- 5 to 8 of the 127 seats up for election -- would make the Japan New Party, as it is officially known in English, a force that the Liberal Democrats will have to reckon with.
In the last election, three years ago, the governing party lost control of the upper house for the first time in decades. Since then the country's most powerful leaders have been forced to negotiate with smaller parties to pass any major bill that is opposed by the Socialists and the Communists.
Mr. Hosokawa expresses admiration for Ross Perot, the undeclared Presidential candidate, and seems to be following his strategy of running as an outsider with insider credentials. On Friday he said he wanted to appear on call-in shows to get his views directly to the people, in the Perot style, but there are no call-in shows in Japan, and television networks are severely restricted in how they can report campaign news. (Candidates are forbidden from buying television time.)
Mr. Hosokawa asserts that he has been the subject of relentless harassment from the Liberal Democrats since he announced in May that he would form a new party. "The L.D.P.'s attitude is that if you are not L.D.P., you are not a human being," he said.
He asserts that the governing party has asked members of Keidanren, the leading organization of big businesses and the nation's most important political contributor, to starve the new party of money. One of his candidates, he says, Yoshio Terasawa, a former top executive of Nomura Securities, was threatened in Washington recently by "a messenger from the L.D.P" who insisted that he withdraw.
Liberal Democrats say there is no harassment. But if the governing party is worried, the reason may be that Mr. Hosokawa's theme of local autonomy strikes a particularly potent emotion these days, as people outside Tokyo grow resentful of how much control bureaucrats in the capital wield over the smallest details of their lives. The arrangement seemed necessary during Japan's postwar economic growth, when the bureaucracy plotted the course of the auto and computer chip industries, and rebuilt bombed-out cities.
What led to his decision to run, Mr. Hoosokawa says, was his conclusion that the often-repeated pledges of Japan to reform itself were largely empty. Serving on a high-level Government committee last year that was exploring ways to halt Japan's endless series of financial scandals, he watched as the governing party and the Finance Ministry forced the group to drop a recommendation that would create an independent Securities and Exchange Commission. Instead, they wanted to continue regulating the ministry's supervision of the industry. "It is like letting the thieves become the judge," Mr. Hosokawa said.
 
Businesses Are Unimpressed
 But the business sector, whose support Mr. Hosokawa needs the most, is unimpressed with his vows to clean the country up. Few believe Mr. Hosokawa's beliefs are as strong as his oratory. Few want to tinker with the political stability that single-party domination has brought.
"The fact is that in Japan, if you don't have the L.D.P. you don't have anything," said Katsunosuke Maeda, who was raised in Kumamoto and is now the chief executive of Toray, a major fiber manufacturer. "To create a new party requires certain skills. Looking at the candidates that he has put together, I am not sure they have those skills."
Mr. Hosokawa's candidates are mostly political novices: a television newscaster, a popular feminist, a much-quoted economic commentator. Polls show that initial voter enthusiasm has begun to slip.
As a result, the new party could fade as quickly as it has bloomed, becoming another of the minor political groups that live on the fringes of Japan's political system, forced to form alliances with the Liberal Democrats. That depends, Mr. Hosokawa says, largely "on whether the anger of the people will explode," something that he concedes has not happened since his ancestors vied to rule parts of the country.
"I am afraid," he said somewhat ruefully, "that the anger of the Japanese public is not so strong."

HEADLINE: THE OPPOSITION -- NEWS ANALYSIS;
Perot in Trouble
Internal Strife, Missed Opportunities And Missteps on Issues Stall a Drive

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, July 13

 BODY:
It started out so hopefully; a bantam unafraid to speak his mind, blowing in like a cool, clean wind from the prairie to cleanse government and the political process. But in the hot glare of the campaign, the insurgency of Ross Perot is dangerously close to unraveling.
In recent weeks, Hamilton Jordan, the co-chairman of the Perot for President Committee, has threatened to quit the campaign, frustrated because the independent-minded Texan has refused to heed his counsel. Then Mr. Perot severed his ties with Hal Riney & Partners, a widely respected advertising company, when his advisers were pushing the Texas billionaire to begin a campaign to define himself to voters. 
 Pushed by groups representing homosexuals, Mr. Perot reversed his opposition to appointing gay members of the Cabinet, making it seem that he could succumb to heat from pressure groups. But, he then fudged his position on whether he would lift the ban against homosexuals in the armed forces. Mr. Perot said theat while he was against discrimination, he would leave the final decision to his Secretary of Defense.
 
Missing an Opportunity
 And then Mr. Perot missed a golden opportunity to expand his appeal beyond the volunteer force working zealously to place him on the ballot. Rather than laying the groundwork for an effort to reach out to voters from minorities, Mr. Perot's speech on Saturday before the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People was marred by some ill-chosen words that left the impression that he lacked appreciation of black sensibilities.
"Last week was not a good week for us," said a campaign official who would speak only on the condition of not being named. "To have stories about gays and that he is insensitive toward minorities is not the way you want to leave things when you are going to be out of the public eye for a week because of the Democratic Convention."
Campaign officials are particularly worried about Mr. Perot's recent slide in the polls. As surveys show the Texan drifting down toward 25 percent, there is concern that he might reach the point where many of those seeking a change from President Bush will feel Mr. Perot is unelectable and abandon him wholesale.
Reports are swirling around Mr. Perot's campaign that the professional political consultants on his staff are increasingly frustrated over his unwillingness to take their advice.
 
Sticking to His Plan
 But as things have turned sour, Mr. Perot has stuck to his basic strategy of not being specific about issues, not using political advertising and addressing only rallies of his supporters as they submit peititions to place him on the ballot. Some of Mr. Peort's advisers feel an opportunity is being missed.
"It's like there is a wide receiver open down field, and you have a quarterback who keeps running the fullback up the middle," said the official with the campaign.
Perhaps no event more symbolizes fumbled opportunity than Mr. Perot's appearance before the N.A.A.C.P. Instead of rousing his audience with a stirring call for black economic development, which he believes in, Mr. Perot's speech was flatly delivered and devoid of specifics on issues of importance to blacks.
Worse, his remarks were sprinkled with references to "you people" and "your people," words that have traditionally offended many blacks, who feel that such terms unfairly lump all members of the race together and indicate a lack of appreciation for diversity among blacks.
 
Speech Leads to Apology
 And Mr. Perot's story of his father's giving a business card to black workers to protect them from being treated "rudely" by whites struck some in the crowd as paternalistic.
Mr. Perot, who writes his own speeches, later apologized for any unintended slight, saying in a telephone call to the Cable News Network that he "would never say anything to hurt another person, knowingly."
To be sure, the audience that Mr. Perot faced on Saturday was, no doubt, the toughest he had confronted since first expressing interest in seeking the Presidency. Of all groups, middle-aged and older blacks, who formed the backbone of the crowd and of the N.A.A.C.P., tend to be the most cool toward a Perot candidacy.
But the audience was never openly hostile, and, more importantly, his appearance gave Mr. Perot an opportunity to send a message to younger black professionals, who have in some polls exressed an interest in his insurgent movement. But much of Mr. Perot's message of economic development and rebuilding the inner cities was lost in the news reports that highlighted his verbal gaffes.
"It was a failed opportunity," said Milton Morris, vice president of the Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies, a research organization specializing in black-oriented issues. "He has had no direct contact with the black population thus far. This was his first opportunity, using about the best platform or stage he's going to have."
It was not the first time Mr. Perot's navigation of America's multicultural seas has been clumsy. When discussing aid by the United States and Japan to the former Soviet Union during a May 29 interview, Mr. Perot said: "You know the Japanese give money, and they say you have to buy Japanese products. We give money and say, 'rotsa ruck, fellow,' just buy whatever you want anywhere." This prompted a letter of protest to him from the Japanese-American Citizens League, complaining of "cheap, racial sterotypes."
But officials in the Perot campaign say it is not too late for things to turn around. The say that commercials should begin running soon after the Democratic Convention. They chalk up the mistakes to Mr. Perot's being a neophyte politician who is trying to change the system. But they also feel that to really change things, he must first win, and to do that, he must learn the traditional ropes.
"He initially thought this was going to be totally different," said the campaign official. "He was not going to play by the rules and was having great fun. As long as we were doing well in the polls, it didn't matter. But he's learning that if you're going to play the game, you're going to have to play by the rules."

HEADLINE: ISSUES AND INTERESTS -- ON THE SIDELINES;
Dukakis Views Clinton as G.O.P.'s Worst Nightmare

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, July 9

 BODY:
What is Michael S. Dukakis doing these days? "Mike Dukakis is growing tomatoes, of course," the 1988 Democratic Presidential candidate said, gently mocking his once well-chronicled penchant for gardening.
As Mr. Dukakis spoke, he was sitting in his cramped office in a converted industrial building at Northeastern University. With his opponent of four years ago, George Bush, in the White House, and the man who nominated him, Gov. Bill Clinton, ready to accept the Democratic mantle in New York, Mr. Dukakis is teaching political science at this working-class institution that is usually overshadowed by its neighbors, Harvard University and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. 
 Now 58 years old, the former Governor of Massachusetts still looks the same as he did in 1988. But now he shares two secretaries with 24 other professors. His book-lined study overlooks a parking lot on the edge of Roxbury, a poor and predominantly black section of Boston. And he has traded his dark suits for standard academic garb: rumpled chinos, sneakers and a tieless shirt.
 
Enthusiastic About Clinton
 But despite his rapid fall from grace -- he and his wife, Kitty, have only a ceremonial role at the Democratic National Convention -- Mr. Dukakis retains much of his characteristic optimism.
"Bill Clinton will be a terrific candidate," he said, adding that the Arkansas Governor will win the election in November over President Bush and Ross Perot.
Mr. Dukakis bases his assessment in part on his 15-year friendship with Mr. Clinton as a fellow Democratic Governor, a man who, like Mr. Dukakis, was defeated after his first term and engineered a comeback.
"Clinton has always been the Republicans' worst nightmare: a tough, smart, progressive Southerner," Mr. Dukakis said.
 
Sees Bush Foundering
 Mr. Dukakis does not hide the pleasure he takes in the President's predicament today. "Poor old Bush, he can't seem to come to grips with things," he said, speaking with as much bitterness as his carefully controlled temperament allows.
The last four years have been difficult for Mr. Dukakis. After his failed Presidential bid, he returned to Boston as Governor, only to watch his prized Massachusetts economy tumble, undercutting tax revenues and throwing the state's budget into chaos. By the time his term ended in 1991, Mr. Dukakis had become everyone's favorite whipping boy. He went as far away as he could get, first to Australia and then to Hawaii to teach.
In recent months, he has devoted much of his time to researching and writing about universal health care, an issue to which he devoted extensive effort as Governor. Having observed former President Jimmy Carter's political rehabilitation, Mr. Dukakis said, he has concluded that a defeated nominee should devote himself to one or two substantive issues.
Mrs. Dukakis, who struggled with alcoholism after her husband's defeat, has been taking a course on addiction counseling at the University of Massachusetts in Boston and is considering work with drug and alcohol addicts.
 
Behind-the-Scenes Role
 The Dukakises plan to arrive in New York on Wednesday for the final two days of the convention. Mr. Dukakis said that he and other former Presidential nominees would be recognized at some point, but that he would not make a speech.
He said that he talks with Mr. Clinton on the phone from time to time and that he has sent out warnings about moving fast to rebut negative campaigning. "The most effective way to deal with a negative campaign is to turn it into a character issue on the guy who is doing it," Mr. Dukakis said.
So when Vice President Dan Quayle or Mr. Bush begin to talk about family values, he said: "I'd stick it up their ears. I'd tell the American people what they know -- that family values are the security of having a good job or being able to take the kids to the doctor without wondering if you can pay for it."
But over all, Mr. Dukakis said, he has been chary about offering Mr. Clinton advice.
"Look, if I knew anything about this business, I'd be talking to you from the Oval Office," he said.

HEADLINE: Rhode Island Banker Is Indicted in '91 Crisis

 BODY:
Joseph Mollicone Jr., the bank president accused of triggering Rhode Island's banking crisis, was indicted yesterday on 47 counts of embezzlement, bank fraud and conspiracy.
The indictment, which charged Mr. Mollicone with embezzling $15.8 million from the bank he headed until he disappeared last Nov. 8, was the result of a 19-month state grand jury investigation. It clears the way for the state to bring its case against Mr. Mollicone to trial, said James E. O'Neil, the Attorney General of Rhode Island, in a telephone interview. 
 Mr. Mollicone could be sentenced up to 920 years in jail and fined $920,000 if he is found guilty of all 47 charges. He will be arraigned on July 22.

HEADLINE: Joyful Mood at Black Catholic Meeting

BYLINE: By PETER STEINFELS

 BODY:
More than 1,000 representatives of the nation's two million black Roman Catholics asserted their African roots last weekend in a meeting devoted to the needs of black families and to problems confronting young black men.
From the African drum rhythms at the Mass that opened the congress on Thursday night to the applause and amens that interrupted the major speeches over the weekend, a joyful mood marked the seventh National Black Catholic Congress in New Orleans, overcoming the grim realities of broken families, unemployment, poverty, drug abuse and teen-age homicide that the delegates discussed in workshops and caucuses. 
 Wilton D. Gregory, an auxiliary bishop in Chicago and one of the nation's 11 black Catholic bishops, said the black family was more than a formal topic at the congress. "What is being experienced here is the family spirit of the African-American community," he said. "It is like a big family reunion, with feelings of love, hope, disappointment, longing, shared frustrations."
The delegates endorsed a range of social programs and policy changes including increases in the minimum wage, universal health insurance, lifelong job training, updated standards for defining poverty and "Afrocentric" curriculums in both public and Catholic schools.
They also drew up a long list of proposals for parishes, dioceses and organizations to strengthen black families, offer leadership roles to black Catholics and help black adolescents by providing mentors.
And the delegates approved a last-minute proposal from black priests asking the group that organized the congress to conduct a study on establishing "an African-American rite," a step that might encompass everything from a distinctly African-American form of worship to a separate jurisdiction, under the Pope, of black American bishops, dioceses and parishes. Such a move would ultimately have to be approved by the Vatican, which recognizes 17 distinct rites within the church.
 
A Century's Pause
 Five national congresses of black Catholics were held from 1889 to 1894, but almost a century passed before the sixth one, held in Washington in 1987.
The first congresses were a major achievement for a small group of believers -- perhaps 200,000 people -- who saw Catholicism as a force for racial justice despite the segregation and neglect they experienced in a church preoccupied with a flood of European immigrants.
Today 1 out of every 25 American Catholics is black. Over 1,000 of the nation's 20,000 Catholic parishes have predominantly black congregations, and there are 11 black bishops. One measure of the group's growing significance was that all six American cardinals and 85 other bishops, almost one-third of the American hierarchy, attended the congress.
 
Changes in Five Years
 New emphases on African identity and on public policy distinguished the recent congress from the one five years ago, delegates said. "In five years, we went from being black to being African-American," one said.
Many of the speeches and workshops invoked the strengths of the African extended family and the spiritual dimension of African culture. References to the Ibo, Yoruba, Ashanti and other African peoples came more frequently than references to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. And even many of the white clergymen and lay Catholics who were observers at the meeting wore a bit of the striped African cloth known as kente.
As for the new attention paid to public policy matters, Joseph A. Francis, Auxiliary Bishop of Newark, said, "We realized you simply cannot look internally so much of the time."
But internal church concerns were not absent, as indicated by the call for exploring the possibility of a separate black American rite. Delegates, some of whom could remember when Catholic schools were segregated, when black parishioners in the South could not receive Communion until whites had done so and when there were no black Catholic bishops, hailed changes but also voiced continuing frustrations.
"The church isn't responsive to black needs," said Laura Mae Turner, a retired city worker from Syracuse. "There are many black people in our parish, but it is not much reflected in the liturgy. It is good to be among all my people here because when I go to church in Syracuse, I don't see myself reflected on the altar."
To attend the congress, delegates had to take part in extensive training and were required to pledge to work for two more years trying to put the group's recommendations to work in their local dioceses and parishes.
"We went home and floundered a bit" after the last congress, Bishop Francis said, although one development was the establishment of special offices dealing with black Catholic concerns in over 100 of the country's 197 dioceses.
Asked about the heavy emphasis on African identity at the congress, Bishop Gregory said: "I'm delighted. It bespeaks a maturity and a kind of shared journey that we are all involved in."
But he added that "every journey into the unknown has its own risks and perils" and said some debates were inevitable.
The bishop, who heads the committee on liturgy of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops, expressed reservations about a black American rite. "When people hear 'rite,' they think it only refers to forms of worship, but a rite is much more complex," he said, possibly involving its own language or code of church law.
Those calling for a new rite, he said, may be "proceeding on a very delicate question without understanding all the intricacies."

(Matt Anderson for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: ISSUES AND INTERESTS -- TWO VOICES;
Speaking as One in Search of a Constituency to Combat AIDS

BYLINE: By JEFFREY SCHMALZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, July 10

 BODY:
They are at once very similar and very different -- a well-to-do mother in her spacious home near the ocean, packing her 7-year-old son off to summer camp with a peck on the cheek; a gay environmental advocate, punctuating each sentence with "cool, that's cool" as he shouts into the phone in his cluttered, cramped downtown office here.
Together they will be the voice of AIDS on Tuesday night, the first people who are open about having the disease to address a national political convention. 
 "My daughter did not survive the Reagan Administration," said Elizabeth Glaser, whose daughter, Ariel, died of AIDS in 1988 at the age of 7. Both Mrs. Glaser and her son, Jake, are also infected with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, which she got in a blood transfusion and passed on to her children.
"I want people to understand that the life and death of my family hinges on who the next President is," she said. "It hinges on government leading the way, on more money for drug trials and research, for vaccine development."
Bob Hattoy, a gay environmentalist who will speak at the Democratic National Convention immediately before Mrs. Glaser, put it this way: "I want to say, 'Mr. President, your family, the family of America, has AIDS, and you're not doing anything about it. Because of that, people are dying, and it's your fault.' "
Those are tough words from people who at times seem tough and at other times wounded and scared. Occasionally, in separate chats, each seemed almost icy, talking about life and death matter-of-factly. Theirs is an AIDS world of resignation where, as the writer Paul Monette described it, the cup is neither half empty nor half full, just half. One minute they were impassioned fighters, the next reasoned lobbyists. Their emotions welled up from time to time, Mrs. Glaser asking for a tissue to wipe her eyes, Mr. Hattoy blurting out, "I think I will probably die of AIDS."
With her shorts, white sneakers, blond-gray hair and bouncy walk, Mrs. Glaser, at 44, looks the aging chearleader. She is by far the better known of the two speakers. She made AIDS a cause after the death of Ariel, for whom such potentially life-saving drugs as AZT were long denied because so little had been studied about children with AIDS.
Drawing on connections made through her husband, Paul Michael Glaser, a director and formerly Starsky of the "Starsky and Hutch" television series, she helped found the Pediatric AIDS Foundation, which has raised $13 million for research, much of it for the Ariel Project, which is searching for ways to block transmission of AIDS from a mother to her fetus. Ariel got the virus through breast milk, Jake in the womb.
 
The Words Inside Her
 But the mood in her living room in Santa Monica is of life, not death. Jake's teepee sticks up in the backyard. The family dog, Georgie, pokes about in the living room. Regardless of whether she was a speaker, Mrs. Glaser would be at the convention anyway, as a Clinton delegate. AIDS, she said, is merely a metaphor for Republican failures. She laughs when told that she gives a more passionate Clinton speech than Gov. Bill Clinton himself.
"I think it's because he's a Southerner, and I'm a New Yorker," said Mrs. Glaser, who grew up in Hewlett Harbor, L.I. She was chosen to speak after confronting Mr. Clinton's campaign chairman, Mickey Kantor, at a Los Angeles picnic, saying, "I have words inside me that I have to share."
Mrs. Glaser has never met the Arkansas Governor. Mr. Hattoy, on the other hand, is part of the Clinton political family. A longtime environmental advocate, he joined the campaign at the beginning of the year, traveling from primary to primary. It was during the primary campaign in Oregon that he noticed a lump under his arm. It turned out he had AIDS-related lymphoma.
 
He's Not Dead Yet
 Shortly afterward, Mr. Hattoy -- who seems younger than his 40 years, with a teen-ager's gangly look about him and a campy humor -- met with Mr. Clinton in Los Angeles. "We sat in his room and talked and got all weepy and teary," Mr. Hattoy said. "He said, 'What can we do for you?' I said, 'Don't treat me like I'm dead.' "
He continues to serve as an issues adviser, but was uncomfortable about speaking at the convention: "I said, 'I'm not sure I should do it; maybe it should be a black or a woman.' Bill said: 'Of course you should do it. You've got AIDS. You're close to Hillary and me.' My friends said: 'Do it. It's important a gay man do it.' So I'm doing it."
The issue of whether Mr. Hattoy and Mrs. Glaser represent the true face of AIDS is a touchy one.
"She's a celebrity, and he's a campaign worker," said Thomas B. Stoddard, a New York gay rights leader. "It's a false image of AIDS. It's a mistake not to have a person of color. These people are well-to-do with access to the best health care. The true nature of H.I.V. is the lack of basic health care that tens of thousands of individuals must confront by nature of poverty and other conditions."
Mrs. Glaser argued that she and Mr. Hattoy were as good a choice as any. "In some ways I'm with the haves and some with the have-nots," she said. "I have one foot in economic stability, a two-parent family, an ability to have support systems. But having all that did not save my daughter. And it's not going to save my son."
Implicit in the comments by the two speakers is a faith in medicine, a belief that with enough money and effort, AIDS can be cured or made manageable, like diabetes.
"I want to believe it's possible," Mrs. Glaser said. "I'm not asking for a guarantee that I will live. What is unacceptable is if people die because we didn't care enough to at least try."
The speeches are to begin around 8 or 8:30 P.M., but the networks are not scheduled to start live coverage until later. "None of what I dream about is going to happen as a result of my speech," Mr. Hattoy said. "George Bush will be fishing. Most of America will get up and get a beer. And I'll still have AIDS."

HEADLINE: After State Cutbacks, What One Theater Is Doing to Survive

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN

 BODY:
One morning last July, Miriam Colon, the diminutive, intense founding director of the Puerto Rican Traveling Theater, opened her mail and thought she would faint. A letter from Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said the state contribution to the bilingual theater Ms. Colon had nurtured for nearly a quarter of a century would be cut by $36,000.
"I went limp; I went numb; I went dizzy," said Ms. Colon, a former actress who supplements her vocabulary with emphatic gestures. "But soon my mind was racing a mile a minute trying to figure out how we're going to fill the void." 
 The void, she soon discovered, went even deeper. The country's economic slump was also affecting her corporate and private supporters, who were cutting their contributions, too. All told, the theater's $650,000 annual operating budget was coming up nearly $100,000 short.
 
Trading on Credibility
 After the shock sank in, Ms. Colon began to search for ways to replace the lost revenue. Eventually, she hit upon the idea of trading on the theater's credibility with Hispanic audiences for support from corporations hoping to do business with that growing segment of the population. It would not hurt a company that wanted to sell life insurance or toothpaste to the Hispanic residents of the New York area to become a visible supporter of the Puerto Rican Traveling Theater, said Ms. Colon, who was born in Puerto Rico. Whatever money the corporation spent in this way could be justified as advertising and promotion rather than as a donation, she said.
By April, these and other efforts had proved successful enough for Ms. Colon to open the theater's 25th anniversary season, with a production of "The Oxcart," Rene Marques's play about the misadventures of a family of rural Puerto Ricans who move to New York City: an unintended paradigm for what this theater itself had experienced. The production was wellreceived by critics and general audiences.
The company's second production, a new comedy with music by Eugene Rodriguez called "Mambo Louie and the Dancing Machine," is in rehearsal and is to open on July 22 at the company's theater, at 304 West 47th Street on the West Side of Manhattan.
 
Free on the Streets
 After a two-week run, "Mambo Louie," as with all Puerto Rican Traveling Theater productions, will be performed free on the streets of New York, in this case through August.
There is still a third production of the season to be financed, and Ms. Colon said the other day that she needed to raise about $75,000 before autumn for the company to complete its season. She also said her struggles to scare up money and the need to lay off valued staff members had made 1992 "the worst year of my life." Still, her success so far is an example of how arts organizations, staggered by the loss of government, corporate and private support during the last two years of recession, may yet find ways to survive.
In general, Ms. Colon said she learned two basic lessons. The first is that a dependence on government support is a snare and a delusion for arts organizations. "I'm not saying the government shouldn't support us," she said. "They should. We are just as entitled to that money as the people who build roads. But we must not count on it. Through no fault of our own, it can vanish."
The second lesson, she said, is about the need to forge links with the business world based on common interests, a challenge to which she has risen with extraordinary results.
 
'Never in Such Desperation'
 Soon after receiving Governor Cuomo's letter, Ms. Colon sat down with Philip Langer, the theater's development director, and leafed through the Foundation Directory, whose current volume lists the names and basic data on more than 5,000 charitable foundations in the United States. They selected a group of almost 200 institutions that might be persuaded to support the company, and Ms. Colon drafted an urgent appeal.
"We had solicited many of these foundations before," she said, "but never in such desperation and anguish."
Four percent of the recipients responded favorably, Mr. Langer said, including such new supporters as the Anheuser-Busch Companies, the Panasonic Company, the Prudential Foundation and the Bristol-Myers Squibb Company.
Anheuser-Busch not only contributed $1,000, but one of its executives, Luis Gonzalez, together with Joseph Wiscovitch, a public-relations agent who specializes in the Hispanic market, also secured the agreement of Raul Julia to give a performance of "Man of La Mancha" as a benefit for the Puerto Rican theater. Mr. Wiscovitch said he knew that Mr. Julia had appeared with Ms. Colon in a production of "The Oxcart" 25 years ago at the Greenwich Mews Theater in the West Village, and had been a friend and supporter of Ms. Colon ever since.
Anheuser-Busch bought 400 tickets for the performance on June 2 and helped sell them for $200 each. The theater raised about about $47,000 from the benefit, Ms. Colon said.
Response to the appeal was weak otherwise. On one hand, Con Edison, a previous sponsor, increased its grant to $7,500 from $5,000. But Citibank, also a longtime supporter, said it was overcommitted and would have to say no for now.
"The favorable responses didn't come in a rush," Ms. Colon said. "They trickled in, one at a time."
Ms. Colon also wrote a direct appeal to 35,000 current and past ticket buyers whose names had been collected over the years.
Mayor David N. Dinkins responded with a personal check for $1,000, but otherwise there was just a trickle of donations, from $10 to $150 each. All told, these added up to only $8,000.
Ms. Colon got bolder. Among other things, she began to visit Hispanic business leaders to plead her cause in person. She persuaded Dennis Rivera, the president of Local 1199 of the Drug, Hospital and Health Care Employees Union, which has a 45 percent Hispanic membership, to cover the cost of mailing 30,000 letters to announce the opening of the theater's 25th anniversary season. He also promised to hold a breakfast for Ms. Colon with a group of union leaders to discuss ways to interest union members in attending this theater.
Most beneficial was a luncheon on March 25 by the Avon Products Foundation at its executive dining room in mid-Manhattan. The object was to introduce Ms. Colon and her top staff members to representatives of a dozen major corporations seeking to gain access to the Hispanic market.
Speaking to representatives of Bristol-Myers Squibb, McGraw-Hill, Republic National Bank, New York National Bank and others, Ms. Colon said: "We have had a good association with this community for 25 years. We have educated their children, kept up their pride and their uniqueness and given the Puerto Rican and Hispanic people a positive image of themselves. You can share in that by becoming one of our sponsors."
The first result was a $15,000, three-year grant from Bristol-Myers Squibb. Next, Serafin Mariel, the president of the New York National Bank, which has its headquarters in Hunts Point, the Bronx, agreed to serve on a committee to review the theater's financial plan for the future. Ms. Colon said she and her staff members were continuing a round of visits to the executives they met at the Avon luncheon.
 
'Speaks From the Heart'
 "We support the Puerto Rican Traveling Theater as a way of investing in the community that has made us No. 1 in the Hispanic market," said Ralph Casanova, the manager of special markets for the Northeast region of Anheuser-Busch.
Mr. Wiscovitch said of Ms. Colon: "She's a great actor, but she speaks from the heart. She overwhelms people, and they can't say no."
As the Puerto Rican Traveling Theater prepares for its second production of the season, Ms. Colon said she was "cautiously optimistic but still nervous" about the company's status.
"The day I relax," she said, "is when we are out of debt and have a reserve."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Miriam Colon, who overcame financing cutbacks to open the 25th season of the Puerto Rican Traveling Theater. (Marilynn K. Yee/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Behind the Old Boxer's Dark Shades

BYLINE: By IRA BERKOW

 BODY:
IT was Monday morning, five days after the savage fight. The former champ was wearing dark glasses as he slid into the booth of the coffee shop in the Bronx, where he was born and raised and where, after traveling and boxing around the world for 23 years, sometimes followed by adoring crowds, he still lives, in a modest apartment.
When the companion he met at breakfast asked to see the left eye, the one that had absorbed such a beating, the former champ removed the shades. The eye was still a little closed and very much black and blue, looking like a terrible tattoo. 
 "The scars of a warrior," the fighter said, smiling somewhat.
This was Saoul Mamby, who held the world junior welterweight title for two and a half years, from 1980 to 1982, and who, at age 45, is the oldest active fighter in the world. One might have to qualify the word active, though, because he has lost six straight fights, including one last Wednesday, a unanimous six-round decision, in a preliminary to the World Television Champions II pay-per-view tournament. Mamby was beaten by one Charlie (White Lightning) Brown, a fighter who, at 27 -- Mamby referred to him as "the kid" -- is just 4 years older than Mamby's daughter, Yvette.
"I know I didn't look good," Mamby said. "But I only had three days to train. They called me up and said, 'Mamby, we need you to fight.' Well, I didn't want to get thrown out of the tournament, and so I fought."'
Once, Mamby was known as a great ring technician, someone with the beautiful skills of a boxing artist. "His reflexes are shot," one of the television promoters said. "He was a ghost of himself -- not even that."
After the fight, Mamby's trainer, Don Turner, told him he should hang up his gloves. So did Don Elbaum, a promoter of the fight. "But I can still fight given the right training," he said. "And I'd like to go out a winner. I'd like one more shot at a title. Look at George Foreman -- he's 44 -- and Larry Holmes -- he's 43. They've fought for titles."
He says he understands the risks. "You see a guy like Ali who's taken too many blows to the head, and it's tragic," said Mamby. "But I'm a boxer. I know how to avoid getting hit."
That wasn't the case last Wednesday, in a surreal, if not bizarre setting. Six live fights were held in the Supper Club, a restaurant and night club on West 47th Street in Manhattan. A boxing ring, illuminated by the bright TV lights, was set down amid the tables. While people punched each other and drew blood, the clientele watched and ate dinner. Those at ringside might not have been surprised to find a mouthpiece land in their salmon, or have their marinara sauce turn a brighter red.
"My God, when you're up this close you realize how vicious fighting is," said a patron. "When you watch it on television, it just looks like a dance."
"It's a brutal sport, but it's a brutal society," said Mamby. "People don't come to a fight to see nice boxing. They come to see someone knocked out. They come lusting for blood."
It had been a long night Wednesday night for Mamby, longer even than the six rounds, which, for an ex-champion, is a comedown from his usual 10 and 12-round bouts. He had spent five hours in the room there trying to get his money in cash, and not a check that would have to be deposited.
"The whole night was degrading," he said. "But this was really embarrassing." Not only, as he said, having to "scrounge" for the money, but the money itself: $1,500. It was a long, long way from his best purse, $370,000, when he outpointed Thomas Americo in Jakarta, Indonesia, in 1981 to retain his title.
Why does he keep fighting? To keep hearing the roar of the crowd? Or is it the money? "It's what I know, it's what I've done well," he said.
And the money? "There's a saying. 'If you have a million, you want another million.' I've made a million. But I got ripped off by a lot of people. When I won that $370,000, for instance, I kept only about $135,000."
Between fights in recent years he has worked as a cab driver and a chauffeur. "Right now," he said, "I'm like most of them out there. I'm unemployed."
In the next week or two, the New York State Athletic Commission will suspend Mamby. It has a rule that after six straight losses, there is an automatic suspension.
It is easy to be moralistic and say that boxing is disgusting and someone like Mamby should never fight again. Of course he shouldn't -- for his health, and for our sense of propriety. But in the end, the whole brutal business of boxing says less about Mamby than it does about the rest of us.

NEW YORK CITY
 
AN ENDORSEMENT OF PEROT DRAWS FIRE
Three days after endorsing Ross Perot for President, the Rev. Calvin O. Butts 3d, pastor of the Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem, has come under fire from some local black political leaders who expressed dismay over the minister's choice of candidate, following Mr. Perot's reference to blacks as "you people" in a speech last week. B3.
 
 A MAYORAL CONFIDANT WHO IS MUCH MORE
Wherever Mayor Dinkins goes, Arnie Segarra is never far behind. He is often seen whispering in the Mayor's ear, shepherding him through crowds, carrying his belongings or just standing in the background watching over the city's chief executive. Mr. Segarra is perhaps the Mayor's most trusted confidant. B3.
 
 WANTED: BILINGUAL GOVERNMENT WORKERS
As more and more immigrants from many different countries settle in New York City, city agencies are taking steps to prevent the Babel of languages filling their offices from paralyzing their work. They are hiring bilingual staff and interpreters, translating forms and pamphlets into a jumble of languages and teaching their employees to be more sensitive to people who do not speak English. B8.

 PAYING MORE FOR CLEANER CLAMS

PUB-DATE: July 14, 1992

SECTION: Section B; Page 3; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1383 words

HEADLINE: This Man Whispers in Dinkins's Ear (a Lot)

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
At first glance, they are a most unlikely pair: the proper, tennis-playing grandfather and the hip bachelor whose name often comes up in the gossip columns as he escorts famous actresses around town.
The grandfather is the Mayor, David N. Dinkins, and the sidekick is Arnaldo Segarra, a longtime friend whose constant attention to the Mayor has made him one of the most recognizable figures at City Hall. Although few people know his name or exactly what he does, Mr. Segarra is perhaps the Mayor's most trusted confidant. When the chips are down, it is Mr. Segarra whom the Mayor ultimately turns to for counsel and moral support, aides to Mr. Dinkins said. 
"A lot of people think that Arnie is a flunky, a toady or just another bodyguard, but he's so much more than that," said Betsy Gotbaum, the city's Parks Commissioner. "Arnie is the protector of the Mayor. He is both savvy and street smart. He steers the Mayor away from people who would do him wrong."
Wherever Mr. Dinkins goes, Mr. Segarra, or Arnie as he is better known, is never far behind. He is often seen whispering in the Mayor's ear, shepherding him through crowds, carrying his belongings, getting him a drink of water or just standing in the background watching over the city's chief executive.
 
'But What Do You Do?'
 So common is it to see Mr. Segarra with the Mayor on television or in newspaper photographs that many people mistake the tall, urbane Puerto Rican man for a bodyguard or top city official. "Who are you?" a woman asked Mr. Segarra at a recent event at the Waldorf-Astoria where Mr. Dinkins was speaking. "I always see you with the Mayor, but what do you do?"
Mr. Segarra's official title is director of the Mayor's advance team -- a $47,588-a-year job that largely involves scheduling the Mayor's public appearances and making sure the events run smoothly. But Mr. Segarra's true role is much more vital: while he does not have the rank or influence of, say, a deputy mayor, Mr. Segarra is the Mayor's security blanket.
Mr. Segarra accompanies the Mayor to about 90 percent of his scheduled events and it is his job to anticipate and resolve unforeseen problems that arise when the Mayor is in public. Either Mr. Segarra or his associate, Michael Gaspard, arrives at the event well in advance of the Mayor to survey the situation. If there is a protest at the event, for example, the advance team alerts the Mayor before he arrives.
The Mayor relies on Mr. Segarra, who has been involved in city politics since the late 1960's and appears to know everyone who is someone in New York society, to tell him what officials or dignitaries are in the audience and should be recognized, or who just got married or had a baby or a death in the family. He is constantly passing notes to the Mayor.
 
Condoms and Hecklers
 At a recent health-care fair in Brooklyn, AIDS advocates gave the Mayor some free condoms that they were distributing, and Mr. Dinkins immediately turned to Mr. Segarra, pinched his cheeks, and said, "Here Arnie, take care of these." Mr. Dinkins often refers angry hecklers to Mr. Segarra, who helps resolve their complaints.
And when things go awry, as they often do, the Mayor has been known to scream and yell at Mr. Segarra, even when the situation is not of his making, mayoral aides say. Still, Mr. Segarra remains fiercely loyal to Mr. Dinkins, never disclosing what he has seen and heard in the confidence of his boss.
"I am very fond of Arnie," Mr. Dinkins said. "We are as close as folks can get. He is a tremendous political asset to me because of his experience and contacts in all circles. But his biggest value is that he is totally trustworthy."
Sid Davidoff, a lobbyist and former aide to Mayor John V. Lindsay, said that every public official needed someone like Mr. Segarra to look out for them and take care of details. "Arnie has the type of ego that doesn't mind hanging up the Mayor's coat, but he also has the smarts to head off serious problems," he said.
 
A 'Vision for Society'
 Asked about his loyalty to the Mayor, Mr. Segarra speaks philosophically about the goals that tie the two together: "Long before Dave Dinkins wanted to be Mayor, he was standing up and fighting for the rights of the underprivileged. We have the same vision for society, and I see my role as doing whatever I can to see that vision become a reality."
Mr. Segarra and the Mayor first met in the early 1970's when Mr. Segarra was an aide to Mr. Lindsay and Mr. Dinkins was active in politics in Harlem.
"Because I'm in the background, I hear and see things that the Mayor does not," Mr. Segarra said. "I know who's done him in and who's tried to do him in and that includes people outside and inside this administration."
 
Dismissed From 2 Jobs
 Puzzling to some both inside and outside the administration, who admit they know little about Mr. Segarra, is why the Mayor puts so much trust in a mid-level aide who was dismissed from two political jobs in 1970.
Arthur J. Goldberg, the Democratic gubernatorial candidate, dismissed Mr. Segarra for being part of a crowd that heckled and threw eggs at Mr. Goldberg's opponent, Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller. While Mr. Segarra denied throwing eggs, he said the mostly Puerto Rican crowd was angry because the Governor had arrived in a chauffeured limousine in a rundown neighborhood.
That same year, Mr. Segarra lost his job with Mr. Lindsay when he publicly endorsed the Young Lords, a Puerto Rican community group that had taken over a church.
"I believed then, as I do now, that you have to stand up for what's right no matter what the consequences," Mr. Segarra said.
Though he began his political career as an outspoken advocate for Puerto Rican causes, Mr. Segarra has apparently not helped the Mayor to resolve his problems with Hispanic leaders, who have publicly criticized Mr. Dinkins as being insensitive to the needs of Hispanic residents.
Some of those Hispanic leaders said in interviews that while they believed the administration could do more to address their needs, they did not fault Mr. Segarra, who some praised as being politically astute.
"We understand that Arnie is the confidant of the Mayor, and we don't want to put him in a predicament by pushing our agenda with him," said Councilman Israel Ruiz of the Bronx. "That would be out of bounds. But if we really, desperately need to get a message to the Mayor, we believe that Arnie would at least deliver it."
Mr. Segarra, who played a major role in organizing the Mayor's trip to Puerto Rico and the Dominican Republic in May, said that while Hispanic issues were no longer his sole agenda, he often advised Mr. Dinkins on how to deal with Hispanic voters.
Mr. Segarra has gained a reputation as a man about town, with his name appearing in local gossip columns as a frequent escort of such movie stars as Jessica Lange, Shelley Hack and Victoria Abril. Mr. Segarra acknowledges that he has spent time with the actresses, but he dismisses the romantic implications of the gossip columns, saying that they are "just acquaintances."
"Besides if I was doing 1 percent of what they say I'm doing, I'd be in the hospital," he said.
 
From Gangs to Basketball
 Mr. Segarra, who is the son of factory workers, was raised in the Johnson housing projects in East Harlem, where he was a member of a local gang until he joined the Boys Club to play basketball. He became a basketball star in high school and attended two years of junior college before dropping out to work with a Harlem housing organization.
Aides to the Mayor said that Mr. Segarra was one of the few people, aside from the Mayor's wife, Joyce, with whom Mr. Dinkins feels totally comfortable and can be himself. The two men occasionally go to jazz clubs to relax, Mr. Segarra said, and the aide is often present at Dinkins family functions at Gracie Mansion, the Mayor's official residence.
"Arnie's greatest value to the Mayor is that he feels totally at ease with him and relaxed when he's around," said Sally Hernandez-Pinero, the former Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development, who is now chairwoman of the New York Housing Authority. "Arnie is like an old-fashioned political aide: He believes his job is to do whatever the Mayor wants whenever."

HEADLINE: Ferruzzi's Ex-Chief Is Back, Defiant

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RAVENNA, Italy

 BODY:
Raul Gardini knows how to make waves.
Last year, he was ousted as head of Ferruzzi-Montedison, Italy's second- biggest conglomerate, after the three Ferruzzi siblings who control the agribusiness and chemical concern decided that Mr. Gardini -- their brother-in-law -- was taking the company in the wrong direction. 
 After the ouster, his wife, Idina, sold her 23 percent stake in the company to the family for $390 million.
Mr. Gardini spent much of this year yachting. His boat, Il Moro di Venezia, lost the America's Cup in May but was the first European boat in almost 30 years to reach the final round of the world's premier yachting event, helping to catapult yachting into the spectator-sport stratosphere, usually thought of as a soccer monopoly in this country.
Now, after retiring at least for now from racing, Mr. Gardini is re-entering the Italian business scene -- and with as much high drama and dynastic derring-do as his exit.
 
More Feuds in the Offing
 His plan to build a consumer products company in Italy is likely to provide yet another round of feuding within the powerful Ferruzzi clan. It was widely reported that as part of his severance deal with the Ferruzzis, Mr. Gardini agreed informally to steer clear of directly competing with any of the family's businesses -- a notion that Mr. Gardini says was an "invention of the Ferruzzis."
But he and the chairman of Ferruzzi-Montedison's own sugar company have already jointly bought an interest in a sugar company. Last month, he offered to buy the Quaker Oats Company's lucrative Italian cooking oil and soft drinks division. The offer, which was turned down, would have put him in direct competition with the Ferruzzis' oil marketer.
"My only moral duty is not to use my knowledge of their business," Mr. Gardini says, "and I have never done that."
Now, he is trying to buy the country's top-selling Levissima mineral water, a venture that would have no Ferruzzi rival.
On May 21, Italian newspapers reported, the Ferruzzi family apparently snubbed Mr. Gardini and his wife at a special concert here -- the family's home base -- by the Philadelphia Orchestra under its conductor, Riccardo Muti.
"It has never been very easy, but no one quarreled in public, or shouted," said one person at the company, who refused to be named. "They are all very stylish people. Under the surface, though, there may still be some jealousies."
 
Second-Largest Conglomerate
 Mr. Gardini became chairman of the Ferruzzi holdings in 1979, after his father-in-law, Serafino Ferruzzi, the group's founder, died in a plane crash. Over the next 11 years, he turned what had been a prosperous but conservative agribusiness based on grain-trading into Italy's second- largest conglomerate, after Fiat, broadening its base, particularly with the 1987 takeover of the Montedison chemical giant.
But the three Ferruzzi siblings began to worry that Mr. Gardini was leading the group into ever more controversial waters, especially when he tangled with Italy's political establishment over a short-lived 1989 merger between Montedison and the chemical division of the state oil company, ENI.
"My exit from Italy and Ferruzzi was provoked by the economic and political situation in this country," he said.
The investment in Enimont, as the merged company was called, led to a collision over the lugubrious and overstaffed management methods of Italy's large state-run business sector.
"Having paid a lot of money, I thought it would be possible to manage it in an economic way," Mr. Gardini said.
But the state placed conditions on the sale that would have thwarted Mr. Gardini's plans to close plants and sell assets. Montedison eventually sold its share of Enimont back to ENI for the equivalent of around $2.3 billion, which, according to Ferruzzi executives, was a profit of "a few hundred million."
After the incident, Mr. Gardini went on an extended vacation to sail in California, saying, "I no longer want anything to do with Italy."
But the final rift with the Ferruzzis came when the 58-year-old Mr. Gardini promoted a restructuring plan that would have broadened the shareholding away from Serafino's four children to embrace some of Mr. Gardini's business associates and several Ferruzzi grandchildren, including his own son Ivan.
 
Idea, Si; Mechanism, No
 "The family agreed with the idea, but not the mechanism," said a Ferruzzi spokesman, without elaborating.
"Everyone knows the proposal was not accepted," Mr. Gardini said, "so I left the group."
After negotiations between June and August 1991, the elder brother, Arturo Ferruzzi, who held a majority share all along, took charge of the company. Today, he controls 40 percent of the shares, and his sisters Franca and Alessandra have 30 percent each.
Mr. Gardini began the yachting venture while still head of Ferruzzi, which had already spent $50 million to buy a shipyard and a company to build the yacht. When he left, the company set a limit of $40 million on the development budget for the yacht, which Mr. Gardini used in conjunction with an undisclosed amount of his own money to build his yacht.
While not ruling out another run at the cup, Mr. Gardini said he would "tread softly" with yacht racing. Ferruzzi itself, an executive said, is "talking about the possibility of trying again."
"But it is impossible that we would compete again with Mr. Gardini," the executive said.
On June 30 Mr. Gardini cut his ties with the yacht-racing division of Ferruzzi, as required under the severance agreement.
He felt, he said, that it was time "to revive an adventure in this country."
In Italy, big business seems to revolve around a handful of big-name players whose activities make the general-news pages as much as the business pages. Each has a nickname. Just as Fiat's Gianni Agnelli is "l'avvocato," the lawyer, and Olivetti's Carlo de Benedetti is "l'ingegnere," the engineer, Mr. Gardini is "il contadino," meaning farmer, a named earned because of his activities in agribusiness.
Fittingly, he has chosen a barn, refurbished, surrounding it with acres of billiard-smooth lawn, as the corporate offices for his Italian holding company, Gardini , on the fringes of this ancient northern city. Antique tapestries have replaced the hayracks , and heavy brass ashtrays around the big, circular conference table bear the name "Il Moro di Venezia," his yacht, which lost this year to America3 in San Diego.
Last December, Mr. Gardini and his associate, Jean Marc Vernes, spent $311 million on holdings in the French food business, including a 16.6 percent stake in the ailing Sucden sugar, chocolate and meat concern, placing him potentially in competition with the Ferruzzi-controlled Eridania-Beghin Say sugar group. Curiously, Mr. Vernes runs Eridania.
Mr. Gardini has vowed to avoid direct competition with Eridania, but "if we can't avoid it, we can't."
Mr. Vernes's association with both Ferruzzi and Mr. Gardini is "rather anomalous," a Ferruzzi executive said. But Ferruzzi officials say the operation of Ferruzzi's sugar interests is no longer in Mr. Vernes's control and Mr. Vernes has announced plans to leave Ferruzzi at the end of the year.
He had apparently chosen "between a young business relationship that is probably long-lasting with Mr. Gardini and a slowly, quietly fading relationship with Ferruzzi," said a Ferruzzi executive speaking in return for anonymity.
Some of Ferruzzi's principal international competitors, including Archer-Daniels-Midland, Britain's Tate & Lyle and the Luxembourg holding company CIP, have each taken a 5 percent stake in another of Mr. Gardini's holding companies, Gardini et Associes.
Whether the association with its competitors worries Ferruzzi is open to debate.
"He's involving himself in a series of acquisitions, some successful, some unsuccessful," a Ferruzzi official said. "He's set up some small companies, but it's not in our league."
Ferruzzi made $94 million on $14.6 billion in sales in 1991.
Mr. Gardini, meanwhile, along with Giulio Malgara, the former European chief of Quaker Oats, put together $160 million to bid for part of Quaker's Italian business, including the market-leading cooking oils division, whose annual sales are $125 million.
"I was certainly the right person to make the offer," Mr. Malgara said, voicing disappointment, "but Quaker did not accept mine like it didn't accept others."

HEADLINE: Fannie Mae Net Advances 21%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 13

 BODY:
The Federal National Mortgage Association reported today that second-quarter earnings rose 21 percent, to a record $402 million, or $1.47 a share, as low interest rates increased the volume of its business.
In the period a year earlier, Fannie Mae, as the Government-sponsored enterprise is called, earned $331.5 million, or $1.21 a share. 
 First-half earnings grew 20 percent, to $783.6 million, or $2.86 a share, from $651.5 million, or $2.40 a share, in 1991's first six months.
In New York Stock Exchange trading today, Fannie Mae's shares fell 75 cents to $63.75.
The company's total business volume reached a record $67 billion in the second quarter and $123 billion for the half, compared with $38 billion and $61 billion in the respective periods a year earlier.
The added volume made up for a slight increase in loan losses and a narrowing of the company's net interest margin, the difference between the interest it earns on mortgage loans and what it pays to obtain money.
Fannie Mae finances about one in every eight of the nation's single-family home purchases. It buys mortgages from lenders, holding some in its portfolio and packaging others into securities for resale to investors.

HEADLINE: Rethinking the National Chip Policy

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, July 13

 BODY:
A short five years ago, as America's semiconductor industry recoiled at the threat of Japanese domination, I.B.M. quietly helped create with the Federal Government an industry consortium to rebuild the nation's chip-making technology base.
The result was Sematech, in which the Government has poured a half-billion dollars since 1987, and U.S. Memories Inc., a private effort to assure United States computer makers of a steady supply of advanced memory chips for computers. 
 But U.S. Memories never went anywhere. And now, after I.B.M. announced a chip-making alliance with Toshiba and Siemens today, and Advanced Micro Devices announced one with Fujitsu, industry executives are re-evaluating whether supporting a nationalistic industrial policy is an appropriate corporate strategy.
 
'Survival Is the First Priority'
 I.B.M. executives, for example, said today that it was no longer feasible for the country to employ a Fortress America technology strategy.
"Companies need to be able compete globally to survive," Jack D. Kuehler, I.B.M.'s president said in a telephone interview today after a New York press conference held by executives of I.B.M., Toshiba and Siemens. "Survival is the first priority," he said. "Nationalistic factors are second priority."
Just as America's role as the world's military superpower has been redefined by Communism's collapse, the latest chip-development alliances suggest that future efforts to bolster American technology may need to become increasingly international.
 
The Korean Factor
 "We are past the point where the U.S. can do all of this on its own," said Michael Borrus, a political economist at University of California at Berkeley. "The question is how to reorganize ourselves so that we can get what we need from abroad while safeguarding the values we hold most dear."
He said that the aggressive entry of the Korean chip maker Samsung into the international memory chip market had been one of the most significant factors in dropping barriers to international cooperation. The Koreans have invested between $4 billion and $5 billion in computer memory technology, he said, and have taken 15 percent of the world memory market since they began production in 1987. "It has all come out of the Japanese market share," Mr. Borrus said.
Sematech officials, for their part, said that despite being surprised by the I.B.M. announcement, they agreed with I.B.M.'s changing philosphy.
"Clearly, the biggest concern is spending tax dollars to create jobs in other countries," said William J. Spencer, president and chief executive of Sematech, which is based in Austin, Tex., "But we're entering an era when nationalistic issues will continue to decline. Sematech gradually will become an international organization."
Mr. Spencer said Sematech had already held discussions with its counterpart in Europe, and he did not rule out cooperation with Japan in the future.
But I.B.M. executives were not ready to say the Government should put an end to its national industrial efforts. In fact they paid tribute to Sematech's role in developing the equipment that will be used in the newly announced development project. The project's goal will be to design chips that store 256 million bits of information -- 16 times more information than is stored on today's highest-capacity memory chips.
 
Reviving the Debate
 Nevertheless, I.B.M.'s alliance, which will combine engineers from the three companies at I.B.M.'s advanced technology semiconductor center in East Fishkill, N.Y., is certain to revive the debate over the role that the United States Government should play in supporting critical technologies like semiconductors and computers.
One perspective held by some industry executives and consultants is that there increasingly will be less need for Government-sponsored technology initiatives because national boundaries will play a smaller role in determining the makeup of huge technology projects.
"National boundaries no longer stop the flow of technology," said Shmuel Halevi, executive vice president at the Technology Research Group, a Boston-based semiconductor industry consultant. "Simply put, this alliance will kill whatever rationale there is left for Sematech."
Sematech has been given credit recently for helping to reverse the slide in market share of the American semiconductor equipment manufacturers. The world market for semiconductor manufacturing equipment is $20 billion, and American makers of such production gear registered an increase in 1991 worldwide market share to nearly 41 percent from 38 percent in 1990.
 
Sematech's Legacy
 Indeed, last month Silicon Valley Group Lithography Systems Inc., based in Wilton, Conn., introduced fundamentally new chip-making systems that industry executives say will become the basis of both I.B.M.'s and Toshiba's independent 64-million-bit memory chip efforts and may possibly be used for their jointly developed 256-million-bit chips scheduled to go into production at the end of the decade.
Significantly, the new lithography system, called the Micrascan II, was developed in part with funding from Sematech. I.B.M. played a lead role in seeing that the new system reached the market after its original developer, Perkin-Elmer, decided to pull out of the semiconductor manufacturing business.
Sematech officials said that the consortium's role would continue to be a crucial one, particularly in transferring technology between semiconductor equipment makers and chip makers.
"If Sematech weren't here, I.B.M. might have been able to make this agreement," Mr. Spencer said. "But 10 years from now it won't be possible. You can imagine Toshiba merely manufacturing here and keeping profits flowing back to Japan."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jack D. Kuehler, center, the president of I.B.M., talked with Tsuyoshi Kawanishi, left, a senior vice president of the Toshiba Corporation, and Dr. Karlheinz Kaske, the president of Siemens A.G., yesterday after announcing that their companies were forming a new global chip-making alliance. (Stacey P. Morgan for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
4 Of Nation's Biggest Banks Post Higher 2d-Quarter Nets

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON

 BODY:
Four of the nation's largest banks reported higher second-quarter earnings yesterday, demonstrating that lower interest rates have helped them more than a weak economy has hurt.
The biggest surprise to industry analysts came from J. P. Morgan & Company, where profits rose 66.7 percent from the second quarter of last year on broad-based improvements, including stronger trading and corporate finance. 
 Chase Manhattan gained 15.2 percent, helped, like Morgan, by a wider spread between the interest rates it paid for deposits and other funds and the rates it received on loans and other investments.
Earnings at First Chicago rose 19 percent and at Barnett Banks Inc., 85.3 percent.
Frank R. DeSantis Jr., an analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, said the latest reports confirmed a turnaround that began in the middle of last year. "Earnings have been strong and getting stronger," he said.
Following are the details of the second-quarter earnings results:
 
 
Morgan
 Morgan, the fifth-largest banking company, earned $385 million, or $1.94 a share, up from $231 million, or $1.17 a share, a year earlier.
Morgan continued its march into provinces that investment banks once dominated. Revenues from securities and currency trading, down sharply during the first quarter, rebounded to $287 million, up 22 percent from a year ago. Corporate finance revenues rose 21 percent, to $110 million, as Morgan became the first commercial banking company to lead a public stock offering in 60 years.
"Morgan is becoming the world's dominant trading and investment banking house, and the results prove that," said Thomas H. Hanley, an analyst at First Boston. These activities also, however, contributed to a 27 percent increase in operating expenses, to $745 million.
The company did better in virtually all of its other businesses, but analysts said the overall picture was not quite so impressive as the net earnings made it appear. They had expected Morgan to earn $1.35 a share, and ascribed most of its improvement to such one-time gains as a $124 million profit on the sale of bonds.
Morgan's shares closed yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange at $61.50, down 12.5 cents.
For the first six months of the year, Morgan earned $684 million, up 35.7 percent from $504 million in the first half of 1991.
 
Chase
 Chase Manhattan, the sixth-largest banking company, earned $152 million in the second quarter, or 83 cents a share, up from $132 million, or 80 cents a share, a year earlier.
The results, somewhat better than industry analysts expected, were attributed to higher interest income, stronger corporate finance and some profits on leveraged buyouts. Although loans shrank to $64.6 billion, from $72.8 billion a year ago, net interest revenues rose 5 percent, to $878 million from $834 million.
Chase showed less progress than some other major banks in managing its problem loans. The total of loans not currently paying interest rose $129 million over the quarter to $4.47 billion, including $153 million to borrowers in Yugoslavia.
For the first six months of the year, Chase earned $293 million, up 18 percent from $248 million in the first half of last year. Chase stock closed at $27.875, down $1.25.
 
First Chicago
 The First Chicago Corporation earned $68.2 million in the second quarter, or 79 cents a share, up from $57.3 million, or 73 cents a share.
Net interest revenues rose 9 percent, to $301 million from $275 million. But $368 million in real estate loans, including some to Olympia and York, were not making payments, up by $95 million over the quarter.
First Chicago shares closed at $35.875, down 62.5 cents.
 
Barnett
 Barnett Banks Inc. earned $54.1 million, or 67 cents a share, in the second quarter, up from $29.2 million, or 42 cents a share, a year ago.
It also had higher net interest income, as well as some improvement in the performance of its loans.
For the first six months of the year, Barnett earned $97.7 million, more than doubling its earnings of $47.5 million in the first half of last year.
Barnett shares closed on the Big Board at $37.25, down 75 cents.

HEADLINE: G.O.P. Is Told Not to Alter Constitution

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, July 13

 BODY:
Blaming what he called "right-wing extremists" within the Republican Party, the Senate Democratic leader, John A. Lynch, accused the Republican legislative majority today of trying to undermine the State Constitution.
During a half-hour news conference, Mr. Lynch made a frequently rambling, partisan attack on the Republicans, charging that if they succeeded in amending the Constitution it would create two separate New Jerseys divided along geographic and economic lines. 
 His comments marked the start of a Democratic campaign to arouse public sentiment against the proposed amendments and the Republicans, who have three weeks to pass legislation that would put the constitutional changes on the ballot Nov. 2.
Among the various amendments planned by the Republicans, he said, are one that would reduce requirements to give extra help to poor urban school districts and one that would prevent the state from fighting racism by joining school districts to achieve desegregation.
 
'Appears to Be on a Rampage'
 "The Republican majority in the Legislature appears to be on a rampage to amend the State Constitution," Mr. Lynch said. "This headstrong amendment blitz is a reckless bid to undermine the integrity of a document which has stood as a national model for a state government since its modern-day creation in 1947."
In a Republican response to Mr. Lynch, the Senate President, Donald T. DiFrancesco, said in a statement:
"It is ironic that a Democratic Party that presided over the placement of more than 30 proposed constitutional amendments since 1974, including legislative oversight and others, would raise questions about the propriety of placing a handful of questions on the ballot.
"These questions that the public will decide passed the Senate with bi-partisan support," Mr. DiFrancesco said.
Mr. Lynch, only half jokingly, told reporters that he had timed his news conference to take advantage of what he anticipated would be a news void in Trenton created by the start of the Democratic National Convention in New York City.
"This news conference is for all of us who have not been invited to the convention," he said.
The Legislature is in recess until July 20, when it is expected to take up a number of constitutional issues, including whether to grant the public a direct say in lawmaking through initiative and referendum balloting.
Since the Republican-controlled 205th Legislature began its two-year session in January, legislators have introduced nearly 90 bills to amend the State Constitution, about a dozen of them sponsored by Democrats.
Three of the Republican proposals have cleared the legislative labyrinth and will be placed on the November ballot. They are amendments to permit the Legislature to review administrative rules and regulations, to transfer certain judicial and probation costs from the counties to the state by July 1, 1977 and to strengthen the state death-penalty law.
Three more have cleared one chamber and are awaiting final passage in the second. Mr. Lynch suggested today that as many as six more Republican-sponsored amendments may come up for a vote in November.
"Over the 45 years of existence, the State Constitution has been amended on a number of occasions, but mostly on significant issues such as casino gambling, improving of our judicial system and dedicating income-tax receipts to property-tax relief," Mr. Lynch said. "Now, in a single year, there is a real possibility the Republicans will place more than a dozen amendments on the November ballot.
"This situation marks a dangerous time for New Jersey residents, not only for the maze of questions they will encounter once they enter voting booths, but also for what Republicans are willing to do to foist their brand of right-wing extremism on the people of New Jersey."
 
No 'Thorough and Efficient'
 Mr. Lynch distributed a list of a dozen Republican-sponsored bills to amend the Constitution. He singled out two proposals as especially egregious -- an amendment to remove the constitutional provision that every public school child be given a thorough and efficient education and one to prohibit the state from forcing school district consolidations to achieve desegregation.
Mr. DiFrancesco, the Senate President, defended the amendments the Republicans were suggesting, saying they gave "the people more input into the regulatory bureaucracy that rules, and sometimes ruins, their lives."

GRAPHIC: Photo: John A. Lynch, the Senate Democratic leader in Trenton, assaulted Republican efforts to amend the State Constitution yesterday in a news conference at which he said the majority party was on a "rampage." (Laura Pedrick for The New York Times)
