HEADLINE: Convention Summary

 BODY:

WITH PLATFORM, DEMOCRATS AIM FOR THE MIDDLE
 Seeking a middle ground between unfettered capitalism and welfare-state economics, the Democrats' platform stresses conservative values and liberal programs. The platform is salted with phrases like "personal responsibility" and "market forces," but it also endorses universal medical insurance and higher taxes on the wealthy.
 
GOV. BROWN STILL TALKING ABOUT TALKING AT CONVENTION
 The Democrats grudgingly yielded former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. 20 minutes at the podium on Wednesday -- when the three major networks were not scheduled to carry the proceedings. But unlike the Rev. Jesse Jackson, who chose to cooperate with the party, Mr. Brown preferred to keep arguing. His spokesman said there was "no deal," and that he wanted a prime-time slot unconditioned on an endorsement.
 
DEMOCRATS AND DEMONSTRATORS VIE FOR FACE TIME
 The convention may be a ratings bust, but New York's Democrats and demonstrators are treating it like the opportunity of a politicial lifetime. For politicians, tactics for garnering exposure vary from elbowing for position in a staged photo to cruising through 20 events daily. For demonstators, group performance is what counts: 10,000 people held a rally that was part disco and part wake to demand better care for Americans with AIDS.
 
WHO'S THAT RADICAL IN THE BROOKS BROTHERS SHIRT?
 Conventioners figured out to spot New Yorkers, but they were still having trouble separating the moderates from the progressives at their parties. Style cues proved treacherous.

HEADLINE: Temple of the Lord in a Tent in the Bronx

BYLINE: By ARI L. GOLDMAN

 BODY:
Toward evening, when the heat of the summer day had finally broken, they began to arrive by the hundreds under a tent set up on a vacant lot in the Bronx.
Young and old, in shorts and dungarees, in housedresses and sundresses, they came for a touch of that old-time religion usually associated with the American South and the islands of the Caribbean: the outdoor Christian revival meeting. 
 "Who here has special needs?" Pastor Samuel Bulgin asked the makeshift congregation.
A thousand hands went up, including those of the ministers, the ushers and the members of the choir; everyone but the keyboard player, whose hands were busy keeping the inspirational music going.
"Good," said Mr. Bulgin looking out on the crowd. "Because I believe God is still in the needs-answering business."
"Lord, we have many, many, many needs," he prayed. "We need jobs, we need places to live, we need companionship. We are parents concerned about our children. We are children concerned about our parents."
Every head was bowed as the prayers went up from what the pastor called "this canvas cathedral," pitched on hardscrabble land between a fast-food outlet and an auto-transmission shop at Baychester Avenue and Boston Road.
The revival, which ends its five-week run on July 25, was sponsored by the Greater New York Conference of Seventh-day Adventists, but it could have been a project of any one of a number of churches around New York City. Each summer, dozens pitch their tents on vacant lots, especially in Brooklyn and the Bronx.
The Rev. Patricia Reeberg, executive director of the Council of Churches of the City of New York, said that the organization did not have precise figures on the number of tents. But the number is growing, she said, because the recession has had the dual effect of slowing the development of vacant lots and heightening the spiritual needs of New Yorkers, especially the poor.
Some tents, like the Bronx tent of the Adventists', are pitched on private land, in this case rented from the neighboring Kentucky Fried Chicken outlet. Others are on city-owned land, like the giant blue tent of the Brooklyn Tabernacle Deliverance Center, next to Woodhull Medical and Mental Health Center in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn.
Over the years, the image of tent revivals has been sullied by charlatans, best epitomized by the fictional Elmer Gantry, whose love for money, women and booze far outstrips his love for God and flock. Sinclair Lewis, who wrote "Elmer Gantry" in 1927, clearly was drawing on the shady evangelists of his day.
Pastor Robert C. Connor, the evangelist who organized the Adventist meeting, said he was well aware that he was working in a medium that many found odious. But he said the tent was used in the urban setting of the Bronx for many of the same reasons they were employed on the frontier.
"People are more comfortable in a tent," said the 52-year-old evangelist, who remembers attending tent meetings as a boy in South Carolina. "It is their turf, their neighborhood. They don't have to dress up like they do when they go to church."
"When you put up a tent," he said, "you reach the unchurched."
Not that the enterprise is without its travails. People walk by with boom boxes. Trucks backfire. Guns fire. On one occasion a few years ago Mr. Connor said that a bullet came whizzing through the tent where he was preaching on a vacant lot in Harlem.
The tents also have an impact on the community. For one thing, they are loud. Eight suitcase-size speakers were set up at various locations around the Adventist tent, carrying the gospel songs and fiery sermons thundering through the neighborhood.
But just a few doors away, people didn't seem to mind. "I'd rather hear that than the crackheads," said one woman, who did not want to be identified, as she sat on her porch.
"We're Catholic but it doesn't bother me," said Hector Cabrera, a carpenter, who was working on his property. "It's always good to hear the word of God."
 
$25,000 for 5 Weeks
 Seventh-day Adventist organizers say that the Bronx crusade costs them about $25,000 for the five-week run. They own the tent and the chairs, but have to pay a modest rental fee for the land as well as for round-the-clock security guards and four portable toilets. They also pay the salaries of the church workers who run the concurrent Vacation Bible School, the "health fair" and the clinic to help people stop smoking.
All the programs are free and, although the plate is passed at all the revival meetings, organizers said that the collection covers less than a quarter of their total costs.
Randall Balmer, a professor of religion at Barnard College, said that tent meetings are "an important part of American religious history and culture" that were especially popular in the American frontier in the 19th century.
"They represent an unabashed populism and its readiness to go to where the people are," he said.
Inside the Bronx tent, things were heating up. Women were fanning themselves with their songbooks. People slapped at mosquitoes on their arms and legs. Fireflies and moths fluttered about.
The evangelist, already in his second week of preaching, showed signs of losing his voice. With the help of Biblical verses flashed on a 10-foot by 10-foot screen, he was explaining the Adventists' reasons for marking the Sabbath on Saturday rather than Sunday like most Christians.
Mr. Connor drew a distinction between "the moral law" as embodied in the Ten Commandments and "the ceremonial law" and "the ordinances" written by Moses.
"Who wrote the moral law?" Mr. Connor asked the congregation.
"God," they answered limply.
"There is something wrong with my voice, but you have no excuses," he said. "Now, who wrote the moral law?"
"God!" they roared.
"And how did He write it?"
"With His finger!" they said as one.
 
The Commandments Endure
 Using Scriptural verses, Mr. Connor sought to demonstrate that while the suffering of Jesus "set aside" the Mosaic law -- in the words of Colossians 2:14, "nailing it to the cross" -- the Ten Commandments "written with the finger of God" (Deuteronomy 9:10) still endure.
"I just want to set the record straight," he said. "When we stand before God, we are going to be judged by those laws."
Recorded music swelled as, in a Charlton Heston-like voice, he recounted the Ten Commandments. "I am the Lord your God," he began.
When he finished, he asked: "Am I making it plain? I am not here to preach. I am here to teach. I want to make it real plain.
"The Fourth Commandment, 'Keep the Sabbath,' is just as important as 'Thou shalt not kill.' "
He ended with this finale: "You've been keeping nine of God's Commandments. Now keep all 10!"
Most of the worshipers were Adventists who were there, they said, to strengthen their faith. Some of them brought friends from outside the church, like Hyacinth Barnes, a nurse, who brought her friend Barbara Brown.
Afterward, the two women debated the merits of Saturday versus Sunday worship. "The only thing you can't fight is the Holy Spirit," Ms. Barnes told her friend.
Others came for the experience. Jennifer Guthrie, a college student who seemed more than a little homesick for her native Jamaica, stayed in her seat as others were leaving and the tent lights were being turned low.
"Back home we do this all year round," she said, looking out into the night. "It just feels good to be here."

HEADLINE: Santa Monica Journal;
Where Only the Ocean Makes Waves

BYLINE: By SARA RIMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SANTA MONICA, Calif.

 BODY:
Jane Fonda has moved to Montana, but this seaside town still has movie stars and fitness factories, along with Tom Hayden and a social conscience. It has art for the masses -- like the two lifeguard chairs that hum in the wind, badly, some residents complain -- storm drain sensors that are activated by pollutants to summon pump trucks, and a city attorney who runs his own feeding program for the homeless on Saturdays.
This year the People's Republic of Santa Monica, as it has been called, had something else it hadn't had in 20 years -- a deficit. "The recession caught up with us," said a City Council member, Denny Zane, who is an environmental consultant. 
 City officials had to reduce tax-supported services by $5.7 million. "We tried not to go into a panic mode," said the city manager, John Jalili, who attributes his calm manner in part to his daily eight-mile run. He said he certainly was not about to recommend anything drastic, like closing the library on Sunday, or slashing services to the homeless.
The seven-member City Council met recently to approve the cuts. Mr. Jalili predicted hours of heated debate. "We're known for our political fervor," he said.
The meeting began with four women in gold lame minidresses and gold high heels and two men in billowing black shirts and black pants performing a New Age rendition, on bells and xylophones, of Dave Brubeck's "Take Five."
This was the "inspiration," as it was listed in the agenda, a Santa Monica substitute for an invocational prayer. The night's performing group was the Campanile Jazz Ensemble. Previous meetings have featured a gospel choir, chanting and Japanese martial arts.
"I thought it was pretty far out," Mr. Zane said, referring to the Brubeck. "It helped create a generous mood."
Forty-five residents had signed up to speak before the Council. Joe Piperski, who owns Joe's Diner on Main Street, expressed compassion for the City Council, saying, "I know you're stressed out."
They didn't look it. Mayor Ken Genser calmly sipped caffeine-free Diet Coke and shared handfuls of peanut M&M's with his fellow Council members.
The meeting went on until 1 A.M. Most of the speakers pleaded for the Council not to cut money for the schools or the homeless. It didn't. Programs for the homeless, in fact, were allotted $1.6 million, up $500,000 from the previous year.
Not everyone was pleased, of course. "I don't think we need any more off-the-wall art projects, or $500,000 bicycle master plans," said Carolyn Caesar, a registered dietician who was there to represent a more conservative section of the city's residents. Or more money for the homeless, she added.
Budget deficit or no, Santa Monica, population 86,905, still has one of the highest municipal bond ratings in the state. It has 400 restaurants and 75 art galleries and it costs $600,000 to buy a two-bedroom cottage on the beach.
The $185.2 million budget was approved, 5 to 2. Major cuts were made by eliminating 60 city jobs through attrition. Also cut were some capital improvements, like the $500,000 for bicycle paths, which had become so controversial that some city officials were afraid to be seen on their bicycles.
The Council allotted $2 million for schools, the same as last year, but $500,000 more than two years ago. Though social services did take a 1 percent cut, they still got a relatively generous $5.7 million.
The Mayor said that he had briefly favored cutting social services, but that he had changed his mind. "I felt really, really good about voting for social services," he said.
Mr. Genser, who is up for re-election next fall, did vote to cut his own travel budget to $4,700 from $8,300.
Another $75,000 was saved by eliminating the July 4 fireworks, traditionally set at 5 A.M. with the Los Angeles Pops providing accompaniment on the beach.
But there is plenty of money, $2.5 million to be exact, for environmental innovations like the storm sensors, as well as a "toilet retrofit" program to help residents save water. The library will stay open seven days a week.
Mr. Jalili and his staff had been working on the budget for weeks, and Mr. Zane gave the city manager much of the credit for making the cuts as painless as possible.
Mr. Jalili seemed a little disappointed. He had only one word for the big budget meeting: "Boring."

HEADLINE: Contractors Reap Gains Promised by Convention

BYLINE: By RALPH BLUMENTHAL

 BODY:
In the scramble for the millions of dollars of business generated by New York City's third Democratic convention in 16 years, some well-connected (or just connected) local companies snared big contracts, while others fought over the relative scraps and still others lost out as irrevocably as Edmund G. Brown Jr.
The largest city contract, for a nearly $6 million renovation of Madison Square Garden, went to AJ Contracting Company of Manhattan, which counts a former city official as an executive vice president. It then subcontracted $355,000 in carpentry work to a company named in a mob-related bid-rigging case, Nastasi White Inc. of Flushing, Queens. A less lucrative but highly prestigious contract went to Howard J. Rubenstein Associates. Mr. Rubenstein, crowned as the public relations bonanza's official public relations man, says he is losing money on his $25,000 consultant's contract. 
 For eager vendors the arithmetic has been tantalizing. The city committed itself to spend $20.8 million on the convention. Of this, $6.6 million was earmarked for police overtime and convention security. Some $4 million was for rental of the Garden, and most of the rest was for construction alterations.
For this, the city figured to earn $27 million in extra taxes on $190 million in direct spending by the approximately 25,000 visitors, according to NY92, a partnership between the city and a committee of business sponsors who raised $6.5 million in private grants and in-kind contributions. Secondary spending on things like hotel renovation was expected to generate an additional $280 million.
The biggest single prize was the general contract for renovation of the Garden. The Economic Development Corporation, a nonprofit public development unit under contract to the city, advertised in papers for minority groups and city journals and winnowed down 31 proposals to select 10 contractors for follow-up interviews, said James A. Schmidt, the unit's executive vice president. Seven were invited to submit two figures, for both an early and a late start on the work, depending on the playoff fortunes of the Knicks and the Rangers.
 
An Experienced Bidder
 Five sent in bids and of these, AJ Contracting came in lowest, at $5.94 million for an early start, more than $1 million less than the next lowest, figures show. The company prepared the sites for the 1976, 1980 and 1984 Democratic conventions and has as its executive vice president and a partner, Kenneth D. Smith, an engineer who worked for the city from 1971 until 1980. He was chief of staff in the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development and assistant deputy commissioner in the Department of Real Estate.
The president of one company interviewed but not invited to bid for the general contract, Andrew Velez of the Velez Organization in Manhattan, said yesterday that he felt misled and contended that as a minority enterprise with a record of multimillion-dollar jobs, his company should have been allowed to bid.
Mr. Schmidt said the Velez company was not considered among the most qualified and denied that AJ Contracting had been shown any favoritism. He also said there was no requirement to let the contract to a minority company, although some news accounts, citing the Chilean background of AJ's president, Charles Uribe, mistakenly identified the firm as owned by a member of a minority group. This led to a recent charge by the New Alliance Party candidate for President, Lenora B. Fulani, that the Democrats were exaggerating the proportion of contracts awarded to companies owned by members of minority groups.
Among the subcontractors chosen by AJ Contracting was Nastasi White, which, with a New Jersey-based company, Improved Dry Wall Inc., which is owned by a member of a minority group, shared a $666,000 carpentry job.
Nastasi White, which was one of AJ's subcontractors for previous conventions, was taken off city projects by former Mayor Edward I. Koch after the company came up in an investigation of an alleged payoff by a former plasterers' union official. According to Robert Maas, an assistant district attorney in Manhattan, the union official, Louis D. Moscatiello, was recorded while giving money to an informant, Mel Eckhaus, saying that it came from a company official, Thomas Nastasi.
The company, while never indicted, is also cited in a continuing civil racketeering case brought by the United States Attorney in the Southern District of New York against the carpenters' district council and organized crime figures linked to the Genovese crime family.
Company officials did not respond to messages left at the Nastasi White office.
Mr. Schmidt and Frank Marino, a spokesman for AJ, defended the subcontract award, saying that the Nastasi company had a good record of performance and had not been charged with wrongdoing.
Although Henry Miller, the chief executive officer of NY92, declined to give the amount being paid by his group to Mr. Rubenstein until the group's official expense filing, Mr. Rubenstein said he would get $25,000. He said it was less than half his cost in devoting 11 employees to organizing news coverage for the 15,000 reporters present.
Among other happy contractors was Robert See, whose company, See Factor Industry of Long Island City, Queens, was hired for nearly $300,000 by AJ Contracting to put up the 90 tons of ceiling spotlights and rigging and work with other specialists on effects.
He wouldn't say if he was a Democrat. "Money knows no political boundaries," he said.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Coke's 2d-Period Net Grew, But Shipments Were Weak

BYLINE: By EBEN SHAPIRO

 BODY:
The Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that second-quarter net income advanced 20 percent despite weak shipments in important markets, including the United States, Japan, Brazil and Mexico.
Despite the sharp jump in profits, Coke's shares dropped 62.5 cents yesterday, closing at $41.50 on the New York Stock Exchange. While earnings matched analysts' expectations, Coke's shipments of concentrate to bottlers were lower than expected. 
 "People looked at the shipment numbers and got concerned," said Emanuel Goldman, a beverage analyst with Paine Webber. The stock fell as much as $1 during the day.
In the second quarter, Coke earnings rose to $581 million, or 44 cents a share, from $482.4 million, or 36 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. Sales grew 17 percent, to $3.55 billion from $3.03 billion.
Roberto C. Goizueta, chairman, said the earnings "demonstrated once again the ability of our global enterprise to deliver impressive, profitable growth despite difficult economic climates in some of our key markets."
Martin Romm of First Boston called Coke's profit performance impressive, given that volume declined in four of the company's top five markets. "It shows how well they are managing the business," he said.
Marc Cohen, an analyst with Goldman, Sachs, said, "It is a little disappointing to see volume down, but I don't see it as earth-shattering."
In the second quarter, worldwide sales of concentrates inched up 2 percent.
In the United States, gallon sales of concentrate to bottlers fell 2.5 percent. The company tied the drop to a slow economy and said grocers were letting inventories run low.
Roy Burry, an analyst with Kidder, Peabody, said it was unclear whether industry sales had slowed or whether Coke was losing sales to Pepsico Inc.
Case sales in the important Japanese market fell 6 percent in the second quarter. The company said June was very rainy and cool in Japan. Analysts believe that Japan accounts for about 20 percent of Coke's profits.
Case sales fell 4 percent in Latin America, mostly because of drops of 20 percent in Brazil and 5 percent in Mexico.
Mr. Goizueta said the soft performance in those markets was more than offset by solid results in Coke's other markets. In the European Community, case sales increased 14 percent, including gains of 25 percent in France, 17 percent in Britain, and 12 percent in Germany and Italy.

HEADLINE: Yields Continue to Plunge For Bank Funds and C.D.'s

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
With the drop in the Federal discount rate and the subsequent cut in the prime lending rate by most big banks nearly two weeks old, banks were still chopping yields on money market accounts and certificates of deposit in the week ended today.
In contrast to the pricing of bank yields in the latest week, discount rates at the Treasury's weekly auction of three- and six-month bills on Monday saw only a slight downtick. The auction is considered a barometer of what many banks will eventually pay to their depositors. 
 The average rate on a three-month bill at auction was 3.22 percent, down a basis point, or a hundredth of a percentage point, from the previous auction, while the six-month bill also slipped a basis point, to 3.31 percent.
 
Unusually Fast Drop
 According to analysts at The Bank Rate Monitor, the sharpness of the declines in bank-fund yields in the latest week was surprising. He said that a half-point cut in the prime rate would usually causes yields on C.D.'s to fall 25 to 33 basis points in six weeks. "It appears that this may happen in two weeks," said Robert K. Heady, publisher of The Monitor.
"Consumers may have to get used to sub-3 percent yields, as banks do not appear to be squeamish about chopping yields as depositors flee to higher paying investments," Mr. Heady said."
New York area banks reduced the average money market account and six-month certificate by 6 basis points, to 3.14 percent and 3.42 percent, respectively; the average three-month certificate was cut 7 basis points, to 3.23 percent.
Commercial banks, which make up part of the New York average, were more aggressive in lowering yields than their savings bank counterparts, lowering money market accounts 6 basis points, to 2.90 percent; three-month certificates 9 basis points, to 3.01 percent, and six-month C.D.'s 7 basis points, to 3.15 percent.
Savings banks, the other part of the New York average, were less aggressive, but just as thorough, lowering the average yield on money market accounts 5 basis points, to 3.39 percent; three-month certificates 7 basis points, to 3.45 percent, and six-month C.D.'s 4 basis points, to 3.69 percent.
The largest yield adjustments at a New York area bank was at the Hartford-based Connecticut National Bank, which lowered its money market 36 basis points, to 3.04 percent; its three-month certificate 51 basis points, to 3.05 percent, and its six-month C.D. 31 basis points, to 3.36 percent.
Yields at 20 large banks outside the New York market were also down sharply, with an average bank money market account off 7 basis points, to 3.04 percent, and a six-month certificate, down 13 basis points to 3.29 percent.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rises on Expectation Of Meeting of Bundesbank

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar rose against major foreign currencies yesterday in what traders described as technical dealing ahead of a German central bank meeting later this week.
Gold prices rose. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery was quoted at $351.10 per troy ounce, up $2 from late Monday. A late bid from the Republic National Bank of New York quoted it at $350.60 a troy ounce, up $1.90. 
 The dollar's rise came at the expense of the German mark and the Japanese yen, traders said. The mark fell after a two-day rally spurred by persistent speculation that Germany's Bundesbank might soon increase interest rates. Some traders sold the mark during the session and bought dollars in technically driven trading.
The technical selling also hit the Japanese yen, traders said.
Alex Scarsini, a trader for Continental Illinois National Bank in Chicago, said expectations were building concerning a meeting scheduled for tomorrow of the Bundesbank's central bank council. The dollar could advance solidly against the mark if the Germans decide not to raise rates at that session, he said.
In late European trading, the dollar was quoted at 1.4890 German marks, up from 1.4780 on Monday. At the close in New York, the dollar was quoted at 1.4845 marks, up from 1.4755 the day before.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 124.95 yen, down 0.23 yen from Monday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 124.95 yen. At closing in New York, the dollar was quoted at 125.10, up from 124.85 late Monday.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.9140, from $1.9285 late Monday. The pound was trading at $1.9200 at closing in New York, less expensive than late Monday's rate of $1.9295.

HEADLINE: Retail Sales Up 0.5% in June; Consumer Prices Rose 0.3%

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
Consumers spent a little more money last month than in May, but consumer prices stayed relatively well behaved, the Government reported yesterday.
Both reports underscored the sluggish pace of the economic recovery in the quarter ended in June. 
 "The retail sales report was very weak," said Cynthia Latta, an economist at Data Resources/McGraw Hill.
But economists said the silver lining was the continued absence of cost pressures.
"The inflation dragon isn't dead, but he's tame," said John E. Silvia, chief economist at Kemper Financial Services in Chicago. "Politically, that gives the Fed some flexibility."
 
Retail Sales
 Retail sales of goods, which account for about one-third of the gross domestic product, rose five-tenths of 1 percent in June, the Department of Commerce reported yesterday. The agency also revised its May report on retail sales up to four-tenths of 1 percent from the previously reported two-tenths of 1 percent.
But most of the June increase reflected brisker car sales, which ran at an annualized rate of about 6.5 million domestic models last month, a rate that continued in the first 10 days in July. Most of the gains, however, reflected purchases by rental fleets.
"Consumers weren't buying many more cars in June than in May," Ms. Latta said.
Spending on items other than cars edged up just one-tenth of 1 percent. "The weather wasn't steamy hot in June," Ms. Latta added, "so nobody was rushing out to buy fans, air-conditioners and bikinis."
Sales of building materials dropped sharply, a sign of weakness in the housing market.
But discounting lifted clothing sales for the second straight month. And higher pump prices inflated gasoline sales.
Overall spending in June was 3 percent or so higher than a year earlier, but the average for the second quarter was below that of the first. That suggests that consumer spending did not contribute much, if at all, to economic growth in the spring. DRI/McGraw Hill's G.D.P. forecast for the second quarter has assumed that modestly higher spending on services will just offset lower spending on goods.
In any case, consumer spending seems likely to stay in low gear for several months to come. The weekly ABC/Money magazine consumer confidence poll shows that confidence is wavering in the wake of bad news on unemployment and company layoffs. Consumers do not have much in their wallets either. Income has been flat because jobs are not growing and pay increases have been tiny.
 
Consumer Prices
 In the meantime, consumer price inflation shows no signs of picking up, despite a jolt from higher gasoline prices in June, which was the biggest spurt in energy prices since October 1990. The Consumer Price Index increased just three-tenths of 1 percent last month. And inflation for the second quarter amounted to only a 2.6 percent annual rate, down from a 3.5 percent rate in the first quarter.
Energy prices jumped by 2 percent. The sharp increase largely reflects Saudi Arabia's success in tightening OPEC pricing policy. Oil prices are no longer declining.
Food prices were nearly flat. And the prices of services were up a relatively modest three-tenths of 1 percent despite the effect of higher gasoline prices on transportation costs. But analysts noted the unusual slowdown in the price of medical services in the last two months.
"Those concerned with sticky services inflation," Mr. Silvia said, "see this as a positive sign."
Many analysts, Mr. Silvia included, expect inflation to ease some more in the next few months. Among the encouraging signs: faster productivity growth combined with modest wage gains to hold cost pressures at bay.

HEADLINE: Personal Health

BYLINE: By Jane E. Brody

 BODY:
WHEN it comes to buying and wearing shoes, many people, women in particular, pay far too little attention to how a shoe fits and often end up with shoes that are too small in front, too loose in back, inadequately cushioned or otherwise inappropriate for the wearer or the use to which they will be put.
The unhappy results of wearing ill-fitting shoes -- from blisters and bunions to neuromas and backaches -- are helping to make thriving practices for podiatrists, orthopedists and chiropractors. 
 For example, a recent orthopedic evaluation of 255 women from 20 to 60 years old found that 73 percent of them regularly experienced foot pain and 69 percent had one or more deformities in the front part of their feet. The deformities included displaced big toes, hammer toes, bunions and bony protrusions on the ball of the foot.
The problem seems to be particularly severe for women with "big" feet (size 8 or larger), according to Dr. Carol Frey, an orthopedic surgeon at the University of California School of Medicine in Los Angeles. Dr. Frey made her report last month to the American Orthopedic Foot and Ankle Society. Such women, she found, either choose shoes that are ill-fitting in an effort to make their feet look smaller or are stuck with the limited offerings of shoe manufacturers. If they choose a shoe that fits the forefoot properly, it is likely to slip off the heel, and if it hugs the heel, it is likely to scrunch the forefoot.
Dr. Frey's survey found that 80 percent of the women with shoe sizes of 8 or larger suffered foot pain and 75 percent had one or more foot deformities. For women who wear size 10 or larger, the comparable percentages were 84 and 89. In other words, only one woman in 10 had "normal" feet.
The study was a followup to one Dr. Frey had done a year earlier among 356 healthy women. That study found that an astonishing 88 percent of the women wore shoes smaller than their feet and that three-fourths of those surveyed had not had their feet measured for more than five years. The earlier study had included an evaluation of work shoes. Of the 72 percent who said the shoes they wore to work were comfortable, 19 percent wore sneakers, 27 percent wore high heels and 54 percent wore flats. But of the 28 percent who said their work shoes were uncomfortable, only 4 percent wore sneakers, 34 percent wore flats and 62 percent wore high heels.
Clearly, Dr. Frey said, high heels are contributing to more than their fair share of foot problems, but they were by no means the only culprit.
 
Design for Health
 "Shoes are the only part of your wardrobe that can have health consequences," Dr. Frey said. Yet it is common for people, men as well as women, to spend less time, and often less money, on selecting new shoes than on buying a new shirt.
Women who are slaves to fashion seem to have the hardest time. Convinced by the fashion industry that tallness and long legs are synonymous with sexiness, women often choose high-heeled shoes that, a recent study showed, double the pressure placed on the forefoot, throw the back out of line, stress the knee and render the ankle vulnerable to twists and turns.
Fashionable shoes for women are narrower through the forefoot than the shape of a normal woman's foot. If the woman selects a shoe that fits from heel to toe and does not slip off the heel when she walks, chances are the shoe will squeeze the bones in her forefoot together and force her toes into an abnormal wedge shape more appropriate for a creature that has only three toes with the longest one in the middle.
With few exceptions, gone are the days of the so-called combination last, the shoe form that is sized differently in the forefoot and heel; for example, C width in front with a double-A heel. Today, perhaps for reasons of economy, Dr. Frey said, manufacturers make shoes bigger "by enlarging all the dimensions proportionally, as if a longer foot is necessarily wider and thicker in all areas."
Given a choice, most women select a shoe that squeezes the forefoot over one that falls off the heel. To make matters worse, in single-last high-heeled shoes, there is nothing to stop the foot from sliding down into the instep, putting even more of a squeeze on the forefoot and toes.
Then there is the matter of cushioning and ventilation. More and more shoes that the average woman can afford are made with "synthetic uppers." That means the shoes are made not of leather, a material that "breathes," but an imitation leather or plastic that can result in hot, sweaty feet that are more susceptible to fungus infections and skin irritations. But even leather can be a problem, if it is stiff or if it is used on the sole of a shoe that will be walked and stood in for a large part of the day.
There are better choices. Women seeking moderately priced, comfortable and health-promoting, as well as stylish, shoes would be wise to overcome their reluctance to shop for the brands they grew up thinking of as "old lady shoes." Those brands may be making stylish pumps with internal features like extra support, cushioning and absorbent liners.
Dr. Suzanne S. Levine, a New York podiatrist, found in a study of two kinds of similar-looking shoes that when 36 women compared a so-called athletically designed pump with a classic pump of similar design and heel height, the athletically designed pump was twice as comfortable when walked in for at least two miles a day for five workdays.
 
Choosing a Shoe
 The American Orthopedic Foot and Ankle Society offers these suggestions to improve shoe comfort and reduce the risk of foot troubles.
Know your feet. Make a wet imprint of your bare feet and determine whether you have flat feet (the whole foot will show up) or an unusually high arch (no connection between the forefoot and heel). Check your old shoes to see how they wear. You may need extra support or orthotic inserts in your shoes to compensate for a weakness in your feet or gait.
Choose a shoe appropriate for the activity. That may mean buying one pair to walk to work in and a second pair to wear once in the office and seated for most of the day. It also means different shoes for tennis and running, which place different stresses on your feet and ankles.
Don't stint on quality. And if you find shoes that are especially comfortable, buy more than one pair.
Work with a reliable and knowledgeable salesperson. Choose one who measures both of your feet and can discuss the relative virtues of materials and shoe construction.
And when walking around in the shoes before you decide to buy them, allow at least 10 minutes and keep in mind that shoe stores put extra-thick carpets on their floors to make the shoes feel better on your feet.


GRAPHIC: 1. Buy by fit, not by size, which can vary among manufacturers and styles.
Chart: "10 Steps for Shoe Buyers"
 2. Choose a showe that best conforms to the shape of your foot.
 3. Have your feet measured often; shoe size changes with age.
 4. Have both feet measured and buy shoes to fit the larger one.
 5. Go shopping for shoes at the end of the day, when you feet are largest.
 6. Stand up when being fitted and be sure there is a space of from one-eighth inch to one-half inch ahead of your longest toe.
 7. Be sure the ball of your foot fits snugly into the widest part of the shoe.
 8. Do not buy tight shoes that you hope will stretch. They should be comfortable when you leave the store.
 9. Check to be sure your heel is not slipping out of the shoes when you walk.
 10. Walk in the shoes long enough to be sure they fit comfortably before you buy them.
 
(Sources: National Shoe Retailers Association; Prescription Footwear Association; American Orthopedic Foot and Ankle Society)

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Attendance In Majors Taking A Dip

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
After a season that drew a record number of fans -- almost 57 million -- major league baseball attendance has lost 555,000 paying fans so far this year. At the All-Star break, attendance of 19 of the 26 clubs was down from the corresponding period last season, and total attendance has slipped by 1.8 percent.
No one reason is readily apparent for the decrease, from 30,598,159 to 30,043,250, but it has not yet created panic in the upper echelon of the sport. 
 "We talk about it all the time, though not in serious tones as far as worry is concerned," Bobby Brown, the American League president, said by telephone from San Diego. "It may be that we're reaching a plateau. We've done awfully well; we've broken a record for five or six years. You wonder if we're going to be fortunate to have this trend continue forever. When he was alive, Bob Fishel -- a league official -- said it has to level off somewhere; we have to have a bad year sometime."
 
Braves and Twins Surge
 Since the strike-split season of 1981, major league attendance fell in only two of nine years, dropping by 1.8 percent in 1984 and by 0.6 percent in 1990. After each drop, however, the majors enjoyed a hefty increase, 4.7 percent in 1985 and 3.6 percent last year.
Despite last year's record of 56,813,760, half of the 26 teams lost attendance from the previous year. The sizable increases by the Atlanta Braves and the Minnesota Twins, both of whom jumped from last place to the World Series, the Chicago White Sox (new park) and the Seattle Mariners (fans trying to keep them in town) were primarily responsible for the record.
In the first half of this season, the continued upswing in Atlanta and Minnesota and the new park in Baltimore have prevented the total attendance from falling even further. Camden Yards has drawn 547,637 more fans for the Orioles; the Braves are up by 552,067 and the Twins by 360,566.
Besides the Orioles and the Twins, only the Toronto Blue Jays (24,298), who sell out virtually every game, have had an increase in attendance in the American League. Attendance for the other 11 teams has decreased, ranging from 9,835 for the Boston Red Sox to 194,168 for the Texas Rangers.
The Rangers' decline, in fact, might have contributed to the decision last week to dismiss their manager, Bobby Valentine.
 
Searching for Answers
 Trying to find reasons for the general decline, Brown suggested the reasons that have been mentioned throughout the season.
"I think we had a bad spring for weather," he said. "That hurt us. The Yankees haven't drawn as well as we would like. That hurts. I don't know if the economy has anything to do with it. I would suspect it has something to do with it. You read that people are upset about the salary structure, but you come to workouts here yesterday and you have 40,000 people, so you wonder."
Fans may also simply be responding to poor and disappointing teams. Brown mentioned the Yankees, whose attendance is off 10.4 percent. With Yankee Stadium attendance down in each of the previous three seasons, Yankee fans have indicated that they will not tolerate the poor teams they have been provided.
Mets' fans have expressed their disappointment by staying away in such droves that Shea Stadium crowds are down 20.2 percent. The fans very likely are expressing their feelings about a team that is paying so much money to players who have failed to earn it.
The Los Angeles Dodgers, down by 15 percent, have suffered not only from a disappointing, inept team but also from the loss of four consecutive games earlier in the season because of the violence in South-Central Los Angeles. They recently made up the games as parts of doubleheaders, a loss of four dates and perhaps 140,000 in attendance (based on their average), which would account for about half of their decline.

SECTION: Section A; Page 20; Column 4; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 475 words

HEADLINE: Even in the U.S., Ideology Infects Language

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Doris Lessing ends "Language and the Lunatic Fringe" (Op-Ed, June 26) with a warning that those in former Communist countries now search, "perhaps not even knowing it," for another dogma. They need look no further than the United States.
While lavishing praise upon ourselves for having prevailed over Communism, we too have become enslaved by catch phrases and empty slogans -- and, not surprisingly, few of us realize it. I offer a few examples of some of the dead language of orthodox capitalism: 
 (1) "Economic Growth." This is the sacred cow of what passes for economic debate in our society, and its utterance instantly silences all policy critics of every stripe. We seem to have become convinced that economic growth is the most urgent goal of humanity, yet the United States economy grew from a $3 trillion yearly gross national product in 1982 to more than $5 trillion before this recession. I challenge anybody to prove that this enormous increase has made life better for any but a privileged minority, or that it is or will be environmentally sustainable.
(2) "The Consumer." This term straight out of economic theory has virtually replaced citizen or even person as the principal mode of reference to human beings by both the Government and the press in the United States. By acknowledging people only in the economic role that capitalism prefers to see them perform, we ignore the importance of contribution, cooperation and labor to society, reducing all human action and endeavor to a question of individual gain. Thus art, medical care and education are consumed, as we unconsciously endorse the privatization and capitalization of every sphere of activity -- a process whose ramifications need debate, not linguistically embedded complicity.
(3) "Compete." Ms. Lessing complains about Communism's strictly utilitarian approach to art and literature, valuing them only insofar as they were about something inimical to the socialist struggle. In the United States, all ideas about the renovation of our infrastructure, and even about education and health care, are evaluated mainly for their utility in helping us "compete in the world economy." The use of this slogan, a symptom of our insecurities in the face of economic decline, stifles us from imagining less mercenary reasons to stop punishing ourselves and start living as civilly -- if not as wealthily -- as the Germans or Japanese.
It is ridiculous in 1992 for serious thinkers to be sifting through the smoldering ruins of Communist thought for ideological infections. We might instead start examining how the uncritical acceptance of orthodox capitalism's dogmas by West and East is distracting humanity from taking rational steps toward surviving as a species in a world with limited resources.
 
JEFFREY F. OBSER
New York, June 28, 1992

SECTION: Section A; Page 20; Column 5; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 352 words

HEADLINE: Even in the U.S., Ideology Infects Language;
Long Before Marx

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Doris Lessing's contention in "Language and the Lunatic Fringe" (Op
Ed, June 26) that political correctness is the intellectual progeny of Communism is full of amusing, though apparently unintended, irony. Surely she must realize that political correctness is a pejorative coined by those who disagree with the prevailing values of academia in order to discredit them. That political correctness in one form or another has always existed in every human institution is self-evident: the phrase is only the latest weapon of choice in the battle of ideologues.
Attributing "pedantries and verbosities" and "language that seemed designed to fill up as much space as possible without actually saying anything" solely to Communism and its philosophical antecedents is either intellectual myopia or disingenuous posturing by Ms. Lessing. Euphemism, obfuscation and evasion: have they not been the hallmark of American politics since long before the advent of Communism? 
 Where could this linguistic malaise be more blatantly manifest that in our own legal and medical professions? And what of that bastion of orthodoxy enforced and responsibility avoided through Orwellian newspeak, the capitalist corporation? No, the corruption of language is hardly the exclusive domain of the Marxist-Leninist state, and we need not look to Kant, Hegel or Marx for the source of our failure to communicate.
That a writer held in such high regard is irritated by the demand that stories be about something strikes a particularly sardonic note. Does Ms. Lessing truly believe that mere description of what has happened (or been imagined) qualifies a written work as art?
Are not metaphor, allegory and myth, devices that express timeless ideas and universal experiences with such force, essential among the ingredients that distinguish literature from journalism, and have they not always been so?
Yes, there are perils in a dogmatic embrace of today's political correctness, but Doris Lessing ought to choose her bogymen a bit more carefully.
 
STEPHEN E. KILIANSKI
Nutley, N.J., June 26, 1992

HEADLINE: Once Again, Are You Better Off Today?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Are you better off today than you were four years ago?" This simple query is one of the most consequential questions that can be asked in politics, especially during a Presidential campaign.
Ronald Reagan, the Great Communicator, asked this question repeatedly on his way to winning the White House in 1980 and again in 1984. It's a question that's worth asking again during the 1992 Presidential election; but don't expect President Bush to ask it. 
 When it comes to the health of the United States economy, George Bush has been the single most unsuccessful President of the post-World War II era. For any four-year Presidential term since 1952, Mr. Bush's scorecard on economic policy shows the following:
The worst record for overall economic growth; the highest average annual budget deficit; the lowest job growth; the largest increase in the public debt; the lowest growth in personal income; the lowest number of housing starts; the only decline recorded in industrial production.
Despite Mr. Bush's record of economic negligence and neglect, it's certainly possible that some citizens are better off today than they were four years ago. But for the overwhelming number of Americans, even a great many living in Orange County, California, widely known as "Reagan Country," the answer to Ronald Reagan's frequently asked question is a resounding no.
Citizens who are better off today than they were four years ago will doubtless support the President. But most Americans aren't so fortunate as that. And if they render electoral judgments in November that are consistent with the logic of Mr. Reagan's question, then there will be a new occupant of the White House come next January.
 
MARK P. PETRACCA
Irvine, Calif., June 27, 1992
 
The writer is co-author of "The American Presidency" (1983).

HEADLINE: Rent Regulation Helps Keep the Middle Class in New York City

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"The Enduring Cost of Rent Control," your June 27 editorial attack on rent control in New York City, is ill considered and should be condemned.
Your newspaper, as much as any other source of power in the city, ought to be concerned with retaining the middle-class taxpayer. This class has been and is continually leaving New York, as the quality of life sinks under the burden of great pockets of drug dealing, crime, poor schools, dirty streets and other problems, which make our community less desirable as a place for people to live decent lives and bring up their children in a wholesome environment. 
 Many of the middle-class taxpayers continue to reside here only because our rent control and rent stabilization laws give them an element of economic security. Take steps to erode this fabric of protection, and the flow of outgoing taxpayers will resemble a flood.
The bill to decontrol luxury apartments, which is bottled up in the State Assembly, has been submitted only as a first step in getting rid of rent control. It seeks to introduce a means test to decontrol apartments renting for more than $2,000 a month, which are only a glut on the market anyway.
No new construction is discouraged by the rent control laws, since all new construction is free of controls.
It is too bad that many of the people pushing to eliminate rent regulations do not realize that in the long run, whether they be owners of apartment dwellings or others, the continued loss of desirable taxpaying citizens from our city will be a price too high to pay for the elimination of rent regulations. If it is asked when emergency rent regulations will be eliminated, the answer is that if we continue on our road to a depression, the market will make rent controls unnecessary because the controlled rents will not equal the lower market rents.
 
HARRIS L. PRESENT
New York, July 2, 1992

HEADLINE: Rent Regulation Helps Keep the Middle Class in New York City;
Never for the Poor

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"The Enduring Cost of Rent Control" (editorial, June 28) cites many problems with New York City's rent regulations but manages to perpetuate one myth: "It purports to help the poor afford housing."
None of the rent control or rent stabilization laws enacted or continued since World War II even mentions housing poor people. Protecting the poor is a banner supporters of rent control march under because it's less embarrassing than saying, "I've got mine, protect me." 
 The stated purpose of rent regulation is to prevent rent gouging in an emergency housing shortage created by, depending on the legislation's year, World War II, rampant inflation, "decline in private housing construction" or "proposed cuts in Federal assistance to housing programs." The idea is that if the market rent for a one-bedroom apartment in Queens is $600 and, because of the housing shortage, there is only one vacant apartment left, the owner cannot profiteer by charging $1,400 for that last apartment.
The greatest divergences from fair market rents in New York are the result of regulations that have kept the rents of long-term tenants low. Perhaps this has something to do with the decline of private investment in rental housing.
 
DAN MARGULIES
New York, June 29, 1992
 
The writer is executive director of Community Housing Improvement Program, which represents apartment owners.

HEADLINE: With Skilled Jobs Unfilled, Vocational Training Changes Course

BYLINE: By WILLIAM CELIS 3d

 BODY:
Once a backwater for students who were not college bound, vocational education is shedding its second-class image as more educators, business executives and policymakers view improved job training as an answer to many of the nation's economic and social woes.
But the rehabilitation will take many years and millions of dollars. American public schools have emphasized academics over vocational education for so long, educators and policymakers say, that most job-training courses offered in high schools are outdated. 
 As a result, vocational schools have produced hundreds of thousands of students over the last four decades whose abilities do not match the increasingly complex skills required for a growing number of jobs. This gap between graduates' abilities and job skills appeared in the 1950's and began to widen in the 1960's, then expanded rapidly in the last two decades and into the 1990's, educators say.
For decades, 20 to 25 percent of all high school graduates have taken vocational education, and for much of that time the quality of instruction met the demands of the job market.
 
Training Out of Step
 "Vocational education wasn't bad in the past, but it hasn't kept up with the times," said Dale Parnell, the Commissioner of the Oregon Community Colleges system and the author of "The Neglected Majority" (Community College Press, 1985), which examines how vocational education has failed students. "If we are going to help people prepare for high-performance work places, we have to change how we prepare them."
Supported by increasing sums of state and Federal aid, schools in growing numbers have updated their vocational curriculums with courses and equipment that allow high school graduates to move into the expanding technical and specialized segments of the job market. The graduates are working as nurses aides, medical technicians, medical-records keepers, X-ray technicians, graphic artists, paralegals and specialists in repairing computers and other highly technical equipment.
Some high schools, like those in Newark, have forged relationships with community colleges under the so-called tech-prep programs financed by the Federal Government. These programs allow a student enrolled in vocational education in public school to receive college credits. Once in college, the student takes job-training courses along with related academic classes toward a two-year degree.
Perhaps the most advanced state in improving job-training is Oregon. Last year it became the first state to redesign its high schools' vocational curriculums so that students can enter an apprenticeship job-training program after the 10th grade.
These students continue to take academic courses while working for businesses that will guarantee them jobs on graduation. The model has since been adopted, with variations, in Wisconsin, Rhode Island and North and South Carolinas.
 
Offering Outdated Courses
 But the vocational curriculums in many states have long been dated. Many automotive repair classes, for example, continue to instruct students about carburetors when more and more autos are being equipped with fuel-injection systems. In addition, while many high schools provide general vocational training in the rudiments of carpentry, plumbing, electricity and masonry, the instruction is not comprehensive enough to enable a student to be proficient in any of these trades.
But now employers' complaints have pushed states from California to New York to try upgrade vocational curriculums for a swiftly changing job market. An estimated 24 million jobs will be created through the year 2005, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, bringing the total number of jobs to 147 million in 2005, up from 123 million in 1990.
More than 20 percent of the expansion is expected to occur in jobs that involve high technology and specialized skills in the computer and health care industries. These jobs often command salaries that are competitive with those earned by college graduates.
"In one city after another, there is a shortage of qualified applicants for high-skilled, high-paying jobs and a great surplus of people applying for low-skilled, low-paying jobs," said Marc S. Tucker, president of the National Center for Education in the Economy, a research organization in Rochester. "Our whole system is geared to kids going to college. We do the least of any industrialized nation to educate young people for the workplace."
 
More Young People Jobless
 The shortage of adequate job training has led not only to higher unemployment rates among young people, Mr. Tucker said, but also to the sense of hopelessness that many people saw as a root cause of the Los Angeles riots. Forty percent of all high school graduates -- many of them black or Hispanic pupils -- do not go on to college, according to the National Center for Education Statistics. These students, along with another 25 percent who attend college but never complete requirements for a degree, go directly into the work force, with many of them winding up frustrated because of their lack of abilities.
This inability to perform highly skilled jobs was a major factor in a 1991 unemployment rate of 13.6 percent for those 16 to 24 years old, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. For high school dropouts, the 1991 jobless rate was even higher, 23.1 percent. The 1991 unemployment rate for all workers was 6.7 percent.
"There is frustration over jobs," said Jack Kyser, chief economist for the Economic Development Corporation of Los Angeles. "You have young people growing up in South-Central Los Angeles and seeing their parents working like dogs, and they sense there is no future for them. The system has failed them."
But bit by bit the tide is turning for students like Luisa Urbina, a vocational education student who graduated last month from Manual Arts High School in South-Central Los Angeles. Miss Urbina, who is 18 years old, worked during the school year at First Interstate Bank in the charitable trust department. After graduation she started work as a clerk trainee at the Atlantic Richfield Company, a job she hopes will lead to management.
"I'm not worried about the future, because I learned a lot about business in school," said Miss Urbina, who lives with her mother, a sewing machine operator. "My mother is happy for me because I'll have opportunities she didn't have."
Her school also offers job training in health-care, graphic arts and banking. And in the last five years, reflecting the growing reliance on technology throughout the job market, the school has initiated courses in the repair of mobile telephones and auto alarms.
"These vocational programs are designed to help students take their place in society," said Bernadette Graham, the career adviser at the school, where minorities make up more than 50 percent of the enrollment. "Minorities have never taken their place in society. That's when you get the frustration and the burning and the looting."
Other school districts moving to fill the job-training breach are asking local businesses to help them tailor curriculums to meet market needs. In Corpus Christi, Tex., for instance, where about 5,000 of 42,000 students are enrolled in vocational education programs, the school system dropped its welding courses after business executives told school officials that the job was largely a seasonal one. The district then instituted courses like computer-aided design.
 
Major Federal Support
 The expense of rebuilding vocational education nationwide has largely been absorbed by the Carl T. Perkins Vocational Education and Training Act, named for the longtime United States Representative from Kentucky whose interests included vocational education. The act, now in its third decade, was extended by Congress for another five years in 1990. It is providing $1.01 billion to schools in the fiscal year 1992.
Despite this infusion of money and the calls for urgent change, broad improvements in vocational education are expected to progress slowly. A philosophical battle goes on between academic teachers and vocational instructors over the continued emphasis on preparing high school students for college.
Vocational educators have long argued that emphasizing academics at the expense of job training hurts the very students -- many of them from minorities -- who need the most help from school to succeed in life.
The traditional low-priority treatment of vocational education "is partly racism and partly classism," said Mr. Tucker of the National Center for Education in the Economy, who argues that this is why vocational education remains underfinanced and outdated in many school systems.
Schools also have trouble finding teachers who are skilled in the newest technologies. Although the Perkins act is pumping more money into job-training curriculums, schools are still feeling the effects of the recession, which led to deep budget cuts and teacher layoffs.
"We really have to do much more with these students," said Morgan Lewis, a research scientist at Ohio State University's Center on Education and Training for Employment. "Vocational education evokes images of a second-class education, and it doesn't have to be that."

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; National Desk; The Convention

LENGTH: 1406 words

HEADLINE: UNDER THE BIG TOP -- THE OVERVIEW;
DEMOCRATS GIVE CLINTON THEIR BLESSING; CUOMO HAILS 'NEW VOICE FOR NEW AMERICA'

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER

 BODY:
The Democratic National Convention nominated Gov. Bill Clinton for the Presidency last night after Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York made an impassioned case for the man from Hope, Ark., and declared that the nation could not afford another Democratic defeat.
Mr. Clinton capped the emotional night with a joyous march from a restaurant in Macy's to the convention floor in Madison Square Garden a block away. Illuminated by floodlights and cascades of red, white and blue glitter confetti falling from the ceiling, Mr. Clinton strode into the convention hall, which was packed by roaring, triumphant Democrats. 
 Beaming a vibrant image to national television audiences, Mr. Clinton made his way slowly to the Arkansas delegation. He threw open his arms, shouted "I love you," and embraced his mother, Virginia Kelley, who had cast the first votes for his nomination.
He appealed, quite directly, to the memory of John F. Kennedy, saying, "The rules of the convention preclude my acceptance tonight, but 32 years ago another young candidate who wanted to get this country moving again came to the convention to say a simple thank you."
Earlier in the evening, Mr. Cuomo and Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, perennial favorites of the party's liberals, bestowed political blessings on the fifth-generation Arkansan who comes from a very different wing of the party. The Governor of New York hailed Mr. Clinton's character, his humble roots, his commitment to the party's traditions and values.
"It's time for change," Mr. Cuomo said, endorsing Mr. Clinton with far more spirit and passion than many had expected. "It's time for someone smart enough to know, strong enough to do, sure enough to lead. The comeback kid. A new voice for a new America." [Transcript, page A14.]
 
'The Man From Hope'
 The Governor of New York, who spoke to a rapt audience, declared, "Because I love New York, because I love America, I nominate for the office of the President of the United States the man from Hope, Arkansas, Governor Bill Clinton."
The convention then proceeded to the old, joyous ceremony of the roll-call of the states, ratifying what the primary voters had finished more than a month ago. Mr. Clinton went over the top, the necessary 2,145 delegates to win, at 10:54 P.M., when Ohio voted. The hall rocked with cheers, chants of "We want Bill" and Sousa marches in a demonstration that lasted 30 minutes.
Mr. Clinton, accompanied by his wife, Hillary, and his daughter, Chelsea, watched the packed and happy hall on television in Macy's. The convention could watch him, as well, on two huge screens high above the Garden floor.
Then, in a move that caught many of the delegates by surprise but was planned well in advance, he strode through the men's furnishings department, out into Seventh Avenue in a light drizzle, and headed toward the Garden. He was surrounded by cheering supporters, ecstatic from reports of new polls, reveling in the moment. Ronald Reagan made a similar visit to the Republicans' convention hall when he was nominated in 1980, as did Walter F. Mondale to the Democrats' 1984 convention.
The night was a triumph of strategy, endurance and simple fire in the belly for Mr. Clinton, who had plunged into this race when President Bush had been soaring in public opinion polls and the Democratic Party's heavyweights had turned away.
Mr. Clinton, 45 years old, from a tiny state that has never before produced a Democratic nominee, was beaming and clutching his daughter's hand as he watched the votes tallied. He wiped tears from his eyes as New Hampshire, the scene of his toughest primary battle, announced its votes.
Not since Jimmy Carter has a Southerner risen to the top of his party, and Mr. Clinton did so with a message that asserted that the party had to moderate its policies to reclaim the middle class and return to the White House. Last night, as the party rallied itself for an intensely competitive three-way campaign in the fall, Mr. Clinton was oratorically embraced by the tribunes of the party's Northern liberals.
Mr. Cuomo's speech began with an indictment of 12 years of Republican rule, which he asserted had rocked the middle class, devastated a generation of urban children, ravaged the economy with policies akin to Herbert Hoover's and left the nation angry and yearning for change.
 
'The Shining City'
 "This time, we cannot afford to fail to deliver the message, not just to Democrats but to the whole nation," Mr. Cuomo said. "Because the ship of state is headed for the rocks. The crew knows it. The passengers know it. Only the captain of the ship, President Bush, appears not to know it."
Mr. Cuomo's most compelling image, as the "shining city on the hill" was in his speech in 1984, was the notion of a national parade celebrating victory over domestic problems, just as the nation reveled after the Persian Gulf war. "So step aside, Mr. Bush; you've had your parade," Mr. Cuomo said. "It's time for a change."
With that, Mr. Cuomo ended a political saga: a primary year in which many expected the Governor from New York to be the principal challenger to the Governor from Arkansas. Clinton allies, who saw the advance text of the speech earlier in the day, said they were very pleased. One Democratic strategist, noting that it was a strong validation by a man who is probably the pre-eminent Northern Democrat, said, "There's always a problem with a Southern nominee in the Northeast, and this is a very powerful piece of politics."
Senator Kennedy, who ended his own doomed campaign for the nomination in Madison Square Garden in 1980, said Mr. Clinton "has sought to heal" across lines of race and class, as Robert F. Kennedy did. The Massachusetts Senator cast the Clinton campaign as the continuation of a long Democratic struggle for justice, equality and economic opportunity.
"I have stood with so many of you in so many great causes," Mr. Kennedy said. "The times have changed, but the ideals are the same. We will never give up. We will never give in. And in 1992, we are going to win."
In a mood of nostalgia and reconciliation, the Democrats began the evening with a film about Robert Kennedy that recalled the triumph and the poignancy of the Kennedy years, an era that left its mark on many of the delegates here, as well as on Mr. Clinton himself.
The delegates also finished some final business from the nominating season. Former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California saw his proposals for a sweeping review of party rules and procedures voted down by a group far more focused on defeating the incumbent Republican President. The Brown delegates robustly booed.
Mr. Brown, when he finally spoke on behalf of his own nomination, used his speech to denounce the "influence of power and money" that he said was behind "everything that's wrong with this country." The former Governor from California, who bucked the unity tableau throughout this week, stayed recalcitrant to the end and never mentioned his party's nominee. "I intend to fight for this party, tonight, tomorrow, this year, every year," he said, reiterating the themes of his angry, anti-politics-as-usual campaign.
 
Tsongas Leads Chant
 Former Senator Paul E. Tsongas, whose victory in the New Hampshire primary turned him into Mr. Clinton's most determined challenger for a time, was playing the loyal team player last night. Arguing that the party had a historic obligation to "create an inclusive and just society" and "insure economic security," the former Massachusetts Senator led a chant: "Never under George Bush; next year under Bill Clinton."
It was a night when the Democratic Party, fractious and often proud of it, was deep in the quadrennial ritual of anointing a new standard-bearer and pledging allegiance to him. Mr. Cuomo set the tone, recalling that he had warned of the cost of Republican inaction with his keynote address to the Democratic convention that nominated Mr. Mondale.
Mr. Clinton, who spent much of the day working on his acceptance speech, which he will deliver tonight, got other good news yesterday. The teamsters union, which backed the Republican ticket in the past three Presidential elections, announced that it was endorsing Mr. Clinton. "Bill Clinton is our best hope for getting this country moving again," said the union's president, Ronald R. Carey, echoing the Kennedyesque theme of the day.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 3; National Desk; The Convention

LENGTH: 1467 words

HEADLINE: UNDER THE BIG TOP -- NEWS ANALYSIS;
Bursts of Fire at an Orderly Convention

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr.

 BODY:
Last night, for a few sweet, fleeting moments, they finally let the Democrats be Democrats.
The managers at Madison Square Garden let former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California, the Peck's Bad Boy of this year's politics, spell out his plans to overturn the nefarious American "system." They asked Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts to evoke the glow of Camelot once more. 
 They let former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts, surely the year's most surprising Presidential contender, talk about his own quirky prescriptions for his party. And they called on the party's often Delphic orator in chief, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York, to set the place alight.
These were the losers, the men not nominated, the paths not taken, and there were contradictions aplenty. Mr. Tsongas wants the party to pay more attention to the needs of business, and Mr. Brown wants it to pay less, to cite an obvious example. Mr. Kennedy scorns the conspiracy theories of Oliver Stone, the film maker, but the Democrats gave the disputatious Mr. Stone a moment to speak for Mr. Brown.
The 4,928 delegates and alternates packed onto the floor and into the first balcony at the Garden didn't seem to mind. A little contradiction, a lot of zeal, a dose of the offbeat and a flash or two of ego supplied the ideal antidote for a convention in danger of choking on its own decorum.
Mr. Cuomo came on to the roll of kettledrums and the sight of red-and-white "We Love Mario" signs, then showed again his easy command of all the oratorical skills of another time, before television, when the likes of William Jennings Bryan and Franklin Delano Roosevelt captivated Democratic conventions.
Mr. Cuomo's voice rose and fell, his cadence accelerated and slowed; he was sarcastic at one moment, expansive the next, then full of scorn and fury a few minutes after that. As he had in San Francisco in 1984, he wowed his party and made not a few of its members wish he had run.
The delegates loved it when he attributed to President Bush "the politics of decline, decay and deception," when he said the country needed a President to halt a Republican attempt "to tell us what god to believe in, and how to apply that god's judgment to our schoolrooms, our bedrooms and our bodies," and perhaps most of all when he told the Democrats that the 1992 nominee was "an admirable aberration" in a world of "fragile and thin-skinned politicians."
Governor Cuomo's peroration echoed the New Deal and Fair Deal as he celebrated the old American verities -- verities that the American electorate once saw exemplified by the Democratic Party, verities the party yearns to make its own again this year as it pursues the elusive middle-class vote.
"I want to sing," he said in one of many soaring moments, "proud songs, happy songs, arm in arm with workers who have a real stake in their company's success, who once again have the assurance that a lifetime of hard work will make life better for their children than it's been for them."
 
Roll-Call and Commercials
 The time-worn, ever-popular hokum of the roll-call followed, complete with commercials for local industries, causes, attractions and heroes, and a few unity-bucking votes for Gov. Robert P. Casey of Pennsylvania and Representative Patricia Schroeder of Colorado. When Mr. Clinton went over the top, confetti poured from the ceiling.
A tradition-shattering visit by Mr. Clinton and his family, who walked several blocks to the arena from Macy's, closed the evening on an effervescent note, with the delegates' roars leaving no doubt they were pleased with their choice.
At conventions like this, with everything cut and dried, with nothing really left to fight over, eloquence is at a premium. And before last night only Elizabeth Glaser, a woman suffering from AIDS, and the Rev. Jesse Jackson had generated real bursts of emotional electricity.
Last night Mr. Kennedy came close as he opened the parade of not-quite-nominees to the podium: three who sought the Democratic nomination and failed to get it, and one, Governor Cuomo, who has never brought himself to enter the race, despite entreaties to do so for almost a decade.
 
1964 Tribute Recalled
 Mr. Kennedy's role was an eerie reprise of one of the most emotional moments in the recent history of nominating conventions. When the Democrats met at Atlantic City in 1964, John F. Kennedy had not yet been dead for a year, and his brother Robert F. Kennedy was called upon to introduce a memorial film.
For 16 long minutes he stood, unable to speak above the great roar of applause washing over him. Then he reduced uncounted millions to tears by quoting from Act III of "Romeo and Juliet": "When he shall die, take him and cut him out in little stars, for he shall make heaven so fine that all the world will be in love with night and pay no worship to the garish sun."
Last night Edward Kennedy, the last surviving male member of his generation of a family at once blessed and haunted, spoke after a film tribute to Robert Kennedy -- "gone now," as he said, "nearly a quarter of a century." The film was introduced by Representative Joseph P. Kennedy 2d of Massachusetts, Robert Kennedy's oldest son.
Senator Kennedy quoted not Shakespeare but the modern English poet Stephen Spender in remembering his slain brothers: "Born of the sun, they traveled a short while toward the sun and left the vivid air signed with their honor." And he found moving language of his own when he said of his brothers, "Their truest history is written in your hearts and the hearts of people everywhere who refuse to be content with things as they are."
Most of the delegates do not like Mr. Brown at all; they view him as a trouble-making upstart. But he delivered his radical message with verve -- denouncing what he called "government of, by and for the privileged," railing at the world of contacts and access and power brokers and pledging to "create power for the powerless."
His heavily outnumbered backers on the floor, mostly political neophytes, launched a high-spirited if carefully orchestrated demonstration. Amid the mass-produced placards, a hand-lettered sign stood out with a theme of last-ditch defiance -- "You can't paint a picture of unity with the paintbrush of suppression" -- but the crowd quickly subsided when asked to.
Bill Clinton's personal formula for electoral success -- his platform, his selection for Vice President, his orderly approach to things -- has shaped the 1992 Democratic National Convention. The watchwords here have been restraint, organization, unity and that old wet blanket, dignity.
The delegates accept it, at least most of them. Mr. Clinton won the nomination against all the odds, after all, and he has convinced them, at least intellectually, that his way is their best hope for taking back the White House this fall. But it is all a bit bloodless, satisfying but not thrilling, for a party that relishes a good brawl the way the Republicans relish a good balance sheet.
 
The Way Things Were
 When the convention voted down a commission for Democratic Party renewal early in the evening, the Brown forces booed and chanted. Mayor Maynard Jackson of Atlanta, presiding, quieted them easily enough, and he smiled a little at the brief reminder of the way things used to be.
The health police have taken away the smoke-filled room, and now the responsibility police have taken away the shouting matches that used to cause convention chairmen to shatter their gavels in frustration.
To Peggy Noonan, who has been watching the proceedings through the eyes of a speech writer for both Ronald Reagan and George Bush, the Democrats looked like "people fighting against their own nature."
Not during the nostalgic look back to the Kennedy era.
When Senator Kennedy called for a "return to the ideal of compassion" after 12 years of "wintry indifference" sponsored by the Republicans, his declaration sounded more like an endorsement of the values of Democratic campaigns past than an echo of this year's cool new rhetoric.
The Senator himself identified the whole liberal agenda: women's rights and abortion rights, gay rights and civil rights, health care and urban renewal, "war against poverty, not war against the poor." The thing that matters most about Bill Clinton, he said, is that "he has sought to heal."
Mr. Tsongas restated his central campaign themes, including his new brand of economics that Mr. Clinton often ridiculed in the primary campaign.
The elegant phrase has never been Mr. Tsongas's forte, but the Clinton campaign could find a worse battle cry than his plain-spoken indictment of the Bush and Reagan Administrations:
"They told us it was morning in America. They told us we could have it all. They lied."
