HEADLINE: Income-Based School Busing Stirs Anger in Wisconsin

BYLINE: By WILLIAM CELIS 3d

 BODY:
Four of nine members of the LaCrosse, Wis., School Board were defeated in a recall election Tuesday and two more were forced into runoff elections, as residents expressed anger over a plan to bus students based on family income.
The plan, believed to be the first of its kind in the nation, was designed to ease overcrowding in the district's 11 elementary schools and to break up large blocks of poor children who had been concentrated in two of the schools. Poor children are defined by the district as those receiving free lunches under the Federal school-lunch program. 
 By busing both affluent and poor students, the district hoped to ease the burden on teachers at schools with higher numbers of poor children, who often require more attention; enhance the education of poor children, and expose all children to a greater cross-section of classmates.
But this city of 51,000 has had virtually no busing before now, and voters, expressing their preference for neighborhood schools, rejected the school board's arguments. Since the busing plan has already been approved for a September start, it is not clear how the plan will change.
 
'Totally Frustrated'
 "The public was totally frustrated with a school board that was not listening to what the public wanted for its children," said Jay Hoeschler, a real estate developer and a member of Recall Alliance, a group that fielded six of the eight candidates who opposed incumbents. "They brought forced busing to a community that has no need for forced busing."
The four defeated incumbents lost by at least 1,000 votes each in an election in which 12,000 people, or 33 percent of the registered voters, cast ballots. The two others who had supported the busing plan trailed their challengers in three-way races and will meet Aug. 11 in runoffs.
The other three board members were not affected by the recall because they were elected in April, and under Wisconsin law an elected official cannot be subjected to a recall vote until after serving one year in office. Those three opposed the busing plan, and were elected on that platform.
"It was a well-orchestrated backlash on the busing plan," said Kenneth G. French, one of the four defeated board members. "The group that led the recall did a good selling job to a number of people."
 
Was Money an Issue?
 Mr. Hoeschler and other opponents of the plan said the recall vote also reflected demands from voters for more fiscal accountability. He asserted that the school district spent too much on two new elementary schools opening this fall to ease overcrowding in the system, whose 7,772 students include 3,500 of elementary school age.
John D. Parkyn, the chairman of the school board, said his defeat and those of his fellow board members also reflected confusion among voters over whether the vote was a referendum on school spending or on busing.
But the challengers said busing was the main issue. "Busing children on the basis of their parents' income at a time when busing programs are under criticism across the nation was very much the catalyst in the recall election," said Douglas Farmer, a bank executive who unseated Mr. French.
"Busing was behind the success of the candidates 100 percent," added Susan Knight, who is in a runoff with an incumbent, Roger Winter.
 
Plenty of Signatures
 Recall Alliance was required to collect at least 7,500 signatures for each of the six board members it wanted to recall. It began collecting in April and got 9,500 to 10,500 for each candidate. Although the board got an injunction against the recall from a state court, the group appealed, and a higher court ruled last Thursday that the election could be held.
Mr. Parkyn said he had voted for the busing plan in January "without hesitation" and would do so again. "We had to diversify our schools so that all our children could move ahead," said Mr. Parkyn, a nuclear engineer.
The Superintendent of Schools, Richard A. Swantz, said he plans to meet with the four new members Wednesday, when they take office, to determine what changes they want to make. A rollback of the plan is all but certain, some school officials and ousted board members said. But Mr. Swantz warned that if the new members tinker too much they could well set off another round of agitation in the community, which Mr. Swantz said had generally come to accept the plan despite the recall election.
 
Wide Disparities
 Under the plan conceived by elementary school teachers and principals, a third of the district's 3,500 elementary school students would have been bused, most for the first time. The plan was designed to disperse concentrations of poor students in two schools that amounted to 70 percent or more as against 3 percent in more affluent schools.
Reconfigured boundaries produced a mix in which no school had more than 50 percent of its students who qualified for free lunch. Before the redrawing, 71 percent of the pupils at Hamilton Elementary qualified for free lunch. In more affluent schools, like State Road Elementary, the percentage of poor students grew to about 20 percent from 3 percent, the district said.
Many of the poorer students are Hmong immigrants who have flocked to LaCrosse in the past 10 years. Of the 7,772 students enrolled in the 1991-92 school year, 84.9 percent were white; 11.7 percent were Asian, with most of that Hmong; 1.5 percent were American Indians; 1.4 percent were black, and 0.5 percent from other backgrounds. Administrators say the numbers of Hmong residents have forced the district to spend more to teach as a second language.
Busing experts and education policy makers who followed the LaCrosse plan said the district had embarked on a bold but risky move to address concentrations of poverty. But they maintained that the district had not explored other options to disperse students based on socio-economic factors. Magnet schools, they added, provide a more palatable way to encourage parents to participate in a busing plan.
Despite the election outcome, some parents still supported the plan and said leaders of the citizens' group had wrought havoc with children's lives.
"I like the fact that the schools were trying to balance the schools," said Grace Dahl, whose two sons would have been affected by the busing plan. "School is one place that should be a stable place for kids to go."

GRAPHIC: Photo: At the affluent State Road Elementary school, classes like this kindergarten, shown last January when the La Crosse, Wis., school board voted for busing, would see a 17 percent rise in students who receive government-sponsored free lunches. Opposition to the plan, which proposed transporting children from all income brackets, has resulted in a recall vote of four board of education members. (Steve Woit for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: New Talks Set in Pittsburgh Newspaper Strike

DATELINE: PITTSBURGH, July 15

 BODY:
Six unions whose members were laid off after a strike against a company that publishes two Pittsburgh newspapers decided today to meet to discuss the company's plan to resume operations. The newspapers have not published since May.
The company, The Pittsburgh Press Company, said on Tuesday that it intended to resume publication of one or both papers, possibly within 10 days, with or without an agreement with the striking union, Local 211 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters. 
 On Tuesday, as the strike by drivers and other teamsters members entered its ninth week, the company said it had discussed its plans with the teamsters local and with six other unions that represent newspaper employees, most of whom were laid off after the strike. These unions represent production and advertising employees.
The company's vice president and general manager, Jimmy E. Manis, said the strike had had a "detrimental effect" not only on the health of the newspapers but on the city's economy.
"We firmly believe that the time has come to put the interests of this community in the forefront," he said.
A spokesman for the teamsters declined to comment on the company's announcement except to say that it appeared to rule out "an amicable solution."
Mr. Manis's announcement may mean that only The Pittsburgh Press, which is owned and published by the company, will resume publication.
 
Unions 'Invited' to Return
 After his statement on Tuesday, executives of The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette, which is published by the company under a joint operating agreement, said there was no accord to resume publishing that paper. The Post-Gazette is owned by the P G Publishing Company.
Mr. Manis did not say how his company planned to distribute papers without the striking drivers, but he said the unions had been invited back to work.
"We've invited them to discuss, or negotiate, how to come back," he said.
The announcement also left open questions about whether editorial and other union employees that have not been on strike might be engulfed in the labor turmoil, blocking the company's plan to resume publication.
Neither newspaper has appeared since May 17, when truck drivers from Local 211 walked off the job over a stalemate in negotiations concerning the company's staffing plans.
The company is seeking to revamp its newspaper distribution system. The effect of adopting the new system would be to eliminate 450 of the 605 jobs now held by teamsters members.
A spokesman for the striking union, Joseph Pass, said on Tuesday: "It sends a signal that they're not looking for an amicable solution. It sends a signal that they want a confrontation."
But Mr. Pass said he would not comment on whether the union would try to prevent the distribution of the papers or whether union members would picket the building in which both newspapers are housed. He said it was not clear how the union would respond if the company resumed distribution operations. "We'll cross that bridge when we come to it," he said.
The Press has retained its entire editorial staff, which is producing a mail publication called The Allegheny Bulletin. The Post-Gazette has retained a skeleton crew of reporters and editors and is experimenting with fax transmissions and a radio network.
In addressing his staff on Tuesday, the editor of The Post-Gazette, John G. Craig Jr., quoted a statement by the newspaper's publishers saying that the paper had no agreement with the Press Company to resume publication.
In a cryptically worded statement, William Block Jr. and John Robinson Block, the paper's publishers, said they supported any effort by the Press Company to reduce costs of delivering papers. But they added that no agreement had been reached and that any such agreement would "have to serve the best interests of the newspaper."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (94%);

HEADLINE: Falling Costs Seen as Draw To Employers

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
Amid ample evidence that the New York metropolitan area remains mired in recession, a report yesterday by the Federal Home Loan Bank of New York said that declining commercial rents and a slowdown in wage increases were making the region more attractive to business.
Office rents across the region have plummeted by as much as 40 percent since the late 1980's, the study said. And while wages in the New York area remain far higher than elsewhere in the nation, the study found that the wage differences in some segments of the economy, including the retail-trade and the service industries, had begun to narrow. 
 "An extraordinary correction is under way," said Rae D. Rosen, the bank's economist and the author of the report. "New York is becoming a comparatively cheaper location for business."
 
A Battered Economy
 The study follows a series of economic setbacks for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, which are still reeling under a recession that has been longer and deeper than any since World War II.
Personal bankruptcies and business failures have soared recently. After a sharp increase in June, unemployment in the region is at its highest level in eight years, and consumer prices for utilities, health care, residential rents, taxes and other essentials have been rising faster than elsewhere in the nation.
These indicators have left some economic analysts suggesting that hard times still lie ahead.
But by focusing on those costs that have the most direct bearing on business -- wages and commercial rent -- the bank said it had uncovered strong evidence that the groundwork had been laid for recovery in the metropolitan region.
"What this tells us is that we are not going downhill forever," said Ms. Rosen. "The forces of supply and demand are are work, and the turning point is coming."
The Federal Home Loan Bank of New York is one of 12 federally chartered lending institutions across the nation that provide money to other banks and thrift institutions for mortgage lending. Because of its huge stake in the real estate market, the bank has traditionally engaged in detailed analysis of the regional economy.
The report said commercial rents, "the bedrock issue" for many businesses, had plummeted. Because vast amounts of new office space were completed just as the recession began and still lack tenants, it has become common to offer "concessions, decorating allowances, first-year free terms and other adjustments" to tenants, the report said.
The study is bolstered by recent reports by the real-estate industry reflecting a decline in rents on new leases for offices. Cushman & Wakefield, the region's largest commercial brokerage, said asking prices had declined 10 percent since 1988.
But the bank's report said that prices reflected in rent surveys "overstate the cost of most new leases" and that the price of office space has dropped by over 30 percent on many new leases and in some cases by as much as 40 percent.
"Firms that might have decided to move away have now decided to stay," Ms. Rosen said. "Those that stay will eventually begin hiring again."
Data compiled by the bank on wages show that labor costs in the New York region, which have for decades exceeded those in other cities and states, grew at a torrid rate in the 1980's, forcing employers to pay more than their competitors elsewhere in the nation.
The study said that the gap remains broad and continues to expand in some the region's most prominent, highest-paying industry. Banks, Wall Street investment houses, insurance companies and real estate concerns, all of which have cut deeply into their staffing, are nonetheless dispersing average paychecks more than 50 percent higher in the New York area than elsewhere, it said.
Overall, wages in New York State, which were 6 percent above the national average in 1980, had climbed to 20 percent above the national average in 1991, the report said.
 
A Narrowing Gap
 But the report also found that the gap had narrowed in retail sales since 1989, with merchants paying their employees in the New York area slightly less than 110 percent of the national average. In the service industries, including health-care, law and engineering companies, and a host of companies that provide business services, it said the difference between wages in the New York area and the nation stabilized last year.
Wages paid by the region's government agencies, public utilities and transportation companies have also been rising at slightly less than, or equal to, the national average, the report said.
Ms. Rosen said the wage increases have been held down by a growing pool of experienced workers who are either out of jobs or willing to accept smaller pay hikes. "New York will offer increasingly competitively priced construction, legal, financial, retail and service talent in the coming recovery period," the report said.
Business people said lower costs, or even a reduced rate of increase, were bound to encourage companies to stay in the region, and might help the region attract others. Among them was Ronald K. Shelp, the president of the New York Chamber of Commerce and Industry, which respresents 1,500 businesses.
"Every interview and every survey shows that business costs are the most important issues," he said.
"Anything that lowers or stabilizes costs will help sell New York," he added.
 
Obstacles Remain
 To be sure, not all analysts are as upbeat about the future of the New York metropolitan area. In a report on Monday, Elizabeth Holtzman, the New York City Comptroller, said rising consumer prices in the city may stand in the way of economic recovery. Since the end of 1989, consumer prices in the city have risen 15.9 percent, compared to an increase of 13.9 percent elsewhere in the nation.
"The city might not benefit from a possible national recovery because of the continuing rise in local inflation," she said.
But the bank's report said businesses are bound to respond to the easing pace of price increases, at least in commercial rents and wages, by making new commitments to the region.
A slow upturn "appears likely to develop as small retail establishments, financial firms and service-oriented firms discover they can afford to be in New York," she said, adding that the region's recovery was likely to begin in 1993. "The break-even point is dropping."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Issues Continue to Rise

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities moved higher again yesterday and interest rates, including long-term bond yields, moved lower.
Traders said that after several days of selling failed to push prices appreciably lower, investors were returning to the Treasury market. 
"There was a lot of profit taking on Friday and more on Monday and Tuesday," one government securities trader said. "Those people are all out of the way, and bids are coming in from all sorts of accounts."
Once again, much of the demand centered on shorter-term notes and bills. But as the spread between short-term and long-term issues continued to widen, some investors were beginning to buy bonds.
"Over the last couple of days retail customers have been looking to buy short-term securities when their prices fell," said Jay Goldinger, a principal in Capital Insight, a bond brokerage firm in Beverly Hills, Calif.
"But the short end hasn't dipped, so now investors are starting to reach for yield out the curve because they are frustrated by the strength in the short end."
In addition, analysts said bond prices were bolstered by rumors from Chicago that Argentina would need to purchase bonds in the open market as part of its debt refinancing plan. They added that economic reports this week have been favorable for the bond market.
"Most of the reports have either been in line with expectations or a bit better," said William V. Sullivan Jr., a senior vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds. "The weight of that evidence convinced some portfolio managers that it was time to extend positions further out the yield curve."
The three-tenths of a percent drop in industrial production reported for June by the Federal Reserve yesterday was largely in line with market expectations. Analysts had been expecting a decline after the Labor Department released extremely weak employment numbers earlier this month.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 percent 29 1/2-year bonds of 2021 were offered late yesterday at a price of 104 14/32, up 26/32, to yield 7.61 percent, compared with 7.68 percent late Tuesday.
Among outstanding Treasury note issues, the 7 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 104 15/32, up 21/32, to yield 6.86 percent. And the 5 percent two-year notes were offered at 101 16/32, up 5/32, to yield 4.19 percent.
Rates on short-term Treasury bills continued to fall, as expectations grew that continued weakness in the economy will force the Federal Reserve Board to cut short-term interest rates yet again.
Three-month bills were offered late yesterday at a discount rate of 3.16 percent, down three basis points, or three one-hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates fell by six basis points, to a late offered rate of 3.20 percent. And one-year bill rates fell by nine basis points, to a late rate of 3.31 percent.
The rally in the Government market came on a day when corporate bond issuance picked up after a couple of slack sessions.
Among the issuers yesterday were the Matsushita Electrical Industrial Company, which sold $1 billion worth of Eurobonds in London, and in New York the Long Island Lighting Company, which priced more than $800 million worth of debt securities.
In addition to those offerings, Bloomberg Business News reported that Goldman Sachs Group LP, parent company of Goldman, Sachs & Co., priced $400 million worth of 10-year noncallable notes.
The debt offering is highly unusual for Goldman, Wall Street's last remaining private partnership.
The 7.80 percent notes were priced at $99.80, to yield 7.829 percent, 93 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7 1/2 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricing.
The securities were sold as a private placement because the Goldman is not registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission as a public company.
Demand for the issue was so strong that it was increased in size from $250 million.
The securities are rated A-1 by Moody's Investors Service and A+ by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

HEADLINE: Rise in Sales-Tax Revenue Eases Suffolk Deficit and Layoff Plans

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HAUPPAUGE, L.I., July 15

 BODY:
A welcome increase in sales-tax revenues has eased Suffolk County's financial crisis and enabled officials to reconsider plans to borrow money, cut wages and lay off county employees.
After a year and a half of declining sales-tax revenues, collections in the county this year are up about 3.5 percent from the same period in 1991, with all of the gains coming in the second quarter. 
 "And if the trend holds, we may have enough to wipe out the 1992 deficit," said James Spero, deputy director of the County Legislature's Office of Budget Review. Earlier this year, budget analysts predicted a sales-tax shortfall of $25 million. That estimate has now been reduced to $14 million, about equal to the county's 1992 budget deficit.
"We couldn't be more pleased," said Tim Ryan, a spokesman for County Executive Robert J. Gaffney. "This is extremely encouraging." Citing an increase in tourism during the second quarter as a possible factor in the brighter revenue picture, he added, "We hope it's a trend that will hold."
 
Albany Cuts Crisis Aid
 Only last week Mr. Gaffney announced that the deficit in the county's $1.3 billion budget had been reduced from $91 million to $47 million. Most of that gap -- $36 million -- was left over from 1991; the remaining $11 million was for this year. Mr. Gaffney said the reduction in the deficit resulted from cost-cutting measures, faster payments from the state for social services and lower-than-expected pension costs.
Because of Suffolk's improving finances, negotiators in Albany today reduced the county's request for deficit borrowing power from $91 million to $71 million, according to Michael D. O'Donohoe, a Conservative and a member of the county's bipartisan legislative coalition. He said the bailout may still be necessary if the deficit ballooned again.
"But if the sales tax revenues continue to come in, we may balance this year's budget and use general-obligation bonds to pay off last year's deficit without asking for any help from Albany," he said.
Mr. Spero warned, meanwhile, that the county could be hit later this year by a sharp drop in property-tax revenues. He recalled that last year the county came up $100 million short because of nonpayment of taxes. "This left us with a real cash shortage," he said. "And there are no guarantees there won't be another shortfall this year."
All property taxes in Suffolk are collected at the town level, Mr. Spero said, then distributed to school districts, library districts, the towns themselves and finally the county, in that order. "The county is at the end of the line, and if the collections come up short, we end up holding the empty bag," he said.
He said the school districts get most of the property taxes collected by the towns, about 70 percent, while the county gets about 20 percent. Property taxes make up only 14 percent of the county's general-fund revenues, Mr. Spero said, while sales-tax receipts, which are collected by the state, contribute nearly 42 percent. State and Federal aid make up 30 percent, with the remaining 14 percent coming from various fees.
He said that Suffolk outperformed both the state and Nassau County in the second quarter. Sales-tax receipts for the state were up 1.3 percent, while Nassau's were flat.
Six weeks ago, the prospect of a $91 million deficit led Mr. Gaffney to propose an across-the-board 10 percent pay cut for county workers and the layoff of 1,300 employees, including 300 police officers. That threat has subsided, as has the threat of a property-tax increase, thanks to the higher sales-tax revenues. "Things are looking rosier," Mr. O'Donohoe said.
Mr. Gaffney and the bipartisan county legislative coalition are now discussing the possibility of dropping the layoff plan, reducing the pay cut to 5 percent and limiting it to 400 nonunion employees.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Money Funds' Yields Down, Hurt by the Fed's Rate Cut

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Money market fund yields dropped in the latest week, according to IBC/ Donoghue's Money Fund Report. Analysts said the Federal Reserve's cut in short-term interest rates two weeks ago continued to put pressure on fund yields.
Tax-exempt money funds suffered another sharp drop in yields. A number of investors who suddenly redeemed their municipal-bond holdings because of lower interest rates rushed to park that fresh cash in money-market funds. This forced yields down as the supply of short-term tax-exempt paper tightened. 
 In taxable funds, yields are down more as a direct result of the recent Fed easing on other short-term investments like Treasury bills, Federal funds and commercial paper.
 
'Out There on the Yield Curve'
 The seven-day compounded average yield for a tax-exempt fund fell 16 basis points, to 2.09 percent, while the simple yield eased 17 basis points, to 2.06 percent. Over the course of 30 days the compounded and simple average yields each fell 12 basis basis points, to 2.34 percent and 2.31 percent, respectively. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Donoghue's said assets of tax-exempt money funds rose by $4.4 billion, to a total of $97.3 billion. The average number of days left to maturity of tax-exempt securities held in fund portfolios fell 1, to 63, which analysts still called a long stretch. "That the portfolio managers are out there on the yield curve for this long a period of time also indicates that they are not fearful of interest rates suddenly going back up and taking them for a loss," said Walter S. Frank, Donoghue's chief economist.
For investors in the 28 percent tax bracket, the taxable equivalent of the current seven-day tax-free yield is 2.9 percent, while the equivalent for those investors in the 31 percent tax bracket is 3.02 percent.
In its weekly survey of tax-exempt funds with assets greater than $100 million, Donoghue's said the Strong Municipal Money Market funds, distributed by Strong/Corneliuson in Milwaukee, gave the best return for the fourth straight week, at 2.99 percent.
Yields in taxable money-market funds fell again, as assets rose $4.5 billion, to a total of $493.3 billion. Donoghue's analysts said it was right in line with how the gain was broken down. Institutional assets accounted for all the gain as they moved into money-market funds from other investments to the tune of $5.3 billion, for a total of $172.5 billion.
 
Retail Assets Decline
 On the other hand, the public pulled out $800 million from the so-called retail money-fund assets to seek higher yields elsewhere, perhaps in bond funds, analysts said. Retail assets thus fell to a total of $320.8 billion.
The average seven-day compounded yield for taxable money market funds was 3.29 percent, down 12 basis points, while the simple yield fell 11 basis points, to 3.24 percent. Over a 30-day period the compounded average yield is down 5 basis points, to 3.42 percent, and the simple is down 4 basis points, to 3.37 percent.
Analysts said the average days to maturity of securities in portfolios rose one day, to 63.
Olde Premium Plus Money Market Series, distributed by the Olde Discount Corporation in Detroit, again turned in the best yield for the week, at 4.12 percent, down 15 basis points from a week ago. The fund absorbs expenses and reflects it by offering a higher yield.
For the purpose of comparison, the average yield of a bank money-market account, the prime competitor of money funds, dropped 6 basis points, to 3.18 percent.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Ogilvy Gets Jaguar Account In Chief's First Big Victory

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT

 BODY:
FOR the fourth time in less than a year, a large automotive marketer has dismissed its longtime agency after a competitive, closely watched review.
In March, Jaguar Cars Inc. announced that its estimated $15 million account, at Geer, DuBois Inc. in New York since 1986, would be reassessed. And yesterday, Jaguar Cars, the Mahwah, N.J., American subsidiary of the troubled British luxury-car maker, said it would move the account, effectively immediately, to Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide in New York. 
 The decision was not surprising. For one thing, in the other three recent auto reviews -- Subaru of America, American Isuzu Motors and Mercedes-Benz of North America -- the incumbent shops lost. For another, Ogilvy has a lengthy, friendly relationship in this country and overseas with the Ford Motor Company, which paid $2.5 billion to acquire Jaguar Ltd. in 1989.
"A major change has taken place because we've been purchased by Ford," said Michael Dale, president of Jaguar Cars, "giving us dramatically different potential for Jaguar in the future.
"We needed a marketing partner," he added, "not just an advertising agency, to help us with all the things we need to grow into."
While Ogilvy "was picked because of its abilities" in areas like direct marketing and dealer relations, Mr. Dale continued, "I would be stupid not to say the fact it is a Ford agency would be of great advantage to us."
And it did not hurt Ogilvy that Charlotte Beers, its chairwoman and chief executive, owns two Jaguars -- one red, one green -- and was directly involved in Ogilvy's efforts to land the account.
"In some ways, it was my first show-and-tell," said Ms. Beers, who joined Ogilvy in April as the giant agency sought to stem a string of big account losses that by one estimate exceeded $70 million from prestigious clients like American Express and Campbell Soup.
Jaguar Cars is Ogilvy's first big gain since Ms. Beers's arrival. Though "I don't think we won because I own a Jag," she added, she expressed enormous satisfaction with the review's outcome, reading the headline on a staff memo: "Guess who's parking at Ogilvy?"
What was surprising about the decision was its timing. It came two weeks before the six finalists in the review were to present their strategic recommendations. (Besides Geer, DuBois and Ogilvy, the finalists were Carmichael Lynch in Minneapolis and three other New York shops: Margeotes Fertitta & Weiss, McCaffrey & McCall and Weiss, Whitten, Carroll, Stagliano.)
Ms. Beers said that Jaguar Cars had "canceled the review" because executives there were impressed with Ogilvy's "elite, highly intensive team" as well as the agency's resources and came to this conclusion: "If we're persuaded this could be a team that would be a true partner, why go anywhere else?"
Neal Gilliatt, the consultant who advised Jaguar Cars on the review, said the decision to cut it short was also attributable to the impending arrival of the 1993 model year.
In the course of two meetings held with each of the six agencies, he added, "I think we had an opportunity to look pretty carefully at the people, and their abilities and their way of thinking, without going into a final strategic presentation."
"It was felt, given the pressures, that Jaguar obviously had to get on with it," Mr. Gilliatt continued.
Among the pressures confronting Jaguar Ltd. are fierce competition in its high-priced segment of the auto market, a sales slump, a sluggish global economy and large losses. In the United States, Jaguar Cars sold 4,809 units in the first six months of this year, up 10.8 percent from the comparable period a year ago, a gain a spokeswoman attributed to a new leasing program called "Super Lease" that sent sales soaring in May and June.
The account loss is another blow for Geer, DuBois, which recently lost about $30 million of its total $120 million in billings even before the departure of Jaguar Cars, its second-largest client after the Paddington Corporation.
"It's a terrific marque," Stephen G. Bowen Jr., the agency's president and chief executive, said of Jaguar, "and I would've given my left arm if we'd really had a chance to keep it."
Since the loss was "not unexpected," he added, Geer, DuBois had already laid off about a dozen employees, reducing its staff to 75, and consolidated to two floors from four at its office at 114 Fifth Avenue in Manhattan.
"I'm giving us a year to replace Jaguar," he continued, "and I think we can do that." One decision the agency was glad to hear was Paddington's verdict in a creative shoot-out over the Stubbs rum account, with an estimated $3 million to $5 million in billings. Geer, DuBois retained it in a competition that also included three other New York shops: Ayer Inc., Grace & Rothschild and McCann-Erickson.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
S.&P. Stuns Bond Market By Cut in California Rating

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
The Standard & Poor's Corporation stunned the municipal bond market yesterday by announcing that it had lowered its ratings on debt securities issued by the State of California by two notches, to A+ from AA.
S.& P. said the downgrade, which affects about $13 billion of debt outstanding, reflected the state's continued weak financial position, "with little likelihood of improvement in the near future." 
 The ratings agency also criticized the state's "unprecedented and wide-scale" use of registered warrants, a kind of i.o.u., last used in California in the Depresssion, to meet its normal and recurring payment obligations.
At the end of its 1992 fiscal year, California had a budget deficit of some $3.8 billion. Estimates of the amount of red ink that might flow in the current 1993 fiscal year vary, but reach as high as $8 billion.
 
Impasse on Solution
 At present, Gov. Pete Wilson, a Republican, and the California Legislature are at an impasse over how to redress the deficit.
At a news conference in Sacramento yesterday, State Treasurer Kathleen Brown, a Democrat, called on the Governor to reconvene meetings with the Legislature as soon as possible.
"We are in political paralysis, and California is in a ratings free fall," Mrs. Brown said.
As recently as last December, California credit was AAA-rated. With yesterday's downgrade, it is one of the four lowest-rated states in the country.
Standard & Poor's lowered its ratings on California debt securities to AA from AAA on Dec. 13, 1991.
On April 28, as the state's economy worsened and the deficit swelled, the ratings agency placed California on its credit watch.
Because of the state's deteriorating financial position, municipal bond market participants had been expecting a ratings downgrade. But the magnitude of the drop came as a real surprise.
 
No Flood of Selling
 "A lot of people were suspecting half a jump rather than a full jump," said Peck Ferrin, a vice president and manager of the municipal bond department at the Bank of America in San Francisco.
Despite the surprise, Mr. Ferrin and other market participants who trade California debt issues said the downgrade had not caused a flood of sell orders.
"There was a lot of selling in state credits over the last couple of days in anticipation of a one-grade ratings decline," one trader in Los Angeles said. "But right now people are pretty much just scratching their heads."

HEADLINE: Industrial Output Off; Inventories Up

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
Manufacturing lost steam in June and inventories are piling up again, signs that feeble consumer and business buying is beginning to affect the nation's factories, mines and utilities.
"There is no acceleration in the economy's growth," said Allen Sinai, president of the Boston Company. "The rebound in production has faded." 
 Industrial production fell three-tenths of 1 percent in June, the Federal Reserve reported, and factory utilization slipped to 78.5 percent, its lowest level in three months, and down from 78.9 percent in May. Output growth in May was also revised down, from six-tenths of 1 percent to five-tenths of 1 percent.
In the meantime, the Department of Commerce reported, business inventories -- stocks of finished goods, work in progress and raw materials -- edged up one-tenth of 1 percent in May, the fourth straight increase.
Yesterday's reports suggest that the economy will do no more than muddle through the summer.
"You've had pretty weak sales and an inventory buildup," said Alan C. Lerner, a managing director of Bankers Trust. "These cycles usually take a while to work through."
Mr. Lerner expects the gross domestic product to slog along at a 1.5 percent annual rate in the third quarter -- about the same as in the second quarter and far too slowly to shave the 7.8 percent jobless rate.
 
Industrial Output
 The dip in industrial production came as no surprise. Earlier this month, the purchasing managers' index signaled a sharp slowdown in the manufacturing expansion, and the Department of Labor reported a loss of 58,000 factory jobs.
The two-day rail strike was responsible for a steep drop in coal output. But production of most other goods, including cars and consumer goods, also slipped.
The cutback in car production was unexpected and analysts do not think it will continue. Inventories are down to 55 days or so and car sales have been running at an annual rate of 6.5 million models for six weeks, well ahead of June's 6.1 million production rate.
"The auto industry had some pretty fancy production plans, and I'm not sure that demand warrants all that much more production," Mr. Lerner said. "But it warrants some."
 
Inventories
 The rise in inventories was the fourth monthly increase in a row, while business sales declined by two-tenths of 1 percent. A small decline in store inventories and flat wholesale stocks was offset by an increase in stocks of finished goods and materials in factories. The inventory gain in April was revised up to three-tenths of 1 percent from one-tenth of 1 percent.
This gradual accumulation of inventories, Mr. Sinai said, is likely to account for nearly all of the meager rise in G.D.P. in the quarter that just ended. "Final sales were flat," he said, referring to exports, consumer spending and business outlays on new plant and equipment.
More important, the ratio of inventory to sales, which had been hovering comfortably around 1.49, has suddenly increased to 1.52. Given that executives have repeatedly made it clear that they are determined to keep inventories to a minimum, this unwelcome development increases the likelihood that production will stay subdued.
"I think we'll see an uneven pattern, though not a string of negatives," Mr. Sinai said.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls as Fears Rise On German Bank Meeting

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar declined against most major foreign currencies yesterday in trading dominated by speculation about a meeting of Germany's central bank. Gold prices rose.
On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery gained $2.90, to $354 a troy ounce. A late bid at the Republic National Bank of New York quoted gold at $353.15 a troy ounce, up $2.55. 
 For a fourth straight day, traders seemed obsessed by today's scheduled meeting of Germany's Bundesbank central council. The mark continued to rise against the dollar amid predictions the Germans would raise interest rates, which would make the mark more valuable.
"There is a great deal of debate if they will raise rates and which rates they will raise," said John McCarthy, chief currency dealer for the New York branch of Abn-Amro Bank, a major Netherlands bank. "As a consequence, the mark was very strong today."
In late European trading, the dollar was quoted at 1.4770 German marks, down from 1.4890 on Tuesday. At the close in New York, the dollar was quoted at 1.4810 marks, down from 1.4845 marks the day before.
Mr. McCarthy said the latest economic reports on industrial production and business inventories had little effect on the dollar. The Government reported industrial production dropped three-tenths of 1 percent in June, while inventories gained one-tenth of 1 percent last month.
Currency analysts and economists said the figures were within expecations and showed continued weakness in the nation's economy, which bodes ill for the dollar.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 125.32 yen, up 0.37 yen from Tuesday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 125.05 yen. At the close in New York, the dollar fetched 125.10 yen, the same as late Tuesday's level.
In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.9260, up from $1.9140 late Tuesday. The pound quoted at $1.9225 at the close in New York, more expensive than $1.9200 late Tuesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's rates, included 1.3395 Swiss francs, down from 1.3425; 5.0050 French francs, down from 5.0120; 1,128 Italian lire, up from 1,125, and 1.19335 Canadian dollars, up from 1.19275.
Gold traded in London late yesterday at $351.85 an ounce, up from $350.75 bid an ounce late Tuesday. In Zurich, the bid price was $351.10, up from $348.40 late Tuesday. In Hong Kong, gold rose 42 cents to close at a bid of $351.18.
Silver prices also rose. Silver traded in London at a bid price of $3.95 a troy ounce, up from Tuesday's $3.94. On the New York Comex, silver for current delivery was quoted at $3.940 a troy ounce, up from $3.938 a troy ounce the day before.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Leaner Times, Meaner Times

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
HARD times could put Bill Clinton in the White House. But they could bury his Administration, much as they threaten George Bush's. Does the Arkansas Democrat have the right stuff to fix the economy?
Mr. Clinton, it is safe to say, has been too busy raising money and acting Presidential to figure out how he would get from here to there. But in contrast to Ross Perot and George Bush, candidate Clinton has delivered a remarkable amount of protein along with the empty rhetorical calories. And it appears that many of the strategic choices that would drive his economic policies have already been made: 
 Deficits are here to stay. The Clinton economic issue broadside calls for halving the Federal deficit by 1996. But Martin Feldstein, the Harvard economist and sometime adviser to Republican Presidents, points out that Mr. Clinton is just taking credit for what is likely to happen anyway.
Most of the planned reduction, he notes, would come automatically with the economic recovery already under way. And most of the rest would come from unspecified savings in government administration and closing tax loopholes -- a process Benjamin Friedman of Harvard finds "all very similar to Reagan's planned savings from eliminating fraud, waste and abuse." Thus, in the most plausible scenario, the economy would reach full tilt at mid-decade with a "structural" deficit close to $200 billion.
One explanation, Mr. Feldstein suggests, is that like George Bush, Mr. Clinton does not have the courage to challenge the incredibly expensive pension and medical care subsidies that old folks, both rich and poor, now demand from Uncle Sam. The other, which economists generally view more charitably, is that beefing up investment is more important than trimming the deficit.
"The reason for opposing deficits," Mr. Friedman said, "is that they soak up savings" going into investment. Thus if the Clintonauts are really serious about tilting spending toward public investment, tolerance of deficits would not seem nearly as damning.
In a pinch, Washington can pick winners. In apparent homage to the ideas of Ira Magaziner, a Rhode Island business consultant who advises Mr. Clinton, the campaign plan bubbles with enthusiasm for infrastructure: "Just as constructing interstate highways in the 1950's ushered in two decades of unparalleled growth, creating the concrete foundations of the 21st century will help put Americans back to work and spur economic growth." All told, Mr. Clinton would channel $50 billion more a year into bricks and mortar and educated minds.
Alicia Munnell, the research director of the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston, thinks "the basic thrust is correct." She is convinced that America invests too little and that private markets cannot do the job alone.
But Ms. Munnell worries that objective "cost-benefit" criteria will not be used to separate the cheetahs from the tabbies. And the Clinton plan offers little to relieve her anxieties: While the Congressional Budget Office has estimated that exceptionally high returns in public investment often come in mundane areas like road repair, the plan targets hot-button technologies ranging from toxic waste treatment to high-speed passenger trains.
The working poor come first. While the choice of Al Gore for Vice President has been widely interpreted as a bow to the Rainforest Crunch bunch, Mr. Clinton's economic heart still apparently belongs with the people who count their change at Taco Bell. Indeed, Gene Sperling, the campaign coordinator for economic issues, makes no secret of the fact that Mr. Clinton scrapped the promise of middle-class tax cuts in order to be able to pay for programs that coax the poor off welfare and into the world of work -- everything from a national apprenticeship program to beefed-up Federal wage subsidies.
This commitment draws rave reviews from Rebecca Blank, an economist at Northwestern University, who argues that "the biggest problem the country faces in labor markets is the decline of earnings of the unskilled." However, it is going to be a tough one to sustain politically.
Research suggests that mainstreaming the poor is doable but expensive -- and thus bound to be resented by voters working harder than they ever expected to meet their mortgage and car payments. Only a big jump in average earnings is likely to take the pressure off. And that is mostly in the hands of the capricious gods of productivity growth, who have not deigned to smile on this economy since Cadillacs had fins.
The sobering reality is that lean times have left the next President with little room for economic maneuver. More sobering still, an effort to reinvest in people and places would take years to bear fruit. If Mr. Clinton is elected, his toughest job may be to preach sacrifice and patience to an electorate grown cynical on voodoo economics.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Goodrich Net Jumps by 57.8%

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

DATELINE: AKRON, Ohio, July 15

 BODY:
The B. F. Goodrich Company, citing strength in its aerospace products and services segment, said second-quarter net income rose 57.8 percent.
Net income rose to $13.1 million, or 43 cents a share, from $8.3 million, or 25 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter a year ago. Revenue increased 3.2 percent, to $657.3 million from $637 million. 
 Operating income rose in the aerospace products and services segment, with strong performance in the commercial aircraft wheel and brake unit, Goodrich said.
In specialty chemicals, operating income declined to $13.7 million from $18.7 million as demand for construction sealants declined with the sluggish pace of commercial construction. Demand for roofing maintenance products and adhesives was also limited.
Goodrich said third-quarter earnings should continue to improve, but the magnitude of the increase would depend on economic conditions. The company's stock climbed $1.125, to $44.625, in trading today on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: Arts Czar Of Berlin: Power and Problems

BYLINE: By JOHN ROCKWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BERLIN, July 13

 BODY:
Cultural bureaucrats lead shadowy lives, lost behind the brilliance of better-known artists and directors. Which is as it should be. Yet some such bureaucrats wield enormous power and use that power to shape a city's or a country's cultural life in ways that are ultimately as lasting as those of any single artist.
Take Ulrich Roloff-Momin, for instance. As the Berlin Senator for Cultural Affairs, Mr. Roloff-Momin probably has more power than any other cultural official in the world aside from Jack Lang. Mr. Lang's long tenure as Minister of Culture in the highly centralized French system makes him easily the world's foremost cultural politician. 
 In no other country is there a national figure like Mr. Lang, but Mr. Roloff-Momin runs him a reasonably close second. While Germany gives an enormous amount of public money to the arts, that money is apportioned through a federal structure in which individual states -- Berlin is simultaneously a city and its own state -- exercise decisive power.
As Berlin's cultural senator, Mr. Roloff-Momin is head of an agency of 210 cultural administrators and oversees an annual budget that in 1992 consists of nearly $600 million. By comparison, the 1992 budget of the National Endowment for the Arts in Washington, meant for the entire United States, is only $174 million.
 
More Than Just Money
 Berlin's beehive of cultural activity draws nourishment from the subsidies Mr. Roloff-Momin's agency dispenses, freeing arts institutions from the need to court the broadest popularity or to spend time beseeching corporations and foundations and wealthy (and often conservative) individuals for support.
But Mr. Roloff-Momin does far more than merely dole out subsidies. He is also responsible for choosing those who run Berlin's theaters and orchestras and opera houses. In theory, once an administrator has been selected, that person is in charge of further artistic and financial decisions and is protected from political and bureaucratic interference. In practice, Mr. Roloff-Momin's power reaches still further.
For example, he chose Georg Quander to be the administrative director of the German State Opera in the heart of the former East Berlin. But he also cooperated closely with Mr. Quander in signing the conductor Daniel Barenboim to become that theater's artistic director.
The major limitation on his jurisdiction is the Prussian Cultural Foundation, controlled by the federal Government in Bonn and intended to oversee the former property of the Hohenzollern monarchy. It still has the decisive say at the big museums. But that may change when a new law to reorganize relations between the states and the federal Government is negotiated in 1995.
What remains under Mr. Roloff-Momin's control, however, is a huge area excluding private galleries and commercial film theaters but including just about everything else, from the grandest institutions down to community centers. "Whoever sits in this position has to concern himself with the widest possible range of culture," Mr. Roloff-Momin explained.
 
Unifying Parallel Worlds
 There is yet another, vitally important aspect to Mr. Roloff-Momin's activities. It is he who must make nearly all the basic decisions involving the enormously complex process of coordinating often parallel cultural institutions in the former East and West Berlins. What to do about two Academies of Art, two Museums of Asian Art and on and on?
It would seem to be a job destined to make enemies. Asked recently at an outdoor cafe in Berlin's Dahlem district if there had been complaints about his near-absolute rule, Mr. Roloff-Momin -- who has a sense of humor -- said, "Not that I'm aware of."
He may be right, at least in that he seems to have managed to make fewer enemies than almost anyone else in his position might be expected to do. An example of his persuasive powers was his treatment of two competing choral groups, one from the East and one from the West and both regarding themselves as the legitimate heir to the city's foremost amateur chorus, the Singakademie.
The groups were at loggerheads, unable to agree on a unification plan. Instead of forcing the issue, Mr. Roloff-Momin invited both to a dinner at the old East Berlin city hall in May of last year. After a friendly speech and a good deal of city-supported alcoholic lubrication, the evening ended in a spontaneous sing-along. In the wake of cheery and teary protestations of good will, a unification plan arose from the groups themselves, rather than being imposed from on high.
 
The Subtler Pressures
 In the United States, governmental arts support is often paralyzed by political controversy. In Europe, given centuries-old traditions of monarchical underwriting of the arts, overt political interference is more muted. Still, political pressure manifests itself in subtler ways. Mr. Roloff-Momin tries to minimize politics by remaining unaffiliated with a political party, although he adds quickly that he is ideologically close to the Socialists.
Berlin's municipal Senate is chosen by the elected Parliament of the state of Berlin. The senators then appoint themselves to the various jurisdictional areas. A lawyer, the 53-year-old Mr. Roloff-Momin was for 13 years the head of the University of the Arts in West Berlin. He has been cultural senator since early 1991 and must report on his activities every two weeks to a Senate standing committee.
Despite his successes and seeming popularity, his job has not been easy. Germany is feeling the unexpectedly high costs of reunification, coupled with the worldwide recession. Berlin's $600 million cultural budget includes about $130 million from the federal Government in Bonn. But that has been cut recently, and the task of deciding just what economies must be made has been passed on to the heads of the city's cultural institutions.
 
Answers for Critics
 Like all Berliners, Mr. Roloff-Momin hopes that Bonn gets around soon to passing a formal "capital contract," wherein Berlin will receive an agreed-upon sum annually from the national Government that will include culture. Now each year's level of federal support must be dickered for, with politicians from Bavaria and the Rhineland and elsewhere not always sympathetic to Berlin's special needs.
There are those who complain about Berlin's three opera houses and eight symphony orchestras, for instance. But with three and a half million inhabitants, Berlin has, by Mr. Roloff-Momin's calculations, roughly the area and the population of the Ruhr district, with nine opera houses. The Berlin budget breaks down to a $175 per citizen for culture, compared with $535 in Frankfurt.
"Berlin is a model for the rest of Germany," Mr. Roloff-Momin argued. "If we choose a good person -- Barenboim, for example -- that is a signal to the other cities that they should press for similar quality. But if we began to eliminate theaters, then other finance ministers would do that, too." So far, he adds, no theater or major cultural institution in the western or eastern parts or the city has had to close, despite a rather grimmer record in surrounding eastern Germany.
The main objections to Mr. Roloff-Momin's tenure seem to revolve around his appointments, especially in the area of theater. Partly to resolve unification personnel problems, he has shown a penchant for cumbersome committee rule, as in the recent naming of five well-known directors to run Brecht's old theater, the Berliner Ensemble. Or the equally unwieldy directorate at the combined Berlin State Theaters, which has just broken up in bitterness.
Still, whether any other system or person could do a better job is open to question; certainly there seems to be no campaign to replace Mr. Roloff-Momin. The Culture Senator himself presses forward, seeking to resolve differences, steer his charges through economic and political shoals and support any new institution or idea that comes forward and appears to deserve public money.
"If it's good," he said, summarizing an attitude far removed from the angry impoverishment of American cultural politics, "it will get support."

HEADLINE: Character vs. Caricature;
Can Bill Clinton Be Trusted?

 BODY:
In 1988, he nominated Michael Dukakis with a speech voicing anguish over America's lack of concern for children. But no one remembers that; the 19-page address brought groans from a Democratic Convention that had barely five pages of patience. It was, someone gibed, either the longest nominating speech or the shortest Presidential candidacy in history.
This time around, Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas has shrewdly and tirelessly persevered to win the nomination. Tonight, following Gov. Mario Cuomo's stirring nomination last night, he goes before the 1992 Democratic Convention to make another speech, to rally the public to his own candidacy. But if he is to succeed he'll need more than wit and energy. He'll have to confront a bigger, simpler subject: trust. 
 Even in ordinary times, it's hard for unknowns like Jimmy Carter or Michael Dukakis to establish themselves as Presidential timber. It's even more difficult in this era when the public mistrusts all politicians. It's harder still for Bill Clinton. He had hardly presented his fresh face to New Hampshire primary voters before it was defaced with one mud pie after another -- accusations of adultery, ducking the draft, fudging about marijuana, improving on the truth.
The medieval trial by fire has become today's media trial by electronic fire; and he survived. Even so, fairly or not, the doubts persist and Americans are left to ask, Can the public trust his character? Tonight he has the opportunity to transcend the caricatures. Instead of being judged by isolated incidents and hostile allegations, he can define himself in terms of lifetime values, preached and practiced.
How well he does that will help answer the related question, Can the public trust his leadership? Governor Clinton has so far done a laudable job of telling where he would lead. He argues persuasively that the only way to compete in the new global economy is to invest in people -- in their education, training and productivity.
It's a cogent plan. Productivity surely is the key to economic growth. But investment requires money, and so far Mr. Clinton has barely begun to tell where to find it. He calls for dismayingly small cuts in defense and no large tax increases, and exaggerates administrative savings, especially in health care. The failure to capture the peace dividend alone is enough to raise worries about how well he would stand up to Congress.
There have, however, been some hopeful signs of candor at the convention. The keynoter Barbara Jordan, for instance, solemnly pronounced the need for "Equity of sacrifice. That idea says that we will sacrifice for growth, but that everybody must join in the sacrifice, not just a few."
It would be reassuring to hear words like that from the nominee. There must be room, somewhere between empty oratory and suicidal candor, to express a commitment to sharing the burden.
Sharing the burden: That could also be a motto for America's relations with the world. Can the public trust his global leadership? With the end of the cold war, the President may no longer be The Leader of the Free World. But he remains the most important one. Mr. Clinton talks sense about a list of foreign issues, but it's still a list. He would make a stronger case with a larger vision. What, for example, does he think should be the relationship of the New World to the New World Order?
 Finally, Can the public trust his leadership on political integrity? Money and politics is no longer the passion of a few good-government goo-goos. Voters everywhere say they are disgusted. It's small wonder, as political action committees pour millions into the campaigns of legislators who then vote for billions in benefits.
Governor Clinton's record on this subject is exemplary -- as reassuring as President Bush's surrender is repellent. Mr. Clinton has had to struggle for campaign funds in part because he refuses to take any PAC money. He supports limits on campaign spending. He supports ending the flow of underground sewer money to candidates. He favors easier voter registration. These are all reforms the President has just vetoed.
There is one puzzle. Politicians often say the right thing and duck when the time comes to do it. That's one reason for what Bill Clinton describes as the "wall of cynicism" he faces from voters. But here's an area in which he demonstrably does the right thing; what's puzzling is why he doesn't say more about it. This is one subject on which he already has earned the treasure of trust.

HEADLINE: Essay;
The Me-Too Democrats

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

 BODY:
If Russia can abandon Communism, the Democratic Party -- in a New York minute -- can say goodbye to income redistribution, the essence of liberalism.
"Growth" -- the economics of the bigger pie -- is the unabashed message of Clintonomics. "Why not change from a party with a reputation of tax-and-spend," intoned the keynote lecturer Barbara Jordan, "to one with a reputation of investment and growth?" 
 While Republicans want to stimulate that growth through tax reduction, Democrats want to stimulate growth through government "investment" (never say "spending") in training and technology. Different painless paths, same growth goal.
Ex-liberals will continue to waggle a vestigial digit at F.D.R.'s "economic royalists," but they know that not even confiscation of the incomes of millionaires will put a dent in the deficit. The Clinton platform admits that the passion to redistribute income is as outdated as the cold war.
If conservatism has won, why are conservatives in danger of losing in '92? We can rightly claim that the "misery index," adding inflation to unemployment, is half that of the dismal Carter years, with today's interest rates falling and the stock market rising, but who cares? Mr. Bush is running against a party that is stealing his clothes of growth.
The ticket of the broad shoulders, Clinton and Gore, is electable, as the Perot aberration is not (that summertime tent is not a political home, and will fold). The buoyant Democrats offer a contrast to the present lassitude and rhetorical aimlessness of the Bush White House.
In a nutshell, the 1992 campaign is about aspects of personal freedom embodied in the word "choice." In education, health care and product or environmental regulation, Republicans stress personal choice and local option, while Democrats prefer national standards and less choice; but when it comes to abortion and the toleration of dissent, Democrats are for personal freedom while Republican dogma calls for national prohibition or restrictions.
How have the Democrats, in convention assembled, presented their aspects of freedom? Not as well as I had hoped; in his desperation to differentiate his convention from the divisive gatherings of the past, Bill Clinton shut down dissent.
He was right to demand a pre-convention endorsement from Jesse Jackson before giving him a speaking slot, because the irreverent reverend has chosen the celebrity of talk-show host to the nitty-gritty of political office. (He called King Herod "the Dan Quayle of his day" in a silly display of Salome tactics.)
But Clinton was wrong to demand prior allegiance from Jerry Brown, who came with 600 hard-earned delegates. This allowed the far-out Californian to pop off on prime-time newscasts before he was begrudged speaking time from the podium. The foolish Clinton muscle-flexing showed an intolerance of diversity and a tendency to be a sore winner.
The same desire to run a well-dressed, orderly, Republican-style convention slammed the door on anti-abortion dissenters. Gov. Robert Casey of Pennsylvania, whose state's abortion restrictions were upheld in the superb Supreme Court decision reaffirming Roe v. Wade, was shut out. Clinton's message: No pro-lifers need apply.
That politics of exclusion opens an opportunity for Republicans at their Houston convention. In contrast to the lockstep-enforcement in Madison Square Garden, the anti-abortion Bushies could give podium time to pro-choice Republican women. A respectful hearing -- with a stern no-booing admonition from the G.O.P. convention chairman -- would dramatize the "big tent" idea and the intolerance of the Democratic Convention.
But that is next month's controversy. For Democrats coming home to their party today, it makes good sense to acknowledge defeat of an economic ideology, to come up with an adaptation that can be labeled a third way.
Such "me-tooism" makes sense. What rings false, however, is the spectacle of the party of the people on its best behavior, meekly following its script.
Clinton's platform "covenant," like the word "convention," is rooted in the Latin convenire, "to come together, agree." His followers rightly agree on wrenching ideological change. But must Democrats forsake their lusty diversity in aping Republican discipline? Sometimes party unity asks too much.

HEADLINE: Stop Legal Harassment of Our Trade Partners

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Trade Gap Too High? Export a Few Lawyers" (Business Day, July 2), an otherwise insightful look at trade complaints by American steel companies, fails to expose the real problems of the growth of dumping suits against foreign companies. The unmanageable Comprehensive Trade Act of 1987, which many dubbed the "full employment of Washington lawyers and lobbyists act," has abetted legal and political harassment of foreign products and companies. 
 However, many Americans are not aware that greedy bedfellows of United States steel executives, unions, Washington lawyers and their friendly politicians are gouging billions of dollars at the expense of American consumers and businesses. They are gutting the technological and employment bases of the economy.
Under the camouflage of "dumping," "export subsidies" and "fair market value," American plaintiffs manipulate their numbers to prove their complaints. Foreign defendants cannot expect fair hearings from the International Trade Commission, the supposedly neutral adjudicator staffed by President Bush's appointees, which sides overtly with American plaintiffs. The commission is giving foreign defendants only five minutes each to rebut more than 30,000 pages of American complaints.
American steel companies state that a mere 6.5 million tons a year of flat steel imports are hurting them, while they sell 45.5 million tons a year of comparable products. Eliminating 6.5 million tons of imports would increase by 20 percent the price of $385 a ton. Such a price increase would provide windfall and monopoly profits of $2 billion a year to the United States steel industry. The foreign import pressure to modernize the industry would also disappear.
No wonder that the steel companies are willing to spend $30 million in legal and lobbying fees to get a $2 billion-a-year return indefinitely. It is not foreigners but American consumers and businesses that would pay dearly for inflated prices and inferior quality of American steel products.
Since automobile and other industries imitate the greedy steel industry, Americans would lose more. The United States automobile industry got a taste of such lucrative legal investment last month. A groundless dumping charge against Toyota and Mazda mini-vans stopped the imports of Japanese mini-vans and increased the prices of American mini-vans by 20 percent. Only American society as a whole lost badly.
Legal harassment of competitors has let American businesses and unions avoid facing the real causes of their economic decline: archaic management, self-serving executives and manipulative lawyers. With Presidential leadership adrift, in an increasingly fractious society, industry blames competitors for problems of its own making, and it costs the United States legal expenses of $120 billion a year. That's more than is spent on research and development.
Besides prison guards, prison facilities and private security businesses, legal harassment is the only growth business in the United States. Not only does it add little to America's technological and employment base, but more important it is also pushing American and foreign businesses to reduce American operations and take their jobs abroad.
To counteract legal and political harassment, Japan and other countries will begin to retaliate. Japanese steel companies that have helped American steel companies with money and technology will pull support from the United States steel industry. The Japanese Government is waking up to let American businesses in Japan taste a dose of their own medicine of frivolous legal harassment.
When similar retaliation spreads from Canada to Europe, from Korea to Brazil, worldwide trading and investing systems will further collapse. Is this the price Americans are prepared to pay in addition to the immediate $2 billion a year additionally to the United States steel industry and its lawyers?
 
YOSHI TSURUMI
Professor of International Business
Baruch College, CUNY
Scarsdale, N.Y., July 2, 1992

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: DIALOGUE: Adrenaline for the Economy -- Whose Road to Prosperity?
Clinton: Spur Growth

BYLINE: By Robert B. Reich; Robert B. Reich, a political economist at Harvard's
John F. Kennedy School of Government, is an economic adviser to Gov. Bill
Clinton.

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
Gov. Bill Clinton's plan to revive the economy calls for some carefully focused private investment. But the centerpiece is public investment, which in the emerging global economy is critical.
 The Administration's economic record, the worst since Herbert Hoover's, stems from the failed "trickle down" logic of supply-side economics. Today, private investment does not necessarily trickle down: it trickles out to wherever around the world it can get the highest return. 
A country's major asset, on which its future standard of living uniquely depends, is its people -- their education, insights and skills -- and the infrastructure supporting them. Private investors worldwide can be induced to create good jobs in a country only by a skilled work force, first-class transportation and communications systems and cost-efficient energy supplies.
 Germany is building "smart" highways and expanding its apprenticeship system. France has a national program for worker retraining and an information network linking all homes. Japan is extending its high-speed inter-city railways. Most industrialized nations provide early-childhood education and health care.
 In contrast, the U.S. has turned its back on public investment. Since 1980, the Government has cut funding of education, training, child health and infrastructure by a third.
 The Clinton growth strategy calls for $219.5 billion in new public investment over four years. About half this sum would be invested in people -- insuring healthy infants and children, fully financing Head Start, creating good schools, giving school dropouts a second chance, providing kids who are not going to college with apprenticeship training, enabling all eligible students to pay for college, retraining workers and helping people off welfare and into jobs.
 The other half would connect major cities by high-speed rail, reduce highway congestion through "smart" roads, control toxic wastes, develop clean and efficient energy sources, link every home and classroom to a national information network and upgrade urban transportation, water and sewage systems.
 The Clinton plan would raise $295 billion -- enough also to give some tax relief to the middle class and to reduce the deficit; the deficit would be halved by 1996, mostly through faster economic growth. The investments in people would be financed largely by a tax increase on the top 2 percent of income earners (yielding $92 billion over four years) -- the only Americans whose after-tax incomes grew during the 1980's and whose share of the national wealth soared.
 About a third ($43 billion) of the infrastructure investment would be financed out of defense cuts. It would spur the conversion of our military technologies into world-class transportation, communication, energy and pollution-control technologies. The remaining revenues would come from other spending cuts and the closing of corporate tax loopholes.
 Some parts of the plan could be accelerated to jump-start the economy right away. Several infrastructure projects could create jobs immediately. But many payoffs would not come for years -- when today's kids become productive members of the future work force.
 The plan, requiring accountability, would set tough performance standards for schools and training programs, require that college loans be repaid out of future earnings or community service and use the line-item veto to block pork-barrel projects. Bill Clinton's plan sets the right direction and priorities for America's economic future. Instead of rewarding a few at the top and relying on capital to trickle down, it nurtures the grass roots of our economy -- where our work force is.

SECTION: Section A; Page 25; Column 2; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 612 words

HEADLINE: DIALOGUE: Adrenaline for the Economy -- Whose Road to Prosperity?
Bush's Plan Means Jobs

BYLINE: By Roger B. Porter; Roger B. Porter is Assistant to the President for
Economic and Domestic Policy.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
President Bush has advanced a comprehensive economic program to create jobs and increase the standard of living for all Americans. His growth agenda is based on three convictions about America and the 1990's.
 First, we must invest in our future. A wise nation does not consume its seed corn through excessive current consumption. It makes sound investments in plant, equipment, research, development, infrastructure and the education and training of its people. 
Second, growth must be our first priority. Rather than arguing about how to divide the economic pie, the Bush plan focuses on how to enlarge it.Third, we must strengthen our global competitiveness and maintain our position as the world's leading exporter. Protectionism sacrifices prosperity for the many to achieve security for the few. Reducing trade barriers enhances competition, creates jobs and expands opportunity.
 These convictions rest on the President's belief that markets allocate resources more efficiently than Government bureaucracies, that economic growth is essential to achieving our aspirations as a society and that we need not fear foreign competition.
 Investing in the future requires increasing private savings and reducing public borrowing. The President's proposals for flexible I.R.A.'s, an investment tax allowance, enterprise zones and capital gains will stimulate greater private savings. His proposals to eliminate 246 unnecessary Federal programs, reduce others and cap the growth of entitlements (while fully protecting Social Security) represents the only detailed plan to date to restrain the growth of spending and balance the budget.
 The President's budget focuses resources on those most in need, seeks record Federal investment in research, development, infrastructure, training and education and expands funding for children.
 Generating growth also requires stimulating technological innovation, removing unnecessary regulations and reducing litigation. We must also invigorate the energy, telecommunications and banking industries by enacting the President's reform proposals.
 Central to economic growth is an educated, skilled work force. The national education goals advanced by President Bush and all 50 governors have been followed by the President's America 2000 education strategy, already embraced by 45 states, in the largest bipartisan effort to revolutionize our schools in America's history.
 The fundamental reality of the 1990's is that the global economy has become increasingly integrated, whether measured by trade in goods and services, investment flows or financial arrangements.
 Ours is the largest national economy, with the highest productivity per worker. In the last two years America has again become the world's largest exporter. Since 1986, exports have accounted for nearly two million new jobs.
 U.S. leadership has brought us within reach of success in the most ambitious global trade negotiations ever undertaken and in forging a North American Free Trade Agreement with Canada and Mexico. Both agreements will mean more and better jobs.
 Future economic historians will emphasize two factors that have contributed to economic frustration for many Americans. First, the money supply grew far too slowly for far too long. Economic growth was sacrificed in an abundance of caution over the fear of rekindling inflation. Second, for three successive years the Congress failed to enact the President's economic growth proposals. Recently lowered interest rates should help, but what is most needed now is a majority in Congress deeply committed to economic growth and willing to enact the President's growth agenda.
