HEADLINE: THE DEMOCRATICS TICKET: SONS OF THE SOUTH;
Presidential Ticket Sprouts From Soil of 2 Tiny Farm Towns 450 Miles Apart

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOPE, Ark., July 14

 BODY:
Both places have telephone books as thin as pocket Bibles and, as unlikely as it seems, they both now have native sons on the Democratic ticket.
In recent days the candidates have made a point of claiming the towns -- Hope, Ark., the birthplace of Gov. Bill Clinton, and Carthage, Tenn., home to his running mate, Senator Al Gore -- as cradles of early thought, emotion and values, places that despite the 450 miles between them may even unite the men in some fundamental way. 
 "I've never been to Hope, Ark., but I'm told it's just like Carthage in one respect," Senator Gore said when he was invited to join the ticket. "It's a place where people know about it when you're born and care about it when you die."
 
Myths in the Making
 In the case of both men, the connection between biography and geography is complex, since they each spent much time growing up in other places. But both communities are now caught up in a bit of geographic myth-making by admiring friends and family, egged on by candidates who sometimes assert that they remain small-town boys at heart.
Hope draws both its name and location from the railroad, which established it as a whistlestop in 1873 and named it after a manager's daughter.
Much has been written about Mr. Clinton's modest economic roots, with his mother widowed months before his birth. But in Hope, as elsewhere, disadvantage is relative. Asked if Mr. Clinton grew up underprivileged, Falba Lively, his mother's cousin, grows incredulous. "Bill?" she exclaimed.
"They were a little more fortunate than the rest of us, because we didn't even have electricity," said Ms. Lively, 61 years old, referring to the farmhouse outside Hope where she was living when Mr. Clinton was born.
Mr. Clinton left Hope after the first grade, spending the rest of his school years with his mother and stepfather in the more cosmopolitan setting of Hot Springs, a resort town. Then he added addresses at Georgetown, Oxford and Yale to his list of formative residences.
But as parochial as Hope and Carthage may seem, both managed to provide the future politicians with a broader range of acquaintances than they might otherwise have known.
Mr. Clinton would often join his grandfather at his dry-goods store north of the railroad tracks, where he sold goods to black field hands and laborers. Many of his friends and relatives, swayed no doubt by their affection for the Governor, insist that the experience planted the seeds of racial empathy.
"That's where he learned to respect the Afro-Americans so much," said Dale Drake, a 78-year-old cousin. "His grandfather taught him to never, never be ugly to anyone, no matter what color, what anything -- poor, rich, or otherwise."
On a later visit home from college at Georgetown, Ms. Drake said, Mr. Clinton angered his mother by convincing her maid to quit, telling her she deserved a better job.
Neither place has produced race relations that fit antagonistic Southern stereotypes. In Carthage, a picturesque hamlet of 3,500 in the Appalachian foothills, 95 percent of the population is white, and race has not been much of a civic issue. In Hope, a prairie crossroads of 10,000 people, a third of the population is black. So is the town's former Mayor and its only practicing obstetrician.
If Mr. Clinton has now given Hope a taste of fame, it takes credit for occasionally reminding the Rhodes Scholar of the people's priorities.
Ms. Lively remembers a visit after his defeat in his first campaign for re-election as Governor. "Daddy told him, 'You raised the car license fees that's why you lost," she said.
Mr. Clinton returned to office two years later, and he has not lost an election since.
Four hundred and fifty miles northeast, Carthage is a smaller, greener and older place, more hilly and a bit more prosperous.
Median household income in the surrounding county is $23,000, about halfway between figure of $17,000 in the county surrounding Hope and the national average of $30,000.
It too was an isolated farming community a generation ago. Like Hope, it is now caught in transition from an agricultural past to an increasingly industrial future, with factories sprouting where fields once stood.
The Gores like to tell a story about the whittlers who while their days on the courthouse steps. They are said to have called Mr. Gore's Vice-Presidential bid the town's second-biggest event, after the opening of the Wal-Mart store several years ago.
But Mr. Gore is just one of Carthage's famous politicians. Before him was his father, Albert Gore Sr., who served in both the House and Senate. And the previous Carthage generation produced Cordell Hull, Franklin Delano Roosevelt's Secretary of State.
In childhood, Mr. Gore split his time living in Carthage and Washington, where he attended an elite preparatory school before moving on to Harvard. But when not in Washington, he spent summers and vacations working on his father's 218-acre farm three miles east of town. He now has his own home on an 88-acre plot a stone's throw away.
These days the original Gore farm appears more manor than tobacco patch, with its chicken shed converted into a heated indoor pool. But in his youth Mr. Gore sometimes stayed for weeks at a time with the farm manager's family, who still did not have indoor plumbing.
Like them, he groomed cattle and chopped tobacco, although neighbors said the family later stopped growing it after Mr. Gore's sister died of lung cancer. The Gores had more than 300 head of cattle on the farm. The walls of the father's spacious kitchen are lined with pictures of the younger Mr. Gore showing cattle at county fairs.
"His introduction to saving the earth was right here on his daddy's farm," said the elder Mr. Gore, linking early rake work to prevent soil erosion to his son's current aspirations as an environmentalist.
If it took some effort to make the transition from attending preparatory school to working as a farm hand, the younger Mr. Gore apparently did not let it show.
"He just had a knack of fitting in," said Gordon Thompson, 47, whose parents managed the Gore farm. Mr. Thompson remembers traveling with Mr. Gore to county fairs to show cattle, sleeping in straw stalls, and comparing the bruises left when the cattle stepped on their feet.
 
Seeing 'the Other Side'
 "He's seen the other side of people who're a little less fortunate than he was," Mr. Thompson said.
Mr. Gore's father has even suggested that his son's early friendships with laborers who were being drafted into the Vietnam war may have influenced his decision to go, despite the youth's opposition and ample opportunities to join other privileged sons in devising escapes.
But another picture on the Gore kitchen wall serves as a reminder that this was no ordinary farm boy. In it, the elder Mr. Gore is dressed in tails, bidding young Al goodbye as he leaves his Washington residence for a White House ball. "As we turned to go," the senior Mr. Gore said, pointing toward the photo, "he hollered out at me: 'Dad, keep that outfit. I may need it someday.' "

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN -- PRESIDENT BUSH;
Bush Switches From Trout And Fishes for Perot Voters

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOULDER, Wyo., July 16

 BODY:
President Bush abruptly broke into a wilderness fishing vacation today to scramble for the remains of Ross Perot's political support, at the same time opening the door to putting Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d in charge of the White House and Bush campaign.
In a brief telephone message to reporters and in a news conference later at a desolate Air Force outpost here, Mr. Bush said he was confident that voters who had backed Mr. Perot's independent candidacy would support his re-election now that Mr. Perot had decided not to run for President. 
 But at the same time the President sent the strongest signal yet that he might recruit Mr. Baker, his Wyoming host, to the White House to help rejuvenate the struggling Bush campaign.
Asked whether he would lay to rest rumors that the Secretary would be changing jobs, Mr. Bush replied: "No, I can't resolve it here today at all. I know nobody will believe this, but it is 3 o'clock in Wyoming, and honestly, I have not talked about that with Jim Baker yet."
"Always, when I'm talking to an old trusted friend, all options are open about what I talk about," the President continued. "But what happens is pure speculation."
He noted that Mr. Baker "has a full portfolio" now, leaving Saturday for the Middle East to try to speed negotiations between Israel and its Arab neighbors. "But after that," Mr. Bush added, "who knows?"
The President's impromptu media blitz, orchestrated from Mr. Baker's 1,700-acre ranch where the two men and two of their sons are fishing, clearly tried to keep his campaign in the minds of Perot backers on a day when his remaining rival, Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, dominated the news.
Mr. Bush first talked to reporters about Mr. Perot's decision by satellite phone from the bank of a river on Mr. Baker's ranch. But that message proved too scratchy and muddled for television, and he later summoned the reporters 75 miles from Jackson, Wyo., to the outskirts of Boulder to speak to television cameras.
 
An Unusual Occurrence
 Mr. Bush's news conference, on a barren, brush-covered prairie nearly two hours from any town of measurable size, was among the most unusual in recent years. So remote was the locale and so hastily arranged was the session that television reporters were unable to acquire phone lines or satellite dishes to broadcast the session live. Instead, videotape was rushed by the state police 75 miles to Jackson for relay to network headquarters.
Standing before a backdrop of sagebrush and mountain foothills, the President made his case to Mr. Perot's backers.
"I see this as a positive development, in a sense," he said, "because I am convinced that the conservatives who support Ross Perot -- the legions of conservative people -- will end up being with me, because I think they share the same values I am talking about."
Earlier, Mr. Bush said Mr. Perot's backers were "basically conservative people" who fretted about the erosion of family values, the stagnant economy and rising Federal deficits, and crime and other social problems.
 
To Forgive and Forget
 Mr. Bush said he told Mr. Perot he would welcome an endorsement from the Texas billionaire, who has been described by Vice President Dan Quayle and other Bush surrogates as a "temperamental tycoon" with no known political philosophy beyond a contempt for civil liberties. Only last month, the President condemned as "beyond the pale" news reports that Mr. Perot had once investigated his background and that of his children.
Today, all was forgotten and forgiven as Mr. Bush sought to identify his campaign with the fears and frustration of those who had fueled Mr. Perot's squall-line campaign for the Presidency. In his telephone message, Mr. Bush said he had called Mr. Perot "on a very personal basis" to express admiration for his campaign.
"We will make it clear to all those Perot supporters that we share many of their same principles and that we want their support, and that we welcome them warmly into our campaign," the President said.
 
A Break for the Trout
 The speed and intensity of the White House reaction today seemed to underscore the importance that Mr. Bush's strategists attached to Mr. Perot's withdrawal from the Presidential race.
The President was fishing at about 9:15 A.M. on the second day of a two-day trout-fishing expedition with Mr. Baker when Samuel K. Skinner, the White House chief of staff, called with news of Mr. Perot's decision not to run for President. That was 15 minutes after Mr. Perot's televised announcement.
Mr. Bush talked to Mr. Perot and decided to make two statements to the press within the next three hours.
In Washington the Bush campaign chairman, Robert M. Teeter, issued a statement saying Mr. Perot's grass-roots campaign had "clearly touched a chord with the American people."
The President seemed relaxed and almost laconic at his news conference. Some questions were greeted with a dry wit, such as a query as to whether he had offered congratulations to Mr. Clinton on his nomination, as he had to Mr. Perot on his withdrawal.
Mr. Bush's eyebrows rose. "Oh, no, I forgot to do that," he said to laughter. "Maybe I can do that now. He fought hard, he won his party's nomination and, having been there before myself, I can say that's no mean achievement."
But that was the end of the generosity. "We'll go to general quarters in the fall," he said. "Because we differ on almost everything."

HEADLINE: RATE OF MARRIAGE CONTINUES DECLINE

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 16

 BODY:
Even as "family values" have become a central theme in the 1992 Presidential campaign, newly released Government statistics show that the decadelong decline in American marriage rates accelerated sharply last year.
The figures, from the National Center for Health Statistics, were followed today by new Census Bureau data showing that in 1991, one in four Americans of ages 18 and older, about 41 million people, had never married. In 1970, that figure was about one in six adults. 
 Sociologists and statisticians speculated today that the most likely causes of the drop in marriage rates were economic hard times combined with demographic shifts that have reduced the number of young adults, the age group most likely to marry.
The proportion of Americans getting married in 1991 was lower than any year since 1965, a year when the oldest members of the post-World War II baby boom were just coming into prime marrying age.
While divorce rates peaked in the 1980's and have been leveling off, the drop in marriage rates was accompanied by continuing increases in single-parent families. Between 1970 and 1991, the Census Bureau reported, "the proportion of children living in two-parent living arrangements declined from 85 percent to 72 percent, while the proportion living with one parent more than doubled, from 12 percent to 26 percent."
There were sharp differences in these statistics for whites and blacks. More than half the nation's black children, 58 percent, were living with one parent in 1991, compared with 20 percent of white children.
The statistics also showed more people postponing marriage, especially men. Last year, 17.6 percent of men in the 35-to-39 age group had never married, up from 7.8 percent in 1980. For women, the increase was almost as sharp: Never-married women, who were 6.2 percent of females in the 35-to-39 age group in 1980, accounted for 11.7 percent of the same group in 1991.
At all age levels, black men were disproportionately represented in the "never married" column. For instance, 31 percent of black men ages 35 to 39 had never been married in 1991, up from 18.5 percent in 1980 and 15.8 percent in 1970.
The Census Bureau data also showed that in almost all age groups from 25 to 74 more than a quarter of black men were not living with a spouse, a parent or with children. Only between the ages of 40 and 44 did the percentage of black men not in such family groups fall below 25 percent, to 23.7 percent.
For white men, the rate of those not living in a family group peaked between the ages of 25 and 29 at 28.3 percent, then declines rapidly. In the 40-to-44 age bracket, for example, 15.8 percent of white men do not live in family groups, and that rate drops to 12.9 percent between aqes 55 to 64.
"This pattern is distinctively different for blacks and whites," said Robert J. Willis, who directs the economics research center of the University of Chicago's National Opinion Research Center. He said the differing patterns of marriage and family were evident not just in the less-educated segments of society but show up in surveys of high school graduates as well.
He also said that many statistics involving marriage, child-bearing and child-rearing indicate that recent trends among whites have been mimicking earlier trends among blacks.
For the population as a whole, he said, "My own hunch is that the decline in marriage rates has something to do with the recession. Marriages tend to be accelerated or postponed depending on the state of the economy."
The median age at first marriage has also been increasing. It now stands at 26.3 years for men and 24.1 years for women, higher than at any time in the last century, and continuing long-established trends, he said. For women, he said, "there are two activities that are extremely time-intensive: bearing and raising children, and establishing yourself in a career."
"A lot of people are trying different ways of sequencing them -- marriage first, then babies, then career, or getting established in a career first, then marriage or babies." he said. "It seems to me until people have found a right way to travel through this, it'll be very difficult to predict how these statistics are going to change."

HEADLINE: Feud Over Geothermal Water Rights Pits Yellowstone Against a Church

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CORWIN SPRINGS, Mont., July 9

 BODY:
Two of the worst neighbors in the West are at it again, feuding this time over the underground currents of hot water that make up the world's largest geyser system and define the character of Yellowstone National Park.
The park and its neighbors to the north, the Church Universal and Triumphant, led by Elizabeth Clare Prophet, have been at odds ever since church leaders moved their headquarters here in 1986 and began installing an elaborate system of underground bomb shelters. But the latest fight, over geothermal water rights, has brought Congress into the act. 
 Last month, the Senate began considering legislation to prevent landowners from tapping into underground reservoirs of hot water bordering the park; this led church members to untap a geothermal well on its property and fill a swimming pool.
 
Effects on Geysers
 Yellowstone officials were infuriated by the opening of this vein of pressurized water about 10 miles north of the park. Church leaders, citing a geological study, said their well would not affect Yellowstone's geysers. But scientists at the park say one hole in the system could lead to other wells that would eventually drain the system.
Ultimately at stake, says Yellowstone's Superintendent, Robert L. Barbee, is no less an icon than Old Faithful, which is to geysers what the Statue of Liberty is to monuments. Old Faithful, which erupts every 78 minutes on average, is Yellowstone's biggest tourist attraction.
"It would be a national tragedy if something were ever to happen to this park's geothermal features," Mr. Barbee said. "We can't afford the risk. If you let one hole be punched into the ground around the park, why not 10, then a hundred?"
With 60 percent of the world's geysers on its 2.2 million acres, Yellowstone National Park is in the largest geothermal basin on earth. The hot springs, gurgling mud ponds, geysers and steam vents that run through Yellowstone provided the initial impetus for the move to protect the area in 1872, when Yellowstone became the first national park.
Last year, the Old Faithful Protection Act was introduced in Congress as a way to assure that Yellowstone's geysers were not weakened by outside development. But that bill, which passed the House in November, has been stalled in the Senate by advocates of property rights.
When church leaders untapped the well on June 30, they said they wanted to establish a property right to the water so they would be compensated if Congress banned geothermal development around Yellowstone. The well was dug in 1986 but had not been used.
The church, which owns more than 28,000 acres in Paradise Valley, just north of the park, will seek a payment of up to $450,000 if it is deprived of the use of the well, said Edward L. Francis, the church's vice president. Mr. Francis is married to Elizabeth Clare Prophet, the spiritual leader of the church, who said she was directed by God to establish her religious headquarters in the valley.
 
Fears of Money Seekers
 Yellowstone officials and many environmental groups view the church's action as a provocative stab in a long- running conflict between the park and the church. They worry that other landowners around the park, seeing a potential to make money from the Government, could start drilling into geothermal aquifers with the intention of demanding compensation.
In California, Nevada, New Zealand and other places with active hot springs and geysers, developments have drained the natural features of their energy.
"We know that punching holes into the source of geothermal features will eventually ruin them," said John Varley, the chief naturalist at Yellowstone. "So why take the chance?"
 
Constitution Is Cited
 Church leaders say they also want to protect Yellowstone's geysers and hot springs. But they say constitutional guarantees of private-property rights are at issue. They cite a provision of the Fifth Amendment that prohibits a Government from "taking" property without providing just compensation.
Last month, the Supreme Court ruled that the Government must take into account a property owner's economic loss when restrictions are placed on land use. But it is unclear how the decision will apply to the numerous cases of property owners' fighting environmental regulations. The groups battling those restrictions have not rallied to the side of the Church Universal and Triumphant.
It has never been established whether the church even has a right to the hot water that it has pumped from a well 450 feet deep. The church claims that right, but last month Montana state officials said it had no such right in an opinion by the state land use agency.
But the church's critics see other motives.
"This is not a taking," said Represenative Pat Williams, a Montana Democrat who introduced the Yellowstone Protection Act. "The church has no right to such a well. What they have done is place Yellowstone Park in real jeopardy."
Western Republicans on the Senate Energy Commmittee have considerably weakened the bill, Mr. Williams said. The Republicans say they are trying to assure that property rights are not trammeled by the legislation.
The Greater Yellowstone Coalition, the largest environmental group in this area, called the church's untapping of the well "a transparent attempt to pump a geothermal aquifer or the Federal Treasury."
Scientists are not certain exactly how wells drilled into the church land would affect Yellowstone's features. A study by the United States Geological Survey found that the well, if it pumped water at a relativeley small rate, would not hurt the park's geothermal features. But if the pumping were to accelerate and drain the underground reservoir, the Federal scientists said, it "could conceivably cause adverse effects on thermal features in Yellowstone National Park."
The geothermal controversy is the latest in a series of conflicts between the church and its neighbors. Paradise Valley, a high-mountain ribbon of cottonwoods and wild animals, has still not got over an episode three years ago when church members prepared to go into their underground fallout shelters.
Mrs. Prophet has repeatedly raised the prospect of imminent nuclear war. To prepare for such a catastrophe, the church built a shelter for 700 staff and family members and then decreed that all developments on other church-owned land must have fallout shelters.
State officials have held up approval of the shelters ever since April 1990, when 32,500 gallons of fuel leaked from tanks at the shelter complex.
Some Yellowstone officials have also said the church's ranch activities had been detrimental to elk and bison herds, which sometimes roam outside the park in the winter. Church officials say they have gone out of their way to accommodate the animals.
The church headquarters is on a ranch once owned by Malcolm Forbes, the late publisher. The Federal Government had a chance to buy the land in 1980, but turned it down. The church bought the ranch for about $7 million.

HEADLINE: Bids Opened For Altering Of Shoreham

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON

DATELINE: GARDEN CITY, L.I., July 16

 BODY:
The Long Island Power Authority received bids today from three consortiums to convert the Shoreham nuclear power plant to a natural-gas-fired plant by the mid-1990's.
Richard M. Kessel, the chairman of the authority, said, "The fact that the consortiums consist of well-respected energy firms from all over the country shows that the state was prudent in reaching out to determine if there was an alternative use for the plant. 
 "And if we can show that converting Shoreham will allow us to be economically competitive, it will also allow us to move ahead and reduce our dependence on foreign oil," he said, adding that the agency hoped to make a decision this year on whether to convert the plant and if so, which of the bids to accept.
A month ago, the two-year process of decommissioning began. Expected to cost $186 million, it involves the partial dismantling and removal of radioactive parts from the $5.5 billion plant, which is on the North Shore about 55 miles east of Manhattan.
If feasible, Mr. Kessel would like to convert Shoreham to a natural-gas plant and help make Long Island less dependent on the imported oil that fuels Lilco's generators.
 
Three Bids
 The first bid opened, for $274 million, came from a group made up of the New York Power Authority, United Engineers and Constructors Incorporated of Philadelphia, the Enron Power Development Corporation of Houston and Siemens Power Ventures Inc. of Manhattan.
The second bid, for $347 million, was submitted by the Phoenix Shoreham Repowering Partnership of Brooklyn, consisting of Gas Energy Incorporated, a subsidiary of the Brooklyn Union Gas Company, and Union Energy Incorporated of Toronto, Ontario.
The third bid was submitted by the Peconic Energy Venture of Holtsville, L.I., a consortium of subsidiaries of the Bechtel Group Incorporated of San Francisco, the CMS Energy Corporation of Dearborn, Mich., the General Electric Company of Schenectady. N.Y., and the Panhandle Eastern Corporation of Houston. It included three options, priced at $346 million, $343 million and $218 million.
Each bidder also offered to complete the conversion, operate the plant, supply the natural gas and sell the electricity to Lilco.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
After Wild Swings, a Mixed Close

BYLINE: BY KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities staged an abrupt turnaround yesterday, and closed narrowly mixed after being down by as much as a point early in the session.
Traders and analysts were left scratching their heads over the cause of the wild price swings. 
 "This was one of the dizzier days that I can remember," said Ward McCarthy, a managing director at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates, a Princeton, N.J. firm that provides research and commentary on developments in the foreign exchange and credit markets. "It was hard to get a handle on why the market got hammered in the morning, and hard to figure what brought it back in the afternoon."
A desire to capitalize on the recent run-up in prices was clearly a motivating force in Europe, as market participants sold Treasury securities immediately after Germany's central bank announced it was raising its discount rate to 8.75 percent from 8 percent.
 
German Move's Effect
 Talk that the Bundesbank might make such a move had circulated for days, but analysts said that with German interest rates already much higher than those in the United States, any increase should not have lasting effect on the American credit markets.
Prices slid further once trading shifted to the United States on news that initial claims for unemployment insurance fell by an unexpectedly large 15,000 during the week ended July 4. And traders chose to focus on a surge in new mortgage applications rather than a 3.2 percent drop in housing starts during June.
Aping the move in stock prices, the bond market began to perform better after Ross Perot announced he would not run for President.
Some traders said they saw no reason for Mr. Perot's withdrawal from the race as a reason to buy bonds.
"Of the three men in the race, Perot was the only one that really saw the budget deficit as a serious problem," one government-securities trader said. "As a result, I really can't see why his departure from the race would be a help to the bond market."
But others said Mr. Perot's departure seemingly improved President Bush's re-election chances and appeared to eliminate the possibility that the November race would be decided in the House of Representatives next January.
After being buffeted for much of the session, market participants seemed to shrug off a report from the Federal Reserve Board showing that two of the three measures of the nation's money supply it tracks on a weekly basis rose during the week ended July 6.
The $11.2 billion rise in M-1 and the $8.9 billion in M-2 were slightly larger than expected. At the same time, however, analysts said they had not expected M-3, the broadest money measure, to decline by $7.2 billion.
Despite the weekly increase, money supply growth remains extremely weak.
For the month of June, M-1 fell by $2.4 billion, M-2 dropped by $10.7 billion and M-3 fell by $15.1 billion.
Few analysts are expecting a pickup in money growth anytime soon. They said continued weakness would afford the Federal Reserve the opportunity to ease monetary policy again.

HEADLINE: Fewer Housing Starts But a Better Job Outlook

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 16

 BODY:
Housing starts fell 3.2 percent in June, the Government said today, but analysts expect modest improvement starting in July because of the lowest mortgage rates in two decades.
In one of the few bright spots in recently bleak reports, the Government also reported that first-time applications for unemployment benefits fell in early July to the lowest level in nine months. And a four-week moving average, which analysts prefer because it evens out the often volatile weekly numbers, also fell. 
 Nationally, starts of new homes and apartments totaled 1.17 million at a seasonally adjusted annual rate, down from 1.21 million in May, with construction down in every region except for the West, the Commerce Department said.
 
Impact of Lower Rates Seen
 "We have to realize that these June figures are prediscount-rate-cut figures, and in the coming months we should see substantial improvement," said Jean Sundrla of Evans Economics, a Washington forecasting firm.
On July 2, the Federal Reserve slashed both the discount rate, which it charges commercial banks for loans, and the Federal funds rate, which banks charge each other for overnight loans.
Mortgage rates, which had been falling gradually, immediately began to drop sharply. By last Friday, 30-year fixed-rate mortgages were averaging 8.13 percent, down from their 9.03 percent peak in March and the lowest since July 1973.
 
Germany Bucks the Trend
 Meanwhile, the Bundesbank, Germany's equivalent of the Federal Reserve, raised its discount rate today to a record 8.75 percent from 8 percent, in part to combat inflation.
The move came just 10 days after President Bush and other leaders of the world's seven major industrial nations held a summit meeting in Munich, Germany, at which they pledged to cooperate in international economic matters.
The Bundesbank action could curb United States exports, since the move would tend to slow the German economy and its ability to buy American products.
Even with the lower mortgage rates in the United States, most analysts expect any improvement in housing to be modest and well below the 1.7 million annual level of starts in 1983 and 1984, the years following the previous recession.
"Until people feel better about the economy and the job market, housing is going to be held down," said David F. Seiders, an economist for the National Association of Home Builders.
The Labor Department suggested some improvement in employment during the week that ended July 4. It said first-time claims for jobless benefits dropped by 15,000, to 401,000, down from 416,000 a week earlier and the lowest level since claims totaled 401,000 during the week that ended Oct. 5.
The four-week moving average dipped to 414,500 in the period that ended July 4, from 415,750 during the period ending the previous week.
The 11 percent increase in housing starts in May was the largest advance since starts jumped 19 percent in February 1991 as the housing industry began to climb out of its recession.
But the May increase failed to recoup a revised 19 percent plunge in April, even steeper than the earlier estimate of 17.3 percent.
"We wound up the second quarter well below the first," Mr. Seiders said. "It seems clear that moving into the third quarter, both the economy and the housing market lack momentum."
 
Region by Region
 Applications for building permits -- often a barometer of future activity -- fell 1.3 percent, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.04 million. It was the fourth straight decline.
Regionally, the West posted a 7.1 percent advance in starts, to a 303,000 annual rate, after gaining 8.4 percent a month earlier.
But starts fell elsewhere. They were down 9.5 percent in the Midwest, to a 277,000 rate. They fell 5.7 percent in the South, to a 463,000 rate. And they were off eight-tenths of a percent in the Northeast, to a 124,000 rate.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Presidential Politics Adds To Fall in Gold and Silver

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Gold and silver prices fell yesterday because the decision by Ross Perot not to run for President as an independent candidate reduced the uncertainty surrounding the Presidential race.
"The market's gut reaction to the Perot news was bearish," one trader said. "The feeling seemed to be that with him out of the race, Bush's chances of staying in the White House increase, and he's seen as less threatening to the economy than Clinton." Gov. Bill Clinton won the Democratic Presidential nomination on Wednesday. 
 Precious metals have often been seen as a haven during political and economic uncertainty.
Gold also weakened yesterday because the dollar fell after Germany's central bank tightened monetary policy by raising its discount rate three-quarters of a point, to 8.75 percent.
On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for delivery in August fell $1.50, to $353.20 an ounce, and silver for September dropped 3.2 cents, to $3.928 an ounce.
Platinum prices also tumbled amid signs of revived diplomatic efforts in South Africa and a general feeling that the rise in platinum tied to political unrest may have been overdone.
One analyst said involvement by the United Nations in racial turmoil in South Africa, the world's leading producer of platinum, and the possibility that Cyrus R. Vance, former Secretary of State, might act as a mediator, could head off a general strike scheduled for Aug. 3.
Platinum for October tumbled $6.30, to $383.50 an ounce, on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
Oil prices closed slightly firmer after a mixed showing that reflected a dearth of market-moving news.
Crude oil for August gained 8 cents, to $21.79 a barrel, after trading as low as $21.65, and gasoline for August advanced 1.04 cents, to 60.95 cents a gallon. Some investors bought gasoline contracts against sales of heating oil, causing August heating oil to fall 0.22 cent, to 60.12 cents a gallon.

HEADLINE: Dow Up 16.21, After Jump on Perot News

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Stocks rose yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average finishing up 16.21 points at 3,361.63. The average had spurted 18 points after Ross Perot suddenly withdrew from the Presidential race, but that rally faded quickly.
Analysts said overriding concerns about the economy and earnings had tempered the market's enthusiasm over the removal of uncertainty that had been brought on by the three-way race. 
 Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was an active 206.9 million shares, compared with 208.3 million on Wednesday. Increasing issues outnumbered losing declining stocks by 877 to 820.
Bradley Turner, chairman of McDonald & Company's investment policy committee, said while the day's political fireworks raised eyebrows, they did not significantly move markets.
 
Traders Watch Earnings
 "Right now, earnings and the economy are in the driver's seat," he said.
Robert Stovall, president of Stovall/21st Advisers, said: "The big uncertainty was dumping the election decision into the House of Representatives. Now, that has been removed, and we will have a final decision in November."
Mexican stocks, which had been battered on Mr. Perot's stance against a free-trade agreement for Mexico, Canada and the United States, were the most visible beneficiaries of the news.
Otherwise, given that no real themes emerged apart from the gains in Mexican shares, "stocks are really just responding very quickly and decisively to earnings surprises," said Hersh Cohen, president of Shearson Asset Management.
Stocks may also have been dampened by the discount rate increase yesterday morning by Germany's Bundesbank. Bonds fell on the news but recovered.
The 30-year Treasury bond rose 6/32 , to 10416/32 , and the yield slipped to 7.60 percent, from 7.61 percent on Wednesday.
 
What Germany's Doing
 Ron Clarke, managing director in equities for Aetna Capital Management, said the stock market's main concerns seemed to be the German rate increase and the American economy. The Bundesbank raised the rate to 8.75 percent from 8 percent.
Mexican shares that trade in the United States gained on the Perot news included Telefonos de Mexico, up 1 1/2, to 49 5/8; ICA, up 7/8, to 18 3/4; the Mexico Fund, ahead 2 3/8, to 25 7/8, and the Mexico Equity and Income Fund, up 1, to 15 5/8.
Centocor rose 1 3/4, to 16 1/4. Eli Lilly said it would provide up to $125 million to the diagnostic-test maker Centocor, including an investment of $50 million for just under a 5 percent stake.
Shares of Sierra Semiconductor tumbled 3 3/4, to 12 1/4. Analysts said the company cautioned them about third-quarter earnings.
Shares of Chemical Banking fell 1 1/4, to 35 5/8; Boatmen's Bancshares lost 2 3/8, to 50 3/4, and Bank of New York was up 1/8, to 40. Merrill Lynch lowered its ratings on all three.
The Standard & Poor's composite index of 500 stocks rose 0.44 point, to 417.54. The American Stock Exchange index rose 1.47, to 388.34.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index of all listed common stocks rose 0.29, to 229.49. The average price per share rose 4 cents.
The Nasdaq index rose 0.72 point, to 576.19.
The Wilshire Associates Equity Index, the market value of Big Board, American Exchange and Nasdaq issues, was 4,022.968, up 5.320, or 0.13 percent.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
New President Named For Hewlett-Packard

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, July 16

 BODY:
The Hewlett-Packard Company ended more than a year of suspense today when it chose an aggressive computer industry executive, Lewis E. Platt, to succeed John A. Young as president of the Silicon Valley-based electronics company on Nov. 1.
Mr. Platt, who has been given high marks for masterminding the company's revitalized computer business, has been mentioned frequently as a candidate to succeed Mr. Young, 60 years old, who will retire at the end of October after 14 years as Hewlett-Packard's president and chief executive. 
 Mr. Platt, who is 51, will take over the leadership of a company that has for several decades been emblematic of Silicon Valley's informal and engineering-oriented business style. He had previously been executive vice president and head of the company's computer systems organization, which accounts for nearly 75 percent of Hewlett-Packard's revenue.
The company also announced today that Dean O. Morton, also 60, would retire as chief operating officer and would not be replaced. David Packard, 79, co-founder of the company, will remain chairman. Two other Hewlett-Packard executives were promoted to new responsibilities. They are Richard A. Hackborn, 55, executive vice president and head of the company's computer products organization, which is responsible for the company's very successful laser and inkjet printers, and Willem P. Roelandts, 47, vice president and general manager of the networked systems group, which runs the company's communications businesses.
 
Difficult Choice of Successors
 Both Mr. Platt and Mr. Hackborn have been groomed as successors to take the top spot at Hewlett-Packard and industry analysts said yesterday that the choice had been a difficult one.
"The company has one of the deepest benches in the world," said Michael Murphy, editor of the California High Technology Stock Letter. "But they are handing the torch to the right guy."
Despite industry speculation about the succession process, Mr. Platt said that there had been no corporate infighting.
"It wasn't nearly as exciting as the press characterized it," he said. "Dick and I have worked together closely since 1985 and we talked about our strengths and weakness, but there was no feeling of internal competition between the two of us."
In turning around Hewlett-Packard's computer business Mr. Platt has developed a reputation as a hard-charging executive and has made the company a factor across the entire range of computing systems from portable handheld systems to the mainframe market.
"When people see Lew Platt ascending to the presidency it sends a clear message that being successful at H-P now means demonstrating that you are aggressive," said Robert Herwick, an analyst at Hambrecht & Quist. "You have to wear flashier suits and take a tougher line, and don't be afraid to knock on doors where H-P hasn't been seen before."
Mr. Platt was chosen after a two-year search carried out by a company succession committee, Mr. Young said in a telephone interview. Mr. Young will leave the company's board of directors, but will remain available in a consulting role as needed.
He said that he had not decided on personal plans past his retirement and planned to take a number of months to consider different options. Mr. Young has been active on national policy and economic issues in the past. He was named chairman of President Ronald Reagan's Commission on Industrial Competitiveness in 1983.
Mr. Young also established an industry-sponsored Council on Competitiveness in Washington. The council has no connection with Vice President Dan Quayle's taxpayer-financed competitiveness council. As Hewlett-Packard chief since 1978, Mr. Young attained a reputation for integrity and good management that was described in "In Search of Excellence," the 1980's management best seller by Thomas J. Peters and Robert H. Waterman.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
A.T.&T. Net Up 3.6%, as Nynex Profit Rises 13.9%

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
A.T.& T., the world's largest telecommunications company, reported yesterday that net income in the second quarter grew a scant 3.6 percent, to $961 million, while revenue rose less than 1 percent, to $15.85 billion.
Meanwhile, the Nynex Corporation, which provides local-telephone service for New York State and New England, said yesterday that second-quarter earnings rose 13.9 percent, to $331.1 million, or $1.62 a share. The sharp rise was partly the result of a one-time credit from a change in a cellular telephone contract. 
 Following are details of the companies' results:
 
A.T.&T.
 The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said the poor quarter-to-quarter comparison was misleading. Last year's quarterly net was helped by a one-time gain of $87 million from the sale of stock held in Sun Microsystems Inc., a computer maker. Without that one-time gain last year, A.T.& T. quarterly net this year would have been up more than 14 percent, despite the economic slump that has cut into the company's domestic and global markets.
Analysts said the overall results were within their expectations. Shares of A.T.& T., the most widely held stock in the country, closed at $44.875, up 75 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.
Sales declined for the huge call-switching computers bought by foreign governments. But A.T.& T. reported strong trends in other operations, including increased call volume for domestic and international long-distance calls and good results at its AT&T Universal Card Services unit, whose consumer credit card can be used both to charge purchases at shops and restaurants and also for A.T.& T. long-distance service.
Revenue from leasing and financial services, a large part of which is the Universal Card, rose 42.9 percent, to $425 million, from $298 million a year earlier.
The largest part of A.T.& T.'s revenue, more than 60 percent, comes from domestic and international long distance. Revenue from long-distance calls grew 2.2 percent, to $9.85 billion, with minutes of use, a critical measure of performance, growing more than 6 percent. By contrast, the struggling Sprint Corporation, the nation's third-largest long-distance carrier, reported earlier this week that its call volume rose about 3 percent.
Analysts say A.T.& T.'s business-customer market is growing much faster than the company's residential market, probably in the range of 10 to 12 percent volume growth on the business side, compared with just 2 percent to 3 percent for residential customers.
Sales of A.T.& T.'s telecommunications network products and systems dropped 12.2 percent, to $1.7 billion, A.T.& T. said. Industrywide, equipment sales -- especially for giant switching computers like A.T.& T.'s 5ESS switch -- have declined for all of the world's telecommunications equipment companies.
 
Nynex
 Second-quarter revenue for Nynex, which is based in White Plains, dropped 2.3 percent, to $3.28 billion, partly because of the discontinuation of a chain of computer stores the company owned.
The largest part of Nynex's revenue, or more than 85 percent, is in local-telephone business. Quarterly revenue for this segment rose only eight-tenths of 1 percent, to $2.82 billion, while operating income rose 5.6 percent, to $664 million. Telephone access lines rose 1.2 percent, to 15.5 million lines.
Cellular telephone operating income rose 24 percent, to $21.7 million, while revenue rose 7.5 percent, to $89.9 million. All the $4.2 million gain reflected a $6 million credit from a "contract modification" that stemmed losses at the unit.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar in a Broad Decline; German Rate Rise a Factor

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell against most currencies yesterday as the German central bank raised a key interest rate and Ross Perot withdrew from the race for the Presidency.
The dollar fell after the Bundesbank in Germany said it was raising its discount rate, but later rallied after Mr. Perot announced his withdrawal. 
 Stephen Flanagan, a vice president at Mitsubishi Bank Ltd. in New York, said that because the market had anticipated Germany's move for a week, there was not a significant change for the dollar. The Bundesbank announced it had raised the discount rate three-quarters of a percentage point, to 8.75 percent.
Robert Ryan, a senior trader with the Bank of New York, also said the German bank's increase was expected because Germany's economy was under pressure.
"It's a major gesture by the Bundesbank but it may not have a significant impact on the dollar in the longer term," Mr. Ryan said. "It's where do we go from here?"
 
U.S. Data Have Little Effect
 In late European trading, the dollar was quoted at 1.4740 German marks, down from 1.4770. At the close in New York, the dollar was quoted at 1.4780 marks, down from 1.4810 late Wednesday.
The dollar later rallied after the Perot announcement because the political picture is clearer and Congress would not be left to make the decision on the country's next leader, Mr. Ryan said.
Traders made no mention of the day's new economic reports, a slight decline in jobless claims for early July and sluggishness in new housing starts.
In Tokyo, the dollar fell to 124.93 Japanese yen, from 125.32 yen at Wednesday's close. Later, in London, it rose to 125.35 yen. The dollar closed at 125.35 yen at the end of the New York session, up from 125.10 late Wednesday.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.9375, from $1.9260 late Wednesday. The pound was trading at $1.9395 at closing in New York, more expensive than $1.9225 late Wednesday.
Other closing prices in New York, compared with late Wednesday, included: 1.3285 Swiss francs, down from 1.3395; 1,121.50 Italian lire, down from 1,128.00; 4.9910 French francs, down from 5.0050; 1.19165 Canadian dollars, down from 1.19335.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Wednesday, were: 1.3345 Swiss francs, down from 1.3360; 4.9775 French francs, down from 4.9915; 1.6625 Dutch guilders, down from 1.6658; 1,118.00 Italian lire, down from 1,124.25, and 1.1908 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1927.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Worth His Weight In Gold

BYLINE: By WILLIAM C. RHODEN

 BODY:
AS a young boy growing up in Silsbee, Tex., Mark Henry was hard-pressed to envision a time when being big wouldn't be enough.
By the fourth grade, Henry was 5 feet 5 inches tall and weighed 255 pounds; by his senior year at Silsbee High School, he was a 6-3, 360-pound offensive lineman.
Then the sky fell in when Henry scored below the 700 on the Scholastic Aptitude Test required for a freshman to compete while on an athletic scholarship. 
 In the past, low scores hadn't stopped colleges from gobbling up athletes with breathtaking physical ability and academic deficiencies. But Henry was caught in the crossfire of academic reform. Gradually the stunning reality set in: size was not enough.
No college was willing to take a chance. "One coach said, 'We can't take the risk on somebody with low scores when we can take somebody else with a higher score that as good or almost as good,' " Henry recalled. "I just told him 'In the future, you'll see that you missed out.' "
Two years later, football's loss is weight lifting's gain.
Henry's meteoric rise in the sport will take him this weekend to Barcelona, Spain, as a member of the United States weight lifting team, competing as a superheavyweight.
After graduation Henry, who has lifted weights throughout high school and was a three-time state weight lifting champion, was introduced to Olympic-style weight lifting by a University of Texas kinesiology professor who had seen him in the 1990 state high school power lifting championships.
A year later, when Henry walked into the Olympic weight-training center for the first time, Lyn Jones, the national coaching coordinator for the weight lifting federation, took one look at his 6-3, 407-pound frame and said that Henry was the "find of the century."
Since then, Henry, 21 years old, has dropped to a less dramatic 367 pounds. And just as he discovered in high school that size alone was not enough, he has learned that power, unaccompanied by technique and discipline, is useless.
"Sixty-five percent of weight lifting is mental," Henry said. "In football, you focus on being aggressive, intimidating people, hitting people to make them shy away from you.
"In weight lifting, you have to control that anger, focus it on the bar. The bar has a force to it -- you can put it over your head and get under it; sometimes you won't be able to hold the weight because you'll be scared. You learn not to be afraid -- you learn to tighten up when you feel like the bar's going to come down, and go up and meet it. It's a mental process."
In losing football, Henry said he gained an opportunity for growth he may not have achieved otherwise.
He has also been exposed to sports that largely have remained outside his reach and of many athletes raised in the inner city. Henry wishes there was a way to divert some of that waiting talent to other areas within the Olympic movement.
"I wish people in the federation could travel around the country and just pick up the best athletes," he said. "There's an Olympic sport called team handball. It's like a cross between soccer and basketball. I was thinking about going back home, seeing if we could raise some money, get a couple brothers off the street who aren't doing anything -- who wanted to play basketball but couldn't make it -- bringing them back here and banging. Within a year or two, they could be a top contending team.
That sounds good in theory, but Henry said it won't happen soon. Many of the Olympic sports, with no scholarship system, no means of providing training, development and income for athletes from economically disadvantaged areas, are luxury items.
"A lot of the better athletes don't have the time or the means to go into a sport that's not a money sport," he said. "So a lot of the guys go into football and basketball because they want to make money fast.
"I would have probably been the same way. The only reason I didn't go into football was because somebody told me 'No.' "
Instead, Silsbee, Tex., is going to Barcelona on Henry's broad shoulders. Henry said that the most satisfying aspect of the trip is that he never gave up on himself.
"Even as a kid, my two goals were to go to the Olympics and play professional football," he said. "But I wasn't the smartest one in my class. I wasn't the strongest, or the fastest, so teachers spent a lot of time telling me what I couldn't do, what I wasn't going to do. When I go back to Silsbee, I tell kids, 'You can do what you want to do.' I tell them, don't let people take your dreams away.' "

SECTION: Section A; Page 26; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 348 words

HEADLINE: A Breakthrough on Mexican Trade

 BODY:
"We are entering the top of the ninth inning on negotiations," said President Bush after meeting with President Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico before Tuesday night's All-Star game. The words were casual but the accomplishment is not. The two countries have settled many of the issues blocking a free trade agreement that American exporters and investors will find enticing.
Mexico has agreed to open up its banking and securities industries to U.S. investors by the year 2000 and has accepted provisions that would prevent Japanese and other foreign manufacturers from gaining unfair access to the U.S. market via Mexico. Meanwhile Mr. Bush is making good on his promise to push through a treaty that would help Mexico and Canada, the other participant. 
 By eliminating most trade barriers, the pact would allow each country to specialize in what it produces best, cutting prices everywhere. It is expected to create about 130,000 more jobs in export industries than it will eliminate in import industries, like automobiles and apparel.
Compare Mr. Bush's good deed with the protectionist demagogy of organized labor and Congressional opponents. The critics spin frightening stories of factory owners rushing south to exploit dollar-a-day Mexican workers. But the Mexican economy is too small -- a 20th the size of the United States' -- to pose a serious threat. Besides, low wages don't explain trade patterns. If they did, American manufacturers would be rushing to Sri Lanka, not Mexico.
Bill Clinton has been generally favorable toward the free trade pact, though he soft-pedaled his support during the early primaries. Left unresolved is whether he's prepared to take on powerful Democrats who oppose the treaty.
The best trade pact is universal and non-discriminatory, which is why the Uruguay Round of trade talks is so important. But Mexico and Canada are neighbors and warrant special treatment.
The free trade pact will inevitably bulk large in the Presidential campaign. On this score, Mr. Bush gets high marks. The jury is still out on Mr. Clinton.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Bethlehem Steel In a Long Battle

BYLINE: By Jonathan P. Hicks

 BODY:
WHEN the Bethlehem Steel Corporation announced earlier this week that it would report a $64 million loss for the second quarter, it caused some nervousness among investors who had generally perceived the fortunes of the nation's second-largest steel producer, after USX, to be improving.
After all, the company's losses had narrowed over the last year or so, and Bethlehem was laying off fewer workers and closing fewer plants. 
 But the $64 million loss made it clear that Bethlehem's problems persist. In part, that loss results from a litigation charge. The company said its results would include a $25 million charge to increase its reserves for loss contingencies in connection with an appeal it lost last month before the Supreme Court of Kentucky over a longstanding dispute over the ownership of a coal mine in eastern Kentucky. But even without that charge, Bethlehem said, the company would have suffered a net loss of $39 million, weaker results than the $29 million net loss in the second quarter of last year.
Of course, the company and all American steel producers are suffering from continued low demand. Cars and appliances are using less and less steel from year to year, a trend that has been under way for decades.
But what is clearly hurting Bethlehem most, analysts and company officials contend, is the continued price competition among steel companies desperate to hold on to market share and customers. The average price of the sheet steel that goes into cars and appliances is now about $300 a ton, roughly the same price it has been for a year and far below the $450-a-ton price of the summer of 1988.
But appearances may be deceiving, analysts further contend. Although Bethlehem has problems aplenty, its competitive position has been steadily improving. The company lost $10 for every ton of steel it shipped in the first quarter of this year, a far narrower loss than the $21 a ton it lost in the fourth quarter of last year and the loss of $22 a ton in the third quarter of 1991. Even the USX Corporation, widely regarded as the most efficient among the nation's big steel companies, also had a $10-a-ton loss in the first quarter, according to industry analysts. In contrast, in the first quarter there was a $32-a-ton loss at Inland Steel and a $46-a-ton loss at Armco.
"If you look at their financial performance, they really haven't been doing that poorly in comparison with the average of the big six steelmakers," said Christopher Plummer, an analyst with Resource Strategies Inc., an economic consulting form in Philadelphia. "They seem to always have some unusual items that affect the net income figure, but have a lot going for them. They have trimmed their work force and cut their labor costs."
Other analysts contend that the company has forcefully brought in new technology. "The company has invested in a lot of good technology and has been looking for new approaches in steelmaking," said John Jacobson, an analyst with AUS Consultants in Philadelphia. "They have been adopting new technology in both their plant at Sparrows Point, Md., and at Burns Harbor, in Indiana. At the same time, there is clearly an effort to have more decision making at the plant level. The mills are doing a better job of making quality products and they are being more and more recognized for having efficient mills and production quality."
Still, many analysts, including Mr. Jacobson, suggest that while Bethlehem's problems have been exaggerated, the company still has to pare down the layers of management. "They are moving in the right direction, but compared with the mini-mills, they are inefficient," Mr. Jacobson said. "Their biggest problem has been in taking forceful efforts to improve their own operations. They have spent too much time in the past by focusing on external factors, such as the trappings of success. They have always had a lot of layers of management. You don't layer upon layer to get things done.
Also, the company still makes some steel products -- structural steel and rail, for example -- that other large steelmakers have abandoned and left to the mini-mills, which make steel from scrap with smaller, lower-paid work forces.
Mr. Plummer also noted that Bethlehem was still saddled with a mountainous unfunded pension liability. "While competitors like Inland and USX are in a positive situation in terms of their pension liabilities, the unfunded pension liabilities at Bethlehem add on quite a bit to their real cost of labor," he said.
Still, the company, which was widely rumored several years ago to be a candidate for a Chapter 11 filing, has come a long way in overcoming its old image of thick layered bureacracy and luxurious executive golf courses. "They are taking their cost- cutting and modernization responsibilities more seriously," Mr. Jacobson said. "But then, to survive in this environment, they don't really have any choice."

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; National Desk; The Campaign

LENGTH: 1433 words

HEADLINE: THE PARTY'S OVER -- BILL CLINTON;
Democratic Team Opens by Appealing to Middle Class

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL

 BODY:
Gov. Bill Clinton and his running mate, Senator Al Gore, opened their general election campaign last night with a stern attack on President Bush's economic policies and a vision for a Democratic administration that would have as its priorities jobs, health care, AIDS research, the environment and political reform.
 In an address intended to dispel the impression that he has character flaws that might disqualify him from the Presidency, the Arkansas Governor spoke of his background as a fatherless child and of his vision of a government based on the values of community, responsibility and compassion. 
I end tonight where it all began for me," Mr. Clinton concluded his speech, evoking the small-town virtues of his birthplace, Hope, Ark. "I still believe in a place called Hope."
 Then the balloons fell and the delegates waved banners, celebrating with the quadrennial burst of unity and enthusiasm that Democrats display whenever they feel the Presidency is within reach once again. Along with their nominee, they chanted, "We can do it!"
 At the conclusion of his acceptance speech, Mr. Gore took an additional turn around the podium, dancing arm in arm with his wife, Tipper.
 Mr. Clinton accused the Bush Administration of giving lip service to those values for political purposes but forgetting them when it came to governing. "Frankly, I'm fed up with politicians in Washington lecturing the rest of us about 'family values,' " he said. "Our families have values. But our government doesn't." [Transcript, page A14.]
 Mr. Clinton asserted a Democratic claim to the issues that the Republicans have monopolized for three elections, even citing passages from the Pledge of Allegiance as if in a defiant challenge to President Bush to use patriotism against him in the manner the Republicans employed so successfully with former Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, the 1988 nominee.
 "In the name of those who do the work, pay the taxes, raise the kids and play by the rules -- in the name of the hard-working Americans who make up our forgotten middle class -- I proudly accept your nomination," Mr. Clinton said. "I am a product of that middle class. And when I am your President, you will be forgotten no more."
 
Demonstration of Optimism
 The delegates, packed shoulder to shoulder on the convention floor, cheered Mr. Clinton at nearly every line, demonstrating with their exuberance the optimism that has overtaken Democrats who see new opportunities in the withdrawal of Ross Perot from the Presidential race. They seemed ready to accept what Mr. Clinton had come to say.
 "I think the average citizen has a false impression of him," said Delia Camacho, a delegate from Texas who teaches kindergarten in El Paso.
 Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore, who today will begin a six-day bus trip that will stop in seven states, used emotional appeals, humor and Biblical references to pursue their mission of redefining Mr. Clinton as a politician who is not only strong, but also worthy of trust.
 "I think he needs to say who he is," said Marian Wright Edelman, a friend of the Clintons and chairwoman of the Children's Defense Fund, as she roamed the convention floor last night. "People have not understood the man's background. We need to know he's a poor boy and not someone to the manor born."
 Saying the middle class had been victimized by 12 years of Republican administrations, Mr. Clinton declared that only a new President could rescue the country from economic decline.
 Mr. Clinton said he could be the bridge to disillusioned supporters of Ross Perot, who dropped out of the race yesterday. He criticized President Bush's "failed economic theory" and, implicitly, a set of policies that he said had failed to help the middle class.
 "People want change, but Government is in the way," Mr. Clinton said. "It has been hijacked by privileged, private interests. It has forgotten who really pays the bills around here. It's taking more of your money and giving you less in service."
 The speech, and especially the 14-minute biographical film that stressed his small-town roots, also took direct aim at the candidate's greatest weakness in the Democratic primary campaign.
 
Centrist Themes
 In the film, Mr. Clinton spoke, haltingly, of the reaction of his 12-year-old daughter, Chelsea, to reports early in the campaign that he had been unfaithful to his wife. Chelsea, he said, said only, "I'm glad that you're my parents."
 In calling for a "new covenant" between the American people and their Government, Mr. Clinton returned to a favorite theme for centrist Democrats who sense a chance to defeat a Republican incumbent this year.
 "We offer our people a new choice based on old values," Mr. Clinton said. "We offer opportunity. And we demand responsibility. The choice we offer is not conservative or liberal, Democratic or Republican. It is different. It is new. And it will work."
 Although Mr. Clinton graduated from Georgetown University and Yale Law School and was a Rhodes Scholar at Oxford, he emphasized his humble roots.
 "My grandfather had a grade-school education," he said. "But in that country store, he taught me more about equality in the eyes of the Lord than all my professors at Georgetown, more about the intrinsic worth of every individual than all the philosophers at Oxford, and he taught me more about the need for equal justice than all the jurists at Yale Law School."
 Mr. Gore also stressed his family background, saying: "I was 8 years old when my father's name was placed in nomination for the Vice Presidency before the Democratic Convention of 1956. Growing up, I watched him stand courageously for civil rights and economic opportunity and a Government that worked for ordinary people."
 Mr. Gore began by poking fun at one of Mr. Clinton's passions. "I've been dreaming of this moment since I was a kid growing up in Tennessee: that one day, I'd have the chance to come here to Madison Square Garden and be the warm-up act for Elvis."
 Mr. Clinton sought to head off any Republican plans to use Mr. Clinton's record as Governor of Arkansas against him, pointing out that, unlike the 1988 nominee, Governor Dukakis, he would not sell himself as a leader who had singlehandedly brought prosperity to his state.
 "There is no Arkansas miracle," he said, "but there are a lot of miraculous people. Good people, pulling together. Because of them, our schools are better, our wages are higher, our factories are busier, our water is cleaner and our budget is balanced. We're moving ahead.
 "And so I say to those who would criticize Arkansas: Come on down," he said. "Especially if you're from Washington, come to Arkansas."
 Mr. Clinton used the word "change" repeatedly and emphasized active words like "seize," "move" or "excite," intending to convey a new energy and purpose.
 
Retelling His Story
 Mr. Clinton and his aides have worried in recent weeks that the positive side of their candidate's story is not widely known, and they made clear last night that his personal background would become a theme of the campaign, countering Republican challenges on the subject of family values.
 "The future entered my life the night our daughter, Chelsea, was born," Mr. Clinton said. "As I stood in that delivery room, I was overcome with the thought that God had given me a blessing my own father never knew: the chance to hold my child in my arms."
 Mr. Clinton credited his mother, Virginia Kelley, his wife, Hillary, and his grandfather for teaching him about caring for women, children and minorities, and he portrayed himself as a man who identified with those who are neglected or burdened.
 "I was raised to believe that the American dream was built on rewarding hard work," he said. "But we have seen the folks in Washington turn that American ethic on its head."
 The film that introduced Mr. Clinton last night, a collage of images of his life and friends, was created by Linda Bloodworth-Thomason, the television producer who is a family friend and creator of the program "Designing Women."
 It was deliberately nonpolitical, serving instead to set the stage for the triumphant entrance of the nominee and give Mr. Clinton the opportunity to tell his own story in his own words.
 At its outset, Mr. Clinton recalled the longwinded address he delivered from the convention podium four years ago, an address that earned him ridicule at the time.
 "I ran for President for one reason and one reason only," he joked. "I wanted to come back and finish that speech I started four years ago."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Ross Perot;
Advisers Describe Perot Disillusion

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, July 17

 BODY:
Officials of what was the Ross Perot campaign painted a picture of the Texas billionaire today as a candidate so disdainful of traditional politics that he resisted spending money on polls or campaign commercials, even as he spent lavishly to finance grass-roots volunteer groups.
"It wasn't that he was unwilling to spend money," said one campaign insider. "He didn't want to spend money on things that mattered." 
 These campaign insiders described Mr. Perot as a man obsessed with his image who began to lose interest in the contest when faced with a barrage of critical news reports. Some also said he lost heart when he began to realize what his advisers told him might be necessary to address the country's economic difficulties, especially the Federal budget deficit, something he once said he could solve "without breaking a sweat."
 
To Tell the Truth
 "When you look at the hard economic problems facing this country, if you tell the truth about it and propose a specific plan to deal with it, then you run away a lot of voters," James Squires, the senior spokesman for the Perot Petition Committee, said on the NBC "Today" program this morning, the day after Mr. Perot said he would not be a candidate for President. "And I think the prospect for that, though there were many factors involved, had a lot to do with Mr. Perot's decision."
The campaign's issues department, headed by John P. White, a former official in the Carter Administration, had developed a complete economic platform that Mr. White said was scheduled to be unveiled in two weeks. Neither he nor other Perot officials would describe the elements of the economic plan, but they said that as the day of the announcement drew near Mr. Perot became wary over how it would be received.
"Ross was continually worried, as we got closer to announcing the platform, about the magnitude of the problem and how easily it could be solved," said a campaign official who, like most others, demanded anonymity.
This evening Mr. Perot raised the possibility of leaving his name on the ballot in the 24 states where he has qualified and allowing petition campaigns to go forward in states where he is not yet certified.
Interviewed on "Larry King Live," he said he said that, if his grass-roots volunteers asked him, he would remain on the ballot to help build a national movement that could provide the "swing vote" in Congressional and Senate campaign as well as the Presidential race.
 
Don't Call Headquarters
 "What we're now discussing with the state chairmen is even more all-encompassing because it goes to endorsing senatorial and Congressional candidate," Mr. Perot said on the Cable News Network program. He added that if the Presidential candidates did not come up with an economic plan that satisfied his volunteers, his name would be on the ballot as a protest.
Mr. Perot said he would "help and support" the effort "in any way they want me to." But later in the program he suggested that volunteers who want to enlist in this effort not call his Dallas headquarters. "It is far more efficient now to sign up with local groups," he said. The telephone bank at Mr. Perot's headquarters is scheduled to be shut down Wednesday.
Mr. Perot also said on the program that as he became more knowledgeable about the country's economic problems and their possible solutions, he realized that merely running for President would not be the answer. "The more deeply I got into it, that's when I realized it has to be the House, the Senate and the White House," he said.
"I have not gone away," Mr. Perot said in an effort to reassure his volunteers that he would work with them if they remained unified. "I will stay with them right through the end."
"But I have concluded I should not be the candidate," he added.
 
Calls From the Wounded
 Midway through the broadcast, Mr. Perot began getting phone calls from disappointed supporters.
"I would like to start out saying how much I hurt," a woman from Cleveland said, her voice breaking. "The tears have not stopped."
Mr. Perot responded, "I do care for you and I love you." A group of leaders of Mr. Perot's grass-roots campaign has traveled to Dallas, where they hope to meet with Mr. Perot on Saturday to try to persuade him to remain in the race.
Beyond Mr. Perot's reluctance to put forward the economic plan he had commissioned, campaign officials say Mr. Perot's effort was listing badly, and he rejected advice on ways to right it. Some aides say he never realized that much of his support was soft. They noted that much of the support he enjoyed from people who are usually Democrats began to erode during that party's convention. They said they thought that unless he changed strategy, the same would have happened with his Republican support.
"We thought his base was somewhere in the neighborhood of 17 to 18 percent," said a campaign official. "Anything above that was people flirting with his candidacy."
 
'No Idea of Television'
 Focus groups conducted by the campaign found that Mr. Perot was still a virtual unknown to most voters. Yet Mr. Perot rejected the advice of subordinates to run advertisements that would have helped define him.
"He had no idea of television," said one staff member. "His idea of television was getting on the 'Today' show and being interviewed by Katie Couric."
Officials of the campaign said Mr. Perot's distrust of professional political consultants such as Edward J. Rollins and Hamilton Jordan, the co-managers of the campaign, was reflected in how he spent money. They said that, while he lavished funds on state volunteer operations, his Dallas campaign headquarters was caught up in heated arguments over whether commercials should be shot on videotape, or on more expensive 35-millimeter film.
 
Notes From an Airplane
 Mr. Perot reportedly also did not like appearing in forums other than rallies at which the presence of a cadre of his hard-core supporters could be assured. He argued against speaking before the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People last weekend, asserting that members of the group "won't vote for me anyway," a campaign aide said.
The Texan then ignored a speech written for the occasion by Mr. Squires. Speaking from notes that he prepared aboard his private jet as he flew to Nashville, Mr. Perot delivered what many considered a patronizing speech that missed a chance to expand his appeal to younger black professionals.
Mr. Perot also seemed reluctant to become well-versed on issues, several campaign insiders say. Though his staff prepared thick briefing books on various issues, Mr. Perot said he preferred one- or two-page memorandums.
 
Loose Selection Process
 Campaign aides say the Perot organization never made any strides toward selecting a running mate, beyond bandying about names of prominent people. Among those mentioned were Gen. Colin L. Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff; Elizabeth H. Dole, president of the American Red Cross; Bernadine P. Healy, director of the National Institutes of Health; Jack F. Kemp, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, and former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts, an early candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination.
None of the group were brought in for any kind of interview to see if they were interested.
