HEADLINE: Dow Off 29.99 as I.B.M. Is Pummeled

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON

 BODY:
Bill Clinton looked good; I.B.M. looked bad. So investors found reason to sell stocks before heading off for the weekend.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 29.99 points yesterday, or just less than 1 percent, to 3,331.64, putting it 1.08 ahead for the week. A $5.25 drop in I.B.M., to $95 a share, directly accounted for more than a third of the average's decline. 
 Market watchers said that the fears aroused by I.B.M.'s disappointing earnings dragged down the rest of the market. Stock analysts are now saying that earnings might not improve so much after all. Maybe, they say, share prices built on the assumption of a respectable recovery will have trouble withstanding repeated disappointments.
 
'Somewhat Overvalued'
 "You have a market that is somewhat overvalued," said Frank Kennedy, chief market strategist at Equitable Capital Mangement. "As you see disappointing earnings reports, you are reminded that the earnings gap between long-term bonds and stocks is rather wide."
Long-term bonds are paying from 7.68 percent for Treasuries and about 8.25 percent for high-grade corporate issues, while dividends on the Standard & Poor's index of 500 issues are yielding 3 percent. A rise in United States bond yields yesterday, after German rates were raised, also weighed on the stock market.
Political events offered investors no diversion. Stocks advanced on Thursday after Ross Perot announced his decision not to enter the Presidential race as an independent. But to some on Wall Street, the beginning of a two-man bout after an optimistic Democratic convention was no more reassuring.
"There was always a residual feeling in the market that Bush would pull it out," said Byron R. Wien, the United States investment strategist at Morgan Stanley. "Clinton's momentum increases the prospects of a Democratic victory."
With Madison Square Garden just about three miles away, it was hard for Wall Street to ignore all the talk there about raising taxes for the rich. Some investors were so jittery that they acted on rumors that President Bush was ill and that Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d or someone else would jump into the race, said Paul Fine, who trades stock-index futures at Shearson Lehman.
The market's decline was broad-based, with losers on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbering gaining issues, 1,054 to 613. Volume was 192.1 million shares, down from 206.9 million on Thursday.
The International Business Machines Corporation's profits did improve fivefold in the second quarter, but analysts expected it to do better after an especially weak second quarter last year. With 5.9 million shares traded, it led the Big Board active list. Apple Computer, which also reported weak earnings, dropped 3 3/4, to 45.
 
More Weak Data
 Investors looking for other signs of weakness readily found them. Reuters reported that the University of Michigan's index of consumer confidence in the economy slipped to 77.1 percent in early July from 80.4 percent for June. May's trade deficit rose to an 18-month high, as sluggish economies abroad meant weak demand for American products.
As a result, analysts said, auto stocks and other cyclical issues that depend heavily on an economic recovery fared poorly, with Ford Motor down 1, to 44 5/8.
Digital Equipment, however, gained 2 1/4, to 43 1/4, on heavy volume after the resignation on Thursday of its founder and chairman, Kenneth H. Olsen. Analysts have blamed him for the company's recent losses.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Companies
I.B.M. reported a fivefold jump in profits to $714 million, or $1.25 a share, for the second quarter, but that was below analysts' estimates. Investors responded by driving the computer maker's shares down $5.25 each, to $95, in active trading. [35.] Texas Instruments reported a profit of $72 million, or 73 cents a share, compared with a loss of $157 million a year earlier. [39.]
Prices of personal computers have plunged in recent weeks, buyers are not snapping up bargains. Instead they seem to be waiting for yet-lower prices. [35.] 
 A Muppet with a bar sinister? The discovery -- and attempted promotion -- of two long-lost fuzzy characters, Wilkins and Wontkins, created by Jim Henson when he was still a student, has led to suits and countersuits, even fisticuffs. [35.]
Dashing, articulate Robert B. Palmer bears no surface resemblence to Kenneth H. Olsen, the lumbering, bearlike founder and president of Digital Equipment, whom he is to succeed. But Mr. Olsen, a 66-year-old former M.I.T. professor, is pleased that he can leave the company in the hands of a visionary scientist rather than turn it over to a salesman. [37.] Pier Carlo Falotti, the president of Digital's European operations, resigned to head the Ask Companies, a leading California software supplier. [37.]
Nationsbank's acquisitive chief executive, Hugh L. McColl Jr., sees a prospect in Baltimore's troubled MNC Financial, which would give him a dominant position in the market around Washington. Nationsbank agreed to invest $200 million in MNC for a 16 percent nonvoting stake and an option to buy the whole company for at least $1.2 billion more by Sept. 30, 1997. [37.]
Byron Donics will leave Estee Lauder's Aramis division, where he is president, to head a financing company that plans to invest in the international and domestic health and beauty industries. [37.]
 
 International
 The nation's merchandise trade deficit widened to $7.38 billion in May, as exports, the mainstay of economic growth since President Bush took office, fell for the third consecutive month. [35.]
Brazil's new debt agreement with its creditor banks has spurred enormous enthusiasm in the Government in Rio de Janeiro and among private economists, despite the country's huge economic problems and a corruption scandal. [41.]
 
The Economy
Consumers' confidence in the economy slipped in early July, a survey prepared by the University of Michigan indicates. The survey -- keenly watched by financial markets -- showed that the sentiment index fell to 77.1 percent in early July from 80.4 percent for the whole of June, recipients said. [48.]
A plan setting aside $50 million for investors who filed late claims against Michael R. Milken and other employees of Drexel Burnham Lambert was approved by a Federal judge. [48.]
 
Markets
 Stocks tumbled, with the Dow Jones industrial average falling 29.99 points, or just under 1 percent, to 3,331.64, as I.B.M. dropped $5.25 to $95. Some market watchers also cited anxiety over the apparent strength of Gov. Bill Clinton. [38.]
Bond prices fell sharply, impelled by a stronger-than-expected regional Federal Reserve bank survey of manufacturers and a big drop in the value of the dollar, among other factors. [38.]
Precious metals prices were drive up by investors seeking a safe harbor. Gold rose $4.80, to $358 an ounce. [45.] The dollar fell against major currencies. [45.]

HEADLINE: Waiting for Even Cheaper PC's

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON

 BODY:
In the economics taught in college, when prices fall, sales rise. But many personal computer customers seemed to have missed a few lessons. Despite the largest price cuts in the history of the personal computer business in recent weeks, they have decided to stop buying, stand back and enjoy the spectacle of an industry whirling into a vortex of hyper-deflation.
"Customers come up to me and say, 'When are the prices going to drop again?' " said Harry Shasho, sarcastically imitating their winks and nudges. A vice president of Willoughby's camera and electronics store on West 32d Street in Manhattan, Mr. Shasho recently surveyed a computer department bereft of customers and said, "When a guy's seen Compaq drop, and AST drop, and Leading Edge drop, all in one month's time, he says, 'Hey, I'll wait.' " 
 During recent weeks, Mr. Shasho said, sales have been down about 10 percent even from the recessionary levels of last year.
 
Cuts of as Much as 40%
 The lack of enthusiasm among some buyers is all the more striking given the extent of the recent price cuts -- as much as 40 percent just in the last month. And it demonstrates that the computer industry obeys its own economic laws: procrastinators are always rewarded, because prices always move lower.
"I am thinking about buying a computer for my aunt," said Thomas Sedlock, a customer at J&R Computer World, near City Hall in lower Manhattan. "Compaq's price cuts stimulated me to see what's available. But, for myself, I'm fussier. I would wait till color laptops are cheaper."
Dr. Sedlock, a psychiatrist, gave a few desultory taps to the keyboard of a NEC 386-5L20 laptop, then he looked longingly at a far more expensive machine that came with a color display.
He said he was confident that color laptops, which at J&R start at $2,899, would soon be cheaper than the black-and-white model he was testing. At J&R, prices are changed so frequently that few are posted, and a salesman had to tap into a computer himself to learn that the NEC costs $1,880.
Michael Ginsburg, a freelance writer testing the word-processing abilities of a Leading Edge computer at J&R, said he was also checking mail-order catalogues. Even then, finding the latest prices took some effort.
"Don't look at the prices," he said he was told when he called to request catalogues. "When you're ready to shop, call us."
The price wars appear to find corporate America asleep at the keyboard. Mr. Shasho said his corporate and institutional customers, including several Ivy League universities, were too fixed in their purchasing habits to either rush after any bargains or wait for further discounts.
"They have budgets, they have committees, they have purchase orders," he said, speaking at his usual 50-megahertz pace. "I'm talking about major companies, not Sid & Al's Hardware."
Kimball Brown, director of personal computer hardware research at the International Data Corporation, a consulting and research company, said all the price-cutting would lead to only minor increases in the number of machines sold this year, and no growth in revenues.
Some buyers, Mr. Brown said, are waiting for the International Business Machines Corporation to make its move. He expects to see a revamped product line in September. "When that happens, we'll have a whole new round of price cuts," he said. The company has already announced plans to sell clones in Europe and Canada under a new Ambra nameplate.
Lower prices for computers are nothing new. Prices have been falling and performance improving since the personal computer industry emerged from some West Coast garages about 15 years ago. But several analysts said the latest price war was fiercer than any they recall and the relative lack of customer response surprising.
"This is the most intense," said Seymour Merrin of Palo Alto, Calif., who publishes a computer newsletter. "This industry is incredibly Darwinian."
The latest struggle for survival started on June 15. The Compaq Computer Corporation of Houston, the first company to sell clones of I.B.M.'s personal computers, grew tired of smaller clone makers doing to it what it had done so well to I.B.M. Its market share and profits dwindling, Compaq struck back.
Before the hostilities, Compaq machines started at about $2,000. Now, for $899, a buyer can get a machine lacking only a few of the higher-priced model's features.
Dell, Toshiba, Sharp, NEC and Hyundai rushed to introduce low-priced computers or cut prices on their current models by as much as 40 percent. Over the last month, price cuts averaged 20 to 30 percent -- as much as computer prices normally fall in a whole year, said Jonathan L. Yarmis, the director of the personal computer division at the Gartner Group, a market research and consulting firm in Stamford, Conn. Gartner is now advising clients to begin buying personal computers again, unless they want to wait for further possible savings from I.B.M. or AST Research.
Among several major computer makers, only Compaq, which has many corporate and institutional buyers, reports that the price cuts have brought a surge of orders -- more than it can immediately satisfy.
Genelle Trader, vice president of marketing at Everex Systems Inc., which sells I.B.M.-compatible clones, said "things got very quiet" after Compaq slashed its prices. "We did see some caution and stalling. I've talked to acquaintances at other competitors and they all see the same thing," she said.
But she said she saw some revived buying last week. And some rapidly growing clone makers, including the Dell Computer Corporation, say the price wars are not costing them any business.
Indeed, hesitation to buy is by no means universal. Some buyers are so awed by the performance they can afford that they see no reason to wait.
In the buy-now camp is Robert D. Holmes, a Southern California Gas Company computer specialist who helps channel more than $2 million in annual purchases of personal computers. He said that to delay buying would deprive the company of the greater productivity the new machines bring.
 
Moves Up the Line
 With a goal of spending about $3,000 a machine, Mr. Holmes had initially planned to buy computers powered by 386DX chips. Now, instead, he plans to buy machines with the much faster, top-of-the-line 486DX chips.
But some people who bought computers recently cannot forgive themselves. A lawyer stopping by J&R said he was proud when he landed a Centrix computer a month ago, powered by the fast and powerful 486DX microprecssor, and connected to a broad, 15-inch color screen -- for $2,500. That system now sells for hundreds of dollars less. "I'm kicking myself," he said.
Adding to the injury, he said, several colleagues at his firm -- some secretaries, too -- are still waiting to buy.
Mr. Shasho of Willoughby's said some customers berated him when they found that a machine they bought for $2,798 16 months ago was now the economy model, selling for $799.
Some buyers do not have the luxury of waiting for lower prices. Gennady Mossin, a shopper at Willoughby's, carefully looked over the least-expensive computers and wondered whether they might someday be able to handle Cyrillic. Mr. Mossin, a translator and interpreter, told a salesman he wanted to buy something small enough to carry back on the plane to Russia.
"For me, it's now or never," Mr. Mossin said.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: At the Truck Stop;
The View From the Semi: Long-Haul Drivers Look Down on Politicians

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SIOUX CITY, Iowa, July 16

 BODY:
Of the various publics largely ignoring politics as the Democrats convened in New York, few did it with such tooth-picking gusto as the nation's long-haul truck drivers. They swaggered down to earth from their air-cushioned driver's seats here at Interstate 29's dusty Truck Haven and sounded more intent on tucking into a stack of pancakes than on taking this nation back, getting it moving again, or whatever the convention cliche was back East.
"You think I should pay attention to them politicians when they can't even balance their own damn checkbooks?" asked Jim Wendt, a 63-year-old driver whose rig full of perishables rested at low idle across the Truck Haven lot beside dozens of other panting, rumbling diesel trucks.
 
Lots of Hissing and Chuffing
 "The same sort of 'respected people' who robbed us in that savings-and-loan scandal get elected as delegates to them things," the driver declared, angrily splitting the blame between the parties with cleaver bluntness. Mr. Wendt repeatedly used the savings-and-loan and House bank scandals to dismiss the convention promises emanating this summer from politicians to do better next time. 
 As the driver fulminated under the bill of his weathered baseball cap, dozens of groaning, hissing truck rigs glided in and chuffed out of the Truck Haven lot. They gathered as if for a counter-convention of angry metal mammoths. But it was only a normal slice of Americana where human survival can get reduced to such a monotonous ramble of work, sleep and meals that politicians seem at best irrelevant outsiders.
"Hell, I was listening to Jesse Jackson the other night, and I kept waiting to have to come to a screeching halt before all the beggars and homeless he says are lying around America," said Tom Liston, one of the rare drivers interviewed who admitted he would pause a bit when he hears politics on his truck radio dial, but mainly to rile himself on a nocturnal haul. "All that doom and gloom just to get themselves elected, so you know they can't afford to talk about the good things," said Mr. Liston, a driver for 15 of his 37 years.
Truck Haven constitutes a small wayside village that never sleeps and a precinct where politicians best tread lightly. Under this week's full moon, rows of corn crowded to the very edge of enormous asphalt parking lots where the thrum of the idling trucks never stopped. Drivers confronted a stranger's questions about politics as if they were being invited to stare up into the Iowa night in search of life beyond the truck stop.
"I been doing my paperwork and can't be bothered with that," said one grizzled man, begging off the task.
"I need a shower right now more than politics," said another, stretching after descending from his work perch.
The way station includes a plain block lodge of motel beds, a repair depot, and a round-the-clock diner replete with promises of Mom's cooking, credit-card phones and ash trays at each table, plus a "Truckfax" phone machine so drivers can get lading bills and seal the paperwork of deals back beyond the antacid shelf in the general store.
"Reagan screwed up," said one driver, complaining about business as he poured syrup onto a prodigious melange of pancakes, eggs, bacon and sausage. "He should have kept those taxes instead of cutting them, and instead cut spending."
A driver on a neighboring stool snorted generally of politicians: "Well, you know they're never gonna cut spending." A third man shifted the talk to the new national driver licenses the truckers find bedeviling. The discussion of Presidential politics was over in a minute, and the heartland seemed stony in comparison with the idealism and optimism to be found on the convention pictures being televised from New York as the drivers moved through the night or paused at their stations.
 
Past Failures Lamented
 Asked about the subject, Mike Turner stopped on his way back to his rig and said, "Clinton may make it, but he's taking over a garbage scene, with all the failure that's gone before." Mr. Turner, a 43-year-old driver who has covered 48 states in long-haul commerce, listens to the popular talk-radio night host, Bill Sanders. He said the talk this week has rarely been of the political convention, but rather of the confusion and supposed inequities of trucking licenses.
Chris Agers, a 29-year-old driver wielding a long-handled squeegee across his wet windshield by the Truck Haven diesel pumps, said politics is a world of "bits and pieces, at best" to him as he rambles cross-country. "My sense is the Democrats are quiet this year, so maybe it's the Republicans' turn to be disruptive," he said.
"I'll tell you, I was in the Air Force serving in Saudi Arabia during Desert Storm, and I found that a waste of taxpayers' money by the politicians," said Mr. Agers. "The President should care about the economy and the people of the U.S. first, then the rest of the world."
Ben Schlaefli's knowledge of the latest news from New York was not at all about the Democrats at Madison Square Garden, but about an annoying new safety requirement to have two special yellow lights always blinking on oversized loads in New York, unlike all the other states of the union. "That raises my hackles more than the convention does," he said.
Jim Tuller, in his 42d year of interstate truck driving, "couldn't care less" about who makes it next to the White House. "Lot of new young drivers on the roads nowadays, and they don't stop to help when you're in trouble," he said when asked what is of concern to him. "It's everybody for himself these days."
"Driving around, of course I can see the hard times, people out of work," said Mr. Tuller. But still he said it was a waste of time to listen to politicians' promises about the problems he can see so plainly through the windshield. "I'm six months from retirement," he said. "Wouldn't you know my wife wants to see the country and drive around a lot." He shrugged as he headed from his rig into the truckers' diner.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Democrats;
With No Break, Clinton Initiates Campaign Tour

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAMDEN, N.J., July 17

 BODY:
Bill Clinton and his running mate, Al Gore, rallied the Democratic faithful today, using the first full day of their campaign to romance supporters of Ross Perot and open a six-day bus tour that will carry them through nine states.
"This is our chance to change America," Mr. Clinton said at a meeting of the Democratic National Committee before leaving New York this morning. "Let's take it." 
 The new Democratic ticket left midtown Manhattan in a caravan of eight buses that took them from a confetti-strewn rally to the outskirts of Camden in about two hours.
Governor Clinton of Arkansas, Senator Gore of Tennessee and their aides were ebullient today, telling their supporters that the Presidency was within reach if they could persuade Mr. Perot's supporters to join the Democrats.
 
Playing Down Polls
 Nonetheless, Mr. Clinton and his strategists played down the latest public opinion polls showing that they have surged to a remarkable lead over President Bush in the last week.
Mr. Clinton had 56 percent to Bush's 33 percent in a USA Today-CNN poll by the Gallup Organization of 602 voters.ABC News polled 527 voters, who gave Mr. Clinton a 54-to-31 percent lead. He enjoyed an even bigger lead among "likely voters," who favored the Arkansas Governor, 58 percent to 29 percent, ABC said. Both polls had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus five percentage points.
The Democrats proudly marched out two Perot-to-Clinton converts at their East 48th Street rally today. Matthew L. Liflander and Thomas Hoving, two Perot organizers in New York State, appeared to announce their decision to embrace the Clinton-Gore ticket.
"All those people who thought Ross Perot had guts -- and he don't -- must go back to the obvious choice, who has guts," said Mr. Hoving, a former New York City Parks commissioner and former director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. "He's proven it. Leadership is courage and persistence in times of adversity."
Mr. Clinton said that Mr. Perot gave Democrats the "ultimate compliment" when he said during a surprise news conference on Thursday that he was abandoning his Presidential bid in part because the Democratic Party had appeared to be revitalizing itself.
"It is for us now to show that we can be trusted to do what we say and to run this country," Mr. Clinton said.
Mr. Clinton, Mr. Gore and their wives traveled in a custom-fitted bus for the first leg of the tour. Their first stop was an aerospace plant here, where employment has dropped from 5,000 workers to 1,600 in five years.
The 1,000-mile itinerary includes stops in New Jersey, Pennsylvania, West Virginia, Ohio, Kentucky, Indiana, Illinois and Missouri. Winning those states along the route is crucial to the Democrats' chances of defeating President Bush in November.
"This will be a campaign of action, words of movement, not just talk," Mr. Clinton said before he left on his bus tour. "We are going to change this country with your help. That is what this whole convention has been about."
The two Democrats continued their theme this afternoon at the Camden stop, where they met with Gov. Jim Florio of New Jersey and Representative Robert E. Andrews, both Democrats.
Repeating the theme that Clinton strategists believe is their best weapon against President Bush, Mr. Clinton described the plant's program to retrain space technology workers as an example of the best kind of change.
"Change is the key to your security," Mr. Clinton said.
"The other side is saying we've been in charge for 12 years and if you want change, vote for more of the same," Mr. Gore said. "That doesn't make sense. Their approach has failed."
Mr. Florio made a pitch that Mr. Clinton is certain to hear more of as he travels the country. "It's been a lonely, lonely effort having every state take care of its problems by itself," the New Jersey Governor said. "We need some help from Washington."
The Clinton campaign has learned well from the mistakes made by Michael S. Dukakis, the 1988 Democratic Presidential nominee, when he disappeared from the campaign trail after the convention. His 17-point lead in the polls subsequently disappeared as well.
Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore have set a busy schedule for themselves this week, and both received a road map and instant camera to take along as they left New York. Reading material on their luxury bus included Jules Witcover's book, "Crapshoot: Rolling the Dice on the Vice Presidency."
Their final stop of the day was at Steelworkers Hall in Coatesville, Pa., where the caravan was to stay for the night. Plans called for the tour to visit the Pennsylvania cities of York, Carlisle, McKeesport and Pittsburgh on Saturday.
Mr. Clinton had a much better time in New York this time than he did when he campaigned there during the April primary and was greeted by hecklers at nearly every stop. Today, hundreds of people cheered as he left his midtown hotel, and hundreds more crowded the street outside for the send-off rally.
"I want to begin by saying a heartfelt welcome for this wonderful city that has been somewhat rough to me but in the end always good to me," he said. "New York, I love you. Thank you."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: In the Heartland;
Clinton Is Reaching Restless Reagan Democrats

BYLINE: By ISABEL WILKERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOMETOWN, Ill., July 17

 BODY:
When Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas took to the podium to accept the Democratic nomination for the Presidency and wax moderate about the needs of working people, he was likely hoping that a guy like Joe Madden was listening from his sky-blue velour recliner, nodding in agreement. And he was.
Mr. Madden, a maintenance supervisor in this working-class suburb southwest of Chicago, is a Democrat's dream. He is white, male and suburban, a family man who is a Democrat at heart, but was stolen away by the Republicans many elections ago. 
 He lives in a town full of Reagan Democrats and Kmart Republicans, a tidy suburb of tract homes in Buick country, where a majority of citizens, regardless of their party affiliation, have voted Republican for the last 12 years, twice for Ronald Reagan and once for George Bush.
Like most of his neighbors and millions of suburbanites across the nation, the 58-year-old Mr. Madden is the kind of voter the Democrats have been trying, and failing, to win over for years.
 
Willing This Time
 But this time, people like Mr. Madden seem willing to believe in them. He and more than a dozen other voters interviewed here since the closing of the Democratic convention on Thursday night said they felt betrayed by the Republicans and were looking over the fence again.
After Governor Clinton's acceptance speech that night Mr. Madden turned off his wide-screen television feeling better about Democrats than he had since he cast his last vote for a Democrat, John F. Kennedy in 1960. For now, he said, with the economy stalled, the Arkansas Governor has his vote.
"I feel he's going to bring the country together," Mr. Madden said. "We're deep in the hole. If he can do half of what he said, four years from now we'll be a much better country."
He sighed when asked about the last vote he cast, the one for President Bush. "I can't see voting for him again," Mr. Madden said. "He's a big wheeler and dealer. The country's going backward instead of forward. We fell for his promises and what did we get? There's too much money going to foreign countries when we got problems right here at home. Bush has been feeding the big guys. The working people can't carry the load anymore."
Hometown (population 4,769) is an unpretentious, aluminum-siding kind of town, where houses have pickup trucks out front and basketball hoops out back, where adult children live a few doors down from their parents and where the mayor has hung a poster in his office that says, "I Am the Flag."
God and country are important here. And the Democrats' red-white-and-blue banners, the close-up shots of Mr. Clinton's mother, her eyes misty, the cheers and banners and orchestrated show of unity during the Democratic National Convention were not lost of Hometown residents.
"I'm listening," said Ronald Jeffrey, an electrician in Hometown. "It's one of the best tickets they've had in a long time. They seem more unified. There isn't all the bickering. They seem to be more towards the center. I like what I see and I'm ready for a change. What wrong can this ticket do?"
Mr. Jeffrey, 42, is the kind of American who remembers going to ball games growing up and getting chills down his spine whenever he heard the national anthem. So when the Democrats play the patriotism card it seems almost a homing device for people like Mr. Jeffrey.
It is a strategy that for now is playing well in Hometown. The town has seen its population and tax base decrease in the years since Mr. Reagan took office. Many point to the local shopping center as proof that the Republicans have presided over a deteriorating economy.
"We're hurting," said Mr. Madden, who is the maintenance supervisor at the shopping center, and serves as the town's director of public works in his off-hours. "We have seven vacant stores. We had a food store, a bakery, a children's store, a shoe store, a Kresge's. All gone."
Mention George Bush here, and unemployment, recession and drugs spill from many people's lips. They seem infuriated that President Bush reneged on his pledge of no new taxes. They express a deep sense of alienation from the President, seeing him as an advocate for the elite, not them.
"He goes on vacation too much," Mr. Jeffrey said. "Every time you look around he's at Kennebunkport or something. Who's running the shop?"
What on the face of it would seem to be Mr. Bush's strengths are seen as weaknesses here. For one, Hometown residents tend to view Mr. Bush's first term as really the third term of the Reagan-Bush Administration. The argument that he needs a second term to complete the programs of the first -- an incumbent's standard line -- does not wash here.
"They've had 12 years to do something, and they haven't," said Joan Doberwits, the town clerk, who like most everyone else is a registered Democrat who has been voting Republican since 1980. "In my heart, I feel Bush has had enough time. He's had his chance."
William Cochrane, a telephone repairman, who has not voted for a Democrat since Harry S. Truman, said: "He's been a do-nothing President. I don't think Bush has done anything. Personally, I feel let down by the man."
The Persian Gulf war is a touchy subject with many residents, who say they are angry that Saddam Hussein is still in power.
"They spent millions of dollars and accomplished nothing," Mr. Corcoran said. "It was such a waste of time."
On the other hand, people seem not as troubled by Mr. Clinton's debits. Gennifer Flowers is long forgotten, whether he did or did not inhale is, to them, talk-show grist and people, for now, seem to be looking past his attempts to avoid Vietnam.
The charges of womanizing, in particular, seem to be a nonissue, and some seemed impressed that Gov. Clinton had weathered the scrutiny. "That kind of gossip irritates me," said Nancy Jeffrey, a nurse who is married to Mr. Jeffrey and has voted Republican with him.
Mr. Jeffrey sees both President Bush and Governor Clinton as morally flawed. "Bush's son was involved in the savings and loan mess," Mr. Jeffrey said. "You could sling mud back and forth all night long. They cancel each other out."
Some residents here say they like the idea of a Democratic Congress and President working together to get something done and others simply like the fact that Bill Clinton is not George Bush, especially now that Ross Perot is no longer in the picture.
"If one has to get in, let it be Clinton," came the voice of a retiree, Patricia Eisner, who until Thursday was a Perot supporter. "I want to believe what Clinton says because it sounds great. But face it, none of them would say what you wouldn't want to hear. They'd be a fool."

HEADLINE: Trade Deficit at $7.38 Billion As Exports Post 3d Decline

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 17

 BODY:
Exports, the mainstay of economic growth since President Bush took office, fell for the third consecutive month in May, with the nation's merchandise trade deficit widening to $7.38 billion, the Commerce Department announced today.
As the Administration sought to minimize the report's significance, Democrats greeted the news as a confirmation of what Gov. Bill Clinton on Thursday night called a need for strengthening American competitiveness in international markets. 
 "It confirms the need for change," said Representative Sander M. Levin, Democrat of Michigan. "It confirms the fact that the No. 1 challenge before America is economic revitalization."
But Commerce Secretary Barbara H. Franklin noted that exports in the first five months of this year were still up 6 percent from last year. "Despite the volatility of monthly trade figures," she said, "the trend in export growth remains solid."
Exports have accounted for 87 percent of the nation's economic growth during the Bush Administration, according to the Commerce Department. But this spring the nation's trade surplus with Western Europe has shrunk as economic growth slows there, and is offsetting less of the nation's widening trade deficit with Japan and oil-producing countries.
Even third world countries, which have been a rapidly growing market for the United States in recent months, cut back their purchases slightly in May.
The overall May deficit was the highest in 18 months.
Stephen S. Roach, the senior economist at Morgan Stanley, said weak exports combined with rising unemployment had prompted his investment bank two weeks ago to cut its estimate of second- and third-quarter economic growth to 2.25 percent from 3.8 percent. "This report is certainly consistent with that revision," he said.
Mr. Roach warned that the trade deficit might continue to deteriorate as the increase in German interest rates announced on Thursday slowed European economies and their appetite for imports, while resumed growth in the United States might renew the demand for imports here.
The gloomiest reaction to the trade figures came from the United States Chamber of Commerce, whose 200,000 member companies have made the organization's views into a broad gauge of corporate sentiment across the country.
"It appears we have the worst of all worlds -- declining exports due to a sluggish global economy and increasingly fierce competition, declining imports reflecting fragile domestic demand, and an expanding trade deficit symptomatic of U.S. trade policies still mired in a cold-war mentality," the chamber's vice president for international issues, Willard A. Workman, said in a statement.
"While exports remain an important part of our economy, the data of the last three months indicate that America cannot rely solely on stimulus from our really stellar export performance of the past three years to mitigate fundamental weaknesses in the U.S. economy," Mr. Workman added. American exports, he said, were still restricted in areas like word-processing computer software.
Total exports, adjusted to exclude seasonal variations, fell to $35.49 billion in May from $36.41 billion in April and a peak of $37.65 billion in February. At $7.38 billion, the merchandise trade deficit in May was the widest since the $9.49 billion recorded for November 1990.
The May deficit would have been even wider if imports had not also fallen in May by $603.6 million, to $42.87 billion. The drop in imports "is not all good news, since some of the decline may be caused by a weaker than expected domestic economy," said Stephen Cooney, the director for international investment at the National Association of Manufacturers, the Washington-based trade group.
Mr. Cooney pointed out that slightly more than half of the drop in exports since February has come in civilian aircraft, which tend to be ordered in large clumps.
But the airline industry's prolonged slump, coupled with recent postponements and cancellations of new aircraft deliveries, could mean that the recent drop may foreshadow continued weakness, Mr. Cooney said.
The politically sensitive trade deficit with Japan narrowed in May to $3.50 billion from $4.21 billion in April. The nation's trade surplus with Mexico, which has accounted for two-fifths of this year's overall growth in exports, showed a small but surprising drop to $434.4 million, from $576.6 million in April.
The United States is in the final stages of negotiating a North American free trade agreement with Mexico and Canada. President Bush has cited the growth in American exports to Mexico and Latin America as one reason for doing so.
Mr. Levin, one of the main authors of a broad trade bill approved last week by the House, said that the new figures increased the odds that Congress would adopt a bill this year.
But Senator Lloyd Bentsen, the Texas Democrat who heads the Finance Committee, has repeatedly said he has not decided whether to introduce a trade bill in the Senate.

HEADLINE: Albany Still Wrestling With Unfinished Business

BYLINE: By SARAH LYALL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, July 17

 BODY:
Another round of meetings today between Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and state legislative leaders failed once again to produce an agreement on a package of bills left over from the legislative session, including a fiscal bailout for Nassau and Suffolk counties.
The bills, which also include an $800 million bond act intended to create jobs across the state, unraveled in the early morning of July 3, just before the Legislature went home for the summer. Since then, staff members from the Governor's office, the Democratic-led Assembly and the Republican-led Senate have been meeting in hope of cutting a deal. 
 Governor Cuomo said today that progress was being made and that some issues had been resolved. But he added that "the deal I made with them is that nothing is agreed to until everything's agreed to. So you say, 'This piece is done provided you do this piece.' "
After a midday meeting of the Governor, Senate Majority Leader Ralph J. Marino and Assembly Speaker Saul Weprin ended with major points unresolved, the group broke for the day. Predictably, aides to Mr. Marino and Mr. Weprin each blamed the other side for the stymie.
But Mr. Cuomo said he was hopeful a resolution could be reached, possibly by the end of the weekend. He scheduled talks for Saturday afternoon to discuss Long Island proposals, and he asked Louis J. Yevoli, the Democratic supervisor of the town of Oyster Bay, and County Executives Thomas S. Gulotta of Nassau and Robert Gaffney of Suffolk to join the three leaders.
 
Tax Increases Sought
 "We want to get this thing resolved as quickly as possible," said Anne Crowley, Governor Cuomo's spokeswoman. "We are running out of time. We need more information from them, and it will be helpful to have all of them in the room with the leaders."
The Nassau leader wants permission to borrow $100 million and to raise the county mortgage-recording tax from 1 percent to 2 percent. The Suffolk leader wants the authority from Albany to borrow up to $91 million and to raise the county sales tax half a percentage point, to 8.5 percent. Leaders in both counties say that without action, they could run out of money by this fall.
Because the state Legislature must pass the jobs bond act by Aug. 3 if the question is to be put on the November ballot, the leaders have less time to resolve the remaining issues. Once an agreement is reached, the Legislature would then have to be called back to Albany for a special session to vote on the bills.
If the bond act and a proposal to expand the powers of the New York State Thruway Authority are extremely important to Mr. Cuomo's economic-development plans, the Long Island bailout is essential for Mr. Marino, who comes from Long Island and whose political base is there.

HEADLINE: New Betrayal, Senecas Say, And New Rage

BYLINE: By LINDSEY GRUSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SALAMANCA, N.Y., July 17

 BODY:
JoJo Redeye is haunted by memories of a happy childhood.
After work, as the sun dips below the pine-crowned hills, Mr. Redeye, the 55-year-old maintenance manager for the Seneca nation, often walks to the reservoir created by the construction of the Kinzu Dam, which wiped out the the places where he was born and raised. 
 "They condemned our land," he said. "They dug up our sacred grounds and scooped up remains. They've caged us and crowded us like a bunch of animals. Sometimes I sit down and cry."
 
White Residents Worry
 Now his anger, shared by many of the 5,500 Senecas who live near here, is bubbling over in a protest against a tax ruling that the Senecas see as the latest in a series of betrayals and broken promises. Although the confrontation was suspended tonight, after the Senecas won a favorable temporary injunction, the dispute, which produced scuffles with the state police and the closing of sections of two highways, is not ended.
The protest revolves around the ability of the state to collect taxes on reservation sales to outsiders. On July 9, the Appellate Court decided in New York's favor, but tonight a State Court of Appeals judge issued a temporary injunction against the state. A hearing was scheduled for July 27 to decide whether the injunction will be permanent.
In addition, Indian leaders said tonight that under an agreement with state troopers, the troopers would no longer come onto the reservations except by invitation of the Senecas, such as to help with a major accident. And a delegation from the Cattauragus and Allegany reservations, including many of the young Senecas who took the lead in the confrontation, is to go to Albany Wednesday to meet with Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.
The court ruling is the latest twist in a tax fight that is several years old.
Treaties establishing Indian reservations as independent nations prohibit states from levying taxes on transactions between Indians. Without the taxes, the price of cigarettes and fuel sold by Indian establishments has been substantially less than that charged by surrounding retailers.
But in an effort to help close the state budget gap, New York three years ago imposed regulations restricting the amount of tax-free cigarettes and fuel that wholesalers could supply to reservations.
Suppliers exceeding the "cap" -- which was to be set through negotiations with tribal leaders or based on the size of the native population -- would be held liable for taxes on merchandise that was presumably to be sold to non-Indians. The state Commissioner of Taxation and Finance, James W. Wetzler, has estimated those sales cost New York $50 million a year in uncollected taxes.
Indians and their suppliers fought the regulations, and the Attea Brothers, a Buffalo-based cigarette wholesaler, filed suit.
Protests began Wednesday night on the Cattaraugus reservation, 40 miles north of here, when about 200 Indians began burning tires and debris on a bridge overlooking the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway, which skirts the Indian land. Shortly after midnight, they started throwing flaming debris onto the Thruway, causing the police to temporarily close a 30-mile section.
 
Taking Back the Thruway
 State police in riot gear moved in. Thirteen Indians were arrested and three suffered minor injuries, state police said. Four state troopers also were hurt, including the region's commander, Major Bruce Roloff.
The protest spread here Thursday when about 300 Senecas cut off a section of State Route 17, the Southern Tier Expressway.
Today, before the judge issued his temporary injunction, the Indians reinforced roadblocks of cars, burning tires and park benches across state roads and prepared for a confrontation with the more than 200 state police on the scene. After the judge's ruling, barricades came down.
"We're mad," said Eliott Jimerson, a Seneca standing at one barricade. "We're going to take drastic action to make people listen. And if they don't listen, there will be violence."
White residents of Salamanca, which has a population of about 3,500 and is built predominantly on the Indian reservation, became increasingly worried as the protests intensified today. Banks closed early and emptied their cash machines. Supermarkets sent employees home early. So did state parks and some convenience stores.
While the imposition of the tax would be an economic blow for the Senecas, Indian businessmen said the protest was not solely because of the ruling.
"It's been brewing a long time," said Art Jimerson, the nephew of the owner of Seneca Hawk Petro, a four-pump gas station, convenience store and restaurant. "We're finally standing up on our own feet and saying we're not taking it any more. Everybody's boiling point came at one time. We can't stand it anymore and we're not taking it anymore."
The Senecas said that if the state insists on levying the tax, they will take back the land under the Thruway and the Expressway.
"The bottom line is the breaking of their treaty. Again," said J. C. Seneca, a tribal leader. "They make sure we keep our side of the bargain. But they only keep theirs when it's convenient."
At a Thursday news conference, Governor Cuomo took note of the longstanding roots of the protest. "It's hard to deny the emotional validity of their position," he said. "That makes it extremely complicated. Extremely."

HEADLINE: Convention Spotlight Has Warm Glow for the Mayor

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
Mayor David N. Dinkins, who brought the Democrats to New York, was no doubt sorry to see them leave yesterday. Few weeks in Mr. Dinkins's often stormy 30-month tenure have been remotely like this one.
At one point, within a span of 48 hours, the Mayor delivered a welcoming speech from the podium at Madison Square Garden; addressed tens of thousands of people crammed into Times Square for an AIDS rally and, the next morning, a salute to Broadway; took Nelson Mandela, the head of the African National Congress, to meet with Gov. Bill Clinton at the Democratic nominee's hotel; was host to mayors from around the country at Gracie Mansion, and kicked off a glitzy fashion show featuring top New York designers under a huge air-conditioned tent in Central Park. 
 Amid the swirl of events, Mr. Dinkins also managed at least a half-dozen television interviews and countless appearances at breakfasts, luncheons and receptions for convention delegates. And he was greeted with standing ovations and compliments, about both his city and his performance as host to the Democratic National Convention.
 
Long Toil Rewarded
 It was a week that offered a powerful reminder of why someone would want to be Mayor of a city as contentious and demanding as New York.
"Mayor Dinkins, it has been wonderful being in your city these past few days," Representative Maxine Waters of California said on Wednesday at a lunch for women in politics sponsored by Essence magazine. "You have been crisscrossing this city, going everywhere, always with a smile. This is a complicated city, and you're doing a wonderful job."
As hundreds of delegates headed home yesterday, some New York officials said much the same thing. After a week of hoopla at Madison Square Garden and carefully staged events from Brooklyn to the Bronx, the city began returning to its own rhythms. [Page 26.]
Mr. Dinkins, who has spent most of his term trying to overcome criticism of his handling of everything from the budget to labor negotiations to the boycott of a Korean grocery in Brooklyn, is not accustomed to hearing such sustained praise. And he did not dispute those who suggested that the glow coming from New York all week might brighten his own standing.
Like Governor Clinton, Mr. Dinkins is likely to enjoy what political operatives call a bounce in the polls as a result of the upbeat week. But even he acknowledged that the political impact of the convention may not be long-lived. Asked yesterday at a news conference how long he thought he might benefit, Mr. Dinkins said, "Who knows? Maybe an hour and a half."
The Mayor is not a man who easily reveals his feelings in public. When he was asked on Thursday what the week had meant to him, he answered with a phrase that he sometimes employs: "It sure as hell is better than a jab in the eye with a sharp stick."
But when pressed, Mr. Dinkins said the week could not have gone better. "I am delighted with the reaction that we've gotten in the city for the convention, and pleased that my speech went well," he said. "This is all good for our city. It may also not be bad for me."
Polishing New York's image as a tourist attraction surely helps the local economy, particularly when the city has endured two years of national news stories that have depicted it as a place overwhelmed by lurid crimes, fleeing corporations and racial and ethnic strife.
Mr. Dinkins, a loyal Democrat, missed few chances this week to help the Clinton-Gore ticket, and he seemed mindful as well of another race -- his own.
Mr. Dinkins's main Democratic rival, Andrew J. Stein, was highly visible this week in a whirl of appearances with groups that included attending the Hispanic Caucus, the Women's Caucus, gay delegates, advocates for people with AIDS march and abortion-rights advocates.
But, it seemed, no one moved faster than the Mayor.
On Wednesday, after meeting with Mr. Mandela and Mr. Clinton, the Mayor rushed downtown for a news conference at the Varick Street offices of the Spanish-language daily, El Diario-La Prensa. There, he was lauded by the Mayor of San Juan, Hector Luis Acevedo, and the president of the Puerto Rican Senate, Miguel Hernandez Agosto, for making changes to the Democratic platform that assured the party's continued support for existing Federal tax incentives for mainland businesses that relocate to Puerto Rico.
Mr. Dinkins, who has been criticized by local Hispanic leaders for failing help their communities, was hailed by Mr. Acevedo, who called his work on the party platform "testament of his effort and his loyalty to the people of Puerto Rico."
So it went all week, with Mr. Dinkins making 8 to 10 stops a day around Manhattan, then spending the evening at Madison Square Garden. And he was much in demand for interviews: the Mayor's press secretary, Leland T. Jones, said an unofficial count showed about 65 convention-related radio and television appearances in the last two weeks.
And while the Mayor tended to the ceremonial occasions, senior aides oversaw the myriad details of keeping the city and the convention functioning smoothly. Deputy Mayor Bill Lynch handled the large-scale political matters, from shepherding the Rev. Jesse Jackson to greeting Mr. Mandela. The director of the Mayor's Office of Operations, Harvey Robins, coordinated the city's vast and largely successful effort to keep midtown streets safe and gridlock-free. Several prescient aides even created an informal group that they dubbed the Delegate Mugging Response Team, to provide a quick, helping hand to unlucky conventioneers.
The preparations freed the Mayor to shuttle from hotel meeting rooms to outdoor rallies, and at nearly every stop he basked in warm praise.
In the lobby of the Sheraton New York Hotel one morning, a man with a Southwestern accent told Mr. Dinkins: "Great city, Mr. Mayor. I've been here 20 straight years, four times a year, and I think it's never been better."
And during the AIDS rally in Times Square, a young woman yelled, "Hey, Dinkins, we love you, man!" The Mayor, seated on the outdoor stage between Gregory Hines and Jessica Lange, smiled broadly and waved.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Republicans;
G.O.P. Asks Perot Backers To Give Its Ticket a Chance

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TAMPA, July 17

 BODY:
In a campaign foray across three Southern states, Vice President Dan Quayle courted supporters of Ross Perot today and vowed to "peel back the veneer to find out what is underneath" Gov. Bill Clinton, whom the Democrats anointed this week as their Presidential nominee.
Almost a continent away, President Bush took much the same tack toward supporters of the Texas billionaire. 
 In Jackson, Wyo., President Bush ended an idyllic two days of trout fishing. Using barbecue and contrition as his lures, he went off in pursuit of the wily Perot supporter.
In a lunchtime appearance before about 1,000 people at the airport in Jackson Hole, Mr. Bush pleaded for Mr. Perot's supporters to give the Republicans a chance to "complete the dream" of his first term.
"Today I have a message for anyone who supported Ross Perot, and any American who identifies with that frustration that brought them together: I hear you, and you've come through loud and clear," Mr. Bush said. "I hear the voices, in so many accents, say that attention must be paid to our jobs, our schools, our families. Attention must be paid to our future. And I hear that call. And more than that, I share your frustration."
Yet it was Mr. Quayle, at stops in Kentucky, Mississippi and Florida, who laid out what are likely to become the principal themes in the campaign. He portrayed Mr. Clinton and his running mate, Senator Al Gore, as traditional tax-and-spend Democrats who have adopted moderate language to mask their underlying liberalism.
 
Putting G.O.P. Label on Issues
 He said he had been surprised to hear Mr. Clinton speak of subjects ranging from family values to national security in his acceptance speech Thursday night."These are all very much Republican issues," Mr. Quayle said. The Vice President said that as he watched Democratic delegates applaud Mr. Clinton's emphasis on the family, he had been amused because "many in that same audience ridiculed me for bringing it up" during his Murphy Brown speech in California this spring.
Mr. Quayle particularly criticized Mr. Clinton's pro-choice position on abortion. He described the Democratic nominee's pledge to appoint Supreme Court justices who will uphold a woman's right to an abortion as "a very extreme statement," and he ridiculed the Democrats' endorsement of family leave in their platform as "a typical big-Government paternalistic response" to an important social issue.
The Vice President also sought to portray Mr. Clinton as unable to lead the economy back to prosperity. He recalled high inflation and interest rates under former President Jimmy Carter and said that Mr. Clinton planned to raise taxes, which "is not the way to create jobs."
Speaking of the Bush Administration, he said, "We have the plan for economic growth. Please look at our program." He added that it was "important for the American people to know who Bill Clinton is, what damage he will do to the economy."
Mr. Quayle also said that he and Mr. Bush planned to "reach out to the volunteers of Ross Perot." Reversing earlier criticism in which he had described Mr. Perot as a "temperamental tycoon" with no respect for the Constitution, Mr. Quayle praised the Texas billionaire for having "energized a lot of people."
At a news conference late this afternoon, Mr. Quayle urged Mr. Perot's supporters not to become disillusioned with the political process and to bring their energy to the Republican Party.
"If you want change, you have to have a united Government," Mr. Quayle said. "Divided Government does not serve us well."
 
Blaming the Democrats
 As he has done repeatedly in the past, Mr. Quayle blamed the Democratic majority in Congress for the impasse in Washington that Mr. Perot made the centerpiece of his now-abandoned crusade.
Earlier in the day, Mr. Quayle met with leaders of the Perot campaign in Kentucky to seek their support. He said that he had answered their questions about issues, and he predicted that with enough encouragement, they would eventually be coaxed into the Republican fold.
"It is especially important to have the Ross Perot supporters come our way, and I think they will," he said. "But it will take time."
In President Bush's appearance, his oratory bore a telling similarity to some early campaign speeches in New Hampshire last January, when he allowed that he had underestimated public dismay over the state of the economy and told one crowd, "Message: I care."
The apologies helped little in New Hampshire, where Patrick Buchanan, a conservative commentator, gave Mr. Bush a brief scare.
Today's blue-jeans and T-shirt crowd munched appreciatively on barbecue and baked beans, toe-tapped to Western music and applauded politely, but otherwise seemed little moved by the President's pleas.
Mr. Bush's appearance today overflowed with political symbolism and stunning patriotic scenery. It began with a dramatic drop from the sky in a Marine helicopter to an airport runway flanked by the towering Grand Teton Mountains, and it ended with Mr. Bush leaping off a Western-style wagon, loaded with hay bales, to pump hands and kiss children.
But substance sometimes seemed lacking. He seemed unable to offer any detailed answer to some of the frustrations that he raised in his speech. Asking, "What do you say to an elderly woman" who is afraid to leave her home, or a child who must pass through metal detectors to go to school, the President answered his own question by responding: "You say, 'Enough is enough!' And, 'Let's put an end to the lawlessness.' "
His campaign chairman, Robert M. Teeter, who is accompanying Mr. Bush on a two-day swing through Wyoming and Utah, said the President's message today began a strong White House push to lure Mr. Perot's backers to the Republican cause.
He dismissed new opinion polls that show Mr. Clinton leading Mr. Bush by as many as 22 percentage points, noting that Mr. Bush had trailed his Democratic foe by 17 points at this time in 1988 and still won in a walk.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: A Hard Sell;
People in Advertising Aren't Surprised Perot Didn't Stay

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT

 BODY:
Ross Perot's withdrawal from the race for the Presidency came as little surprise to advertising executives and people who study the field. The problems that pressured Mr. Perot into withdrawing, they said yesterday, can be comprehended if the selling of a candidate is compared to the selling of a product.
Eugene Secunda, a professor of marketing at Baruch College in New York, likened Mr. Perot's experience to what happens "in almost any consumer-product category you look at, like automobiles or soft drinks." 
 He added, "The same immutable rules of marketing applied to Ross Perot."
Mr. Secunda advised thinking of Mr. Perot as a new product, trying to persuade consumers to switch from two familiar brands -- President Bush and Gov. Bill Clinton -- they were already considering buying.
"He misjudged what it takes to introduce an unknown brand into a category," he said, "where there are established brands already holding market share."
 
Issues of Spending
 The primary misjudgment came in advertising spending, said Bill Koenigsberg, president of Horizon Media in New York, a company that buys commercial time and print ad space for products like Carvel ice cream and Shasta soft drinks.
Mr. Perot, who had already spent $10 million on his nascent campaign, had said he was willing to spend a total of $100 million, including the costs of advertising. Mr. Koenigsberg said that even such a huge sum might have been too low.
By analyzing the spending of recent third-party Presidential candidates, Mr. Koenigsberg estimated that Mr. Perot would have needed to spend roughly $153 million to attract enough votes to win. Mr. Koenigsberg's formula involved calculating the cost per vote for George Wallace in 1968 and John Anderson in 1980, based on what they spent on advertising, adjusted for inflation.
Mr. Secunda said that even for someone who was ready to spend $100 million, Mr. Perot was acting "as if he was already established and could afford to coast." Spending on political ads was a constant source of tension between Mr. Perot and advisers.
And before Mr. Perot withdrew, news reports said he had balked at the cost of proposed commercials and complained he could get them produced for far less.
"Newcomers always claim they can get it done for 49 cents a commercial," Mr. Secunda said. "It's a classic mistake amateurs make."

HEADLINE: Prices of Long-Term Bonds Drop Sharply

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Bond prices fell sharply yesterday, pushed lower by a regional Federal Reserve bank survey of manufacturers in the Mid-Atlantic region that was stronger than expected, a big drop in the value of the dollar and a negative reaction to opinion polls that show Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas holds a commanding lead over President Bush.
Much of the trading, which was fairly heavy, was done by dealers, market participants said. 
 "There is a Friday phenomenon during the summer that portfolio managers and bond mutual funds tend not to be around," one government securities trader said. "In that sort of environment, there is a pattern for the dealer community to flatten up their positions for the weekend."
The dollar's slide began in earnest after the Commerce Department reported that the nation's trade deficit widened for the third straight month in May, to $7.4 billion.
Results of the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia's survey of local manufacturers also came as a surprise.
The July survey showed a marked acceleration in activity from June levels.
Another unwelcome sign of strength to bond investors came from public opinion polls showing that Governor Clinton emerged from the Democratic Convention with a lead of nearly 2 to 1 over President Bush.
Bond investors fear a victory by the Democrats in the fall would lead to a significant increase in the size of the Federal budget deficit.
Virtually all the decline in prices was concentrated among long-term issues. Short- to intermediate-term maturities were little changed.
"It's the same story we have had for months now," said Steven Slifer, an executive vice president and financial market economist at Lehman Brothers.
"The long end underperforms, intermediates do O.K. and the short end is firm because economic statistics remain weak, and the prospect of another easing move by the Fed remains in place. As a consequence, the yield curve continues to steepen relentlessly."
 
Long Bond Yields 7.68%
 In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 percent 29 1/2-year bonds of 2021 were offered late yesterday at a price of 10322/32 , down 27/32 , to yield 7.68 percent, compared with 7.60 percent on Thursday and 7.62 percent on July 10.
Among outstanding Treasury note issues, the 7 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 1049/32 , down 10/32 to yield 6.89 percent. And the 5 percent two-year notes were offered at 10113/32 , down 2/32 , to yield 4.23 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates were little changed.
Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 3.15 percent late yesterday, down 1 basis point, or one-hundredth of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates were unchanged at a late offered rate of 3.20 percent.
Activity was very slow in the corporate and municipal bond markets.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Mostly Lower As Trade Data Add to Woes

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell against major currencies yesterday in what traders described as the latest of several days of bad news for the dollar and the American economy.
Trading was dominated this week by speculation, confirmed on Thursday, that the German central bank would raise its discount rate at the expense of the dollar. 
 The Government reported yesterday that the United States trade deficit widened to $7.38 billion in May, which was more than the market had anticipated. There was also a 2.5 percent drop in exports in May.
"I think what we've seen happening is that the trade data came on the Friday of a week of negative news for the dollar," said David Jacques, a senior dealer at Barclays Bank.
John Painow, a trader with Chemical New York Capital Markets, agreed that the news of the week had been bad for the dollar, along with President Bush's fall in the polls.
He added that the market does not like election-year uncertainty, and dealers are not clear about what effect the election of the Democratic Presidential nominee, Gov. Bill Clinton, would have on the market.
Jay Tucker, a trader with First Boston, went a step further, saying the dollar's fall in several markets, coupled with falling stocks and a rally in gold, indicated a classic shift to haven investments.
"What we seem to be seeing here is a liquidation of U.S. assets, which is led by dollars," Mr. Tucker said. "The dollar has not bounced in weeks. It has gone down without any type of move up."
In Tokyo, the dollar settled at 125.28 yen yesterday, up from 124.93 on Thursday.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.9515, from $1.9375 late on Thursday. The pound closed at $1.9510 in New York, more expensive than $1.9395 on Thursday.
Other closing prices in New York, compared with late on Thursday, included: 1.3015 Swiss francs, down from 1.3285; 1,109 Italian lire, down from 1,121.50; 4.9325 French francs, down from 4.9910, and 1.18915 Canadian dollars, down from 1.19165.

HEADLINE: Delegates Leave Behind A Satisfied New York City

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON

 BODY:
Hundreds of delegates checked out of their hotels yesterday and headed home, leaving behind beaming city officials who declared that the Democratic National Convention had changed the way the world sees New York.
The exodus of delegates produced luggage-cart gridlock at the New York Sheraton Hotel and Towers, one of the headquarters hotels for convention delegates -- the front entrance was briefly blocked by carts until a bellman cleared a path. But as the day went on, the city returned to its regular rhythms after a week of political hoopla at Madison Square Garden and carefully staged events in other parts of the city. 
 Police officers who had massed on street corners near the Garden all week went back to their regular posts in Manhattan and other boroughs. So did Transit Authority workers who spent the week standing in midtown stations, answering delegates' questions about the subterranean labyrinth. At the Seventh Avenue subway station at 53d Street on the IND B, D and E lines, the token-booth clerk, Patricia Hinds, prepared to take down the sign that said, "For Madison Square Garden, take E train downtown to 34th Street-Penn Station." The message had been put up for delegates staying at the Sheraton, just above the station.
And once again, Madison Square Garden looked like a construction zone. A week after the carpenters put away their tools, workers began tearing apart the $20.8 million worth of renovations the Democrats had demanded. A small bulldozer demolished the special raised floor that had supported thousands of cheering delegates all week long. The podium where Gov. Bill Clinton delivered his acceptance speech on Thursday night was knocked down. Hundreds of telephone lines that had been installed just for the convention were ripped out.
 
Litter Left Behind
 Outside the Garden, the cleanup crews were scrubbing and shining the "public furniture," as the sanitation supervisor for the nonprofit 34th Street Partnership called the lampposts, fire hydrants and pay-telephone stands that had been off limits for the week, when the neighborhood was turned into a security zone.
"They may have brought more money to the area, but they also brought more litter than we expected," said Robert Ferrieri, the sanitation supervisor. He estimated that there was 25 percent more trash in the area than usual.
The city said it had collected three tons of paper for recycling from the Garden area. Sanitation Department officials said they could not tell how much litter they had picked up from the streets.
With many delegates raving about their week in New York City, saying the city seemed cleaner than they had expected and the people friendlier, officials said the convention had achieved their main objective by being "good for our economy and good for our image," as Mayor David N. Dinkins put it.
 
City's Image Polished
 Whether the convention will generate long-term gains for the tourist business remains to be seen -- hotel occupancy figures for July will not be available until September. But Marshall Murdaugh, the executive director of the New York City Convention and Visitors Bureau, was optimistic.
"The convention helped dispel the myth of the unfriendly New Yorker," he said. "These delegates felt welcomed by New York, and that's important because the No. 1 way to attract visitors is not through advertising or direct mail, it's through word of mouth, and the word of mouth has never been more positive."
But not from everyone.
"It's so polluted, it makes my face break out," said Donna Bragg, a co-anchor from KFSM-TV in Fort Smith, Ark., when asked what she thought of New York. "I have a friend from New Jersey who said they've really cleaned the city up. I said, 'This is clean?' "
And Marion Garcia of Houston, a Texas delegate, said he was assigned to a hotel room that was already occupied -- by a woman who came out of the shower to open the door for him as he tried to make the room key work. "I guess she assumed I was her husband," he said. "I jumped back and said, 'Lady, at least you didn't shoot.' "

GRAPHIC: Photos: Mayor David N. Dinkins, left, shaking hands yesterday with the Democratic Presidential nominee, Gov. Bill Clinton, has received compliments about both his city and his performance as host to the convention (Marilynn K. HEADLINE: ABOUT NEW YORK;
Business Made Easy, Or Easier At Least

BYLINE: By Douglas Martin

 BODY:
"IT'S still very much the old boys' network," said Heather Faulding, an architect who owns her own firm. "It's no picnic."
Ms. Faulding made the remark in a monthly meeting of female chief executive officers. They gather to chew over common problems, from collecting bills to marketing. What they don't discuss are the touchy-feely sorts of things men might imagine women would bring up in a support group. 
 They are too busy calculating how to make money in what some still imagine is a man-eat-man business world. But more than half the small businesses in the metropolitan area are owned by women, according to the business census, and the proportion continues to grow. To be sure, their role remains mainly at the very lowest rung, with businesses of significant size continuing to be dominated by men.
 These observations come from Rosalind S. Paaswell, president of the American Woman's Economic Development Corporation. The federally and privately financed group exists to aid the swelling number of female entrepreneurs. Each year, it counsels 3,000 businesswomen in the New York area, where the organization, which is now a national one, began in 1976.
Some 40 of these are company heads meeting in three local groups like this one. "Entrepreneurship is a very lonely undertaking," Ms. Paaswell said. "Every entrepreneur needs someone to talk to."
They rotate among their places of business. On Thursday night, they congregated in the Seventh Avenue offices of Ildi Marshall, a designer. Bottles of water and trays of fruit and cheese graced a makeshift board table.
Backgrounds varied. Ms. Marshall fled Hungary in 1956 with "a handbag and a change of underwear" and found a job packing hot dog rolls for $1 an hour. Nights, she studied design. Today her annual sales exceed $1.7 million.
Ms. Faulding emigrated from South Africa 14 years ago and has had her own business for four years. Janet Grossman, who was once a reservations agent for Pan Am, owns a business travel company with annual sales exceeding $5 million. Patricia Scordio owns a construction company with 18 employees that posted $1.6 million in sales last year.
Rita Troshynski, who moved here from Nebraska, has found a niche connecting artists with manufacturers. Pearl Mintzer has made a business of making things more visually attractive, from the Bloomingdale's fragrance department to boxes for leather goods.
The final participant was, of all things, a man, Diego Leiva, who was helped by an older man when he set off in business at 17. Once the seller of computer equipment had become wealthy, he asked the mentor how he could repay him. "Do unto others as I did unto you," he said.
So, for 2 1/2 years, Mr. Leiva has been leading groups like this one. "I get nothing other than to see them succeed," he said.
The discussion began with Ms. Grossman saying she would miss the next meeting because of a bar mitzvah in London. She had unsuccessfully tried to get the date of the bar mitzvah changed. It was agreed she could participate by means of a conference call.
She then told the happy news that she had brought in four new accounts worth $500,000 annually since the last meeting. The bad news followed: the bank had called her $24,000 note.
Mr. Leiva urged her to take a lawyer to the bank meeting, not just her accountant as she had intended. This stirred support.
"Make a big show," Ms. Scordio said. "I don't think they expect that."
Mr. Leiva then interceded with the general thought that all the women should be working from detailed, up-to-date business plans. He said computer programs to write them are available for $99. "There are a thousand good ideas out there," he declared. "The problem is the execution."
Ms. Marshall brought up her difficulties collecting bills, and participants suggested using a buyer's credit card. Ms. Scordio described how an employee had asked for a raise she had intended to give later, and received a battery of welcome advice. Ms. Mintzer complained about buyers knocking off her creations but was rebuked by Mr. Leiva for not having written an ironclad contract.
"This is called a lesson in life," he said.
The discussion veered to a venture capital scheme that Ms. Troshynski needed to discuss. And so it went. These were women navigating waters once barred to their sex, but now frighteningly open to all. The stakes seemed huge.
"I'm alone," Ms. Marshall said. "My whole family's dead. I'm divorced. I have to stay in business to keep living."

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Investors Seeking Safety Drive Up Precious Metals

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Investors seeking a safe harbor from the slumping stock market and a falling dollar drove up prices of precious metals yesterday.
"It was a great end to a great week, if you're a bull," one analyst said. 
 Gold and other precious metals are traditionally seen as safer investments than paper assets in times of economic or political turmoil.
Prices rebounded from Thursday's fall when the market reacted negatively to Ross Perot's dropping out of the Presidential race and to signs of diplomatic efforts in South Africa, which operates some of the world's most productive gold and platinum mines.
At the Commodity Exchange in New York, August gold rose $4.80, to $358 an ounce, and September silver added 6.2 cents, to $3.99 an ounce.
At the New York Mercantile Exchange, October platinum soared $7.80, to $391.30 an ounce.
Ian MacDonald, dealer at Credit Suisse, said the rise in metals prices was attributable to the fall in the dollar and another, more fashionable factor.
"Jewelry demand overseas is really getting strong, running at an all time high," he said.
In the platinum market, sensitivity to events in South Africa remained acute. A general strike is set there for Aug. 3.
"Despite talk of diffusion of tensions in South Africa, this move underscores the concern in the market," said James Steel of Refco Inc. "Anxieties over tension spilling over into the mining sector remain omnipresent."
Copper prices retreated, despite news that Polish copper miners will begin a strike next week.
September copper lost 1.15 cents, to 115.20 cents a pound.
Oil prices also fell on profit taking, particularly in the gasoline market.
"It started off as profit taking and once it got going, we saw some fresh selling," said Peter Beutel, energy director at Pegasus Econometric Inc.
August oil dropped 21 cents, to $21.58 a barrel; August gasoline fell 1.12 cents, to 59.83 cents a gallon, and August heating oil lost 0.23 cent, to 59.89 cents a gallon.
Corn prices extended an eight-day string of losses set off by widespread rains in the Midwest that has chopped 15 cents a bushel off the December contract's price.
The rains have created ideal conditions for the corn and soybean crops, which were suffering through a spring dry spell.
At the Chicago Board of Trade, December corn declined 1.5 cents, to $2.32 3/4 a bushel. November soybeans, which fell for the fifth consecutive trading day, declined another 3.5 cents, to $5.65 3/4 a bushel. July wheat gained 2.75 cents, to $3.48 1/2 a bushel.

HEADLINE: Consumer Confidence Dips

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
A survey prepared by the University of Michigan indicates that consumers' confidence in the economy slipped in early July, people who get the subscription-only report on the survey said yesterday.
They said that the survey -- keenly watched by financial markets -- showed that the sentiment index fell to 77.1 percent in early July from 80.4 percent for the whole of June. Its index of consumer expectations, used by the Federal Government as part of its leading-economic-indicators report, fell to 67.1 percent from 70.7 percent, they said, while the index of current economic conditions fell to 92.7 percent from 95.4 percent. 
 All the figures indicate a depressed consumer view of the state of the economy.
By contrast, a survey by the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia released yesterday showed manufacturers in that area a lot less gloomy about the economy this month. Its index for current conditions rose to 27.0 in July from 10.9 last month.
"This is the highest increase since April 1988," said John Canavan, an analyst at Stone & McCarthy Research Associaties Inc. "It is pretty strong."
"Signs of improvement everywhere are pretty weak," Mr. Canavan cautioned. "Everything's showing a real tepid rise."
The University of Michigan's index is closely guarded by its tabulators, none of whom will comment on it. It is composed of three indexes -- consumer sentiment, current economic conditions and consumer expectations. Financial markets tend to focus on the consumer sentiment portion.
