HEADLINE: More Jobs, Jobs, Jobs

BYLINE: By Roger C. Altman and Arthur Levitt Jr.; Roger C. Altman is co-chairman of the Mayor's Management Advisory Task Force. Arthur Levitt Jr. is chairman of its committee on incentives and tax policy.

 BODY:
Pessimism over New York City's future runs deep. Most people predict a continued exodus of businesses and taxpayers. Apparently the experts have not visited Pittsburgh, which has made a strong comeback over the past year. A key reason is its aggressive approach to economic development. Yes, it has pockets of poverty but has rebuilt an economic core that provides job opportunity.
In May, Mayor David Dinkins's Management Advisory Task Force compared Pittsburgh's economic plans to New York's, found ours inadequate and suggested sweeping changes. Our main proposal is the establishment of a development bank that has substantial financing for long-term, job-intensive projects and is insulated from politics as effectively as possible. We are negotiating with financing sources to try to create one. 
 New York has been severely underspending on economic development. Despite a $29 billion operating budget and a $4 billion capital budget, the city spent only $84 million directly on development last year. The immense pressures for spending for social purposes crowd out development. Pittsburgh's direct spending on projects that create jobs has been 10 times higher than ours per capita.
Cities with the most successful redevelopment records have worked closely with business and leading nonprofit organizations. Unlike New York, they plan all aspects of development with the private sector.
In 1982, Pittsburgh formed an Urban Redevelopment Authority that plans and finances large projects and is a good model for New York. It has an independent board and a history of independent operations. It sells its own bonds but is connected to the city government because it gets Federal and state monies. One recent project is the Pittsburgh Technology Center, a downtown industrial park for research and light-manufacturing businesses, which is projected to create 11,000 jobs.
By contrast, New York City's Economic Development Corporation and the state's Urban Development Corporation are out of money. They depend on their respective legislatures for funds, getting them only in a crisis. For example, when several commodity exchanges threatened to leave New York, the money to subsidize a new location was found. But far-sighted projects like building a biotechnology center together with Columbia University wait for 10 years or more.
The only solution lies in a new organization whose governance and financing are less politically dependent. Its equity must be obtained on a long-term, not year-to-year, basis.
We are negotiating with the city, the Municipal Assistance Corporation and corporate pension funds on multi-year commitments for $150 million in equity. We are also seeking a semi-independent board and management; at least half the directors would be business leaders appointed for fixed terms. These negotiations are not easy because legislatures usually want tight control over the use of money, but the bank would succeed only if it were semi-autonomous.
Once the equity was committed, it would be leveraged by selling bonds in the capital markets. Initially, the city would guarantee the bonds, but by receiving a portion of each project's cash flow, the bank eventually would become self-supporting.
Some believe that large-scale development ignores the most disadvantaged neighborhoods and their small businesses. But we found that central business districts are crucial to creating jobs across the entire income spectrum. Manhattan creates more than a third of the city's jobs, through direct employment and multiplier effects, and this is where the bank would concentrate initially.
The city's economy is not going to recover strongly on its own. An initiative to rekindle the growth of jobs is sorely needed; without them, the best social policies can't succeed. But there is a financing gap to be faced, and development banking can fill it.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

And Bear in Mind
(Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)
THE END OF EQUALITY, by Mickey Kaus. (Basic Books, $25.) Mr. Kaus, an editor of The New Republic, argues boldly and radically that the present welfare system, corrupt and corrupting, should be eliminated and replaced by a guaranteed jobs program.
DESTINY'S JOURNEY, by Alfred Doblin. Edited by Edgar Passler. (Paragon House, $24.95.) This important, nourishing memoir by the author of "Berlin Alexanderplatz" looks at human nature under stress and its recuperative powers in two major episodes: Doblin's flight from Germany to America and his return in 1945.
MEETING EVIL, by Thomas Berger. (Little, Brown, $19.95.) In Mr. Berger's 18th novel, a good-enough man's life is taken over by a bad-as-possible man who suddenly shows up on the doorstep.
IMPOSSIBLE VACATION, by Spalding Gray. (Knopf, $22.) An exercise in the neurotic picaresque, this glum, hilarious first-person novel, with its self-absorbed protagonist, has the rambling, confessional feel of Mr. Gray's customary performance pieces.
THE STOLEN HOUSE, by Bernard L. Herman. (University Press of Virginia, cloth, $35; paper, $16.95.) An account of an 1812 lawsuit leads to a historian's fascinating examination of economic life when most Americans were poor and the few rich knew no shame.
TROMBONE, by Craig Nova. (Grove Weidenfeld, $20.95.) Mr. Nova's restrained, skillful novel exposes a young man who only wants life to be ordinary to the perils of trying to save his father, his friends and himself from an array of extraordinary menaces.
BASTARD OUT OF CAROLINA, by Dorothy Allison. (Dutton, $20.) This first novel, precise and terrible in the details of poverty and meanness, follows its title character to the age of 13, when a dreadful trauma persuades her that her life is finished.

PUB-DATE: July 19, 1992

SECTION: Section 7; Page 32; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 906 words

HEADLINE: New & Noteworthy

BYLINE: BY LAUREL GRAEBER

 BODY:
A VERY THIN LINE: The Iran-Contra Affairs, by Theodore Draper. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $16.) Mr. Draper's concern is that very fine line that separates legitimate from illegitimate use of our Government's power. The Iran-contra affairs, he concludes, were the most startling contemporary example of the latter. Last year our reviewer, Tom Wicker, found this book "meticulous and disturbing," "the most exhaustive examination" of the Iran-contra events.
WARTIME LIES, by Louis Begley. (Ivy, $4.99.) Only the most elaborate kinds of deceit could rescue Maciek, this novel's Polish Jewish narrator, from the horrors of the Holocaust. A middle-aged man when the story begins, he relates his boyhood flight from the Nazis, which he made in the company of his Aunt Tania, a high-spirited young woman. Her quick wits and imaginative acting helped save their lives, but not Maciek's faith and innocence. This is a "masterly first novel," Judith Grossman said here last year. "It seems no less than justice that Maciek and Tania should be given their honorable place . . . in fiction, where lies may be reconciled with truth." 
 ROME AND A VILLA, by Eleanor Clark. (Harper Perennial, $12.) Like the city it celebrates, this book endures. Published 40 years ago, expanded and reissued in 1974, this combination history and memoir has been given a new preface. In 1952 our reviewer, Katherine Anne Porter, said, "With her genius for attention, observation and recording, [Ms. Clark] sees with beautiful accuracy the differences between things."
THE MIRACLE GAME, by Josef Skvorecky. Translated by Paul Wilson. (Norton, $10.95.) This novel spans the period between two crises of faith, one fictional, one real: the controversy following the supposed movement of a statue of St. Joseph in a rural church in Czechoslovakia in 1949, and the democracy-crushing Soviet occupation some 20 years later. These events are seen through the eyes of the narrator, a roguish but good-hearted Czech named Danny. Mr. Skvorecky "is honorable enough to offer no solutions here, only a work of literature, of bitter gravity and of bitter mirth," Angela Carter said in The Book Review last year.
HIS EYE IS ON THE SPARROW: An Autobiography, by Ethel Waters with Charles Samuels. (Da Capo, $13.95.) Born in poverty to a 13-year-old rape victim, Ethel Waters became a chambermaid, then a vaudevillian and ultimately, a stage and film star. When this 1951 best seller was first published, our reviewer, Ruth Chatterton, said: "I felt as if I had been curled up in front of a fire listening as [she] bared her soul. . . . I listened enthralled."
A GLIMPSE OF SCARLET: And Other Stories, by Roxana Robinson. (Harper Perennial, $10.) New York City and its environs are the setting for many of these 14 stories, which revolve around familial love that is often threatened and sometimes regained. This is a "stunning first collection," Bret Lott said here last year. "Ms. Robinson may be John Cheever's heir apparent."
THE MAN WHO KNEW INFINITY: A Life of the Genius Ramanujan, by Robert Kanigel. (Washington Square/Pocket Books, $12.) The brief life of Srinivasa Ramanujan (1887-1920), a poor Brahmin from rural India who became one of the most important contributors to number theory, is "one of the most romantic stories in the history of mathematics," our reviewer, John Allen Paulos, said last year. He added that this book is one "even a complete innumerate can enjoy."
THE TIME AND THE PLACE: And Other Stories, by Naguib Mahfouz. Selected and translated by Denys Johnson-Davies. (Anchor, $8.50.) These 20 stories by the Egyptian Nobel laureate take place in Cairo, but their characters are often transported to other territories through dreams and death. Last year, one critic noted that "Mahfouz uses an economical, simple style to create worlds exotically different from ours yet bound by universal home truths."
THE RITUALS OF DINNER: The Origins, Evolution, Eccentricities, and Meaning of Table Manners, by Margaret Visser. (Penguin, $12.50.) According to Ms. Visser, most tableside etiquette exists to undercut the potential violence inherent in mealtime, when humans gather together with sharp implements to indulge a very basic appetite. "The book progresses like a feast," Molly O'Neill said here last year. "Read it, because you'll never look at a table knife the same way again."
THE TRANSPARENT MAN, by Anthony Hecht. (Knopf, $10.) Beauty, even natural beauty, is cruel in the poems of Anthony Hecht, who explores the grimness and decay beneath the surface of the familiar. In 1990 our reviewer, William Logan, observed that "his dry and melancholy authority has been a brilliant counterirritant to the wastage of our language." Knopf has also reissued Mr. Hecht's COLLECTED EARLIER POEMS ($15), which includes the complete text of his 1968 Pulitzer Prize winner, "The Hard Hours."
YOU MAY PLOW HERE: The Narrative of Sara Brooks, edited by Thordis Simonsen. (Norton, $8.95.) Sara Brooks, a black American, led an ordinary life with extraordinary will: born in 1911 to a struggling Alabama farmer, she became a cleaning woman and union organizer who managed to support five children. This book, consisting of her reminiscences as told over 10 years to the daughter of her Cleveland employers, is a "much-needed addition to our expanding knowledge of American social history," our reviewer, Frances Smith Foster, said in 1986.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 14; Column 5; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 5062 words

HEADLINE: Why Paris Works

BYLINE: By Steven Greenhouse; Steven Greenhouse was a correspondent in The New York Times Paris bureau for five years and recently joined the Washington bureau.

 BODY:
In a hidden, walled-off area, just west of the Boulevard St.-Michel, Paul Rissel looks like a figure borrowed from the 19th century as he opens the door to the lush greenhouse. Wearing a rough brown tweed sport coat and a long camel-colored scarf, he pushes past some ficus and stops next to a dozen unobtrusive black trays. These trays, he points out, are one of the secrets behind the ageless beauty of Paris's ornate Jardin du Luxembourg, which was built for Queen Marie de Medicis some 370 years ago. Rissel, one of the two chief gardeners, explains that the trays produce seedlings for the tens of thousands of geraniums, dahlias and petunias that the Jardin's 80 gardeners meticulously replant each May around the majestic central fountain.
The resplendent array of flowers gives the garden the idyllic air of a Renoir painting. During the gentle rains of spring, lovers stroll hand in hand, and when the sun breaks through, 5-year-olds scamper around the fountain to chase after their toy sailboats. 
 "People just love this garden," says Rissel, with a pride nurtured by 38 years of working at the Jardin. "In most big cities, the natives lack contact with nature, and that's what we're trying to give them."
A soft-spoken man with soft hands and long gray sideburns, Rissel heads a small army of gardeners. Each year they plant or transplant 350,000 flowers, and each spring they cart out 150 palm and orange trees, some of them 200 years old, that were lovingly sheltered from the winter cold.
At a time when cities from Lagos to Los Angeles are afflicted by homelessness, crime and budget traumas, Paris's famed garden is an oasis from urban turmoil. Mayors around the world may be screaming for cash, but the Jardin du Luxembourg is awash in money. It boasts more than one gardener per acre, which allows for an attention to detail and beauty that is rare in modern cities. One gardener devoted two full months to scooping out the rot from the trunk of a beech tree that the gardeners were eager to save because it stood eloquently alongside a small Bartholdi Statue of Liberty. "We function like the gardeners of an old house of the bourgeoisie," Rissel says. "We do much more by hand."
Rissel and the garden he nurses are just one gilded strand in the tapestry of cobbled streets, quaint quays and medieval churches that make Paris one of the world's most beautiful, best-run cities. Although many cities appear to be breaking down from poverty and decaying infrastructure, Paris seems to be improving with age.
FOR MANY OF THE CITY'S 2.2 million residents and many of the 20 million tourists who visit each year, Paris remains a magical, even transcendent, place. While many Americans shun their own cities as if they were places suffering from the plague, Paris is a city with which countless people still have a passionate love affair.
The people who run Paris know that if their city relied on just the charms of its past, it would lose its magic. Thus, they have sought to superimpose a smoothly running, modern metropolis on the city bequeathed them by medieval kings and 18th-century revolutionaries. And they have succeeded royally.
Garbage is picked up seven days a week, mail is delivered three times a day and all of Paris's 800 miles of streets are swept by hand each day. At rush hour, the subways come once every 80 seconds, and many Metro stops are decorated with mosaics and murals. Affluent families are rushing not to flee for the suburbs, but to buy apartments in Paris's choicest neighborhoods and to send their children to public schools.
There is no single explanation for why Paris works so well. Rather, Paris has become a shining model for urban planners thanks to numerous ingredients lacking in many other cities: ample financing, sound administration, farsighted planning, technological ingenuity, a flair for design and an ambition to always improve.
It would be wrong to single out Paris from other French cities as a success story, because Toulouse, Lyons, Nice, Bordeaux and Strasbourg have worked just as hard to keep their beauty, build a vibrant cultural life and remain attractive for families. Nonetheless, Paris, whose metropolitan area includes 10.5 million people (one-fifth of France's population), is undeniably the Olympus of French cities.
Parisians have two major complaints. Traffic congestion has created a miasma of noise, pollution and stress, helping to make Paris's high-strung population even more irritable. The other is that crime is growing, although the roughest parts of Paris seem no more dangerous than the safest parts of many American cities. Paris had 80 murders last year, compared with 482 in Washington, which has about one-fourth the population.
Homelessness is another problem, although it does not seem one of the Parisians' main concerns, perhaps because the city has long romanticized the clochards who sleep along the Seine. The homeless, estimated at between 6,000 and 15,000, can stay for up to six months in 60 government-run or private shelters where they receive free room, board, medical care and job training. Most go to these shelters voluntarily, but the police often round up sleeping drunks to protect them from the cold.
"Paris's streets are cleaner than American cities, its garbage is picked up more regularly, its streets are paved more often and its bureaucracy is more efficient," says Michel Rousseau, an economics professor who studies urban problems. "But all this costs a lot of money."
Fortunately for Paris, the national Government contributes more than half the city's revenues. Because the state pays so much, Paris's affluent families do not shoulder a huge fiscal burden of caring for the immigrants and poor living in the city. This is one reason Paris has not suffered from the middle-class flight that has hurt so many American cities.
As one urban planner puts it: "One reason Paris has so few problems is that the type of people who make problems can't afford to live in Paris." Economic realities force the poor to live in suburbs ringing Paris, but even there, in the ban lieue, the levels of poverty, violence and drugs are a fraction of those in American cities.
"Because of France's republican traditions, there is a real sense of solidarity, a real desire to help the less-well-off," says Roland Castro, director of the national Government's efforts to help the suburbs. "People often point to American cities as a model to avoid. They say, 'That can happen to us if we let things slide.' "
AT ONE OF THE 50 MAHOGANY TABLES under the gaze of two austere Chinese statues, Francois Dupin is scribbling on a napkin to explain why his cafe, Les Deux Magots, remains a mecca for Paris's beau monde. "The Chamber of Deputies is over there," says the short, dapper cafe manager, drawing a short black arrow to the west. "The students come from over there," he says, aiming an arrow to the east. "And all the artists and antique dealers come from down there." His last arrow points north to the Seine.
On the cream-colored wall behind him is a photograph of Simone de Beauvoir hunched over a table, writing at the famed cafe on the Boulevard St.-Germain. Nearby is a photo of a debonair, mustached young Ernest Hemingway, reading a newspaper at the cafe. Partly to imbibe the legend of such famous writers, partly to taste its flavorful coffee and atmosphere, camera-toting Japanese tourists, chain-smoking French intellectuals and lanky American Hemingway-wannabes crowd into Les Deux Magots each day. Many rush to the sidewalk tables, next to artists selling lithographs and in the shadow of the 12th-century towers of the church of St.-Germain-des-Pres.
"We're in a privileged neighborhood," Mr. Dupin says.
In one way or another all of Paris's 20 arrondissements, or districts, are privileged. The first arrondissement has the Palais Royal and Louvre; the fourth has the Place des Vosges and the Ile St.-Louis; the fifth has the Sorbonne; the sixth, the Jardin du Luxembourg and Ecole des Beaux-Arts; the seventh, the Invalides and the Eiffel Tower. The eighth is known for the Champs-Elysees, the Elysee Palace and world-famous shops like Hermes and Christian Lacroix. The ninth has the grandiose 19th-century Palais Garnier opera house, and the plush 16th is renowned for its opulent fin-de-siecle mansions.
Everyone wants to live in these neighborhoods, but only the privileged few need apply. One reason is that Paris is small, about half the size of Brooklyn. Rents have been pushed sky-high by limits on building heights and a shortage of land for new housing, caused in part by all the space used for parks, businesses and government. Not wanting Paris to become Manhattan-sur-Seine, the city's planners have generally limited building heights to seven stories in the historic center and relegated skyscrapers to the outskirts.
A two-bedroom apartment in central Paris often costs $2,500 a month, about the same as in Manhattan and some 60 percent more than in Chicago. Parking a car costs about $250 a month, roughly the same as in Manhattan. Cleaning a suit is around $15 and a good chicken runs $2.30 a pound. About the only things cheaper in Paris than in America are baguettes, Beaujolais and Christian Dior gowns.
"I love to live in Paris -- I love the possibilities it offers," says Francoise Romand, a 36-year-old film maker. "The Metro is great, the buses are great and the city's very safe. If you get lost anywhere, there's hardly any risk."
In her view, there is nowhere else to live in France for people in film. Paris gives her the cultural fix she needs day after day. She recently went to a dance concert by Dominique Bagouet's French troupe, an experimental farce about a restaurant, "Lapin Chasseur," and a rock concert at the Cigalle, one of Paris's hottest nightclubs. She also visited Sophie Calle's photography exhibit at the Museum of Modern Art and Nicholas Garnier's avant-garde show at an art gallery near the Boulevard Montparnasse.
And that's not to mention exhibitions at the Grand Palais, Louvre, Picasso Museum and Musee d'Orsay. The money the national and city governments spend on Paris's cultural life is probably equal to the overall budgets of some third world nations.
"The French remain very attached to the idea of culture and education," says Francoise Cachin, director of the Musee d'Orsay. She says that both the left and the right agree it is important to finance museums generously to improve Paris's cultural life and to keep the tourists coming.
"There is a rivalry between the national and city governments about who can sponsor the best shows," Cachin says. "It's very positive for the museums and museumgoers."
Notwithstanding the impressive array of museums and municipal services, Parisians' local taxes are not astronomical. The reason: L'Etat, the national Government, pays 40 percent of the city's $23 billion operating budget. The national Government also pays half of most large projects, like schools, sewers and day-care centers. In addition, the state finances Paris's public hospitals, covers almost all welfare costs and pays the salaries of Paris's 24,650 teachers and 26,000 police officers and firefighters.
"In almost every European country, the central Government plays an important role in supporting the cities," says Leo van den Berg, director of the European Institute for Comparative Urban Research at the University of Rotterdam. "Europe's cities are very dependent on central money, and not so much on local fiscal circumstances."
That the cost of running Paris is spread throughout France means the city's residents are not socked with exorbitant taxes, although overall the French pay a greater share of their income for national taxes than Americans do. Indeed, the main taxes in Paris -- the apartment tax and the business tax -- are lower than in many country towns, causing some provincial politicians to complain that they are subsidizing Paris's elite.
Paris is probably far more spoiled by the state than are other European cities because it is the seat of Government and the capital of French finance, industry, entertainment and mass communication. Not only that, it is the cradle of French culture and history, the city of Voltaire, Napoleon, Pasteur, Hugo, Proust, de Gaulle and Sartre.
No one will ever see a headline like "Mitterrand to Paris: Drop Dead," because one of President Francois Mitterrand's preoccupations is adding new baubles to the capital. The French press has dubbed him Mitterramses I because of the huge monuments he has built, including the $400 million Bastille Opera, the I. M. Pei glass pyramid at the Louvre, the gigantic new finance ministry and the 350-foot-tall Grande Arche de la Defense. And that doesn't include the $1.3 billion Bibliotheque de France that Mitterrand has commissioned, which is slated to be the world's largest library.
Mitterrand's presidential projects, with a price tag of $3 billion, follow similarly grandiose schemes by his predecessors: Valery Giscard d'Estaing masterminded the Musee d'Orsay and the Cite des Sciences museum, while Georges Pompidou fathered the Pompidou Center, the hugely popular art museum.
Although many critics deride these buildings as monuments to presidential egos, these projects have undeniably increased Paris's stature as a city of art, culture and architecture. The Musee d'Orsay, for instance, attracts almost four million visitors a year, and art critics from around the world have hailed its recent exhibitions on Seurat, Munch and Gauguin. The museum, which used to be a train station, was slated for demolition until President Giscard d'Estaing moved to save it. "It was a project that couldn't be done without the will of the State," says Cachin, the museum's director. "I can only rejoice."
TOURISTS strolling along Quai de Montebello near Notre Dame often pass a man in a green uniform who is intently sweeping the street with what looks like a large twig broom. Street cleaners like him are ubiquitous in Paris -- of the city's 38,000 employees, 4,500 are sweepers, most of them Arab or African immigrants. They sweep each of Paris's streets daily, and heavily trafficked business and tourist streets are swept twice.
All this work by hand shows Paris's efficiency, obsession with detail and willingness to spend money to achieve its goals. Each year Paris spends 10 percent of its budget, or about $2.2 billion, on cleanliness, which translates to $1,000 for every resident.
"The broom remains irreplaceable," says Alain Le Troquet, technical director for Paris's department of sanitation and the environment. "You can't do everything with a machine."
Astute observers will notice a curious thing. The brooms no longer have crude brown branches, but instead bright green plastic fingers. Engineers in Paris's sanitation department had long appreciated how efficiently peasants' twig brooms swept debris along, but they were frustrated by how much the brooms cost and how often the twigs broke.
So Paris's sanitation department, considered Europe's most innovative, asked manufacturers to develop a broom that used sturdy plastic fingers rather than wood. The new plastic brooms cost one-fifth as much as the wooden ones and last seven times as long.
This is just one way Paris's administrators have demonstrated their technological ingenuity. The city's water system churns out a foot-wide stream that runs alongside the city's curbs to wash away litter. Paris has worked with industry to develop a vehicle to clean up the animal oil left from all the poultry, rabbit and beef sold at open-air markets. Voila, the Gyrolave squirts steaming, swirling soapy water onto the pavement and then sweeps the street.
Another truck shoots compressed water under cars to remove the litter beneath them, while a second vehicle has long arms with five joints to pick up leaves. The newest vehicle has an elephantlike trunk that vacuums up sidewalk litter. The city soon hopes to introduce a robotic, unmanned version of this contraption.
"You have to give the French credit for being innovative," says van den Berg, the urban expert in Rotterdam.
Parisians say the city has become much cleaner since 1977 when Jacques Chirac became their first democratically elected mayor in a century. Previously Paris had been run by a prefect appointed by the Interior Minister, but residents often argued that a mayor held accountable in regular elections would be more attentive to their needs. (The prefect still runs the police department.)
When Parisians talk about cleanliness, their main complaint is canine excrement, notwithstanding the city's vaunted new motor scooters that vacuum up dog droppings. Not wanting to alienate dog owners, who represent a powerful voting bloc, the city for years refused to fine owners who did not clean up after their poodles. But with complaints growing, Philippe Galy, director of the department of sanitation and the environment, started ordering fines in May: $110 for the first offense and $230 for the second. "It's absurd," he says. "With all the serious environmental problems, like global warming, the ozone layer, Chernobyl and nuclear waste, it's unbelievable that the No. 1 subject of conversation at every Paris dinner party is dog doo."
PUBLIC HIGH school like Lycee Janson-de-Sailly, built with busts of Pascal, Hugo and other luminaries along its majestic 200-yard facade, simply does not exist in an American city. The 109-year-old institution is in the 16th arrondissement, the Paris equivalent of Park Avenue, and the bankers, diplomats and high government officials who live there scurry to send their children to Janson.
Janson has 3,200 students, a lengthy waiting list and a substantial number of students from Paris's rich western suburbs, who are attracted by the school's reputation. The school has 250 teachers, several of them accomplished novelists and historians. Janson's alumni include former President Giscard d'Estaing, former Prime Minister Laurent Fabius and the Attali twins -- Jacques, president of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development and Bernard, chairman of Air France.
Its paint may be peeling, its long, primitive desks may be gnarled from decades of use and abuse, but its student body continues to excel. About 95 percent of Janson's graduates pass the forbidding, all-important bacca laureat examination that is the ticket to a university.
"The school is excellent in many ways," says Francoise Rietsch, who heads one of Janson's parent associations. "There is a lot of discipline, self-discipline, among the students."
Sitting behind the old wooden desk in her tidy office, Yvonne Cluzet, the school's earnest principal, makes clear that her main concern is academics and not the woes often associated with urban schools.
"Drugs just aren't a problem here," she says. "And we don't have problems with teen-age pregnancy. Our students are mature." The biggest problem she could think of was that two years ago bands of teen-agers from the suburbs stole pocketbooks, wallets and expensive coats from Janson students as they left school. The police quickly stopped it.
Janson and other Parisian schools do not suffer from a vicious cycle in which the middle class pulls its children out of public schools, tilting the balance toward poorer immigrant children and causing more middle-class families to send their children elsewhere.
Jean-Marie Demade, manager at a metallurgy company, moved his family from Rueil-Malmaison, a suburb, back to Paris so his son Julien could attend Janson. "I returned because of the quality of the education," he says. "And life for children is more interesting and lively in Paris, with the movies, museums, theaters and concerts, than it is in the suburbs."
Twenty-four percent of Paris's high-school students go to private schools. Parents choose those schools because they want their children to receive a religious education or because they have underachieving children and think that private schools will be stricter. The overachievers are sent to public schools like Janson, which, good as it is, doesn't even rank at the top of Paris's public lycees. Most teachers rate Louis-le-Grand and Henri IV even higher.
"The middle class flocking to private schools just isn't a problem here," says Michele Gendreau-Massalou, the rector of Paris's school system. "In terms of passing the baccalaureat, public schools produce better results than private schools."
Schools are just one of the quality services that keep families in Paris. The city has begun building moderately priced three-bedroom apartments because many couples have complained that once they have two or three children they can no longer afford Parisian rents. The city issues a "Paris-Famille" card to parents of three or more children entitling them to $400 in annual discounts on a range of activities, including transport, school meals and college tuition.
Another magnet for families is the city-run day-care system, which cares for 20,000 children a day, attracting rich and poor alike. The day-care center at 54 rue St.-Maur is typical of the 250 city-run centers except for its bold architecture: it has a spiraling concrete facade that resembles the Guggenheim Museum. Its front is windowless to keep out street noise and pollution, while its back is filled with sun-drenched floor-to-ceiling windows.
The center on the rue St.-Maur has a staff of 25 to watch over 87 children, aged 3 months to 3 years. Each of its three floors has a glass-enclosed nap area, and the staff has painted pink and blue rabbits and stars on the see-through walls. Each week, one of the center's aides stages a marionette show; the city offers special courses to teach day-care workers how to do such shows.
"I can afford my own au pair, but I much prefer the day-care center," says Patricia Fayet, a radiologist, as she watches her 1-year-old son, Yann, play in a bright blue plastic tub filled with hundreds of striped balls. "At the day-care center, the children get professional care and learn how to live with others."
Each center has a director who lives on the site and is trained as a licensed nurse and specialist in early child development. All the day-care workers must have spent a year in college studying care of children under age 3. A doctor visits each center once a week.
At the center on the rue St.-Maur, parents can leave their children from 7:30 A.M. to 6:30 P.M., but France Galas, the director, chides parents who leave a child for more than eight hours. Payments are on a sliding scale, ranging from $30 to $400 a month per child, with the city picking up half the cost of running the centers.
The centers are so successful that there is a waiting list of thousands of children, and the city is struggling to keep up by building one new day-care center a month.
"A few years ago mothers thought it was bad to put their children in a public day-care center because they felt guilty they weren't doing enough for their kids," says Elisabeth Allaire, director of social services, children and health for Paris. "Now mothers have heard so many good things about our day-care centers that they think they are bad mothers if they don't send their kids to our centers."
IN MANY WAYS, Paris is a tale of two cities. There is the Paris of the travel guides: the city of three-star restaurants and Yves Saint Laurent boutiques, the city of the 2.2 million privileged souls who live within the 22-mile ring road, the Boulevard Peripherique.
Then there is the other Paris, the outer ring where the working classes live, often in anonymous 1960's tower blocks. These are the suburbs where gangs of immigrant teen-agers clash with the police, where the sons of Algerian and Moroccan workers have a 25 percent jobless rate and where the native French tilt heavily toward Jean-Marie Le Pen, the far-right, anti-immigrant leader. These suburbs include Sartrouville, Montfermeil, Mantes-la-Jolie and Gennevilliers.
"One important reason why Paris is successful is that it's a fantastically elitist city," says Christopher Brooks, an economist specializing in urban issues at the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development in Paris. "While a lot of people would like to live there, lots of people can't afford to. The social composition is skewed as a result. The poor are forced to live in the outskirts."
The Quartier du Luth in Gennevilliers is neither the worst nor the best of the banlieue. It is a United Nations of immigrants from Algeria, the Antilles, the Ivory Coast, Morocco, Tunisia, Turkey, Zaire and a dozen other countries. About 40 percent of its 10,000 residents are immigrants, and fewer than half the children finish high school. Teachers complain that they find syringes near the school gates.
"This isn't the greatest neighborhood," says Ahmet Ersoy, a 30-year-old unemployed refugee from Turkey. "We'd like to move on to another neighborhood eventually." Ersoy lives in a nondescript, 14-story, 500-yard-long block that could have won a Stalinist design contest. Its graffiti-splattered walls say "Momo" and "Chaka Chaoui." Social agencies steer immigrants to districts like the Luth, four miles northwest of Paris, because they have the cheapest housing in the region. A modest two-bedroom apartment is $350, about one-seventh the cost in central Paris.
In the Luth, France's activist Government works hard to improve living conditions. There are playgrounds with bright red swings and slides, and an office has been set up where four social workers counsel the Luth's residents.
The district has been designated a "Priority Education Zone." This means its schools receive extra money and teachers to help integrate immigrant children and provide special help to the laggards. At Guy Moquet Middle School, Claude Naveau, the principal, is proud that his school, filled with Botticelli and Manet posters, has a computer room and its own radio station.
"We have a lot of children who don't have a good family environment, who don't have someone asking them, 'Are you doing your homework?' " says Naveau, whose heavy glasses and thick beard make him look like an archetypal intellectual. "Children love our school because it's an oasis from the chaos outside."
To be sure, Paris proper also has its less chic neighborhoods, most notably the 18th, 19th and 20th arrondissements in the north and east. These have a large North African population, much of it second generation, many of whom work in small businesses, especially textiles.
The epicenter of Arab Paris is Barbes-Rochechouart, the intersection of two bustling avenues, which seems a cross between a Moroccan souk and Manhattan's 14th Street. Elevated trains rumble by as people squeeze past a 200-yard line of sidewalk stalls. Nearby, young toughs wait until sundown to begin their purse snatchings.
"A lot of young kids come up from the Maghreb, can't find jobs and start creating trouble," says Youssef Karoui, who runs the Eslem restaurant.
The problem in these neighborhoods, residents say, is not violent crime, but purse-snatchings, burglaries and car thefts. Fortunately for Paris, crack has not made inroads and drug addiction is far less prevalent than in American cities.
THE ENTRANCE TO THE concrete, 1960's building on the Boulevard Bourdon, 250 yards south of the Bastille, could not be more nondescript. There isn't even a nameplate. But deep inside, behind the security guards, is a cavernous room filled with display panels and flashing lights that looks like the Pentagon's war room.
Welcome to the central command post for Paris's subway system, an intricate web with 434 stations, 686 escalators and 1.6 billion riders a year.
At rush hour, 560 trains snake through the city, and on the command center's 13 display panels, each as long as a baseball scoreboard, orange lights show the location and progress of every single train. If there is a subway fire or someone jumps in front of a train -- there are about 150 such suicides each year -- a subway line manager leaps up from his console and runs to his display panel to switch off power for his line.
"We have already extended this display panel to include some new stations that we still haven't opened," says Jean-Pierre Renard, a longtime manager at the command center. The panel shows two stations to be added when line No. 1 is extended under the Seine to La Defense, the ultramodern office district west of Paris.
Probably better than anything else, the Metro demonstrates Paris's devotion to constant improvement: to improve through planning, bold engineering and a willingness to spend money. The Metro recently added a conductorless train that connects Orly Airport with the main subway line. The express suburban rail system, known as the R.E.R., has been extended east to Euro-Disneyland, which opened in April. There are plans for a six-mile-long tramway that will connect blue-collar suburbs north of Paris and for an express subway connecting the southernmost part of Paris to the St.-Lazare train station on the right bank.
The budget for these and other transit projects -- which are selected by a regional transportation board -- will total $3 billion over the next five years. The financing comes from ticket revenues and from the city, regional and national governments.
Thanks to a solid flow of funds, the subway cars undergo maintenance once a week, and as a result mechanical failures are responsible for less than a third of line shutdowns. Usually the problem is human failures, like fights between passengers or pranksters pulling the emergency cord.
"If our trains ran without passengers, we'd hardly have any problems," jokes Renard, a short, dapper man in a blue bow tie and charcoal-striped suit.
Like many Parisian civil servants, Renard exudes an extreme pride in his work and his city. He boasts about a new varnish that helps keep the Metro graffiti-free. He brags about the system's safety record, saying he cannot remember the last time there was a fatal accident.
"I'm a modest man, so don't expect me to say that our Metro is the best in the world," he says, with a twinkle in his eye. "Let's just say it's one of the best.
"We plan to keep it that way."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Along the Seine, near Notre Dame, a new broom (its bristles are plastic) sweeps clean, while a couple celebrates love the old-fashioned way. HEADLINE: The Vulture Game

BYLINE: By Diana B. Henriques; Diana B. Henriques is a financial reporter for The New York Times.

 BODY:
Hubert M. Stiles Jr. is a vulture. As he exits Pennsylvania Station in Manhattan on his way toward Union Square, he scans the surrounding urban landscape from a peculiar point of view.
There is Macy's flagship store up the street; R. H. Macy & Company filed for bankruptcy court protection on Jan. 27, with about $4.9 billion in assets and $5.3 billion in liabilities. Glancing out the rear window of his southbound taxi, he sees the Pan Am building straddling Park Avenue: the airline filed for bankruptcy in January 1991, leaving investors holding $245 million worth of bonds. "The Silence of the Lambs" is playing at a movie house; that film was produced by Orion Pictures Corporation, which filed for bankruptcy last December. 
 A newsstand in Union Square reminds Stiles of a slew of bankruptcies: The Daily News, part of the late Robert Maxwell's troubled publishing empire, whose flagship public company, Maxwell Communication, filed for bankruptcy protection last December; United Press International, the desperately ailing wire service; The New York Post, whose owner, Peter Kalikow, one of the city's biggest real-estate developers, filed for bankruptcy protection a year ago.
To Herb Stiles, Manhattan is an island of insolvency. Lately, even the World Financial Center, near the southern tip of Manhattan, has come under a cloud as its developer, Olympia & York -- owned by the Reichmann family of Canada -- has sought court protection from its creditors. The rest of America is simply more of the same.
Whatever the tidal wave of fiscal failures means to the city or the nation, it spells fresh opportunity for Stiles, who runs a bankruptcy investment fund for T. Rowe Price Associates, a mutual fund company based in Baltimore. He and investors like him get rich by feeding on the carcasses of corporate America. That's why Wall Street calls them vultures.
The large number of insolvencies over the last few years is transforming the bankruptcy investment business. Vulture investing came into its own during the Great Depression of the 1930's, but it has traditionally been an arcane and hermetic corner of the investment world, scorned by mainstream companies. Today, however, the bankruptcy game has gone mainstream, attracting major Wall Street companies, huge institutions with easy access to America's pension funds, private endowments and mutual funds. Typically, they buy up the i.o.u.'s of bankrupt companies for a few cents on the dollar from creditors who are unwilling or unable to wait out the bankruptcy process. Their goal: to collect many more pennies per dollar from the debtor, once the bankruptcy negotiations are completed.
With courtly corporate manners that mask a shrewd eye for bargains, Stiles is typical of the savvy newcomers. Besides T. Rowe Price, the new vultures include giants like Merrill Lynch and Fidelity Investments, and a number of smaller or less familiar companies. By some estimates, more than $10 billion has been raised from institutional investors in recent years to cash in on this boom in going bust.
On any bankruptcy case, Stiles's adversaries might well include some of the sharpest and toughest veterans of the takeover wars of the 1980's. As the number of corporate failures climbs, an army of former mergers and acquisitions specialists on Wall Street are turning to bankruptcy investing. There is a delicious paradox, of course, in this rush of deal makers into the vulture game. Many of the companies in bankruptcy court today are there because they employed those very deal makers in the first place, piling up debts in the 1980's that have overwhelmed the slim profits offered so far by the 90's. Their collapse has created a huge volume of distressed securities, which are the bonds and notes they issued, plus the bank loans and unpaid bills they owed to wholesalers and vendors who did business with them. "Nobody really has a good handle on the size of the market," Stiles says, "but some estimates run as high as $300 billion."
Being in on the vulture game means wily maneuvering to buy the best seat at the negotiating table, and then months, or years, of haggling over how much creditors will be able to collect from the debtor. It is just that sort of conference-room combat that has brought Stiles to Manhattan on a February day. He has an appointment with Stephen D. Weinroth, formerly an executive at Drexel Burnham Lambert and now chairman and chief executive of Integrated Resources, a syndicator of real-estate parterships. Both Drexel and Integrated filed for bankruptcy in February 1990.
The session will be long and private. Stiles represents a bloc of Integrated's unsecured creditors who are trying to negotiate a tiny sliver of Integrated's remaining assets, before the more powerful secured creditors take them all. Afterward, he will meet in a law firm's conference room with representatives of a rival group of creditors with a stronger claim on Integrated's assets.
These negotiations are necessary because not all creditors are created equal. Some lenders demand collateral -- factory equipment, the company's headquarters, the corporate jet -- as a condition of their loan; these are secured creditors. Others make loans without collateral, charging a higher interest rate to reflect the increased risk; they are unsecured creditors. And some -- like wholesalers and suppliers -- simply were not paid for their goods and services. Their unpaid bills are called trade claims. Each type of creditor has a place in the legal pecking order, with secured lenders near the top and unsecured lenders near the bottom, and trade claims unpredictably falling at either end.
Depending on the kinds of creditors a bankrupt company has, there may be as many as five committees of vulture investors involved in bankruptcy negotiations. Increasingly, rival committees are battling with one another to improve their treatment in the final deal, regardless of the pecking order.
That assertiveness is cited by many experts as one of the most dramatic changes to occur in the vulture market in recent years. "Creditors are far less willing to compromise," says George Putnam 3d, editor of the Turnaround Letter in Boston, one of a number of investment newsletters that have sprung up to serve the bankruptcy marketplace. In a few cases, creditors are even trying to buy up enough of a bankrupt company's debt to take control of the entire reorganization process, and perhaps of the company itself -- a variant of venture capital investing that some wags refer to as vulture capital.
In the delicate diplomacy of bankruptcy negotiations, Stiles and his group have little leverage beyond their ability to stall -- a powerful weapon when each moment spent negotiating the deal reduces everyone's potential profit on the money they have invested in the bankruptcy company. Stiles's visit to Integrated Resources is a last-ditch effort to turn that nuisance value into something more tangible. He elected to buy the unsecured debt in the first place because he felt it was the cheapest way to gamble on the outcome. His hope is that the other creditors will agree to give his group some small sop simply to keep them quiet. With competing bids on the table, it is too soon to predict the outcome.
As he heads to his meeting with Weinroth (who subsequently resigned from Integrated), Stiles jokes about the rose-marble elevators that carry him to Integrated's offices. Not exactly a debtor's prison, is it? The elevator is far more elegant, and only slightly smaller, than the office Stiles occupies in Baltimore.
EXCEPT FOR A handsome view of the Inner Harbor, Stiles's command center in Baltimore is dull and bland. Missing, by Wall Street standards, are about 150 square feet of floor space and all the attendant power cliches -- the cigars, the suspenders, the miniature financial documents encased in Lucite, trophies of past deals.
A soft-spoken Alabama native, Stiles left the sedate world of commercial banking in 1988 to make his way into the hottest and riskiest game on Wall Street. He became executive vice president and portfolio manager of the T. Rowe Price Recovery Fund, a private partnership formed that year, and is now president of the company. Armed with more than $100 million raised from major institutions, the 45-year-old Stiles invests in the bonds, notes and other unpaid obligations of bankrupt companies.
"Commercial banking was great," Stiles says, grinning and tilting back in his chair as he reviews the 18 years he spent at Chemical Bank in New York. His career there included service, as a junior banker, on the team that represented Chemical in the historic Penn Central bankruptcy in June 1970, at the time the largest and most complicated bankruptcy.
That case gave Stiles a front-row seat as Victor Palmieri -- the legendary turnaround specialist hired to manage Penn Central -- delicately arm-twisted his way to a settlement with the company's creditors. The Penn Central case enabled a few lucky investors, who bought the railroad's bonds for pennies on the dollar after the bankruptcy filing, to pocket millions when the debts were finally settled nearly a decade later. Palmieri's remarkable performance persuaded Stiles that "bankruptcy is where credit analysis really matters."
Stiles hefts a stack of documents, part of the enormous paper work generated by the bankruptcy of Maxicare Health Plans, the huge health maintenance organization that filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in March 1989 and finally emerged from bankruptcy early last year.
Maxicare, based in Los Angeles, was a big success for Stiles, one that illustrates the lure of this high-stakes game for mainstream newcomers. It also offers a near-textbook example of a process that is being followed, with a few baroque embellishments and considerably more publicity, in today's celebrity bankruptcy cases.
Stiles started watching Maxicare in March 1988, after it jolted Wall Street by reporting a large, unexpected loss for the prior fiscal year. In November 1988, Maxicare failed to make an interest payment owed to its corporate bondholders. Two months later, the company was unable to make the required monthly payments on its bank loans. After a grace period, Maxicare finally filed for bankruptcy court protection in March 1989.
Stiles had a hunch that Maxicare would emerge from bankruptcy with its debts paid off at less than face value and its interest payments sharply reduced. But two questions gave him pause: Would the H.M.O. be treated like an insurance company, under the supervision of insurance regulators in each of the 22 states where it did business, or like a simple bankruptcy case under the supervision of a single judge? And how good was Maxicare's basic business?
A United States bankruptcy judge in Los Angeles, John J. Wilson, answered the first question in June 1989 by barring the states' insurance commissioners from taking regulatory action. The answer to the second question lay deep in a long row of documents filed in the Los Angeles Federal Courthouse.
Those documents are the statement of financial affairs that debtors are required to provide to the bankruptcy court, and Stiles relied on Seidler Amdec Securities, a company specializing in bankrupt securities, to assess those papers. After Stiles looked at the money flowing in and out of each of the company's separate health-care plans, "it became apparent that they had turned the corner," he says. "I was ready."
But what was the best way to get into the game? He could buy the defaulted bonds, traded in the open market, or he could try to buy the unpaid invoices in the hands of the vendors who had done business with the company. Stiles decided, instead, to buy a large portion of the company's outstanding bank loans. These seemed to offer the best mix of price and power -- he could buy them cheaply, and, by acquiring the bankers' rights as lenders, he would be in a strong position in the ultimate negotiations. Between September and December of 1989, he negotiated with three major banks to buy up loans with a face value of $36 million. He paid roughly $5.6 million for the loans -- or about 15 cents to the dollar.
Stiles estimated that Maxicare would ultimately be able to strike a deal with its creditors that would provide about 30 cents on the dollar to whomever held those bank loans.
Stiles rode that case through one aborted takeover bid, endless shouting matches in conference rooms in Los Angeles and continuous disputes over the payment of some of the company's trade claims. In April of last year, he walked away with about 32 cents for each dollar of bank loans he controlled -- more than twice his initial investment.
Although the Maxicare returns are now part of the vulture-market folklore, the risks of bankruptcy speculation have not yet found their way into market mythology. But the continuing bankruptcy boom may change that. The vulture market is little more than a loosely regulated bazaar, and somewhere down the line, less experienced investors might well find themselves faced with a level of volatility and legal uncertainty that will make the ever-shifting Wall Street market look like a placid pond.
MORE THAN 87,000 businesses failed in the United States in 1991 -- more than one every 10 minutes, a 44 percent increase over the previous year's figures, according to Dun & Bradstreet Corporation, the business research company. The companies that failed in 1991 alone had almost $109 billion in liabilities, or nearly twice as much as was owed by the prior year's crop of failures.
Many of the business failures are small fry. Until two years ago, it was rare for more than one billion-dollar company to fail in any given year, says Edward Flynn, a management analyst for the bankruptcy division of the Administrative Office of the United States Courts. "Suddenly," he says, "there are many more." There were 15 in 1990 and 18 in 1991, including Pan Am Corporation and Carter Hawley Hale Stores. So far this year, nine such megacases have been filed.
Some legal experts on bankruptcy say the roots of the recent crop of high-profile bankruptcies go deeper than the debt binge of the 1980's and the economic weakness of the early 90's. They blame a profound change in board-room attitudes: the stigma of bankruptcy has steadily faded.
This changing perception first became apparent in 1982, when Johns-Manville filed for bankruptcy to protect itself from its asbestos-related liabilities. "That was a dramatic watershed," says Martin Nussbaum, a Wall Street securities lawyer who has accompanied his corporate clients into the bankruptcy arena. "It said that bankruptcy was becoming more respectable as a tool of corporate strategy."
The following year, Texaco briefly sought the protection of bankruptcy court after losing an extremely costly lawsuit over its acquisition of Getty Oil. "That bankruptcy filing would have been unthinkable 20 years ago," Nussbaum says. "In the board rooms where I've sat, while there is still a great deal of reluctance to do it, that is diminishing rapidly."
The bankruptcy investment business is exclusively American. "The European recipe for dealing with a bankrupt enterprise has always been fairly simple and direct," Nussbaum says. "You auction the assets, distribute the cash to the creditors and throw the management in jail."
In the United States, it was not until 1898 that an all-encompassing Federal bankruptcy law was adopted, establishing a court-monitored process to allow debtors to negotiate some sort of settlement with their creditors. With some extensive Depression-era amendments, this law remained in effect for 80 years, until widespread dissatisfactionled to the adoption of a new bankruptcy code in 1978.
This new code is more flexible to enable more companies to reorganize, says Lawrence P. King, a professor of law at New York University Law School and one of the original drafters of the new code. Since an insolvent company might someday become profitable again, the new law gives patient creditors an incentive to negotiate seriously, instead of demanding that the company be liquidated.
Exhibit A in support of this less punitive approach is the Federated-Allied department store chain, whose links include such familiar names as Bloomingdale's, Jordan Marsh and Burdines. When Robert Campeau, the Canadian entrepreneur, acquired Allied in 1986 and Federated in 1988, he loaded their ledgers with high-cost debt. In January 1990, unable to repay those debts, the two companies sought shelter in bankruptcy court. Creditors haggled for nearly two years -- as the stores continued to operate -- and finally agreed to accept a package of new securities in lieu of some of the money they were owed. Those at the top of the pecking order got between 80 cents and 100 cents for each dollar they were owed, while less fortunate creditors wound up with as little as 2 cents on the dollar. Early this year, the combined chains emerged from bankruptcy as a single company, under Federated's name.
WHEN companies first began to fail with unnerving regularity in late 1990, prices of distressed securities plummeted. But as giant investors tried to put hundreds of millions of dollars into the relatively small vulture market, the prices went berserk in the first half of last year. The fever cooled slightly as autumn arrived -- all of which causes people like Stiles to worry that speculation has gotten out of control, increasing the already substantial risks of the bankruptcy market.
The prices of bank loans and vendor claims have risen at a slower pace, Stiles says, because they are less familiar to the newcomers rushing into the market. "But I find myself shaking my head over the prices being quoted for publicly traded bonds and, especially, stocks," he says.
These witless price swings have prompted some seasoned participants in the bankruptcy game to argue that the new Wall Street vultures will spoil the market through greed or inexperience. "It was a tidy little game," says A. David Silver, the owner of ADS Financial Services in Santa Fe, N.M., a small investment banking house that specializes in troubled companies. "But today, everybody is piling in. And when white-shoe Wall Street firms start to do business with bankruptcy players, there will be overcrowding, more competition for deals, higher prices than you can justify, less collateral than you need. Suddenly, it's the collapse of the junk-bond market all over again."
Stiles, understandably, disagrees that the newcomers are unskilled at their task. "I don't observe any real dummies out there in the market," he says. But he agrees that there is a worrisome lack of clarity and consistency on regulatory issues that affect the vulture marketplace. "There has always been a fuzzy area where the Securities and Exchange Commission and the bankruptcy courts square off," he says. "Ten or 20 years ago, the regulators seemed more involved. Then I think the S.E.C. overreacted and stepped back too much."
Now the S.E.C. says it is stepping closer. Richard C. Breeden, its chairman, has confirmed that his agency is exploring the legal landscape to determine how -- and whether -- stock market rules against insider trading should be applied to the dimly lit world of vulture investing.
In many cases, securities regulators have no choice but to defer to the bankruptcy courts because, under S.E.C. definitions, many of the wares traded in the distressed securities market, like trade claims and bank loans, are not securities at all. Where the insolvent company does not have public shareholders -- as is the case with many of the failed leveraged buyouts of the 80's -- the S.E.C. must rely on the bankruptcy courts to oversee much of the company's dealing with its creditors in the vulture marketplace, says Michael Berman, a bankruptcy counsel for the commission.
Those courts have sometimes reached contradictory decisions about the rules of the game, treating the same class of creditors differently in different cases or establishing different standards for what a debtor company must disclose to vulture investors in the course of negotiations. This is not surprising, given the increased workload the bankruptcy boom has produced for judges and court clerks.
Peter McCabe, the assistant director of the Administrative Office of the United States Courts, says the overall number of bankruptcy cases, including consumer cases, has more than quadrupled since 1979, the first year under the new code. And the new megacases are complex and time-consuming. In response, the court administrators are seeking Congressional permission to add at least 32 new judges and to expand the clerk's offices in some of the busier jurisdictions.
THE LEGAL FUZZINESS notwithstanding, the bankruptcy market is moving along at a clip. Although today's newcomers are handling money raised exclusively from fairly sophisticated institutional investors, Herb Stiles says he believes that tomorrow's new arrivals may even include public mutual funds devoted exclusively to vulture investing -- vehicles that would give everyone the chance to experience the dubious thrills of bankruptcy speculation.
Stiles supports the notion of opening the vulture market to the general public through professionally managed mutual funds, but he is too familiar with the ways of Wall Street to assume that nothing will go wrong. The most likely catastrophe, in his view, is that unsophisticated mutual fund investors, lured by the promise of high returns, will lose their shirts in bankruptcy speculation -- and will turn to their Congressmen or lawyers for revenge. That kind of fallout could impair the entire market, just as the Government's probe of Drexel's Michael Milken damaged liquidity and prices in the junk bond market.
"There are many degrees of speculation," Stiles explains, "from bank loans, which are relatively secure, to bankrupt common stocks, which are very risky. If someone were to start up a fund and invest just in bankruptcy stocks, you could easily see that producing a disaster."
He pauses and then continues: "There will be horror stories ahead, people who will lose a lot of money in this market." But from his quick grin, it is clear Herb Stiles does not expect to be one of them.

HEADLINE: Talking: Solar Energy;
New Ways To Get Off The Grid

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS

 BODY:
SALES of solar energy devices for the home are rising after a decade in the doldrums despite the recession and even though the cost may not always make economic sense -- an indication, perhaps, of a desire by more homeowners to help preserve the planet.
In 1990, solar hot water system sales rose 15 percent over 1989, according to the Solar Energy Industries Association, a trade group based in Washington, which predicted another 15 percent rise this year. And 1991 sales of solar-powered devices for the home, like attic fans and outdoor lighting, rose 27 percent over 1990, with a further 25 percent gain expected this year, the association said. 
 For some, the potential saving was the catalyst.
"When you feel pinched, you look for ways to reduce your overhead," said Scott Sklar, president of the association.
The group discovered that as some homeowners started to refinance to benefit from lower interest rates, it made financial sense to borrow an extra $4,000 or so to install a typical two-panel solar hot-water system. This was particularly true if, despite the added debt service, the system could save the buyer as much as -- or more than -- he had been paying each month to heat water.
Dr. Mark Novotny, an internist who lives with his wife and two children in Manchester, Vt., installed a $3,200 solar hot-water system in May He estimated that the $38 a month he pays on a 10-year loan would be hardly more than the $30 he had been paying to heat water electrically.
Paul Hood, a peace activist in Charlotte, Vt., said he chose solar as the primary energy source for his new home because "we had a continuing concern about the disposal of nuclear wastes and the using of nonrenewable energy sources."
One home solar hot-water system can cut the discharge of carbon dioxide into the atmosphere -- the principal cause of global warming -- by 20 tons over two decades compared to electric water heating, according to the National Renewable Energy Laboratories, a federally financed research group in Golden, Colo.
Mr. Hood's 1,500-square-foot saltbox has eight roof-mounted photovoltaic panels, with a backup generator. Installed last year by Solar Works of Montpelier, Vt., the system cost $8,000, including the inverter that converts solar-generated DC to 110 volt AC for normal appliances. Mr. Hood said the system cost about a third more than hooking up to power lines, which would have had to be extended a half mile to reach the house.
A glass-covered black metal water tank on the roof provides a simple type of solar-heated hot water during the summer, a cheaper alternative to the traditional solar hot water system, said Mr. Hood. There is a backup propane heater.
One place homeowners can begin searching for solar solutions is with information on the updated products being marketed -- plus the names and phone numbers of local suppliers and installers.
Comprehensive background reading can be found in the Consumer Guide to Solar Energy, a 181-page book published in 1991 by Bonus Books of Chicago. For a copy, send $11 to American Solar Energy Society, 2400 Central Avenue, Boulder, Colo., 80301. The book includes a guide to suppliers and local solar trade associations.
Some 200 solar contractors from around the country are listed in the 1992 edition of the Solar Source Book, a directory compiled by the Solar Energy Industries Association. The book also lists local utility companies that have financial incentive programs or state agencies that can supply information about other financial incentives. Send $12.50 to SEIA, 777 North Capitol Street, Washington, D.C. 20002.
UTILITY incentive programs are also reviving after being discontinued in the mid 80's "because of pressure from their state utility commissions to reduce demand," said Mr. Sklar. "It's cheaper than building new plants."
In New York, utility companies are starting to file plans with state officials and more specific information may not available until later this year, said Gary Brown, a policy analyst for the New York State Energy Office. Elsewhere, homeowners should check with their local utility business office.
New York State has also revived its property tax abatement program for improvements with a solar component. Called the Solar Real Property Tax Exemption, it was reinstated by state legislators on Jan. 1, 1991, after having been discontinued for two years.
One way to enhance solar efficiency on a limited budget might be to consider improvements to an existing system or the use of second-hand hardware.
Everett Barber Jr., president of Sunsearch, a solar contractor in Guilford, Conn., is offering about 50 used collectors at about 40 percent below the cost of similar models bought new. They are most useful, he said, for enhancing an existing system.
Mr. Barber, who is also an associate professor of environmental technologies at Yale School of Architecture, said there are many other ways to put new zest into an older system. He has found, for example, that collectors with a plastic film or fiberglass covering tend to lose about 60 percent of their efficiency after about eight years because the surface gradually clouds over. Replacing the covering costs about $250 a panel, far less than installing new panels.
"Sometimes we find that the problem is as simple as controls that were wired incorrectly," said Mr. Barber, "or backup sources of heat that were never properly installed."
Before choosing a solar contractor, Mr. Barber recommends determining how many years of experience the installer has had with the products being installed; the names of area homeowners who are using the same system; the anticipated life of the solar hot-water tank based on the installer's experience rather than the manufacturer's claims; what procedures might be needed to safeguard the system from overheating during a prolonged absence and anticipated maintenance costs.
Among the many smaller solar-powered items useful for the homeowner on a small budget are attic fans, which sell for around $300. One source is Applied Energy Technology of Swisher, Iowa. (For details, call (319) 857-412.) Much information about solar energy, plus a wide variety of devices -- from toys to complete power systems -- is in the "Real Goods" mail-order catalog. For a free copy, call the company in Ukiah, Calif., toll-free, at (800) 762-7325.

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: Downtown Redevelopment;
35 Condo Units for Danbury

 BODY:
Three buildings with a total of 35 condominium apartments are to be the first private undertaking in the redevelopment of downtown Danbury, Conn. The $3 million residential project, by Davon Development Corporation, is on Liberty Street. It will be called Liberty Terrace.
The buildings will have two-story, two-bedroom units arranged over two-bedroom basement apartments. Prices will range from the mid-$70,000's to the upper $90,000's. Ground-breaking is scheduled for this fall, with completion expected in the fall of 1993. Financing comes from the Union Savings Bank and the Savings Bank of Danbury. The architect is Lewis Zurlo of Danbury. The project includes the relocation of the New Bethel Church of God in Christ, which stands on the site. 
 "One of the ways to make a small city turn around is to bring back the middle class and to bring back residents to downtown," said the developer, George Davon, of Danbury.
Liberty Terrace is at the south end of a 7.7-acre redevelopment district bounded by Patriot Drive and White, Ives, Delay and Liberty Streets. A 550-vehicle municipal parking garage was completed earlier this year. Projects on the drawing board include the 20,000-square-foot Pavilion on the Green, with offices and stores, and a complex with 40 housing units, stores, restaurant and an "entertainment facility" (it was to have been a movie theater, but plans changed).
"We're one of the only places that's got something going on," said Felice Plain, the executive director of CityCenter Danbury. "We feel it puts us in a position to come out of the recession in a positive way." CityCenter is a one-square-mile special-services district that includes the redevelopment area. Services within CityCenter are paid for by a special assessment on 120 property owners.

GRAPHIC: Drawing: Rendering of a residential complex at Liberty Terrace on Liberty Street, Danbury, Conn. (Lewis Zurlo Associates)
