HEADLINE: Commercial Property: Older Industrial Space;
'Repositioning' Buildings for a New Marketplace

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS

 BODY:
AT the end of a dead-end street -- improbably named Progress Drive -- in a tumbledown part of Stamford, Conn., is a 25-year-old rectangular industrial building whose simple concrete-and-glass exterior stands in humble contrast to the glittering office towers less than a mile away.
But with a bit of fixing up, the 116,000-square-foot, two-story structure on a 4.6-acre paved site may turn out to be more in tune than its more glamorous neighbors with the needs of the 90's. 
 Its first tenant was Branson Instruments, maker of flight simulators. It was then leased to Pitney Bowes for the assembly of postage meters. When the Pitney Bowes lease expired earlier this year and the division moved out, the building's owner, Frank Mercede Jr., faced a major problem.
Large industrial structures built for single users -- even the more up-to-date kind like the one on Progress Drive -- are no longer finding tenants. The pattern is familiar all over the New York metropolitan area, brokers report, as more and more manufacturers drift away to less costly locations.
And the recession has compounded the problem.
"Even the manufacturers that are still here are cutting back," said Thom W. Murray, an industrial broker with William Pitt Real Estate of Stamford, the brokerage marketing the Progress Drive building.
Mr. Murray noted that vacancy rates in Fairfield County are about 12 percent, compared with 7 percent in the late 80's. And prices for raw space have fallen to $6 a square foot from around $9 in 1988. Demand, he said, just isn't there, and now that commercial construction is stagnant, properties are not being bought for their land value.
New uses therefore must be devised for such structures, and the key word is "repositioning."
What is happening on Progress Drive is one way to do this. Some $350,000 worth of interior renovations are being completed to better adapt the building to several small users that want to consolidate functions under one roof. The idea also is to attract larger companies that are contracting and interested in cutting overhead by consolidating operations in one location. And, unlike the glitzy towers, such structures also offer lots of free, ground-level parking.
Each of the users, who are expected to need more than 10,000 square feet, will be able to combine office space with light assembly, warehousing or distribution.
THESE were just the sort of tenants that brokers say used to be scorned by landlords for their modest needs and unwillingness to sign long leases. Such tenants therefore had to make do with "leftovers," said Dan Frankel, senior vice president and industrial specialist at Jacobson, Goldfarb & Tanzman Associates, commercial brokers in Woodbridge, N.J., which is seeing similar transformations.
Those leftovers tended to be loft spaces, empty garages or the upper floors of obsolete buildings -- spaces nobody else wanted. They were far from ideal, said Mr. Frankel, but they were the only thing that most small or embryonic companies with multiple needs could afford.
Besides, such space often was the only thing they were offered. It has taken hard times, he added, for landlords to recognize these tenants as a market niche.
Clearly, not all buildings can be easily converted. Those that are more than two stories high and will need a large amount of capital to make the changeover are unlikely to be good candidates because banks are wary of lending for commercial property. And those in sites unsuited to retailing are not going to find tenants easily.
At Progress Drive, the former wide open spaces are being broken up to provide communal hallways and smaller units. As an added incentive, at least one loading dock is being set aside for those tenants who may need to use one only occasionally.
At the rear of the building are hangar-like spaces with 22-foot ceilings. These are meant for smaller distributors who need vertical storage.
NEW bathroom fittings have been installed and, for those whose primary goal is presentable office space at lower cost, a sophisticated lobby area is being created by covering the old cinderblock walls and adding a security desk, potted plants and marble flooring at the entrance.
In addition, the old company cafeteria will be operated as a communal amenity. The former conference room on the second floor will become an exercise room for all. A 12,000-square-foot adjacent building that was part of the Pitney Bowes operation during its tenure is expected to be leased to a day-care operator.
In short, the owner is providing the sorts of on-site extras that only a major company could normally afford.
"We wanted to make it as appealing as possible for the people who are looking," said Donald R. Corbo, director of real estate marketing for Mr. Mercede. "You can't just show them into an empty industrial space and let them imagine what it will look like. You must do some of the work ahead of time."
Even though the changes are not yet complete, two five-year leases have been signed. In March, Computerland took 10,000 square feet on the second floor as a regional center. Up Technologies, a discount computer retailer, moved into 7,000 square feet on the first floor in June.
The effective rate is around $12 a square foot, said Mr. Corbo.
Two more leases, each for 10,000 square feet, are under negotiation, said Mr. Corbo, and are expected to provide a training center and back-office space for two larger local companies.
ALSO gaining attention is the idea of leaving such a building as is and trying to attract the discount retailer who may wish to combine on-site selling with mail-order distribution -- one of the fastest growing segments of retailing.
That's what is being done, for example, to two buildings totaling 135,000 square feet on 8.6 contiguous acres in Port Chester, N.Y., by Auguste Thouard Corporation of Greenwich, Conn. A division of a French property company, it has made a business of buying up these white elephants and finding a new market for them. Home Depot will take over the site.
Since Port Chester is sandwiched between the affluent dormitory towns of Fairfield County and southern Westchester and is full of large industrial structures, it is ideal for the purpose, maintained William Leroy, a principal in Thouard.
Allyn H. Powell, who owns a 25,000 square foot brick building on a 2.3 acre site along Route 1 in Norwalk, Conn, is equally enthusiastic about the warehouse retailing solution.
His one-story office-and-warehouse building, available since January, stands on a section of a street long associated with low-end retailers. And although its Cinderella looks would hardly suit a high-quality or trendy shopkeeper, he maintains that the size, configuration and location are ideal for this newer discount warehouse segment of the retail marketplace.
Thus, he said, he has decided not to spend money up front. Instead, he is making it clear that he is willing to the make the changes that could appeal to such a tenant, such as a new entrance and new loading bays at the rear.
"We'd even tear some of the building down to get their big trucks in, if that's what the tenant wanted," he said.

HEADLINE: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester;
An Affordable-Rental Program Takes Off

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
AN affordable rental-housing program begun in Connecticut in 1985 is emerging from relative obscurity. With commercial lending at a nadir, the Private Rental Investment Mortgage and Equity Program, known as Prime, is one of the few paths to construction money for developers who once shunned subsidized rental housing.
The program requires that 20 to 40 percent of a project's units rent below market rate, keyed to a state formula. Rents cannot exceed 35 percent of gross monthly income. The remaining units rent at full price, ensuring Prime's objective of economic integration. 
 Operating under the umbrella of the Connecticut Housing Finance Agency, Prime has had a flurry of recent applications from developers.
"We are now getting more applications than conventional lenders," said Gary King, director of the Housing Finance Agency and designer of the Prime program. Twelve new projects were approved in June.
While the number of rentals needed in the state has not been established, Mr. King said "estimates of the need for affordable housing, rental or purchased, range up to 100,000 units."
"We give priority in lending to rental housing and homeownership in communities where they don't exist," he said, "and to family housing over elderly housing. The general trend is toward mixed income housing and financing from many sources."
The program combines private and public money, tax credits are an incentive for developers and oversight by Prime helps keep the quality of design and construction high, making the product attractive to planning boards and consumers.
The idea that people paying market rents would not be willing to live in mixed-income developments "is a preconceived notion that is not true," said William E. Haynesworth, senior vice president of the Boston Financial Group, backers of several such projects, including Deer Meadow in Bloomfield, a Hartford suburb.
"You have to be working to afford the rent," he said. "These are not welfare apartments. If you produce a superior product, people will want to live there and they aren't concerned about who lives next door." "Massachusetts pioneered the concept of economic integration in 1969," he said. "Historically, Connecticut had very conservative lending practices and would only finance F.H.A.-insured mortgages with no risk for bond holders."
Deer Meadow opened a model unit on June 27.
"We are processing credit checks on about 400 applications," said Marc S. Levine, the developer. "We expect some young families and unrelated individuals sharing a unit to move in by Aug. 1."
The $5.8 million development circling a landscaped green has 48 garden-style units in five two-story buildings. Market rates start at $850 for a two-bedroom unit and go up to $995 for three bedrooms. Ten three-bedroom units will be rented to qualified low-income tenants at $671, nine two-bedroom units at $580 and one two-bedroom at $467.
Sizes range from 1,003 to 1,278 square feet. Each unit has a dishwasher, sink garbage-disposal, microwave, gas stove, refrigerator, washer-dryer hookup and central air-conditioning. And each has a laundry room, deck, two parking spaces and visitor parking, with no differences between market-rate and low-income units.
The development, on a 13.5-acre site 380 feet back from Blue Hills Avenue in a residential area, is 2.3 miles from Exit 36 of Interstate 91. Close to several local employers, including CIGNA, the University of Hartford, Kaman Aircraft, and Combustion Engineering, it is also near shopping at the Copaco Shopping Center and Bloomfield Center.
Bloomfield's 26 square miles supports 19,400 people whose median income is more than $52,000, with minority representation of up to 40 percent.
"WE pride ourselves on being one of the all-American diversified communities since the 1960's," said Thomas B. Hooper, the town planner. "We are focusing on the shortage of family housing because we lost a lot of rental stock in the last decade through conversion to condominiums."
"Our big problem is retailers," he said, adding:
"They don't understand that we have a population of affluent minorities as well as affluent whites. Retailers just look at the numbers of minority residents. Not that we want a mall, just some stores to fill vacancies in small shopping centers."
Westfarms and Buckland Hills malls are within 15 miles of Bloomfield.
Boston Financial paid $920,000 for its limited Deer Meadow partnership and Mr. Levine put up $86,000 as general partner. The state housing finance agency issued $2.5 million in bonds for permanent and construction financing and the state Department of Housing supplied a $2.3 million second mortgage.
"The project will generate $166,000 of tax credit per year for 10 years," said Mr. Levine. "Boston Financial gets 99 percent of it, I get one percent plus a fee for developing the project."
The units must be rented for 15 years, after which the project may be sold as rentals or condominiums, with Mr. Levine, Boston Financial and the housing finance agency sharing the profits. The same percentage of low-income units must be retained for 99 years.
Diamond Court, another Prime project, developed by Ralph Monti and William Martin, opened in March in a rundown section of downtown Waterbury, on Manhan Street Extension. Sixty-seven units of a total of 80 have been rented or are under contract, and the developers are gearing up to build more on the remaining seven acres of their 14-acre property. The houses are in rows on each side of a center road, with 8 to 12 town houses having small front lawns in each of eight buildings.
"We tell people in advance about the difference in rents," said Mr. Monti. "They don't seem to care."
Two-bedroom, 700-square-foot units rent for $507 with an income under $24,000, or $550 at market rate. A 900-square-foot, three-bedroom town house rents for $650 market, $579 low-income. Four bedrooms cost $825, or $637. Central air-conditioning, full basements, one parking space and all appliances except washer-dryers are included.
Mr. Levine said the principal risk in economically integrated housing is quality. "If the units are not marketable at market rates the project will fail sooner or later," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Drawing of residential units at the Deer Meadow complex in Bloomfield, a suburb of Hartford. (The Steinberg Collaborative)

HEADLINE: Threat of Zebra Mussels Puts Reservoirs on Alert

BYLINE: By HAROLD FABER

DATELINE: KATONAH

 BODY:
WORRIED that zebra mussels might infiltrate the Croton reservoir system, New York City officials have opened a steam-cleaning operation in Cross River to cleanse boats that come from other waters to reservoirs in Westchester and Putnam Counties.
The steam cleaning is free, requiring only a reservation. So far, though, only one boat has been steam cleaned -- and that was involuntary, according to John Duffy, chief inspector for the reservoir system. 
 Inspectors on a tour of the Amawalk Reservoir recently seized a boat on the shoreline that appeared to be excessively dirty.
"It didn't look right," Mr. Duffy said.
The inspectors took the boat to the steam-cleaning site, washed it and then returned it to the owner, who said he had just come into the area after fishing in the Missouri River.
After testing, the debris on the boat proved to be free of zebra mussels, Mr. Duffy said.
No boats have come in voluntarily, although many boat owners have called to inquire about whether cleaning was needed. (The number is 232-5171.)
"Our equipment is ready. Our people are ready to go, but we have no boats," said Carl Picha, district engineer for the city's Bureau of Water Supply, which has an office here.
Mr. Picha and other water officials are concerned about the spreading zebra mussel because it poses a potential threat to the flow of water from reservoirs to the system's nine million consumers in New York City and the northern suburbs. About 80 percent of Westchester County's residents get their water from the New York City system.
Although the mollusk does not affect water purity or public health, it is an economic menace, because it grows in large clumps and can block the intake pipes of power plants and drinking water systems.
 
Recognizing a Potential Danger
 No mussels or their larvae have been found in any of the city's reservoirs in Westchester or in the Catskill Mountains. But they have been found at the intake pipes of the Chelsea Pumping Station on the east bank of the Hudson River, two miles north of Beacon. The station, not in operation now, is used only in case of a severe water shortage.
"We recognize the potential danger," said Sharon Neuman, the zebra mussel project manager for the city water system. Ms. Neuman is deputy chief of water quality planning for the city's Department of Environmental Protection.
That concern is shared by marina operators in the reservoir area, according to Charles Melchner, operator of the Mahopac Marina in Mahopac Falls and a vice president of the Hudson Valley Marina Trades Association. "We feel it's a major problem that has to be monitored," he said. "But we think it's more of a problem in the Hudson River than in the inland waters."
He said that most of the boaters who use the reservoirs were bass fisherman, who cleaned and washed their boats themselves, thus not requiring steam cleaning.
A native of the Caspian Sea, the zebra mussel is named for the dark stripes on its light-brown shell. With no natural enemies in the United States, it reproduces prolifically in fresh water, growing to about one or two inches in length.
Introduced into the Great Lakes in 1988 from the ballast water of ships from Europe, the small bivalve has spread from Duluth, Minn., through Lakes Ontario and Erie across the Mohawk River and down the Hudson as far as Beacon and Newburgh.
 
Thermal Water Heaters
 Its main method of dispersal is by attaching itself to the hulls of pleasure or fishing boats or riding in their bilge water, said scientists who are studying the mussel.
They said that control is expensive, requiring construction of thermal water heaters or pipes to carry chlorine or potassium permanganate to the mouth of intake pipes to kill the mussels. But the best control method, the scientists said, is sanitation. This involves removing the mussels by hand or steam from the hulls of boats, one of the favorite living places for the zebra mussels.
From Minnesota to New York, public utilities and municipal water works are spending millions of dollars to prevent or remove zebra mussel blockages. In the Great Lakes alone, officials estimated that it may cost $5 billion in the next 10 years to combat the zebra mussel.
In New York, no overall cost estimates have been made, but individual municipalities and utilities have started to budget and spend money for zebra mussel control.
 
Chemicals Used by Utility
 "If you lose a day down at a major plant, it could cost $200,000 to $300,000 in lost revenues or in purchasing power from others," said John Holsappple of the New York State Electric Energy Research Corporation. "It's not unreasonable to think in terms of losing hundreds of thousands of dollars, easily in the millions if anything goes wrong."
In Orange County near Newburgh, the Central Hudson Gas and Electric Corporation is trying to prevent losses by using a commercial chemical mixture, Clam-Tro, to treat its intake of cooling water at two power plants, Roseton and Danskammer.
"I would say conservatively that we will spend hundreds of thousands of dollars to control the zebra mussel," said Wayne Mancroni, the utility's manager of water quality.
Across the Hudson, the small village of Rhinebeck in Dutchess County, which takes its drinking water from the river, has approved spending up to $140,000 to treat its intake pipes in the river with potassium permanganate, which kills the mussel and its larvae.
 
$10 Million This Year
 The cost will be much higher to protect New York City's upstate reservoirs, Ms. Neuman said. She estimated that the city would spend about $10 million this year and about $1 million a year thereafter.
"By catching the zebra mussel early, we will save money," she said. "By spending now, we will save millions later."
In preparing for the expected invasion of the zebra mussels, Ms. Neuman's office has singled out the Croton system as the most vulnerable of the reservoirs.
"We rated the Croton system the most vulnerable because of its high calcium content, something that the mussels need to grow their shells," she said. "The Delaware and Catskill systems have less calcium and are less vulnerable."
Even though the Croton system has no direct intake connection to the Hudson River, except for the inoperative Chelsea pumping station, the danger lies in contamination from fishermen and recreational boaters who transport their boats from one body of water to another.
 
Signs and Leaflets
 The city has taken action in two ways: by awarding contracts to private engineering firms to devise a plan of action and by starting an educational program for boaters, including the steam-cleaning operation.
It has hired Acres International of Amherst, N.Y., near Buffalo, to monitor samples of water in all the city reservoirs twice a month. It has also hired Malcolm Pirnie, which has its headquarters in White Plains, to draft plans to combat the mussel in the reservoirs when and if found.
In addition, the city has posted 500 signs and issued 15,000 leaflets, warning boat owners who fish in the reservoirs of the dangers of unwittingly transporting zebra mussels or their veligers (larvae) on boat hulls, in bilge waters or in bait buckets.
"We are being very active about this," Mr. Picha said. "We are willing to steam clean any boat that comes from waters that are contaminated with zebra mussels or suspected of being contaminated. But it's not for boats that use the Croton system alone."
Boats will be cleaned by appointment only, he said. Reservations can be made by calling the water supply's Katonah office, 232-5171.
Mr. Picha seemed disappointed that no one has yet taken advantage of the city's offer.
"We sent out several thousand letters to every fish, bait and tackle shop in Westchester, Putnam and Dutchess Counties," he said. "We got a few dozen calls of inquiry, but no boats have actually been cleaned so far. We are all dressed up, with no place to go."

HEADLINE: Wall Street;
Israeli Stocks' Post-Shamir Rally

BYLINE: By Alison Leigh Cowan

 BODY:
Anyone in Yair Shamir's shoes would have felt torn watching Israel's latest exercise in democracy. The son of the man whom voters cast out of office last month is currently in China and unavailable for comment. But even as he must have mourned the loss of power of his father, Yitzhak, he must also have been pleased by investors' euphoria over the election results.
The younger Mr. Shamir, after all, is executive vice president of one of Israel's hottest growth companies, the Scitex Corporation Ltd. Scitex, a maker of computer graphic systems, is one of many Israeli companies whose stocks have surged in the weeks since the country's Labor Party, led by Yitzhak Rabin, trounced the Likud Party at the polls. 
 Scitex's stock, which trades over the counter in the United States, is up 10.6 percent. Fast-growing ECI Telecommunications Ltd., which has worked mightily to reduce its dependence on military sales, shot up 22.8 percent, while Elron Electronic Industries Ltd., a diversified holding company, jumped 27.6 percent.
Indeed, a survey conducted by Media General Financial Services of 31 Israeli companies traded in American markets found that 27 had risen an average of 15.8 percent since the election, 1 was flat and only 3 retreated (by an average 4.5 percent). One of the losers was BVR Technologies Ltd., a thinly traded company that makes training equipment for fighter planes and whose stock is languishing at $5.88, down 4.1 percent since the election.
What makes the Rabin-ignited rally astonishing is that it was not stopped cold by the prospect of organized labor returning to power. Clearly, investors seem to be saying that peace in the region -- the top priority of the new Government -- would do more for Israel's sputtering economy than any domestic agenda that Labor or Likud might embrace.
The country would be free to spend its hard-earned "peace dividend" on neglected parts of the economy. Stable borders would also pry open new markets for Israeli-made goods in the Arab world and beyond, and possibly encourage allies such as the United States to reward the purveyors of peace with economic aid.
The change in government comes on the heels of other encouraging economic news. The end of the cold war has created markets for Israeli goods in Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union. And the influx of well-educated immigrants from the former Soviet Union makes the labor force more enticing to high-tech companies as well as swelling the consumer population by some 20 percent.
Investors who missed out on the rally should not be discouraged, because there are probably as many ways to play the Israeli economy as there are fringe parties in the Knesset.
United States investors are free, of course, to buy securities listed on the Tel Aviv stock exchange, though they should have some familiarity with Israeli accounting standards and be able to decipher financial statements in Hebrew.
In the United States equity markets, Scitex and ECI Telecommunications are the two most popular Israeli-based companies, judging by market value, though they are showing signs of maturity. Nimrod Fachler, the chief investment officer of international investment for Mitchell Hutchins, likes Teva Pharmaceutical, Israel's largest drug maker, since it is plying some of the newly opened markets in Eastern Europe.
Also in this country, investment bankers plan to take several new Israeli issues public the next few weeks, starting with Tadiran Ltd., a diversified electronics company that hopes to offer 8.05 million shares later this month at about 11 times last year's earnings.
Investors might also do well to investigate American companies with a known Israeli presence. Take Vishay Intertechnology Inc., a Malvern, Pa., maker of electronic components. It discloses that about 10 percent of its $442.3 million in 1991 sales and 25 percent of its $48 million in operating profits came from goods it makes in Israeli factories, largely to take advantage of low wages, generous tax breaks and other government incentives lavished upon businesses that create jobs.
That percentage may climb now that Vishay has negotiated with a troubled German capacitor company to allow it to move as many as 800 jobs to Israel in exchange for pumping cash into the company. "It's the only way Vishay would have agreed to do the deal," said John Westergaard, the president of Westergaard Institutional Network and an analyst who tracks several Israeli companies.
Not to be overlooked is the PEC Israel Economic Corporation, one of the few ways for a small investor to gain exposure to privately owned Israeli companies as well as public ones.
Much like America's best-known merchant banks, PEC typically takes big stakes in companies so it can exercise influence, and digs in for the long haul. As a result, its interests span several industries, ranging from banking to real estate to high technology to shipping.
On June 1, the company floated 3.8 million shares in the United States at $13.50 apiece, adding to the 15 million already in circulation. Despite the dilution, its shares have soared 21.8 percent since the election.
"People often think of us as a mirror for the Israeli economy," said an obviously pleased Joseph Ciechanover, the company's president.
A research report recently prepared by Furman Selz Inc., one of the company's underwriters, makes a good case that the stock could reach $22. It points out that the 11 public companies in PEC's 23-company portfolio have a collective value of $14.76 a share. In addition, the company would have $2.88 a share in cash on hand after repaying its debts.
Thus, an investor who bought the stock for Friday's closing price of $16.75 would not quite get the 12 private holdings for free since the company would probably owe capital gains taxes if it tried to liquidate the investments. Nonetheless, as long as the private companies fetched more than the $4.45 a share it might take to cover the taxes, investors should have something left over.
In fact, analysts think investors would do quite well. Furman Selz believes the 12 private companies, which include Israel's largest manufacturer of paints and a major cable television company, are worth $8.55 a share. A similar Oppenheimer & Company report values those same assets at about $9.70 a share.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
In Washington, The Dollar Has Few Friends

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
As the Democrats recounted the list of economic woes for which they hope voters will hold George Bush responsible, there was a curious omission. The steady slide in the value of the dollar went unnoted and unlamented.
Yet the dollar's fall is in some ways the signal indicator of the decline of America as an economic power over the last three decades. In contrast to such countries as France, where the value of the currency is deemed to be a measure of national accomplishment, the Government of this country has tended to see a sinking buck as a painless way out of economic binds. 
 These days, the hope is that American exports will become more competitive, and thus American incomes (measured in dollars) greater. The fact the same trend damages American consumers by raising the costs of imports is not mentioned. Nor is the fact that as Americans pay more for imports there is less cash left over to buy other things.
In fact, the trade deficit has proved surprisingly resistant to improvement. The May figure released last week was the worst since November 1990, with both exports and imports declining, notwithstanding the fact recessions normally depress imports and boost exports. "The thing that is noteworthy about America is that we are still running trade deficits with a miserable economy," said Michael J. Harkins, the president of Levy, Harkins & Company, a New York money manager that is betting on a further dollar decline.
The dollar's most recent weakness, especially against European currencies, can be traced to Germany's decision to raise interest rates at a time when the only thing the Bush Administration can think of to improve business is to lower rates.
But the decline of the dollar is a longer-term phenomenon. When Ronald Reagan took office, the average American worker earned $249 per week. Last month the average was $363, a 46 percent increase. But expressed in marks it was up just 4 percent, and expressed in yen it was down 11 percent.
Long term, the implications of a depreciating dollar are for rising inflation and a poorer populace. Until now, markets have seemed remarkably unconcerned about such possibilities, but gold's surprising surge last week could signal that is changing.
To a real dollar bear, the eventual result will be a currency crisis, in which the Government must push up interest rates to support the currency, and perhaps even slap on currency controls. But that won't happen as long as the world is happy with the dollar's slow decline, and it seems to be. Bonds sold to foreigners are worth fewer marks or yen than when they were sold, but there is no wholesale liquidation. And few Americans are rushing to take advantage of high German interest rates.
But all that could change, especially if investors decide that it is significant that the once-almighty dollar has few friends in Washington, a fact that will not change whether or not Bill Clinton wins.

HEADLINE: The Calls for an Industrial Policy Grow Louder

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Industrial policy, the notion that government should help the industries and technologies of the future, is moving out of the doghouse and into the limelight.
The idea -- derided by some Reagan and Bush Administration officials as a violation of laissez-faire -- has picked up steam because many Americans yearn for Washington to do more to strengthen the economy. It has also been fueled by concerns that more and more American industries are falling behind their Japanese counterparts. 
 Suddenly, it seems, the importance of muscular policies to help industry is being discussed everywhere -- in the Presidential campaign, in industry councils, in Congressional proposals and in several best-selling books. Everyone seems to agree that helping the industries of tomorrow is crucial for creating jobs -- and high-wage ones at that.
Gov. Bill Clinton has said that if he wins the White House he will set up a powerful agency to help finance and coordinate research and development for "cutting-edge products and technologies." His Democratic running mate, Senator Albert Gore, one of Congress's most vigorous supporters of helping high-tech industries, is sponsoring legislation to build a nationwide network that would link sophisticated computers in businesses, schools, laboratories and hospitals.
For its part, the Bush Administration, despite its free-market philosophy, has stepped up efforts to finance research in promising technologies, like high-speed computing, biotechnology and batteries for electric cars. Richard G. Darman, the budget director and no fan of big government, likes to boast that the Administration has increased the Federal budget for non-military research by 7 percent over last year.
"Industrial policy is an idea whose time has come," said Clyde Prestowitz, a former Reagan Administration official who is president of the Economic Strategy Institute, a Washington-based research group. "Even the Bush Administration is going that way."
Before Ross Perot dropped out of the race, one of the main themes of his campaign was meeting the Japanese industrial challenge head on. He called for targeting industries of the future to keep them from being wiped out by the Japanese, and he wanted to "improve on" Tokyo's vaunted Ministry of International Trade and Industry, which helped orchestrate Japan's great industrial leap forward.
Industrial policy means many things to many people. Its critics say it means that government picks winners and losers among industries and companies. But supporters say industrial policy simply means aiding industry by helping to develop critical technologies and by providing fertile conditions for the industries of tomorrow to grow.
"There is a critical mass developing" on industrial policy, said Senator Jeff Bingaman, a New Mexico Democrat who is Congress's leading advocate of an increased Federal role to back developing technologies. "More and more people seem to recognize that the long-term trends have not been favorable to the U.S. in terms of our ability to compete in world markets. One element of turning that around is having the Government become a more active catalyst for the changes that are required."
The United States has had an undeclared industrial policy for years. That policy aimed to create the world's most advanced military industry, and one reason the Soviet Union collapsed is that it spent so much money trying to keep up.
With the cold war over, the need to convert from military to civilian production is one of the major engines behind the push for an industrial policy. The new Defense Conversion Initiative in Congress aims to insure that the talents of thousands of research engineers who helped build the world's most sophisticated military machine are used to develop commercial technologies. There is also a push to get military companies to adopt flexible manufacturing techniques so that factories that make fighter aircraft today might make high-speed trains tomorrow.
Adding to the momentum for an industrial policy are the many new books and studies showing that government support for Japanese and German industries has often given them a leg up on their American rivals. These books include "Head to Head," by Lester Thurow, dean of M.I.T.'s Sloan School of Management, and "A Cold Peace," by Jeffrey E. Garten, an investment banker who used to work in the State Department.
Airbus Industrie, the four-nation aircraft consortium, is probably the best example of how government aid to a manufacturer has clipped the wings of American competitors. Airbus has badly bruised McDonnell-Douglas and has become Boeing's main challenger thanks to an estimated $20 billion in aid from European governments.
"We're faced with a situation now where the rest of the world takes it as a standard method of operating for industry and government to cooperate on what they consider to be the critical industries and technologies for their country," said William J. Spencer, president of Sematech, a Government-backed alliance of companies in the semiconductor industry. "That's happened in the Pacific Rim countries since World War II, and that's happening in Europe. The U.S. will be at a disadvantage in world competition if we don't find an American way of working together."
Many supporters of industrial policy say it is just one piece of an overall strategy needed to make the American economy more competitive. The litany of additional suggestions to fortify industry is endless: improve schools, cut capital gains taxes to spur investment, increase job training, upgrade roads and airports to reduce transportation costs and adopt a tougher trade policy with countries that discriminate against American goods.
Mr. Clinton's new economic plan contains numerous proposals to help high-technology industries, among them making the research and development tax credit permanent and investing $50 billion more a year in education, job training and infrastructure. He also calls for the creation of a new civilian research agency, which would act like the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency. The Pentagon has used that agency to help develop new technologies, including computer graphics, semiconductors and computer-controlled machine tools. The agency Mr. Clinton proposes would bring together businesses, universities and laboratories to do research and development in civilian technologies.
THE Bush Administration says it backs a technology policy, eschewing the term "industrial policy." In its National Technology Initiative, the Administration encourages businesses to work closely with the 726 Federal laboratories; they have signed 1,200 cooperative agreements in the last 18 months.
The Administration is also setting up a Critical Technologies Institute, staffed by engineers from around the nation, to identify the crucial emerging technologies and determine which deserve Federal backing.
"I think that we have a very major role to play in developing the basic knowledge, the basic generic technologies that undergird all of our industrial activity," said the White House's science adviser, D. Allan Bromley. "Do I think we should pick companies in various fields that may be in trouble and use taxpayer dollars to specifically assist them? Then, the answer is no."
In the 1980's, industrial policy proposals came under attack from conservatives who said it meant that government officials, believing themselves omniscient, would somehow divine the growth industries of tomorrow and throw the Government's weight and money behind them. Critics wondered how the people who brought the world $300 billion annual deficits could summon the vision to decide whether gallium arsenide chips or liquid crystal displays were the technologies to bet on.
"I leave it to I.B.M. and Hewlett-Packard to decide what are the important future technologies," said Herbert Stein, an economist at the American Enterprise Institute. "I don't think Washington has any comparative advantage in doing that."
Fears also abound that Washington would give money to the politically connected rather than the technologically deserving. "It's not very encouraging to see that in the appropriations bill, every Congressman with influence has given his pet college an R.&D. grant," said Charles Schultze, an economist at the Brookings Institution.
The Government has gotten mixed reviews for its past dabblings in industrial policy. A decade ago Washington spent $1 billion to help several military contractors develop high-speed integrated circuits for military equipment. It was embarrassing that Intel got there first without Federal financing.
At the same time, many people say Sematech, which aimed to improve the nation's capability in producing machinery to make semiconductors, is a success. The proof, they say, is that the nation has gained market share in semiconductor sales.
STILL, many people are asking how wise it is for taxpayers to finance programs like Sematech when companies share their expertise with foreign companies and build factories abroad. That happened last week when Advanced Micro Devices announced it would team up with Fujitsu to build a $700 million factory to make advanced semiconductors in Japan.
Nowadays it seems that everyone is against industrial policy if it means that government picks winners and losers. But it also seems that everyone backs industrial policy if it means adopting policies that help industry.
"This is not a matter of picking winners and losers," said Senator Bingaman. "Industry should do the choosing, but when a choice has been made, and when it's clear that a particular technology has the potential to be a winner, government should help it become one."
The Commerce and Defense Departments have made lists of what they view as critical technologies of tomorrow. The Defense list includes robotics, sensitive radars and air-breathing propulsion. The Commerce list includes superconductors, flexible computer-integrated manufacturing and opto-electronics, like lasers and optical fibers. Both cite biotechnology, advanced sensors and advanced semiconductor devices.
"It's very important that the public sector, led by the Administration and Congress, publicly espouse the fact that the country's future growth depends on our technological health, especially on certain critical technologies," said George M. C. Fisher, chairman of Motorola and president of the Council on Competitiveness, a business-labor group. "Other countries seem to be willing to do more about that than we are."
 
 
 
LESSONS FROM GERMANY AND JAPAN
 Americans have a lot to learn from Europe and Japan, supporters of industrial policy say. The Japanese Government spends 50 percent more on non-military research and development than Washington does as a percentage of gross domestic product. Germany spends 14.5 percent of its government R.&D. money on industrial development, while the United States spends less than 1 percent.
Many Americans also admire how fast the Japanese turn basic technologies into commercial products. The Commerce Department is pushing to speed this process by encouraging American companies to cooperate far more closely with Federal laboratories.
"We are trying to accelerate the commercialization of technologies," said Robert M. White, Under Secretary of Commerce for Technology Administration.
Robert Reich, an economics professor at the Kennedy School of Government, praises European policies that support industries with the aim of bolstering job skills. "Europe supports Airbus not because it expects Airbus to be a profitable company, but because it wants to gain cutting-edge skills in aerospace," he said. He argues that efforts to back high-tech industry should also aim to give Americans high-tech skills and jobs.
Many experts envy Japan's Ministry of International Trade and Industry, which not only decides which technologies deserve government backing but also coordinates trade and regulatory policies to help Japanese industry capture the lead in those technologies.
Lester Thurow, dean of M.I.T.'s Sloan School of Management, says American industry could be left behind if Washington sits idly by while its competitors aggressively back industry. "You have to have a defensive industrial policy even if you don't believe in an offensive industrial policy," he said.

HEADLINE: Making a Difference;
Winning Big At Airbus

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
When John Leahy, the vice president of marketing for Airbus Industrie in the United States, was given the job of selling the A320 airplane to United Airlines early this year, he knew he faced a Herculean task.
United had bought nothing but Boeing planes since 1978. It had always been Boeing's biggest and most loyal customer and Mr. Leahy knew Boeing would make every effort to keep it that way. 
 Besides, Airbus had failed three times before to win United over to its planes. Airbus, a consortium of companies from France, Spain, Britain and Germany, controls about 30 percent of the world market and is second in size only to Boeing.
"We had three strikes against us," said Mr. Leahy, who is based in Herndon, Va. Nevertheless, he said, he also knew that if there was any plane that had an advantage over a Boeing product it was the A320 over the 737-400.
The A320 flies faster, higher and with better fuel economy. If the bids were similar in price, Airbus had a good chance for a breakthrough this time around, Mr. Leahy felt.
After five days of intense negotiations early this month, with the Airbus team in one room and the Boeing team in another, the two bids were close in financial terms. It was up to Lou Valerio, the vice president of finance for United, to evaluate them.
To the jubilation of Mr. Leahy and his staff, the evaluation came out in favor of Airbus. On July 9, United announced that it would lease 50 A320's on a long-term basis with options for 50 more. Exact terms were not disclosed but the twin-engine jets normally sell for about $45 million each.
Mr. Leahy, who is 42 years old, has been flying light aircraft since he was a young man and still loves to solo in a Piper or other small plane.
After college -- he holds a degree in communications and philosophy from Fordham University and an M.B.A. from Syracuse -- he went to work for Piper Aircraft in sales. The general aviation market was booming at the time and he was ultimately sent to Geneva to head Piper's European sales operation.
He was recruited by Airbus in 1984. He said he left Piper because the general aviation industry "was going into a recession, liability insurance was up and sales were plummeting. Airbus was going to grow rapidly and I had something to offer them."

HEADLINE: The Shrinking of the American Oil Industry

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
The latest statistics on the American oil industry make it sound as though the oil patch has discovered time travel. Oil imports are at their highest levels since 1978 and domestic production has fallen to where it was back in 1961, the American Petroleum Institute said last week. And the number of oil and gas drilling rigs at work in the country recently hit a low not seen since records began to be kept 50 years ago.
As for the future of the American-based oil industry, it appears to be somewhere abroad, where companies are drilling with a vengeance. 
 The institute, in releasing the dismal figures for the first half of 1992, pointed out that along with disappearing domestic oil there is a disappearing domestic oil industry. In the last 10 years, jobs related to drilling been cut almost in half. Refinery employment is also falling, and companies are cutting headquarters jobs. In just three days earlier this month, Amoco said it would eliminate 8,500 jobs, or 15.7 percent of its total; Mobil said it would cut 2,000 and Unocal, 1,000.
"All of a sudden, you've had a change in psychology, particularly of the major companies," said James Schlesinger, the Carter Administration energy chief who is now with Shearson Lehman Hutton. "They say, 'The American oil province is never going to recover; let's put our money overseas and stop fooling ourselves.' It's almost an infectious decision."
That seems to beg the question: Does the United States really need much of a domestic oil industry anyway?
Mr. Schlesinger and others say that in a really free world market, the most attractive geologic targets will be drilled first, and right now those are abroad. During the cold war, international tensions made oil a strategic asset and provided a rationale for Washington to encourage domestic drilling even if it was uneconomical. But that logic is fading.
At the same time, new clean-air rules are making it harder to refine oil here, and exporting countries are building their own refineries. So while drilling and refining were once a big part of the American economy, for better or for worse, the country will probably have to learn to get along without it, unless Government policy shifts again.
Such a change, of course, would take money, in the form of higher prices or tax subsidies to stimulate production and return the industry to the way it was in the early 1980's. But there is little likelihood that strong action will come from Washington. The National Energy Strategy, which has passed the House and Senate in different forms and is likely to be signed by the President before Election Day, provides nearly nothing for the domestic oil industry.
Although it gives a tax break for independent companies, the strategy continues to keep drilling rigs out of the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, which the industry believes is the country's best prospect for oil. And it extends moratoriums on offshore drilling.
Some in Washington, though, say the Government should be trying harder to save the industry, which was mostly invented here.
"It's very disturbing," Linda G. Stuntz, the acting Deputy Secretary of Energy, said of the decline in the American industry. The Government has allowed other industries to fade away, she said, "and now we're trying desperately to get something back, like high-definition television or flat-panel displays."
Oil, she says, is all the more critical not only because the nation needs fuel, but because the industry supports other parts of the economy. "Along with the actual guys on the rigs," she said, "you don't have the money in the grocery stores and the real estate companies and the banks."
But many economists say that the Government should not help the industry here if the prospects for finding oil look better abroad, and if the country is committed to free trade.
If capital is moving abroad, "all that says is that comparative advantage is changing," said Robert E. Lipsey, an economist at the National Bureau of Economic Research, in New York. "About two-thirds of all the wells ever drilled for oil and gas were drilled in the United States, and these days the grass looks greener elsewhere."
All the signs point toward a continuing contraction in oil:
* The count of drilling rigs looking for oil and gas hit 596 last month, down from a peak of 4,530 at the end of 1981, according to Baker Hughes, a machinery company that keeps track of such things. John Lichtblau, director of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation, predicted the decline would accelerate at the end of this year, when tax incentives on some natural gas drilling expire.
* Last year exploration and development in the United States by a group of 30 large oil and gas companies tracked by Arthur Andersen & Company fell by 4 percent. Their investment abroad increased by 27 percent and their total capital expenditures were more than 50 percent higher abroad than in this country. As recently as 1987, their domestic spending exceeded their foreign expenditures.
* In the first half of 1992, the shift to foreign investment appears to have accelerated. Companies made deep cuts in their North American exploration and production budgets, according to a study by Salomon Brothers, and did not even spend what they had budgeted. Spending abroad, on the other hand, rose.
These trends have conspired to increase imports, which, according to the most recent industry figures, have reached 7.355 million barrels a day, the highest since December 1978, and 52 percent of the amount run through domestic refineries. Domestic production was 7.21 million barrels.
Many politicians and others argue that it is unhealthy for the country to import so much oil, and that this could be fatal in time of war. But the end of the cold war and the end of the Soviet threat to the Middle East, which has two-thirds of the world's known oil reserves, has muted those arguments.
Economists in general say investing in drilling abroad is fine for now because it means the oil industry is globalizing as the auto and steel industries have done. On the question of whether the United States needs an oil industry, "What you need is reflected in what you can produce at a profit," said Robert Z. Lawrence, a professor of international trade and investment at the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard. "Asking what we need is asking, in a sense, 'Is there some nonmarket reason why the Government should be concerned about a particular sector above other sectors?' " In that sense, he said, oil wells are going the way of the family farm, pushed aside by new economic realities.
In fact, efficiency and technological progress contributed to the industry's shrinkage.
For example, said William L. Fisher, of the Bureau of Economic Geology at the University of Texas, companies have to drill only 40 percent as many wells to discover oil as they did 20 years ago. That means less work to go around.

HEADLINE: Business Diary/July 12-17

BYLINE: By Joel Kurtzman

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
 
Clinton Will Run on a Lackluster Economy 

At least some of the tears streaming down the cheeks of those listening to the emotional acceptance speech of Democratic Presidential candidate Bill Clinton belonged to the Republicans. Mr. Clinton had surged ahead of President Bush in the polls. He said he was running on a platform that emphasized rebuilding the economy, taxing the wealthy, investing in people and creating a universal health care system. Mr. Clinton also cited the growth in joblessness, the increase in the size of the Federal deficit and the decline in income growth under President Bush. "Our country is falling behind," Mr. Clinton said. "We've gone from first to 13th in the world in wages since Reagan and Bush have been in office." Reacting to the polls, Robert Teeter, Mr. Bush's campaign chairman, said he was not alarmed. There was "no question in our mind ever that Gov. Clinton would get a big bump out of this convention," he said.
 
Perot Hits the Eject Button
 
Ross Perot, phasers set on stun, blasted into politics by telling viewers on "Larry King Live" he would run for President if they put him on the ballot in all 50 states. They were well on their way to doing that. But last week -- just after Edward J. Rollins, one of Mr. Perot's dream team of political advisers, quit the campaign -- Mr. Perot retired from the race. The withdrawal came shortly after the Texas billionaire played host to a group of 100 would-be advisers for a series of hush-hush meetings in Washington and after he brought scores of savvy citizens to Dallas. But Mr. Perot began tumbling in the polls. He told his volunteers that "there is no question that you have changed politics in this country, and it is a change for the better."
 
The Stutter in Housing Starts
 
It's the housing industry that often leads the nation into recovery. Dig a foundation and you are putting people to work. Put up the walls on your new digs and you have to buy materials. But last month, according to the Commerce Department, the housing industry led the nation where it has already been -- a slump. Housing starts declined by 2.3 percent from May, while requests for building permits were down 1.3 percent.

The Rebound Loses Its Spring
 
If you thought manufacturing output, which had been growing for the last five months, would continue to lift the economy out of its malaise, think again. According to the Federal Reserve, output at the nation's factories fell by 0.3 percent last month. "There is no acceleration in the economy's growth," said Allen Sinai, president of the Boston Company.

Big Brother Gets Bigger
 
Ever wonder what was the result of all that talk about trimming back government? Well, surprise, big government got even bigger. The Labor Department said 18.6 million people were on the nation's Federal, state and local government payrolls in June, up from 16.4 million in 1980. There are now more bureaucrats than factory workers. The department reported that there were 18.2 million manufacturing jobs last month. "Manufacturing jobs have gone overseas," said Kathleen Camilli of Maria Ramirez Capital Consultants. Government jobs, on the other hand, have not been exported.
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
Tightening Up at the Bundesbank
 
When Germany's central bank, the Bundesbank, raised the discount rate to 8.75 percent from 8 percent last week, the move was widely perceived as symbolic. After all, the discount rate only applies to short-term bank borrowing. Long-term rates would only be driven up by a quarter of a percentage point or so as a result of the action, economists said. But Germany is serious about slowing its overheated economy and about curbing the growth of money and credit. As a result, rather than being symbolic, last week's rate increases "may just be the beginning," said Carl Weinberg, chief economist of High Frequency Economics in New York. "My view is there is going to be another tightening of interest rates, most likely before the end of the summer." If Mr. Weinberg is correct, the dollar, which is already at all-time lows against the mark, could fall further.

The Elusive Convertible Ruble
 
Ever since former President Mikhail S. Gorbachev first took power in 1985, reformers in the Kremlin said a fully convertible ruble was just six months away. The latest deadline for convertibility was later this month. But last week, the economic braintrust working for Russian President Boris N. Yeltsin said it would take a little longer than anticipated to make the change. The reason, the economists said, was that the International Monetary Fund has so far refused to set up a $6 billion fund to stabilize the currency. The I.M.F. is unhappy with the pace of reforms in Russia, especially with its inability to control prices. Without real reforms, the I.M.F. said, transferring $6 billion would only add cash to Russia's till, not help the currency. Last week Michel Camdessus, the I.M.F.'s managing director, flew to meet with the reformers in Moscow. As a result of the squabbles, economists say now the ruble is not likely to be convertible until early 1993 -- about six months away.

The Wages of Workaholism
 
In workaholic Japan they call it "karoshi," death from overwork. About 10,000 workers, mostly blue collar, die from karoshi each year, according to the National Defense Council for Victims of Karoshi. But white-collar workers are victims as well. Last week, Japan's Labor Standards Inspection Office ruled that 47-year-old Jun Ishii, an executive at Mitsui & Company, died from karoshi late last year. Mr. Ishii had spent a third of 1991 on the road for his company. He collapsed and died in his hotel room in Nagoya. The ruling means Mr. Ishii's family is now entitled to additional compensation from Mitsui.

 
 
COMPANIES

 
I.B.M.'s Tentacles
 
Over the last year, the International Business Machines Corporation has formed alliances and joint ventures with former rivals and new-found friends from around the world. Apple, Siemens, Toshiba, Thinking Machines, Intel and others are all working on projects with Big Blue. Last week, it made a tripartite deal with Japan's Toshiba and Germany's Siemens to jointly develop a new generation of memory chips capable of storing 256 million bits of data. The alliance shows how strong Big Blue remains in technology and how battered its rivals have become. "Even the Japanese are beginning to feel the heat," said Clyde V. Prestowitz, president of the Economic Strategy Institute.

Advanced Micro's 'Flash' Links
 
While Big Blue dazzles them with yet another new relationship, Advanced Micro Devices Inc. -- a relative stranger to the world of alliances -- is teaming up with Japan's largest computer company, Fujitsu, in a $700 million deal to develop "flash" memory chips. The market for these nifty new devices -- which are small, lightweight and can store information even when the power is switched off -- is expected to grow to $1.5 billion by 1995, from $130 million last year. Flash chips could replace hard disks in laptop and palmtop computers. Advanced Micro has been critical of Japan. But the high cost of developing chips is driving this technology embrace. "It is becoming increasingly difficult to succeed if a company plays by itself," said Hikotaro Masunaga, a managing director of Fujitsu.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 10; Column 5; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 358 words

HEADLINE: Making a Difference;
A Flashy Team Effort

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
HIKOTARO MASUNAGA had been managing director of Fujitsu Ltd. in charge of semiconductors for less than three weeks when he took his first bold step. On Monday, Fujitsu announced that it had entered a joint venture with Advanced Micro Devices Inc., an American semiconductor company, to jointly develop and make an exciting new type of memory chip.
While there has recently been a spate of semiconductor alliances, this one goes further than most. Fujitsu and Advanced Micro said they would contribute equally to build a $700 million factory in Japan to produce flash memories, a type of chip that has the potential to replace disk drives for permanent information storage in computers. To cement the relationship, the two companies also said they would buy small equity positions -- less than 5 percent -- in each other. 
 Such a major collaboration, of course, was not negotiated since Mr. Masunaga's promotion, but has been under discussion since the beginning of the year. Nevertheless, even before his promotion, Mr. Masunaga was the key architect of the deal for Fujitsu.
Joint activities like this one are becoming necessary because few companies can afford the ever more expensive semiconductor factories.
"It is becoming increasingly difficult to succeed if a company is going to play by itself," said Mr. Masunaga. He also predicted the alliance would be "very beneficial to the U.S.-Japan relationship."
Mr. Masunaga, 55, graduated from Waseda University in Tokyo with a degree in engineering and received a master's degree in microwave engineering from London University.
He joined Fujitsu, Japan's largest computer company, as a semiconductor engineer in 1967 and reached the position of general manager of the electronic devices group last year. In June he took on the additional title of managing director and became the company's top semiconductor executive.
Mr. Masunaga has his work cut out for him. With the world economy weak, there is an oversupply of memory chips and prices are depressed. That is sharply cutting profits or even leading to losses in the semiconductor divisions of Japanese electronics companies.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 23; Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 959 words

HEADLINE: At Work;
Data on Disabilities, True and False

BYLINE: By BARBARA PRESLEY NOBLE

 BODY:
Among the early pages of a new study on the impact of the Americans With Disabilities Act is a chart listing 10 dearly held attitudes about people with disabilities and their ability to work. Among them:
* Employees with disabilities cannot succeed in the competitive job market. 
 * Employers believe it will be unduly expensive to provide accommodations for workers under the act.
* Employees with disabilities create safety risks in the workplace.
* Customers and clients are uncomfortable in the presence of disabled employees.
Perhaps the study's author, Peter David Blanck, a law professor at the University of Iowa and a fellow of the Annenberg Foundation, a nonpartisan research group based in Washington, could have simply incorporated the 10 into his text, but that would have lessened the impact of what appears just to the right of each statement: The word "False," forming a 10-rung ladder of reproach down the column.
The questions, of course, are, how does Mr. Blanck know what he says he knows and how does he know it now? The second phase of the A.D.A., requiring compliance from employers with more than 25 workers, does not go into effect until next Sunday. The first phase, affecting public accommodation of people with disabilities, began only in January, and there has been so much anticipatory sound and fury over the legislation that there has hardly been time for a dispassionate evaluation. Is Mr. Blanck just another Harvard-educated, Stanford-trained smarty-pants with a sociopolitical agenda?
"I am at the interface of employers and advocates," Mr. Blanck said during a telephone interview from his office in Iowa City. "The point was to begin a dialogue on these issues and to help resolve disputes without resorting to litigation."
At least four years ago, he said, when the A.D.A. was still just a blur in the eyes of several legislators and lobbying groups, there was an obvious need for empirical information on the ability of people with disabilities to work -- and the ability of workplaces to accommodate them. "There was a lack of information out there," he said. "Just a lack of hard facts."
"We knew that a Federal effort was down the pike, though we didn't know what it would be," Mr. Blanck said. As a scholar with training in psychology, the science of individual behavior, and law, the formal rules of social behavior, Mr. Blanck was aware that policy, the implementation of good intentions, frequently outruns knowledge. There was, for example, little longitudinal research on the impact of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973, a measure affecting Federal workplaces and contractors that was the spiritual ancestor of the A.D.A.
Thus was Mr. Blanck's project, which began in 1989, both obvious and, in policy science, unusual. "To have subsequent comparisons, we needed baseline data," he said. His approach, drawing on techniques used in economic, medical and social research, was interdisciplinary and inclusive of those he refers to as "consumers" of the A.D.A. -- people with disabilities -- and "users" -- the employers.
The consumers studied were mentally retarded, many with various "physical challenges." Mr. Blanck estimates that 20 to 30 percent of the 43 million Americans said to be disabled fall into the category of people he studied. His users covered a range of large and small workplaces, from fast-food businesses to hospitals to sales organizations to high-tech production companies.
It is on the basis of the first year of data, from 1989, that Mr. Blanck assigned some common beliefs about disabilities to the realm of mythology. Perhaps most surprising, given the protesting voices of several trade associations in recent months, was that in 1989 at least, employers displayed little concern over the potential costs of the A.D.A. That may be because employers are more familiar than trade associations with the work of employees with disabilities. Even in 1989, many companies were making efforts to accomodate those with disabilities. "Larger, innovative employers have been doing this all along," Mr. Blanck said.
Employers may do well to transfer that sense of inevitability to other groups of employees. Woven into the wealth of detail on attitudes of and about people with disabilities in Mr. Blanck's study is a subtext about the workplace of the future. More and more employees are seeking flexible work arrangements tailored to their personal lives. The A.D.A. is one version of what employers are doing all the time, said Mr. Blanck: "Accommodating."

 
 
IS IT PERSONAL, OR JOB RELATED?
The Americans With Disabilities Act requires employers to make "reasonable" accommodations so that people with disabilities can perform the "essential functions" of their jobs. But the definition of "reasonable" has vexed the collective corporate mind for several years, according to a baseline study by Peter David Blanck. Part one of the research is published in the current issue of the Journal of Corporation Law.
The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission "said there had to be a 'nexus between an individual's disability and the need for accommodation,' " said Mr. Blanck. That is a less-than-crystalline standard. Employers are particularly concerned about finding the line between personal accommodations, which they need not make, and the job-related accommodations they are required to make.
With many disabilities, there is no clear distinction between the personal and the job -related. Some of the disabled people might need help help getting to the bathroom or communicating with co-workers and clients, for example. "Their personal needs are intimately related to their ability to work," Mr. Blanck said. "Where do you draw the line?"

GRAPHIC: Photo: Peter D. Blanck, University of Iowa: "There was a lack of information out there. Just a lack of hard facts." (Scott Norris for The New York Times)
