SECTION: Section 9; Page 1; Column 3; Styles of The Times

LENGTH: 2255 words

HEADLINE: The Prime of Tipper Gore

BYLINE: By CELIA W. DUGGER

 BODY:
THE times seem to have caught up with Tipper Gore, wife of the the Democratic candidate for Vice President. A vision of blondness, she gathered her four beaming children and her broad-shouldered husband for a family tableau on the convention podium last Thursday night and laid claim to being an updated version of the traditional political wife.
Mrs. Gore and her friends are trying to undo the cartoonish image of her as the prissy, humorless Carry Nation of rock-and-roll. She's really funky and soft-hearted, they say. Her assistant faxed a newspaper article that described her as a woman "whose passion for homeless, poor and mentally ill children carries a world of weight." 
 In an interview last week, Mrs. Gore sheepishly confessed that she had just bought the double compact disk of the Grateful Dead's "Europe '72" album. According to an article in Entertainment Weekly, she played drums in high school in an all-girl band called the Wildcats. And after her husband's acceptance speech, Mrs. Gore, in a form-fitting blue dress, boogied with him to the throbbing beat of Paul Simon and Fleetwood Mac.
She has begun to win over the music industry, which loathed her 1980's crusade against what she called the sadism of Twisted Sister, Motley Crue and other rock bands. She pressured them to voluntarily put labels on albums that contained sexually explicit lyrics, though she opposed legislation to ban the sale of raunchy records to minors. "She stayed faithful to her promise that she was against censorship," said Danny Goldberg, senior vice president of Atlantic Records.
Carter Eskew, a Gore family friend and a consultant to the Clinton campaign, was sure to mention Mrs. Gore's collection of rock and jazz oldies. "She's not at all uptight or judgmental," he said. "She's incredibly fun."
Fun.
In Presidential elections, the wives of candidates become a kind of Rorschach test for the nation on what it means to be a woman. This year's role models could not be more different: Mrs. Gore, Hillary Clinton, Barbara Bush, Marilyn Quayle.
On the so-called baby boomers' ticket, Mrs. Gore and Mrs. Clinton symbolize for many the two paths women of their generation have chosen and the struggle of homemakers and women who work outside the home to come to terms with each other. The strong public reaction to both women reflects society's ambivalence. Each has been caricatured: Mrs. Clinton as the selfish, shrewish career woman, Mrs. Gore as the prudish housewife.
The two are now trying hard to convince the public that they have a lot in common: they are both mothers, feminists and advocates for children. But above all, they are the wives of politicians.
Unlike Mrs. Clinton, Mrs. Gore sacrificed her personal ambitions to raise four children. As her husband's career rose, she gave up her dream of becoming a child psychologist, quit her job as a newspaper photographer and cut short the publicity tour for her book, "Raising PG Kids in an X-Rated Society."
Last week, Mrs. Gore was again in her role as political wife. She has been in it for 16 years, and she is a pro.
Her press aide, Kiki Moore, brought in reporters for half-hour interviews with her in a hotel room. Ms. Moore suggested that Mrs. Gore sit in a wingback chair (better for photographs). Mrs. Gore perched herself at the edge of the chair, poised and polished in her fuchsia suit, black pumps and blow-dried pageboy. She seemed to gird herself
for the painful, intrusive and often silly questions she has to endure.
Asked why she never became a psychologist, Mrs. Gore was silent for a moment. The look on her face was unreadable, almost blank. Finally, she said, "Because that's what made sense to me."
"There are incremental decisions that one makes as one moves through one's life," she said. "I still have young children. My youngest is 9. I'm certainly doing a little bit more in terms of volunteer activity now. It's kind of an ebb and flow. And I've been fortunate enough to be in the position where I don't economically have to go and work full time, which I think many parents do."
The Democrats will portray Mrs. Clinton and Mrs. Gore as apotheoses of their era. "What a powerful team!" said Nancy Hoit, a friend of the Gores. "They are two women who truly represent the women of their generation, trying to balance all the complicated demands of home and career and the causes they care about." Republican strategists have made no secret of their desire to exploit the differences between the women and, if possible, to set them against each other. But Mrs. Gore and Mrs. Clinton have given them little opportunity. On the convention podium, the women threw their arms around each other and hopped up and down like pep squad leaders whose team had just won the game.
Earlier in the week, Mrs. Gore introduced Mrs. Clinton at a party of Congressional wives as "a mother, a child advocate and a person of principle whom I deeply admire." Mrs. Gore later said Mrs. Clinton had been "giving me some great tips" on how to protect her children -- Karenna, 18 years old; Kristin, 15; Sarah, 13, and Albert, 9 -- from the stresses of the campaign. (Rule No. 1: Keep the children away from the press.) Mrs. Gore also had her hair styled by Mrs. Clinton's hairdresser, Kristof, in a cut that is the image of Mrs. Clinton's post-headband pageboy.
Mary Elizabeth Aitcheson was born on Aug. 19, 1948, in Washington. Her mother nicknamed her Tipper when she was a baby. Family history has it that this endearment came from a song her mother sang to her. Her parents were divorced when she was 4, and she and her mother moved in with her grandparents in Virginia. It was the 1950's, a sad and lonely time to be a girl from a broken home -- an experience that she said has given her empathy for the suffering of others.
She attended a girls' school in Washington. She later told a reporter, "I was not raised to do anything except get married and have children." She met Al Gore at his high school prom in suburban Washington, and they soon became sweethearts. He took her home to Carthage, Tenn., to meet his father, Senator Albert Gore, and his mother, Pauline Gore.
"She was dressed fit to kill," the elder Mr. Gore recalled recently. "She was a lovely blonde, beautiful sparkling eyes, shapely and pleasant. I was even more struck by her beauty the next morning. She came to breakfast with every eyelash in place. She was dressed for an evening ball."
Al Jr. went to Harvard University. Tipper followed him to Boston a year later. She graduated with a degree in psychology from Boston University in 1970. The next month, they were married. She was 21.
When her husband was elected to Congress in 1976, Mrs. Gore gave up her job as a newspaper photographer at The Tennessean in Nashville.
"I built a darkroom at my home in Virginia and freelanced in Washington," she said. "I had a picture in The Washington Star. I had some pictures in The Washington Post. One I remember was of the opening of 'Coal Miner's Daughter.' There were others in trade journals. I found that it was better to work with those types of publications because I could set my own schedule. I had young children."
Chris Downey, wife of Representative Thomas J. Downey, Democrat of New York, met Mrs. Gore a few years after the Gores moved to Washington. The women often jog together.
"She's very funny," Mrs. Downey said. "All we do is giggle. When I need to talk to her, she is absolutely there for me. She's a real good friend. She keeps her counsel."
Mrs. Downey said her friend had taken on the primary burden of raising four children. Her husband often goes to Tennessee on weekends and works late on Capitol Hill. She maintains two houses in two worlds: Arlington, Va., and Carthage, Tenn.
"You're sacrificing every day," Mrs. Downey said. "Giving up the book tour and the photography is the least of what Tipper has given up over the years."
"Women like Tipper subsidize the women who work," Mrs. Downey said. "She volunteers for the P.T.A. She improves the quality of children's education. I'm indebted to women like Tipper. I wish I could stay home, but its financially impossible. She's like all those women who could be getting paid money, but choose to make their time available to their families and communities."
Mrs. Gore threw herself into volunteerism in the mid-1980's when her youngest child was a toddler. Two of her causes grew out of conversations with her daughters.
She was driving home with the children one afternoon after they had had lunch with their father in the Senate dining room. They were just a couple of blocks from the Capitol when her girls noticed an unkempt woman on the corner talking to the air.
"Can we help her?" they asked. "Can we take her home with us?"
She and the children decided to volunteer at shelters. She went on to organize Families for the Homeless, a group that raised money and tried to bring attention to the issue.
Mrs. Gore tells the story of the homeless woman in almost every interview. "I am very proud that I decided to do something about my feelings about homeless people," she said. "Every homeless person has one problem. They don't have a home. With a Clinton-Gore Administration, you're going to have a policy that's going to address this."
At the time, her advocacy for the homeless went unnoticed, while her battle against porn rock made Tipper Gore a household name.
One day, her daughter Karenna was listening to Prince's album "Purple Rain." Mrs. Gore was shocked by the sexually explicit lyrics. She got together with other women, including her friend Susan Baker, wife of James Baker, who was Secretary of the Treasury at the time. Together they founded the Parents' Music Resource Center.
They went on talk shows and wrote articles to publicize their outrage that parents were not warned about lyrics that they believed glorified rape, suicide, sadomasochism, incest and the occult.
And they used their access to power. The wives of six House members and 10 Senators wrote to the Recording Industry Association of America, proposing a rating system that would tell consumers if records, tapes or videos contained violent or sexually explicit lyrics. The alarmed president of the association replied with alacrity. Within weeks, the association agreed to place warning labels on albums.
"Because Susan Baker and I were involved, we were able to get doors opened," Mrs. Gore said at the time. Then the women won a hearing on the issue before a Senate committee that Senator Gore served on. Mrs. Gore and Mrs. Baker testified and answered questions from the committee.
"I see this as my thing, not my husband's," Mrs. Gore said afterward. "I don't see this affecting my husband one way or another. I was an activist before I married my husband. I protested the Vietnam War and I worked for civil rights. This is not the wife of a Senator who has suddenly gone nuts."
But her actions were extraordinary for the wife of a Southern politician. She had violated the rules of invisibility and seemliness. She was at the heart of a controversy that many musicians took as an assault on rock-and-roll and freedom of expression. It put Senator Gore, who was contemplating a Presidential bid, in an uncomfortable position.
The issue played well in Tennessee, a Bible Belt state, but it turned off many of the columnists who later wrote about the Senator's Presidential candidacy. It also did not please some potential contributors.
Mrs. Gore was on her book tour when her husband decided to run for President in 1987. She cut the tour short and divided her time between the campaign trail and her children. She and her husband met with leaders of the entertainment industry in Los Angeles to discuss her campaign for record labeling. She tried to explain that she was against censorship, but the group was not convinced.
Later, Mrs. Gore said she had told the executives that she felt she had inadvertently encouraged advocates of censorship at the Senate hearing. Her husband agreed, saying the hearing "was not a good idea."
Senator Gore dropped out of the race. And in the spring of 1989, disaster struck the family. Senator Gore and his son, then 6, were at a baseball game in Baltimore. In the parking lot, Albert pulled his hand out of his father's and darted in front of a speeding car. The boy clung to life for weeks. The Gores kept vigil at his bedside. The boy recovered.
Mrs. Gore neither delved into the horror or exploited it for sympathy. Instead, she quickly moved from the personal to the safer ground of the political. "It stopped everything in its tracks, just like an explosion," she said. "We were in the hospital a month. Al never left his side, except a couple of times for votes.
"The point that I'd like to make is that my husband was able to do that because his employers were the people of Tennessee, who gave him family leave to be with his injured child. A Clinton-Gore Administration is deeply and personally committed to making sure that all Americans have the opportunity for family leave."
For all the portrayals of Mrs. Gore as the loving mother, crusading advocate and selfless volunteer, the image of her that sticks from her moment in the convention limelight is of the politician's wife who is, after all, herself a politician. As her aide signaled that the interview had to end, Mrs. Gore moved near the window so a photographer could get a better shot. Move your hand, he suggested.
And she did.

HEADLINE: ENGAGEMENTS;
Dione N. Green and Arthur E. Mitchell

 BODY:
Mr. and Mrs. Michael L. Green of Philadelphia have announced the engagement of a daughter, Dione Nicole Green, to Arthur Early Mitchell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Herman M. Mitchell of Pittsburgh. An October wedding is planned.
Miss Green and her fiance are 23 years old and graduates of Howard University. She is a microbiologist at Elkins-Sinn, a pharmaceutical company in Cherry Hill, N.J. Her father is the chief probation officer in Trenton for Mercer County, N.J. Her mother, Cheryl Y. Green, is an elementary-school teacher in the Philadelphia school system.

HEADLINE: BARCELONA - A VIEWERS GUIDE;
Rare Air And New Rules for Olympics

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY

DATELINE: BARCELONA, Spain

 BODY:
AS the 25th Summer Olympics since the event's rebirth in 1896, the Barcelona Games that open Saturday triumph a new era in global sports, one virtually bereft of the quaint philosophies that once defined the Games and set them apart from almost all other forms of athletic endeavor.
Somewhere between vanishing and vanished, the notions of purity, integrity and amateurism -- sport for sport's sake -- have been muted by a new universal. 
 In these Benchmark Games of Barcelona, the first in an evolving world order that includes resurgent independent states and infant democracies, sport has become engulfed in an unabashed chase of dollars, pounds, lira, francs, marks and yen. Little else matters. Little else can afford to matter. And what a perfect metaphor for the change: Barcelona organizers have announced that the 257 gold medals to be awarded are, for the first time, the real thing, medals of gold worth about $5,000 each.
Where once the Olympic lure was the common belief that no matter which man, woman or team won, the attempt was honorable, pure and true, the Games are now wholly defined by a single concept: Money.
Money for athletes. Money for television rights. Money for sponsors.
Almost everywhere, multinational corporations like Coca-Cola, Visa, Nike, Phillips, Mars, Adidas, Mobil, Smirnoff Vodka and the Turner Broadcasting System have replaced or enhanced government programs that once supported Olympic efforts, including all those once within the Soviet sphere of influence. Some of the companies have established direct affiliations with the Olympics, at a cost of $20 million or more, so their goods can be advertised as an "official" product of the Games. Coca-Cola has paid a reported $33 million for such honored designation.
In most places, it is a blessing but in many, a necessity as well. In Russia, for example, major contributions by Adidas, Smirnoff and a Yugoslavian clothing company called Goma have kept alive programs that will probably make the Commonwealth of Independent States -- Russia and 11 other former Soviet republics -- the Games' leading medal winner. The Soviet Union was the medal leader in every Summer Olympics but one (1984) for 20 years.
More tailored programs have helped elsewhere -- like Reebok's advertising campaign with the American decathlon stars Dan O'Brien and Dave Johnson; Delta Hotels' support of the Canadian swimming team and the variety of sponsors who support cycling clubs around the world -- to the extent that some are abandoning traditionally strong professional teams that ride in the Tour de France to affiliate with Olympic teams and individual riders.
After the commonwealth -- or Unified Team, as it will known in Barcelona -- those two leading monuments to market economy, Germany and the United States, should emerge with the next highest total medals. But then watch for improvements from Japan, South Korea and even Hungary, which was always a step ahead of the other Soviet satellites in using Western-style
marketing concepts.
"We are virgins no more," Aleksandr Kozlovsky, a vice president of the Russian Olympic Committee, said proudly. "With the same system of six to seven years ago, we would be dead by now. Because of the support of these firms, we can survive."
For smaller countries, too, programs have been saved by corporate expansion, like Mobil's fueling of track and field in African nations. Though dense and disparate with 38 countries over roughly 11.7 million square miles, the African continent has emerged as the next competitive force in track.
"The new feature here is all the sponsorship involved with athletes and individual programs," said Richard Pound, a member of the International Olympic Committee from Canada who is heavily involved in Olympic marketing and television contracts. "I think what we'll see in Barcelona, for the first time, is a graphic demonstration of the need to have a rationalization of all these sports programs so they don't end up diluting each other."
But these Games are about more than sponsorships. As the echoes of the past remain only in the antiquated names of organizations like International Amateur Athletic Federation, nothing symbolizes the move toward corporate takeover more than the United States entry in the men's basketball tournament.
This Dream Team of great and monied players represents the true neo-Olympics, a gracious bow to the marketeers, agents and economic planners who see new regions and countries only as demographics to be conquered. In time, the level of play around the world might improve because of these players' inclusion, just as it did in countries like the Soviet Union, Brazil and Yugoslavia, which studied and copied American college basketball style years ago. More than ever, National Basketball Association rosters reflect the league's expanding reach, with players like Drazen Petrovic of New Jersey, from Croatia; Sarunas Marciulionis of Golden State, from Lithuania; Detlef Schrempf of Indiana, from Germany; Dikembe Mutombo of Denver, from Zaire; and Hakeem Olajuwon of Houston, from Nigeria.
But in the meantime, aesthetics may be damned in Barcelona if the recent Olympic qualifying tournament in Portland, Ore., is any indication. The Dream Team of 11 N.B.A. stars and one college player won its games by 79, 44, 60, 41, 38 and 47 points. No matter. The Word is being spread, and the Olympics is the facilitator. After this summer, how long will Toni Kukoc of Croatia be content to play on the smaller stage of the Italian basketball league when the Chicago Bulls, who drafted him in 1990, beckon?
The N.B.A. phenomenon is also important as a barometer of future marketing possibilities. As more international federations relax their eligibility requirements to include professionals and leading Olympic officials seek new ways to expand within the world economy, Games of future summers are likely to appear significantly altered. Perhaps they will be stripped of sports like team handball, field hockey and modern pentathlon, whose popularity has not generated similar global economic potentials, and be embellished with professional boxers, baseball players, cyclists, golfers, beach volleyball players and our favorite stars from the Worldwide Wrestling Federation.
Is this a logical extension?
Olympic officials received $401 million from NBC for the American television rights to the Barcelona Games. That's a record by more than 33 percent, and organizers for the Atlanta Games of 1996 have predicted they might get $1 billion from a willing American network.
For that kind of money, a network requires saleable products. That's Hulk Hogan, not Matt Ghaffari. Oh, he's a Greco-Roman wrestler from Chandler, Ariz., a potential medalist.
It's hard to say precisely when everything changed. Money has always been a natural and reasonable objective for athletes even if professionalism was an immediate disqualifier to the Games. But that only pushed business underground, creating opportunites for Western promoters to offer illegal payments and for Eastern governments to provide performance incentives unavailable to the masses, like cars and bigger apartments.
In time, shortcuts and cheating were brought to the mix in both systems, chiefly through drug use, whether institutionalized (see: East Germany) or privatized (see: Ben Johnson of Canada, Seoul, 1988). In either case, the benefactors benefitted.
Then, the earth shook. From an epicenter in Moscow three years ago, freedoms were unleashed across Europe, and walls came tumbling down. Yet as ordinary citizens were now allowed to think and ask questions, some of the answers angered them. The rewards of performance flowing from secret government supplies had been unknown to the general public in places like East Germany, Bulgaria and the Soviet Union. It wasn't as if these governments had nothing else to support. When voices were raised in protest over real and perceived corruption, governments simply shut down the supply line.
Thus, sports privatization was born in places that historically decried such bourgeois concepts.
This was barely two years ago.
Now look: Athletes and sports programs from every point on the evolving political spectrum are fighting for the same dollars. In a world economy, all athletes are competitors, no matter the sport or nation. A sprinter from Nigeria needs a pair of training shoes as much as a German kayaker.
Yet the nature of global supply-and-demand makes sense of disparities, like Japan's long-range medal potential outstripping Cuba's or the ability of one member of the United States Olympic team to earn $3.5 million a year (Michael Jordan) while another earns $12,000 (Anna Seaton, a rower). This is, indeed, the new world order and the ultimate consequence of the new world Olympics.

HEADLINE: Why This Recession Is Different

 BODY:
To the Editor:
To make sense of the seemingly conflicting economic statistics spewing forth in great profusion, we must ask, "Why is this recession different from almost all other recessions?" The unequivocal answer: "This is not only the usual cyclical recession, but also a structural recession." 
 The evidence is overwhelming. To reverse the excesses of the 1980's, restructuring has been going on in massive proportions at every level. It is a rare day that newspapers do not report layoffs, often in the thousands in the industrial sector.
The same pattern is duplicated at every governmental plane. As for the military, the loss of jobs has been exponential, with the worst yet to come. Personnel will be reduced from 3.2 million to 2 million over the next five years. Although this is good for the long term, it has exacerbated the recession and will continue to do so unless positive steps are taken.
Since one of the few scientific truths in economics is that two-thirds of our economy is powered by consumer spending, the growing job loss, no longer a lagging indicator, gives us a double whammy. The tax base is reduced, and Government costs rise with higher unemployment benefits. What cannot be quantified in monetary terms is the increase in broken homes, crime and misery.
Next New Year's Day will present us with yet another problem. The European Community will become the family of Europe. It will substantially hurt our ability to be competitive. Since Japan will be similarly affected, expect it to be even more aggressive in our country and in all our export markets.
The situation is more serious than the Administration would have us believe. The drop in interest rates is no solution. During the Great Depression the prime rate went to 1 percent, with no cure. When you are out of work or afraid of losing your job, you do not take on debt. Nor will entrepreneurs borrow even very cheap money unless there is a market.
There is a potential solution. Had the worst-case scenario of a two-year Iraqi war materialized, we would not have flinched if the tab was $200 billion more. Let us sell prosperity bonds, which would be used solely for affordable housing, repair of our decaying infrastructure and to upgrade our second-class educational system. Spending for defense, however necessary, is an expense. Spending for these projects is a returnable investment.
 
HERBERT BARCHOFF
New York, July 6, 1992
 
The writer is a former president of the Council of Economic Advisers.

HEADLINE: Noncandidate Perot, Specialist in Surprises

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES

DATELINE: DALLAS

 BODY:
AT one of the early rallies in his abortive Presidential bid, Ross Perot drove photographers and camera crews crazy. The Texan finished his speech, bounded across the stage to shake the outstretched hands of some of his fervid admirers and, basking in thunderous cheers, departed, his well-known open-mouthed grin stretching across his face. Just as cameramen were capping their lenses and sound engineers turning off their boom mikes, the diminutive billionaire suddenly reappeared to grasp more hands, receive more applause and say a few more words. It seemed Mr. Perot did not know when, or how, to make his exit.
As was the case at that rally in Orlando, Fla., Mr. Perot seems determined not to go quietly into the political night. On Thursday he said he was halting his campaign because a "revitalized" Democratic Party meant that the election was sure to be decided by the House of Representatives, a prospect the Texan said would be "disruptive" to the country. 
 But a day after ringing down the curtain, Mr. Perot said on the "Larry King Live!" television show that he was contemplating leaving his name on the ballot and allowing his petition drives to proceed. His aim, he said, was to be the catalyst for a grass-roots movement that would seek to influence Senatorial and Congressional races, as well as the contest between President Bush and Gov. Bill Clinton.
"Coming together they have created the most powerful force, maybe, in this country," Mr. Perot said, referring to his grass-roots supporters. "It is terribly important that that group stay together and I will help them and assist them and provide anything I can so that they can have an absolutely overwhelming impact, not only on the Presidential race, but the House and Senate races this year."
But while Mr. Perot said he wants to play midwife to this new movement, he reiterated his promise not to seek the Presidency. He said, however, that should the President or Mr. Clinton fail to address the issues of concern to his supporters, the Perot constituency should vote for him as a form of protest.
How much influence Mr. Perot's vision of a third force will have on the Presidential contest is unknown. It may very well be that the Texan's impact on the texture of the campaign will stem more from his past presence than his future role.
Perhaps more than any other player this year Mr. Perot forced the slogan "change" toward the center of the stage. It was a theme trumpeted by others, of course. But with their ties to the existing political parties, neither Patrick J. Buchanan, nor Jerry Brown, nor Paul Tsongas seemed to be able to sound that call in a way that was as energizing.
Mr. Perot also embodied the emergence of the "radical middle," the center of the political spectrum that felt its voice was being drowned out by special interests of the left and the right. When Mr. Clinton accepted his party's nomination on Thursday, he did so "in the name of all the people who do the work, pay the taxes, raise the kids and play by the rules." Close your eyes, give the voice a prairie twang, and it could easily be Mr. Perot talking.
 
Torpedoes for Bush
 Mr. Perot also may have affected the race by sending torpedoes into President Bush's listing campaign. As an ill-defined candidate Mr. Perot was a magnet for conservatives disenchanted with the President because of Mr. Bush's broken promise not to raise taxes. And it was the mudslinging last month between Mr. Perot and Republicans, just as Mr. Clinton was releasing his economic plan, that not only halted the Dallas businessman's meteoric rise in the polls, but started the Democrat's comeback.
In some ways the new role Mr. Perot envisions would allow him to try to re-enter the game on his terms. From the start it was his huge checkbook and the promise to spend $100 million on his candidacy that gave the billionaire a measure of credibility. But, despite his financial resources, his effort was falling apart. Last week it was shaken by the resignation of Edward J. Rollins, the veteran Republican strategist who was frustrated that Mr. Perot was ignoring his advice. The Dallas businessman clearly did not relish the rough and tumble of a Presidential campaign. He was stung by the partisan criticism, resented the media scrutiny and had to be pressed to speak to the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People last weekend -- his only campaign appearance before an audience that contained few, if any, of his mesmerized backers. He grew furious whenever he had to meet with gay rights groups in an attempt to mollify their anger over comments he made about maintaining the ban against gay people serving in the military and not appointing homosexuals to his cabinet.
And when it came to ending his candidacy, the second act of the drama had a decidedly improvisational air, just as the first act had. When he pulled out of the race on Thursday, Mr. Perot said nothing about directing a grass-roots movement that would influence Senate and House races.
Indeed, he did not mention it when he taped an interview Friday afternoon with Barbara Walters for the ABC-TV show, "20/20." In some cities, that show aired after Larry King had already been on an hour, perhaps leaving some people to wonder if they were watching Ross Perot live on one channel and a rerun on another.
Now the question is whether anyone, beyond the hardest of his hard-core supporters, will pay Mr. Perot any heed. Mr. Perot's volunteers gathered more than 3.6 million signatures on nominating petitions in the 31 states where he is already on the ballot and the 7 states where he is awaiting certification. That is a large army and, despite accounts of a sense of betrayal, many of those who put in long hours to do the work may remain true believers.
Walter Stone, a political science professor at the University of Colorado who has studied the role of activists in Presidential campaigns, says that by and large, those who work the hardest in losing campaigns tend not to become disillusioned; rather than drop out, they generally stay involved in the political process.
But those are the zealots. It is more doubtful whether the average voters who signed petitions or told pollsters they supported Mr. Perot -- mainly so they could have an alternative in the race -- will listen to what he has to say.
Without an active campaign and solid platform, Mr. Perot's new effort will be deprived of the publicity that would enable most voters to even realize he is still on the scene. More important, most voters consider their vote for President the most important one they cast. Whether they would toss it away as part of a protest is an open question.
"I don't think this is likely to have any influence at all," said Hugh Hecklo, a professor of public affairs at George Mason University, speaking of the new Perot posture. "I think many people who supported him and his promises are tired of being jerked around."
For sure, the second act of Mr. Perot's electoral drama buoyed some of his hard-core supporters. The broader mass of voters are another matter. In the end, Mr. Perot chose not to be a gladiator in the Presidential arena. Instead he preferred to sit on the sidelines and give thumbs up or thumbs down.

HEADLINE: THE BOUNCE;
Blunt Reminders That It's Not Over Until Nov. 3

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER

 BODY:
NORMALCY seemed to reassert itself last week in one of the quirkiest election seasons in memory.
Ross Perot abruptly ended his independent campaign for the Presidency, taking with him such wild possibilities as an election thrown to the House of Representatives. Gov. Bill Clinton was formally presented with the Democratic nomination, with all the confetti, hoopla and partisan glee of the last 40 Democratic conventions. Republicans returned to traditional lines of attack, with cries of "tax and spend" and "liberal." 
 But 1992 remains a year that defies neat scripts and tidy play books. The Democrats are trying to reinvent themselves. No one is quite sure of the long-range effect of Mr. Perot's abortive candidacy. And President Bush remains a fragile incumbent presiding over an ailing economy.
There was plenty of old-time Democratic religion at Madison Square Garden last week, from the Rev. Jesse Jackson's poignant appeal for the poultry workers of the Carolinas to Senator Edward M. Kennedy's eulogy for the life and times of his brother, Robert. But the real business of this convention was ratifying the careful new politics of Mr. Clinton, his attempt to reclaim what he solicitously calls the "forgotten middle class."
 
A Moderate Image
 When Mr. Clinton took the stage at the Garden Thursday night, it marked the ascendancy of the Southern centrists who have watched their Northern brethren repeatedly run for the White House and lose, and long believed that they could do better. They used the Democratic Leadership Council, a group formed in 1985 with a heavily Southern cast of characters, as their think tank and their base for national influence. But they drew their political instincts from their own regions, where success for a Democrat depends on a strong black vote, a healthy share, if not a majority, of the whites, and the ability to project a moderate image.
Mr. Clinton and his running mate, Senator Al Gore, are emblematic of the breed. "The type of politics that Clinton and Gore are pursuing is exactly the kind of politics that wins elections for Democrats in state races in the South," said Merle Black, an expert in Southern politics at Emory University. "Successful Democrats there mix liberal positions on some issues with conservative positions on others. They isolate the Republicans with just the conservative vote, which is not enough to win."
Mr. Clinton's acceptance speech last week was an example of the art: It was steeped in the values of faith and family, hard work and personal responsibility. It was carefully calibrated to hug the center even as he nodded to the party's core constituencies.
He made the case for policies that might be considered liberal: "An America where health care is a right, not a privilege." New college loan programs. Higher taxes on those couples who make more than $200,000 a year. More opportunity for welfare recipients through training, education and child-care programs. Strong support for abortion rights.
But Mr. Clinton, implicitly and explicitly, also promised his television audience a new, more tough-minded, more moderate Democratic Party. Welfare recipients would be required to go to work. Students would pay back their college loans with national service as teachers or community workers. Poor children would be helped, but fathers who fail to pay child support would be warned to "take responsibility for your children, or we will force you to do it." The Government would be "leaner" and expand "opportunity, not bureaucracy."
The heart of Mr. Clinton's philosophy was this: "The choice we offer is not conservative or liberal, in many ways it's not even Democratic or Republican. It is different."
This is hardly the first time the Democrats have tried to redefine themselves. In 1988, Michael S. Dukakis also offered himself as the post-ideological man; in his case, a technocratic problem-solver who would be as much C. E. O. as President. "This election is not about ideology, it's about competence," he told the Democratic convention in Atlanta. The Republicans, however, turned the election into a referendum on ideology and succeeded in portraying Mr. Dukakis as a liberal and far outside the mainstream.
Republicans indicated that they were ready and eager to take up the task once again, particularly now that Mr. Perot's withdrawal has narrowed the field for a head-to-head comparison. The opening round of their definitional battle seemed clear: Was Mr. Clinton offering a new approach to Government, or simply a repackaging of Democratic orthodoxy? "They can talk about change all they want, but it just sounds like the same old stuff, because it is the same old stuff," said Mary Matalin, a strategist in the Bush campaign, which was busily accusing Mr. Clinton of being another "tax and spend" Democrat last week.
 
A 24-Point Lead
 In the short term, Mr. Clinton seemed to have pulled off a successful convention and an auspicious kickoff to the fall campaign, which he quickly took to the countryside in a nine-state bus tour. The New York Times/CBS News Poll showed the Democrat with a 24-point lead over Mr. Bush, the greatest convention bounce in half a century. "There's some extraordinary good luck in this," said Stan Greenberg, Mr. Clinton's poll taker. Mr. Perot's announcement on the day Mr. Clinton accepted his party's nomination "just gave us an entree into hearts and minds that we couldn't have had at any other time," Mr. Greenberg said.
Democrats cheered, but remembered that such bounces can be very short-lived. This year, the political world has changed so quickly, so many times, that even the pundits have grown wary of punditry. No one was quite sure of the impact of Mr. Perot's withdrawal. At first glance, it seemed to restore to the Republicans their historic advantage on the electoral map: when Mr. Bush no longer has to worry about splitting the votes of conservative whites, the deep South, Texas, Florida and the mountain West look much safer for him.
Still, much of the border South will still be competitive, some analysts said, because of the all-Southern Democratic ticket. And the West, especially California, now looks much more promising for the Democrats, with Mr. Gore's prominence on environmental issues.
Mr. Perot might have helped the Democrats in another way; he articulated the case against Mr. Bush, at a time when Mr. Clinton was struggling to recover from the primaries. And the Dallas billionaire did so in a way that transcended partisan attacks. "The Perot critique was not based on ideology, it was based on weakness of leadership, and it stuck with people," said Geoffrey Garin, a Democratic poll taker.
At week's end, it was unclear just what role Mr. Perot's army of volunteers would play, and whether the Dallas billionaire would try to hold them together as a grass-roots political force. Both Mr. Bush and Mr. Clinton were struggling to fill the void. Both parties recognize that beneath the surface of a standard two-party race, the restlessness that spawned Mr. Perot remains.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 7; Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1216 words

HEADLINE: Conversations/William Julius Wilson;
Responding to Urban Alarm Bells At Scholarship's Glacial Pace

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE

 BODY:
IT wasn't exactly beach reading, but it quickly became a classic. In 1987, Professor William Julius Wilson of the University of Chicago published a 223-page volume called "The Truly Disadvantaged" that offered an ambitious, nuanced and plausible explanation for the deterioration of America's black ghettos. The book became a paradigm, the starting point for a subsequent explosion of research.
Now five years have passed, a city has burned, and Mr. Wilson is on the verge of issuing a sequel. For several years he has presided over a small army of Chicago researchers, surveying thousands of ghetto households in search of further insight. 
 At lunch recently at the faculty club, Mr. Wilson was, as always, the buttoned-down academic, choosing his words with precision, betraying little passion and readily admitting that he knows more about poverty's causes than its cures. Is there a conflict between the urgency of the problems he studies and the glacial pace at which academic understanding advances? "There is a tension there," he said. "I know what it's like to grow up poor. That's one of the reasons I do the work I do. But this is my way to contribute."
In his previous work, Mr. Wilson attacked conservatives who blamed ghetto poverty simply on declining values or Government programs like welfare. But he was, if anything, harder on liberals, who had emphasized only racial discrimination and the flight of jobs. Their refusal, he said, to speak candidly of the behavior problems in the ghetto -- out-of-wedlock births, crime and drugs -- had eroded the liberals' credibility and influence.
With reams of dry charts, Mr. Wilson, a sociologist, tried to build a more complex model to explain the origins of the underclass. The roots were economic, he said, planted in the loss of well-paying jobs for low-skilled workers. But the problems were watered by what he called "concentration effects" of ghetto isolation: In the wake of civil rights laws, the black middle class had fled the inner city, leaving behind few role models and rising drift, family dissolution and crime -- problems that fed upon themselves.
 
Second Thoughts
 Subsequent researchers have found many nits to pick. Some say he overstated the impact of job flight to the suburbs. Others say he put too much emphasis on unemployment when explaining the decline of black marriage rates. Now Mr. Wilson is adding his own revisions. "I'm giving more prominence to culture," he said, though he is quick to add that he still sees it as only one component of the misery, and still not the most important. "People adapt to chronic subordination in unique ways, and sometimes the adaptation is detrimental to the neighborhood, the families and the individuals themselves."
Mr. Wilson's rise to academic preeminence has been an unlikely one. His father, a Pennsylvania coal miner, died when he was 12, forcing the family into a brief stay on welfare until his mother could find a way of supporting her six children. Mr. Wilson fell under the sway of an educated aunt.
But there is nothing in his public demeanor that hints at Mr. Wilson's humble roots. Lunching on roast beef at the faculty club, he is every bit the formal academic, speaking in full and precise paragraphs that, when interrupted, he can repeat virtually verbatim.
He is especially sensitive about the word "culture," a loaded term in discussions of poverty. Though he said he is placing greater emphasis on culture than he has in the past, he insists, "I am not making a cultural argument. What I'm making is an argument that integrates cultural, racial, economic and other variables." The sensitivity over the word dates back at least to the 1965 report by Daniel Patrick Moynihan that warned of the dissolution of the black family. Many blacks and liberals denounced that report, and other discussions of ghetto culture, as a means of "blaming the victims."
Mr. Wilson's earlier plea for a more open discussion of black ghetto behavior carried great weight, coming from a leading black intellectual with political ties to the social-democratic left. For the sequel, Mr. Wilson's researchers surveyed 2,495 households and went back for more extensive interviews with 175 of them.
Ten researchers, though not Mr. Wilson himself, then spent more than a year following ghetto residents, hanging out at pool halls, restaurants or weddings. In addition, the research team interviewed 185 Chicago employers on their attitudes toward employees of various races. The results are to be published in a book next year.
As in the past, Mr. Wilson still argues that persistent ghetto poverty stems most predominantly from the decline of good jobs in places like steel mills and auto plants. But his new materials elaborate on other forces: neighborhoods, attitudes, racial prejudice, social networks and family structures.
Among the questions he addresses is why many unskilled immigrants are faring better than ghetto-born blacks. He argues first that immigrants tend to have certain "structural" advantages over ghetto blacks in seeking jobs.
 
Role of 'Culture'
 The availability of child care, he said, is one of them. Forty-four percent of the blacks his researchers interviewed lived in households with just one adult, meaning they could not take a job unless they could find child care. Only 6 percent of the immigrant families had a single adult. In addition, he said, immigrants tend to live in neighborhoods that are closer to jobs. And they tend to hear about openings from family and friends more readily than blacks who live in areas of high unemployment.
While it will no doubt irk Mr. Wilson, others are certain to re-file factors like family structure under the heading of "culture." Where culture comes in, he says, is in the attitudes that the two groups bring toward low-paid, unappealing work. Many immigrants, fleeing lands of desperate poverty, find even bad jobs a step up. By contrast, he said, many blacks -- men, in particular -- are frustrated by falling wages and sensitive to employer slights. "And the more they complain," he said, "the more they reinforce the image that they're less desirable as workers."
As a result, he argues, it is sometimes difficult for unskilled blacks to get even the dishwashing or janitorial jobs that give many immigrants their start. Thus Mr. Wilson, who is noted for arguing that racial discrimination is a declining factor in black economic life, is now reconsidering. "I would even go so far as to argue that for some black males, those with little education and few skills, race has become even more important in the past two decades," he said.
Mr. Wilson, an informal adviser to the Clinton campaign, confesses he is still groping for solutions. A recent research paper calls for job referral centers, car pools and better job training -- talk that seems tepid in Chicago's worst ghettos, where even several of his hired researchers were mugged.
He is now meeting with leaders from foundations, corporations, labor unions and community groups to chart a more ambitious prescription.
And he understands the need to hurry.
"The ghetto exploded in Los Angeles and it could explode anywhere," he said. "The situation of many of these young black males is desperate."

GRAPHIC: Photo: William Julius Wilson in his office in Chicago last week. (Steve Kagan for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Reborn to Win, the Democrats Party On

BYLINE: By The following was written by Frank Rich and Maureen Dowd, who jointly wrote a daily diary during the Democratic National Convention.

 BODY:
THE big band played "Mood Indigo." The hoi polloi squeezed into a horseshoe balcony high above the swells. A Southern belle dressed in pink moved through the crowd surrounded by swains in black tie. And not far away, a younger, blonde debutante giggled with her circle of female admirers.
The soigne party was longer on big hair and sequins than black and Hispanic faces. Limousines queued outside, ladyfingers were served on silver trays and the preferred drink was champagne in crystal flutes. 
 It could have been the annual summer dinner dance at the Houston Country Club. But in fact it was the convention-eve Texas delegation party at Manhattan's Supper Club, and the two popular women honored were Gov. Ann W. Richards and Hillary Clinton.
So it went at the first Republican Democratic National Convention.
Although the swarm of journalists, who outnumbered the 5,000 delegates 3 to 1, whined that there were no scoops, the week offered a fascinating story. It was hardly by happenstance that the Democratic ticket enjoyed the biggest post-convention bounce in polling history.
The young and expedient Bill Clinton and Al Gore took their party -- for a quarter century associated with fiery principle, raucous ideological donnybrooks and seemingly infinite diversity -- and bled out much of the passion and most of the extremes.
Gone was the exciting, unruly street theater that had helped the Democrats lose five of the last six elections. In its place was a show so bland that even the house rebel, Jerry Brown, who came to the podium to sow guilt about the homeless and to damn the privileged, was as much a well-dressed scion of a rich political family as Senator Gore.
Peggy Noonan, the Republican speechwriter who was observing the rival tribe for Newsweek, was struck by the way the Democrats seemed to be fighting their own nature. She noticed that when the enemy greeted her, they were not their usual prickly, "frisky" selves. Instead of yelling in her face about a thousand points of light, they expressed rational disagreement with her political philosophy. "They were civil," she said, a bit incredulous.
At a party for Jimmy Carter on Wednesday night, Hodding Carter 3d, a Washington journalist who was a State Department spokesman in the Carter Administration, talked about the Madison Square Garden metamorphosis from messy passion to steely Democratic Leadership Council pragmatism. He recalled a conversation he had just had with a black friend, also a high-ranking Carter official. His friend had observed with cynical approval that the meaning of this convention was that the "Democrats have finally figured out that it is, after all, a white man's country."
"We need to win over white males, but in the end the people who win are still Democrats," Hodding Carter said. "The programs will benefit women and minorities and the economically disadvantaged, even if it's only incrementally. The party's major factions finally decided that making a point wasn't as important as winning an election."
The convention did showcase more blacks, women and AIDS sufferers than ever before. The platform was steadfast on racial and women's issues, even though its tone was sanded down. And the tent did not get bigger on abortion, despite the best efforts of Pennsylvania Gov. Robert P. Casey, a staunch opponent of Government funding for abortion, to stretch it.
But it was Mr. Clinton's choreography of the traditional Democratic constituencies that made the week so telling. In a scene reminiscent of a 1950's high-school mixer, where the boys line one wall and the girls the other, the Democrats' prized female candidates got a lot of time together on stage, but it was all as an opening act for the Brookings Bubbas.
It was not lost on the women that the league of their own was shunted into Tuesday night, opposite the major leagues' All-Star game.
 
Sliding Into Arsenio
 Representative Pat Schroeder of Colorado showed up pounding her fist into a baseball mitt. Lena Guerrero, the Texas Railroad Commissioner, offered the score at the top of the seventh. And Sharon Pratt Kelly, the Mayor of the District of Columbia, complained that her 10:40 time slot was so late she might slide from the All-Star game straight into Arsenio Hall.
Unlike the last two Democratic conventions, however, when women were agitating to be represented on the ticket, gender was not a battle zone in 1992. The women, with a fresh political sophistication, agreed with Mr. Clinton that they should not come across as a noisy special interest. They played their supporting roles, with the expectation that larger parts might come their way after November.
Meanwhile, Hillary Clinton and Tipper Gore could easily have been mistaken for suburban Republican wives with their immaculately sprayed blonde pageboys, their women's teas with petits fours, and their determinedly uxorious talk of car pools, cookies and children. Asked how the two strong-willed women, both veterans of independent crusades concerning children, were getting along, Mrs. Gore smiled sweetly and said, "A mother is a mother."
The poignant AIDS speeches were also sequestered on Tuesday night, as was the Rev. Jesse Jackson. It was crucial to Governor Clinton's new vision of a party not held hostage by special interests that Mr. Jackson be isolated and tamed while the support of other black leaders was emphasized.
 
A New Covenant?
 Surveying another nearly all-white posh party at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, an unusual fete honoring Robert Strauss, the former Democratic Party chairman who is now the Ambassador to Russia, Charles Rangel spoke angrily of feeling left out of the New Covenant.
"If you can't take me publicly to the ball, I don't want to dance," said the New York Congressman.
Across the room, Vernon Jordan, a Washington lawyer and former head of the National Urban League, who has been helping Mr. Clinton minimize the few showboating black leaders who have grabbed center stage in the past, said that Mr. Rangel "was just lifting his skirt up a little," trying to get noticed.
Sometimes the new Democratic Republicanism looked convincing enough to pass for the real thing. Robert Farmer, a prominent Democratic fund-raiser, arrived with his own Hill & Knowlton press agent in tow, and the "People First" convention featured not one but two heavily guarded private cocktail clubs for high-rolling contributors.
Sounding suspiciously like George Bush and Dan Quayle at moments, Governor Clinton used his acceptance speech to stress individual responsibility over Government bailouts. He said the choice his ticket offered was neither Republican nor Democratic, and he banished the party's New Deal anthem, "Happy Days Are Here Again," from the convention finale," playing instead Fleetwood Mac's "Don't Stop Thinking About Tomorrow."
While the Democrats were doing their best to act conservative, and to hide from the press such aggressively politically correct Clinton powers as the liberal New York lawyers Harold Ickes and Susan Thomases, the Republicans had their eye on some Democratic events that could be exploited for attack ads come the fall.
Representative Barbara Boxer, a California Senatorial candidate, attended a reception for gay and lesbian journalists at the trendy Royalton Hotel, and made fun of Dan Quayle by listing some "beautiful words that end in e." To wild laughter, her list of "justice, choice and peace" was amended to include "dyke" by a loud voice in the crowd.
Jerry Brown, whose counterculture spirit was not welcome in Madison Square Garden, had to seek haven at Rolling Stone magazine to write his speech. At a party thrown by The Nation magazine in Greenwich Village, itself a red zone for this convention, Mr. Brown made a pitch for including "happiness" in the Democratic platform.
Though Senator Gore said in his acceptance speech that this election "isn't about politics" and "isn't even about winning," the message sent by the first Republican Democratic Convention was in every way the reverse.

HEADLINE: JULY 12-18;
More Americans Are Saying, 'I Don't'

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER

 BODY:
If the political exhortation of the week was "Let's get together," the demographic response was, "Not at the altar."
The Census Bureau released a study of marriage patterns showing that 22.6 percent of Americans 18 years of age and older have never married, up from 16.2 percent in 1970 and 20.6 percent in 1980. 
 The monthly marriage data also revealed an accelerating decline in national marriage rates, which are now about 9.3 marriages per 1,000 people, the lowest level since 1965. Historically, marriage rates have gone down in bad economic times and up in good times. But the overall rate is also influenced by the number of young adults, the group most likely to marry. As the baby boomers age, the number of young adults has been shrinking.
Arlene F. Saluter, author of the Census Bureau's report, said her study, based on the Current Population Survey, showed that while 54.2 percent of 25- to-29-year-olds had a household of their own, another 30 percent were living with parents.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Restlessness Reaches Mongols In China

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF

DATELINE: BEIJING

 BODY:
RELATIONS between the Chinese and the Mongols have been a bit strained ever since Genghis Khan slaughtered millions of Chinese in the 13th century. By one account, the Mongols considered converting all of northern China into a vast pasture; they relented when an adviser pointed out that the Chinese, if spared, could be taxed.
The tradition of mutual distrust is again bubbling to the surface in Chinese-controlled Inner Mongolia, a desert region more than twice the size of California. More and more Mongols there are reasserting their ethnic heritage, establishing links with the outside world, and even organizing underground networks to press for democracy and autonomy. 
 "This is our last chance to achieve democracy, to reassert our culture," Huhehada, a 29-year-old leader of the underground movement, said recently. "Mongols need their own culture, their own history -- recorded in their own hands. Or else they'll face the fate of American Indians or of Tibetans."
Mr. Huhehada was interviewed in exile in Ulan Bator, the capital of the neighboring independent nation of Mongolia, from which he and other Inner Mongolian dissidents are orchestrating their campaign. They say about 2,000 people, half of them living in Inner Mongolia, have joined their newly formed General Coordination Committee of Inner Mongolian Rejuvenation Movements. The group is banned within China and the dissidents fear that Beijing will now press Ulan Bator to ban it as well.
Mongolia itself abandoned one-party Communist rule in 1990, and has since seen a tremendous flowering of traditional Mongol religion and culture. Mongolian radio can be heard in Inner Mongolia, and the growing contact across the border seems to be a major reason for the surge of nationalism among China's Mongols. In addition, Beijing has just announced that it will open the entire border to trade, and that is certain to multiply links with Mongolia and perhaps the demands for change.
Inner Mongolia so far is not nearly as much of a headache for the Chinese leadership as is Tibet, where Buddhist monks and nuns regularly protest for independence and human rights. Nor is Inner Mongolia even as much of a concern as oil-rich Xinjiang, the Muslim region of northwest China where there was an abortive armed uprising in 1990. But many of the same pressures -- resentment at Chinese arrogance and immigration, yearning for self-rule and prosperity, and outrage at repression -- seem to be at work in Inner Mongolia.
"Our economy is based on colonialism," said Tsenglet, another of the Mongol leaders exiled in Ulan Bator. "Our land is rich, but the Chinese take our resources and leave us poor. We see that! And there's been pressure from immigrants. We're now a minority in our own land. Life for our people is worse than ever."
 
Resentments Grow
 The statistics do not bear that out: Ethnic Mongols in Inner Mongolia have rising incomes and improving health conditions. But living standards are not rising as fast as those of most Chinese, and resentment seems to be growing. As in Tibet, Chinese immigration to Mongolia is a particular irritant.
The Han, the main ethnic group in China, began to migrate to Inner Mongolia 200 years ago. By the time of the Communist revolution in 1949, the Han reportedly outnumbered Mongols 5 to 1. The 1990 census found a total population of 21.5 million, of whom 3.4 million were Mongols -- a ratio of 6.4 to 1. It would be even more skewed, except that the Mongols have more children than the Han, and many families of mixed heritage have reclassified themselves as Mongols to win educational benefits and other advantages available to minorities.
There are periodic reports of large anti-Government demonstrations in Inner Mongolia, but many foreign diplomats and Chinese alike are skeptical. The situation is murky in part because China normally will not let foreign journalists visit.
The Chinese Government denounces reports of unrest as lies and fabrications. But most foreigners who have visited have reported modest signs of discontent, and dissidents are forging links with the West to get out documents and information on human rights. "It's been a long-overlooked corner of China," said Robin Munro, a researcher for Asia Watch, a human rights organization that has published two reports about Inner Mongolia in the last 12 months. "Until recently, dissident activity there met the fate of being repressed in obscurity and isolation. Nobody would know about it. But there has been this link forged now with international channels of communication, so that repression in the region is reported on. When it's published outside China, it filters back in through international radio stations, the Inner Mongolian dissidents hear about it, and it basically emboldens them to continue."
As everywhere in China, dissidents face considerable risks. At least 17 people are known to be in Inner Mongolia's prisons for their political activities; the true number may be much higher.
While many of the dissidents would like to see Inner Mongolia reunite with Mongolia, they acknowledge that this would be difficult to achieve because of the preponderance of Han Chinese. Some say they would like to expel the Han, or at least relocate them, while others say they would settle for a solution short of reunification.
"In any case, the first thing we need to get is the freedom to speak out, to express our grievances," said Uringkhai N. Tumen, a 27-year-old in Ulan Bator who heads an underground cultural organization in Inner Mongolia. "At the least, we need real autonomy -- real autonomy, not what we have now."

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 6; National Desk

LENGTH: 1776 words

HEADLINE: MAJOR SHIFT LIKELY AS LAW BANS BIAS TOWARD DISABLED

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 18

 BODY:
A law to ban job discrimination against disabled people takes effect in a week and is widely expected to force changes in employment practices as far-reaching as those that followed the laws that opened jobs to women and blacks.
As half a million businesses -- all those with 25 employees or more -- prepare to comply with the law, organizations representing people with disabilities are calling it their own emancipation proclamation. The law, the Americans With Disabilities Act of 1990, challenges the myths, attitudes and working conditions that its bipartisan authors blame for keeping many disabled adults housebound and impoverished.
 
Applying to Many Businesses
 The provisions that take effect July 26 are intended to outlaw discrimination against the 14 million working-age Americans with physical or mental impairments. In two years, the provisions will be extended to three-quarters of a million other businesses with 15 to 25 workers. 
 Although the law does not require employers to set goals for hiring or promoting the disabled, it could have much the same effect. It tells employers that in hiring, promotion and compensation they cannot discriminate against an otherwise competent worker who has a "physical or mental impairment" that "substantially limits" a major life activity, like seeing, walking, thinking or breathing.
 
Effect Hard to Gauge
 With the law still to take effect and the hiring slow everywhere because of the sluggish economy, no one ventures to guess yet how many people with disabilities will get jobs because of the law or what business will spend to accommodate them.
But few experts doubt that the impact will be widespread. "It means that Government and the private sector must take steps to assure that people with disabilities have access to the mainstream of American life," said Robert A. Katzmann, a specialist in legal and disability issues at the Brookings Institution.
Agencies specializing in placing people in jobs report more contacts with employers. Steve Weiner, placement director at Gallaudet University, a college in Washington for deaf students, reports a surge in companies visiting the campus to interview. "The act is generating a lot of possible hires," he said.
The law is an unabashed venture into social engineering and Government intervention into the private economy, normally anathema to many conservatives and business associations. But although many employers say they fear the cost of complying, others say the law will expand the pool of workers available to industry at a time when there is a shortage of workers with essential skills.
"We'll have a new sector of the work force that we can take advantage of," said Edward Potter, president of the Employment Policy Foundation, a research group financed by 200 major companies.
An example of how the law is intended to work is James Holland, 28 years old, who has been completely blind since he was 12 and works for United Parcel Service, which like some other major companies has established programs for people with disabilities. Mr. Holland has been with the company for four years and is a computer programming instructor at an office in Mahwah, N.J.
He has a voice synthesizer and a headset attached to his computer. The synthesizer reads words on his computer screen and converts the words to speech. It also reads back to him anything he types into the computer. He has another device that scans memorandums and other written documents and feeds them to the computer. U.P.S., he said, has been open to providing the tools he needs to work.
The cost of the equipment was about $11,000. "Their attitude is, 'Except for adaptive equipment, we're going to treat you like anyone else,' " he said. "I've always been thankful for that. I'm a firm believer that people's abilities come from within. You have limitations. Everyone has. You have to overcome your limitations and work with your abilities."
 
Satisfied Employer
 For what they consider a very small investment, U.P.S. officials say they have found an unusually competent programming instructor. "For us, the disabilities act does not present itself as some horrific new regulatory problem," said Fred Fernandez, the official in charge of the company's equal employment opportunity programs. "We're looking at it as an opportunity."
The disabilities act requires employers to promptly provide a "reasonable accommodation," except where it causes "undue hardship," to help the workers cope with their disabilities -- scheduling their hours to permit visits to doctors, for example, widening bathroom stalls to help people in wheelchairs or providing special tools.
The law does not ask employers to hire people who lack vital faculties for a particular job -- blind people to drive trucks, for example. But a disability alone, said Christopher Bell, a senior lawyer for the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, cannot be grounds for rejection. "It's not enough just to have something wrong," said Mr. Bell, who is blind.
Various studies show that workers with disabilities are at least as effective as others. The Du Pont Company does periodic polls of its disabled workers. The latest survey, of the supervisors of 811 disabled workers in 1990, rated the workers on a par with others in attention to safety, marginally below them in job performance and well above them in attendance. Other surveys show much less turnover among the workers, no doubt in part because it is harder for them to find other jobs.
More broadly, experts say, discrimination against people with disabilities is costly to society as a whole. Of the 14.2 million disabled people 16 to 64 years old, Mitchell P. LaPlante, director of the Disability Statistics Program at the University of California in San Francisco, says only 30 percent worked in 1989, mostly at part-time and irregular jobs, while 76 percent of people without disabilities worked, most of them in regular, full-time jobs.
 
Many Need a Lot of Help
 Mr. LaPlante says that many of the 7.9 million disabled he classifies as severely limited would need a lot of help to take jobs, like people to dress them and feed them, but that 6.3 million are more easily employable. Of that group, 58 percent had jobs, and most of the rest could have worked, he said.
He said 23 percent of the disabled adults were poor, almost three times the rate for the rest of the population.
Many survive on largely on food stamps, Medicaid and Social Security checks. Phil Gambino, a spokesman for the Social Security Administration, said 3.2 million former workers who have become totally disabled receive an average of $7,125 a year from Social Security Disability Insurance.
He said three million other adults were ineligible for the insurance because they had not worked enough to qualify. They receive an average of $4,114 in Supplemental Security Income, a form of welfare. The cost of both programs is $3.1 billion a year.
With the law still to take effect, no one knows if the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, the principal enforcement agency, will be deluged with complaints from aggrieved job seekers. But Evan J. Kemp Jr., chairman of the commission, predicts the complaints of civil rights violations workers bring to the commission over the next year will increase 20 percent, or 15,000 new cases.
Joanne Frankfort, a lawyer at the Employment Law Center in San Francisco, which represents workers in occupational disputes, said: "I think we will see significant amounts of litigation. Any action taken against a qualified individual because of his disability could be a violation. And there are teeth in the law."
But advocacy groups and the commission expect many complaints to be summarily rejected because the workers will be found unqualified for the jobs they are denied and than many others will be resolved through negotiation and arbitration. Only the most extreme cases are expected to bring monetary penalties, which can be as high as $300,000.
Even then, enforcement is likely to be slow. The commission says that because of budgetary constraints, it may not be able to hire the 250 new compliance officers to investigate complaints under the act.
Some advocates of disabled people want to avoid litigation. Paul Marchand, chairman of the Consortium for Citizens with Disabilities, a lobbying group in Washington, said: "We are not out to clobber anybody. We hope it would be the last resort. It makes no sense to put business out of business."
 
Vagueness Invites Lawsuits
 But some lawsuits seem inevitable because Congress deliberately left central provisions of the law vague. What is a "reasonable accommodation" and not an "undue hardship" for a company depends largely on its resources.
Smaller businesses, especially, say they fear the cost of compliance. The $11,000 that U.P.S. has spent to accommodate Mr. Holland might be judged an undue hardship for a very small company. But Rick Douglas, executive director of the President's Committee on Employment of People With Disabilities, says the average disabled worker's accommodation costs less than $500. Some adjustments, like scheduling work around doctors' appointments or raising the desk of a worker in a wheelchair, cost nothing.
A large company might be expected to be able to employ a full-time interpreter for deaf workers, but a small company might comply by teaching a deaf worker's supervisor sign language. But many other questions are murkier. Some people are confined to their homes but can do the essential functions of a job. Will a company be required to let the employee work at home? As yet, no one knows.
Here and there, even a very small employer finds that hiring people with disabilities so desirable that Government goading is unnecessary. Two years ago, James W. Snow was opening a business, a commercial laundry in Russellville, Ark. "It was hard to find people who would start at the minimum wage," Mr. Snow said.
"So this friend of mine said, 'You know what might work? These people from the Russell Skills Center.' " There, as at hundreds of other centers in other communities, people who are retarded and have other mental disabilities learn to work and to live independently. " 'They can do the folding, the sorting and the processing of your laundry.' "
Mr. Snow said 5 of his 16 employees come from the center, which provides coaches for the workers until they learn their routines. The workers are paid the same as others without disabilities. "It all works well for me," Mr. Snow said. "I'm ecstatic. If I could do more, I would do more."
