HEADLINE: Gangs Abiding By Cease-Fire In Los Angeles

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, July 18

 BODY:
To the astonishment of the police, a cease-fire among the black gangs of Los Angeles appears to be holding, nearly three months after it began at the time of the riots.
Rival Crips and Bloods have been partying together and calling each other "cuz." And although some drive-by shootings have recently been reported, nervous residents say there is a new quality to nights in the inner city, with fewer sounds of gunfire and police sirens. 
 Last year 771 people were killed in Los Angeles County in confrontations among gangs of all races. But in the months since the rioting, black-on-black gang violence has fallen sharply.
 
'A Man-to-Man Thing'
 Detective Bob Jackson, a gang expert at the Los Angeles Police Department, says four people died in fighting between black gangs in May and June, down from 22 in the same period last year. In areas outside the City of Los Angeles patrolled by the County Sheriff's Department, there was one black-on-black killing in the two-month period, compared with seven in the same period last year.
"The gang truce is real," said Lamont Williams, a member of the Grape Street Watts gang as he lounged in the sun this week near the pale purple buildings of the Jordan Downs housing project. "We're always going to have conflicts, but they aren't escalating now. It's just a man-to-man thing now, not a gang thing."
But the police and some gang members warn that the truce is fragile, given the disorganized nature of the gangs and the continuing atmosphere of frustration and violence in the inner city.
"Time will tell whether or not we are dealing with a real situation where they definitely want to return to society," Detective Jackson said.
Greg Davis, a longtime gang member who goes by the street name Batman, said: "It's going to be hard to bring it all to an end. A lot of us been doing this for years and don't want it to stop. We're killing each other off, and a lot of us don't really care. A lot of these brothers thrill on this violence.
"It's hard to trust somebody you've been shooting at and killing for years," he said.
The signs of a truce are all the more extraordinary because there is no centralized structure or leadership among the county's 100,000 gang members. The "war" that has escalated among the black gangs over the past decade has involved hundreds of street rivalries among many gangs rather than any larger confrontation between those members calling themselves Crips or Bloods.
Hispanic and Asian gangs are still at war among themselves, and the police say black gang members are continuing with robberies, assaults and drug dealing.
"To be quite honest with you, we just don't know why black gangs are not killing each other," said Sgt. Wes McBride, a gang expert with the sheriff's department, noting that cease-fire efforts in the past have broken down almost immediately. "There's no precedent for us to look at. This has never happened before."
He suggested that the city's black gangs might be evolving in some unpredictable way, just as the Crips and Bloods came into being in the years after the Watts riot in 1965.
 
Fun Has Gone From Battle
 Mr. Davis, one of the last surviving founders of the Crips in 1969, said that he had taken part in brief truces in the past and that the difference now is that the killing had risen to unbearable levels.
"It used to be fun," said Mr. Davis, who is 37 years old. "All you're going to get is beat up, swole up. Tomorrow you'll do better. Now everyone's got guns. It's a one-way trip to death. Either he gets you or you get him."
Even before the recent rioting, which began April 29, talk of a cease-fire was spreading among gang members appalled at the fratricidal killings among black men. The riot, with its crescendo of violence, followed by aggressive law enforcement, appears to have given the cease-fire a push, said Mike Genelin, the gang expert for the District Attorney's office.
"What that process did was buy time for this kind of event to be more successful than it might have been," he said. "I'm surprised and very pleased that it appears to be holding."
 
Stepping Out of Shadows
 The truce has allowed some of the young men to gain a sense of identity and purpose through peacemaking and hopes of inclusion in the work force rather than through violence. Some gang members have appeared on television talk shows, and others are eager to step forward in public to express their grievances now that people seem to be paying attention.
But the police and many gang members voice doubts that a truce can last if the social causes of the violence are not addressed. Some local ministers and social agencies have begun to complain of a failure by government and business leaders to seize this opportunity to offer jobs and programs that would tempt young men from the gangs.
"There's a stew pot out there that just cooks these gangs, and they come out of that," Sergeant McBride said, adding that unemployment, drugs and the lack of opportunity contribute to the anger of the young men.
Describing the impulse to violence, Mike Evans, a former gang member, said: "It was like a fire was in me as far as doing destruction. With a lot of the young guys now, the fire is in them, too."
This fire was evident among the groups of young men pacing aimlessly one recent afternoon in the hot sun of the Jordan Downs project.
"They call me Booboo," said one of the men, Robert Lewis. "I've been living here since I was 3 years old. I'm 28 now. I haven't benefited from nothing that society gave me, except how to survive and how to die. How can you expect young men like us to function in society?"
As other men lounging nearby yelled encouragement, he continued: "From the time we come out of our mama's womb we are lacking everything. We are lacking education. We are lacking opportunities. The gang thing is something we know. It's the only thing we know, because we don't know how to work."
 
Loyalty to Their Projects
 His friend, Mr. Williams of the Grape Street Watts, said that the projects offer the young men one thing, a sense of community, and that through their gang affiliations the men return that loyalty.
"We represent where we live at: Grape Street," Mr. Williams said. "I would die for Grape Street."
At the home of Mr. Davis, the old-time Crip, is an engraved plaque with the names of 21 fellow gang members who have given their lives for their neighborhoods. "All your love ones rest in peace," it reads.
Some day, he said, his dream is to erect a sort of Vietnam wall memorial with the names of all the Crips and Bloods who have died in action, "and nobody should come up there and scratch out anybody's name."
Like the young men who died in Vietnam, Mr. Davis said: "They died for a cause. They died for their colors. They died for something they believed in, and that was Crip."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Republicans;
G.O.P. Plotting 2-Edged Effort To Bolster Bush

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
Republican strategists are mapping out a two-pronged effort to restart President Bush's sputtering campaign in the month before their convention. They hope to raise Mr. Bush's dismal approval ratings with a new push on the economy and to blunt Gov. Bill Clinton's surge by redrawing him as a high-taxing, big-spending liberal who cannot be trusted with the nation's security.
Fearful that Mr. Clinton struck what one Bush aide called a "devastating" blow at the Democratic National Convention with his attack on Mr. Bush's leadership and vision for the country, the White House is casting about for new ideas to spur the economy. 
But with the options limited, and the Administration still mired in an old debate over how aggressive to be on economic policy, the most likely result appears to be a repackaging of existing proposals. [Page 18.]
 
Pattern Emerges
 At the same time, Mr. Bush and his representatives will be touring important battleground states in the four weeks before the Republican convention in Houston.
The pattern is already emerging. Mr. Bush, who can ill afford to worsen an already negative image among voters, is avoiding direct attacks, but his proxies are doing it for him.
In a speech in Provo, Utah, today, Mr. Bush made no mention of the Democratic candidates. He talked instead about legal reform, the line-item veto and school choice.
But he stood just a few feet away as Senator Jake Garn of Utah leveled a blistering personal attack at Mr. Clinton and his running mate, Senator Al Gore of Tennessee, whom he ridiculed as "pretty boys."
Mr. Garn denounced Mr. Clinton for enrolling in an R.O.T.C. program in 1968 to avoid the draft. Mr. Garn said he would have disagreed with Mr. Clinton, but still would have respected him, if he had openly avoided the draft by fleeing to Canada. "We don't need those kinds of politicians in either party," he said. "So let's vote for those politicians who have the courage of their convictions."
Mr. Clinton has said he dropped out of the R.O.T.C. program to make himself eligible for the draft, but he did that only after his risk of induction had declined considerably.
 
Time for Frontal Assault
 The Republicans' good-cop, bad-cop approach, which Mr. Bush used frequently in 1988 and during the 1992 primary campaigns, reflects an agreement among his strategists that the emergence of a two-man campaign, when Ross Perot dropped out on Thursday, now permits a frontal assault on Mr. Clinton.
But the withdrawal of Mr. Perot also presents Mr. Bush with major strategic problems.
In expectation of a three-way race in which victory could have been achieved with smaller percentages of votes, the President had swung sharply to the right on issues like the environment and abortion to solidify the Republican conservative base.
Mr. Bush, who has suffered from a public perception that his positions sway with the political wind, cannot afford to be seen as changing course simply because he no longer needs the right wing as badly as he did a few days ago.
Yet he must also appeal to a broader audience in a two-man race, and Mr. Clinton is clearly striking for the center with Republican themes like a strong military and "family values." In his acceptance speech on Thursday, Mr. Clinton even appropriated the tag line from Bush campaign commercials in the New Hampshire primary campaign, declaring, "Now that we have changed the world, it's time to change America."
 
Uncertainty at Top
 Clearly, simply chipping away at Mr. Clinton is not enough, and Bush aides recognize that now more than ever they must present the President as a strong leader and a problem solver. But beyond a recognition that Mr. Bush cannot afford to squander another political opportunity, the Bush campaign still seems uncertain how to proceed.
Bush aides said the White House and the campaign are still debating whether to offer new initiatives to stimulate the sluggish economy and, failing that, how aggressively to press Congress on Mr. Bush's existing economic growth package. Some officials fear any discussion of the economy would be bad for the President now, while others say he must take that risk.
But senior officials said the White House has been unable to produce new initiatives and the Republican strategy seems to rely primarily on undercutting the image that Mr. Clinton has tried to paint for himself as a man of moderate policies and an agent of change.
The outlines of the offensive are clear and they focus on the economy.
"Beyond the rhetoric, the Democrats are up to their old tricks, they want to raise your taxes," Vice President Dan Quayle declared at a news conference on Friday before embarking on a trip to Florida, Kentucky and Mississippi.
But Republican strategists recognize that Mr. Bush is extremely vulnerable on the economy, since public disapproval of his handling of economic issues is especially high.
And in this context, Mary Matalin, the Bush campaign's political director, said the Republican team would also try to portray Mr. Clinton as a political opportunist. "You cannot define yourself by being all things to all people," she said. "He's a pastel watercolor with all the hues running into each other. There are no hard edges to this guy."
 
Visiting G.O.P. Strongholds
 Bush aides said the President would be on the campaign trail one or two days a week until his convention, visiting states like Pennsylvania, New Jersey, Ohio, Illinois, Michigan, California, Missouri and Georgia.
His itinerary reads like a Who's Who of Republican constituencies. Mr. Bush met with the leaders of the Mormon Church in Salt Lake City on Friday. On Tuesday, he will visit a Roman Catholic High School in Philadelphia and a church in New Jersey, where he plans to court the votes of Catholics of Eastern European descent.
With those kinds of voters, Bush aides hope to use Mr. Clinton's support of abortion rights and his party's ties to homosexual groups against him. "When we talk about family values, part of it will be to point out that Clinton went out to California, had a fund-raiser by the biggest gay group there and bought into their agenda, which includes government preferences for gays," said a senior campaign official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity.
Mr. Clinton did address a homosexual organization in San Francisco in May. He has not spoken of "preferences" for homosexuals in government, but has said he would not bar people from his Administration on grounds of sexual preference.
The Bush campaign will rely heavily on those sorts of social issues in the South as well, Republican officials said, as well as on law-and-order themes. The Republicans, who arrange for Mr. Bush to be photographed in the company of police officers as often as possible, say Mr. Clinton gave them an opening by showing little attention to crime in his convention speech.
 
Issue of Environment
 Recognizing that the recession has hurt Mr. Bush badly in the Midwestern Industrial Belt and that the Democrats plan to attack Mr. Bush on the environment, the Republican operation hopes to portray the Democrats as environmental extremists.
Republicans argue that the higher fuel-efficiency standards proposed by Mr. Gore will damage the automobile industry, and Mr. Bush told an audience of outdoorsmen in Utah today that he supported hunting on public lands.
"I just don't think we can go to extremes in the name of the environment, whether it's to deny hunting or fishing on these lands, or to shut down businesses," he said. He called hunting "a sound environmental practice" that thins out animal populations that otherwise would be suffer from famine and disease.
A Republican strategist said, "If they're going to trot Clinton and especially Gore up and down the West Coast as the tree-huggers in this campaign, they are going to cross-pressure themselves in the Midwest."
While Mr. Bush has his own problems with the abortion issue -- many Republicans oppose his call for a constitutional amendment banning abortion -- the Republican campaign hopes to use Mr. Clinton's support for unfettered access to abortion against him with conservative Democrats and religious groups.
And the Republicans hope to raise doubts about whether Mr. Clinton can be trusted to safeguard national security.
 
Maintaining Public Doubts
 While Mr. Bush is not likely to make the kinds of accusations personally that Mr. Garn made today, and Mr. Quayle, who also has been accused of avoiding the draft, is in no position to attack Mr. Clinton on that issue, the Republicans seem confident that they can maintain public doubts about Mr. Clinton by contrasting him with Mr. Bush.
"They talk about strong national defense, but they want to slash the defense budget," said Frederick V. Malek, Mr. Bush's campaign manager. "You contrast that with Bush's record. Here's a guy who fought in one war, who led the world community in a war against an aggressor in the Middle East, which was a crisis of unique proportions in modern presidencies and one in which he was tested under fire and performed extremely well."
The Republicans have been casting about for ways to bring foreign policy back into the political debate and are hoping that Mr. Clinton's efforts to reassure voters that he can make tough decisions in times of crisis will give them an opening to do that.
Mr. Bush's diplomatic record, and the Persian Gulf war, are likely to be central themes at the Republican convention in Houston, officials said.
The "trust" theme, as well as an effort to counter the notion that Mr. Bush has not done enough about domestic issues, are likely to emerge as a theme in the Bush campaign commercials between now and the convention. Republican officials said the commercials would be "positive" in tone and will not attack Mr. Clinton directly.

HEADLINE: C.I.A. Had Warned Bush Over Iraqi Farm Loans

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 18

 BODY:
The Central Intelligence Agency and other intelligence organizations warned President Bush and his aides early in November 1989 that failure to approve a pending $1 billion agricultural loan guarantee program to Iraq would create further tensions in American-Iraqi relations, according to a classified intelligence document and Administration officials.
The brief warning, included in a secret report known as a National Intelligence Estimate, also noted "possible illegal transactions" involving the United States Government loan program through the Atlanta branch of the Italian-owned Banca Nazionale del Lavoro, said Administration officials familiar with the report. 
 The Atlanta branch, which provided most of the loans under the agriculture program, was raided two months earlier by the Federal Bureau of Investigation and was under Federal investigation for a multibillion-dollar loan fraud. Until that time, the credit program was largely financed through the bank.
 
A Consensus View
 But the warning was reportedly buried in a single paragraph deep in the 25-page report and might not have caught the attention of Mr. Bush or senior policy makers who approved the credit guarantee program a few days later.
The scant attention paid to the scandal in the report, which is a consensus view from the nation's intelligence agencies, indicates that the agencies either ignored or did not pursue mounting evidence that Iraq was paying for its weapons programs with loans from the Atlanta bank. The report did not discuss such evidence, for example, or point out that the bank was under Federal investigation.
At the time, some State and Agriculture Department officials were also warning their superiors of their suspicions that some loan money guaranteed by the United States credit program might have been diverted to Iraq's weapons projects. In addition, there were a number of intelligence reports, many generated by the Pentagon, on Iraq's extensive procurement network around the world.
The intelligence report largely followed the conventional wisdom of the Bush Administration that President Saddam Hussein was a leader who could be worked with. It included a discussion of Iraq's ambitious weapons programs and complex procurement network, but concluded that he would focus on rebuilding a country ravaged by eight years of war with Iran and would not attack any of his neighbors in the next two to three years.
The report's timing was particularly crucial because it was delivered just one month after Mr. Bush signed a directive on Oct. 2 that called for the use of economic and political incentives as a way of moderating Mr. Hussein's behavior. A few days after the report was issued, the Bush Administration extended $500 million in new loan guarantees to Iraq.
Mr. Bush remained personally engaged in the policy in that period. When Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d sent a still-secret message to Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz of Iraq after a meeting they had on Oct. 6, he invoked Mr. Bush's name in responding to Mr. Aziz's charge that the United States was trying to destabilize Iraq.
"The President has asked me to say to you and through you to President Saddam Hussein in the most direct way possible that the United States is not involved in any effort to weaken or destabilize Iraq," the message said. "Having looked into the matter and discussed it with the President, I can tell you this with the highest authority. Such an action would be completely contrary to the President's policy, which is to work to strengthen the relationship between the United States and Iraq whenever possible."
The National Intelligence Estimate was the first such document on Iraq in the Bush Administration. Such reports reflect the thinking of the C.I.A. as well as the intelligence arms of the Pentagon, the State Department and other agencies and are circulated to the President, the national security adviser and the Secretaries of State and Defense, among others. Like other intelligence documents, the estimates are intended to provide raw data and analysis, not policy recommendations.
A senior Administration official familiar with intelligence matters said the report, rather than focusing on the Banca Nazionale del Lavoro, "was coming at it from a different direction -- from the standpoint of Iraqi procurement networks and the use of loans from the West."
"Although there were a lot of suspicions that the loans were being used to fund those networks," the official said, "I don't think we had a comprehensive picture of B.N.L."
 
Short-Lived Strains Predicted
 The seeming lack of concern about the unfolding bank scandal was also reflected in a secret C.I.A. document of Nov. 6, 1989, on the scandal's repercussions for both Iraq and Italy. The document, which was disclosed last week by Representative Henry B. Gonzalez, the Texas Democrat and chairman of the House Committee on Banking, Finance and Urban Affairs, stated that the Banca Nazionale scandal was likely to damage United States-Iraqi commercial relations, particularly if the credit program did not proceed. Other officials have since described the document in much fuller detail.
The document described the scandal as a passing phenomenon and a minor irritant in the relationship. Administration officials quoted it as saying, "The strain in U.S.-Iraqi political relations caused by the B.N.L. scandal will probably be short-lived, particularly if Baghdad believes additional credits will be forthcoming after the dust of the investigation settles."
Although the affair "embarrassed" the Italian Government, the document continued, it will not have a major impact on relations with Italy, in part because of Rome's appreciation of the Administration's "low key" reaction to the scandal. The conclusions are puzzling, particularly because the document also includes a section on Iraq's complex procurement networks and names a number of European-based companies involved that received financing from the bank.
"Baghdad has created complex procurement networks of holding companies in Western Europe to acquire technology for its chemical, biological, nuclear and ballistic missile development programs," the document concluded.
 
Disregard Is Asserted
 Mr. Gonzalez, seeking to prove an Administration cover-up, charged in a speech from the House floor that the C.I.A. document "indicates that several of the B.N.L.-financed front companies in the network were secretly procuring technology" for Iraq's weapons programs, but that policy makers ignored the information.
The C.I.A., which does not comment on classified matters, declined to discuss either intelligence report.
As the Administration's policy toward Iraq is stirring as a campaign issue and as the Justice Department considers whether to appoint an independent counsel to investigate allegations of criminality in the conduct of the policy, Senator David L. Boren is eager to uncover what intelligence agencies knew about the bank, the credit program and their potential involvement with Iraq's arms network.
The Oklahoma Democrat, who is chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee, sent a letter to Robert M. Gates, the Director of Central Intelligence, in early June requesting a full document search of the issues by the C.I.A. and other intelligence agencies.
The C.I.A. intends to report that it did not specifically gather intelligence on the Atlanta bank or its loans to Iraq for its arms programs before the Federal Bureau of Investigation raided the bank in August 1989, Administration officials said.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Economy;
Old Economic Ideas or Bold New Plan? Bush Team Is Divided.

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 17

 BODY:
With the economy the biggest threat to President Bush's re-election and little that he can do to give it a jolt, the White House plans to make a big push on an updated version of its growth package, even as the President's advisers continue to debate whether bold new proposals are also needed.
The package, which could be presented as early as next week will rely principally on the main elements of the economic plan the President outlined in January, the officials say, including tax credits for first-time home buyers, a tax allowance for investments, new types of individual retirement accounts and a renewed drive to lower the tax rate on capital gains. 
 The White House strategy is to throw Democrats in Congress on the defensive, blaming the lawmakers for the economy's anemic performance if they again reject the President's proposals. In his State of the Union Message on Jan. 28, Mr. Bush outlined a seven-point economic program, declaring March 20 as a deadline for action; Congress met the deadline to the day, but with a plan that Mr. Bush vetoed.
"Some people feel it's time to really take it to Congress for not passing the good stuff we've already proposed," said one Administration official.
 
'The Mess We're In'
 A first salvo is expected to come in the Mid-Session Review, a budget evaluation that the Office of Management and Budget will release on Friday. The review, written by Richard G. Darman, the President's budget director, is said to use tougher language than is typical for such documents.
But other officials say that significant new elements must be added to the Administration's growth plan before it will capture voters' imaginations.
"The Republican Party cannot defend the status quo, which is Latin for 'the mess we're in,' " Secretary of Housing and Urban Development Jack F. Kemp said in an interview. "It has to present a bold and imaginative and audacious agenda."
If the Administration's new push on growth relies almost exclusively on proposals Mr. Bush put forward in January, it risks being accused of having no new ideas. But if the White House were to abandon much of the January package, it would lay itself open to charges of flip-flopping and caving in to Congress.
 
Victory for Quayle
 Administration officials say some details of the ingredients and timing of the updated package remain undetermined, awaiting decisions at a senior staff meeting on Monday.
That there is a renewed push on economic growth at all appears to be a victory for Vice President Dan Quayle and Michael J. Boskin, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, Administration officials say.
Arguing that the economy was weaker than the President and his inner circle thought, Mr. Quayle and Mr. Boskin asserted that playing Pollyanna on the economy would hurt President Bush's re-election chances. The Administration should act more aggressively to bolster the economy, they said, even if it means confronting Congress.
"We have been right on this issue," said one senior Administration official. "We shouldn't accept blame. We should remind people that we have had a growth agenda. We're much better off reminding people that we haven't had cooperation in Congress."
 
Driven by Political Agenda
 Administration officials say the new push aims in part to counter Gov. Bill Clinton's repeated charges that the President has no economic plan. But Democrats say the Administration's offensive is designed to score political points before November far more than to pep up the economy.
"They're going to argue that the economy is so screwed up because we didn't cut the capital-gains tax," said one Democratic staff member in Congress. "That's ridiculous."
Conservatives have mixed feelings about the White House strategy. "It's wise to emphasize tax cutting," said Lawrence Kudlow, a former Reagan Administration economist who is chief economist at Bear Stearns. "However, I'm not sure it's going to resonate with the electorate. This plan is the original pale gray line. This is a group that's incapable of bold brush change."
Mr. Kudlow said he had discussed the package with Administration officials, and had urged them to do something that would fire the imagination of voters hungry for change.
Secretary Kemp agrees, and he is pushing the Administration to make bolder proposals over the next few weeks and months, especially in light of Ross Perot's announcement of noncandidacy last week.
 
Bold? Maybe. Radical? No.
 "We cannot run on 'It's Morning in America,' " Mr. Kemp said. "We've got to lay out a vision of what a Republican President and, hopefully, a Republican Congress could do to attract the voters who are caught in the middle, including those caught by Perot's dropping out."
But other Administration officials saw virtue in the absence of new measures. "I don't think we'll have any radical new measures," said one senior official. "That would look political and desperate."
The House of Representatives passed a tax plan on July 2 that included some of President Bush's January proposals, such as repealing the luxury tax and restoring some deductions to the shell-shocked real estate industry. Administration officials say their new push aims to get the Senate to act on the entire January package, in the hope that the two houses will compromise on a bill much more to the Administration's liking.
The Administration also plans to press the Senate to authorize 300 enterprise zones around the country. The House has approved designating just 50 such zones, depressed areas in which businesses would receive tax incentives for investing.
 
A Question of Timing
 The consensus among economists is that any program of economic stimulus will take at least four months to bear fruit and can do little before Election Day to lower the jobless rate, which was 7.8 percent in June.
Nonetheless, Administration officials argue that their plan, many elements of which have long been favored in the Bush circle, can make a quick difference. In a speech last week, Secretary of Labor Lynn Martin said that a $5,000 tax credit for first-time home buyers would immediately translate into 275,000 jobs for carpenters, plumbers, furniture makers and others.
The flexible I.R.A.'s in Mr. Bush's plan would allow investors to earn tax-free interest so long as they kept money in the accounts for at least seven years. Administration officials say the new I.R.A.'s would increase savings, making more money available for investment. But many economists contend that the accounts would do little to increase savings and would cost the Government billions of dollars in tax revenues.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Pennsylvania;
Democratic Ticket Heads Into Fertile Territory

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: YORK, Pa., July 18

 BODY:
Pennsylvania, where wildly enthusiastic crowds greeted the Clinton-Gore bus caravan today, could prove fertile territory for Democrats this year.
The unemployment rate is in double digits in 20 of 67 counties. And last November, in a cry for change, Pennsylvanians sent Harris Wofford to the United States Senate, the first time they had elected a Democratic Senator in 30 years. 
 The Democrats' moderate message and focus on the middle class may also play well in this largely rural and suburban state, one that has not favored a Democratic Presidential candidate since Jimmy Carter in 1976.
But Pennsylvania is also the state whose restrictions on abortion were at the heart of the effort to overturn Roe v. Wade, the 1973 Supreme Court decision legalizing abortion. The Governor, Robert P. Casey, a Democrat, is strongly against abortion, and he has feuded with party leaders over their refusal to let him address the party's convention in New York.
 
No Bus Pass for Casey
 Governor Casey was nowhere to be seen on the Clinton-Gore bus tour. "First of all, I wasn't invited," he said Friday in a telephone interview, "and secondly, I am going on vacation." The Governor began his vacation today on Lake Ariel in northeastern Pennsylvania.
Mr. Casey would not say whether he would campaign for the Democratic ticket, and when pressed, he said, "I support the ticket, period, end of quote."
He noted that on Tuesday, the day convention officials had refused to let him speak, the podium went instead to Kathy Sawyer, a registered Republican from Hershey, Pa., who supports abortion rights. "It was outrageous and indefensible," Mr. Casey said.
Political analysts say the Clinton-Gore campaign could certainly use Mr. Casey's help in organizing the state, but they do not think the incident cost the campaign the support of other Democratic leaders in the state. "Eighty percent of the Pennsylvania delegation were wishing Governor Casey would get lost on the subway," said Michael L. Young, professor of politics and public affairs at Pennsylvania State University in Harrisburg.
Still, the bus tour was dogged by anti-abortion protesters. "Pro-life, Pro-family, Pro-Bush," said a sign carried by Glenn Loatman, a 34-year-old horse trainer. He was among about 100 demonstrators who gathered Friday night at the campaign's dinner stop at a steelworkers' union hall in Coatesville, a mill town about 30 miles west of Philadelphia.
The crowds, who spontaneously assembled to greet Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas and Senator Al Gore of Tennessee, held a melting pot of partisan views, but the overwhelming majority seemed to be melting into support for the Democrats. It was the national convention in Madison Square Garden that made the difference, said dozens of voters. Many of these voters also said they had previously felt shortchanged by the field of candidates.
"Before the convention I was close-minded about Clinton," said Lois Yates, 40, a Republican who owns a plumbing and heating business here with her husband, David, 40. "We were waiting to hear what Ross Perot might say, but when he never came through with any policies, we thought we had better pay attention to the other candidates."
 
Impressed by Convention
 "I voted for Bush last time, but I would be nuts to do that again," she said, asserting that Mr. Bush had no domestic policy and had failed to do anything about the recession. "What clinched it for me was the video about Clinton's life; it was an emotional thing for me."
Mr. Yates, who described himself as a "fence sitter," said he was impressed with Mr. Clinton's performance at the convention, but said he wondered "who is going to write all the checks for all of his wonderful programs?"
The national convention seemed to have spellbinding effect on many people, who repeated its slogans and themes as naturally as though they were their own ideas. "They are a young team that will take the U.S.A. into the 21st century," said Janet MacFarland, a 57-year-old secretary.
And some said the Clinton-Gore campaign appearances were an encounter with history. "My great-grandmother was a slave and she told me about the day she saw President Lincoln," said Martha Duerson, a 52-year-old secretary and mother of 11. "Now I can say to my grandchildren that I saw President Clinton before he became President."
